As a general matter, I’ve never really favored statutes of limitation for any crime. However, it’s a balanced sentiment understanding full well the arguments on both sides; and it’s a close call. But I’m not sure that everyone would agree, if the main argument in favor of such limitations really was well understood.

Rape often is a very tough crime to prove when memories of an incident are fresh, resolving itself so many times as a case of he said, she said. But with the passage of time, memories undoubtedly become less sharply delineated as they were immediately following an incident, and even more subject to error. With Bill Cosby or even with other, similar situations when the behavior is alleged to be serial and dozens of women have come forward to claim wrong, it’s easier to defend dropping statutes of limitation in the interests of justice; but in situations that are NOT serial and that are decidedly open to interpretation? How long must a person have a Sword of Damocles hanging over his head (or, increasingly, HER head)?

A close call.

I dunno, Richard. I usually give your conservative-lite sensibility a pass but your earnest reasonableness just seems annoying here.

What is open to interpretation about rape? What is this weird equivocation about "her" head? Are that many women being arrested for sexual assault?

AC:

Well, there's something to be said for being annoying.

If you truly think that there's nothing open to interpretation about charges of rape, then you're either quite naïve or playing the part for the purpose of exciting conversation.

As to the increasing incidence of women accused of rape, Google "Claire Marsh", "Chantae Gilman" and "Rebecca Helen Elder" (Australian).

No, I don't believe that their friendship was an invitation to sexual assault and rape. I am just really struggling with the idea that a woman (gay or straight, in a relationship or not) at the home of a predatory male would take from his hand three pills, put them in her mouth, and wash 'em down with some wine and not know what the deal was. Now imagine that I am the average woman who might serve on the jury who has had the experience of a man offering drugs and wine while we're sitting on his couch (in my day, I recall being offered weed and cocaine as a prelude to sex). My mind immediately thinks this man hit on me twice, now he is trying to get my defenses down. So if that's not what I want, I grab my stuff and run out of there. This case is not cut and dry. There is reasonable doubt, which means NOT GUILTY.
The jury might hear their accounts, actually; depends on if the judge allows "pattern of behavior" testimony.
Prison is not merely for the prevention of future crimes but for punishment of past crimes.
And yet, rape and sexual assault do occur.
Many serial rapists have wives and a normal sex life. It's about the control.

You are commenting without having done your homework on this case.

But even so, not coming forward in a timely manner is still no reason to blame or doubt the victim. I have personally known people who were sexually abused and didn't tell anyone for 40 years.

I'm glad these women came forward. However, I came of age in the 70s and 80s and know full well how things worked. Your boss invites you to his hotel room to go over a presentation? Tell him you'll meet him in the lobby. Too many were willing to pretend naivete - he tried to kiss me after dinner. .. why did you go to his house or room for dinner?

It was a bizarre time. Many women and men a like thought nothing of sex with co-workers or bosses. This doesn't mean that Cosby was wrong, depending on the outcome of trial. But we all need to practice good sense. Meet publically or don't meet at all.

And to young women everywhere - do not feel complimented because some guy, famous or otherwise, wants to have sex (or dinner) with you. Ask yourself how this might end and say no.
We live in a Rape Culture.  Just think how many men have been seduced by women after they got drunk.....Women are not the only innocent victims of sexual predators.

This case is from 2002, not 1500.  The "mores" have never condoned drugging and rape.  And it doesn't take a saint not to do those things.  And I don't know what's in your closet, but rape is not in mine or in most men's.  We have women we love, and it's abhorrent to us.
Here's your answer, Jerry.  If indeed she passed out, and if indeed Cosby molested her then, it was nonconsensual and the man is a rapist.
There never was a time when "mores" excused drugging people so you could perform sex acts on them.

We're not really talking about women who had sex with Cosby in order to get ahead. We're talking about women Cosby drugged in order to do sexual things to them without their consent.  Entirely different scenario.
Why do you think he's no longer a threat?  Did you read what Constand says he did to her?  How is it that he couldn't still do that, at his age?

As in the OJ Simpson case, celebrity, power, and high priced lawyers will triumph over justice. They will point out to the jury that Ms. Constand accepted a settlement in the civil case from Mr. Cosby and that Bruce Castor of the DA's office at that time (2005) declined to prosecute for lack of sufficient evidence. The original purpose of the Internet was to provide a cheap and efficient means for scientists to freely exchange information.  As a result, as originally designed there were no obstacles built into the infrastructure to impede the free flow of ideas. The way we use the Internet today is vastly different, requiring safeguards that the original concept never envisioned.  By the time this became apparent, the train, so to speak, had left the station. We now have nothing more than patches for security issues, and sadly, patches have not proven to be the ideal solution for security concerns on the Internet

I developed a system for dealing with anxiety: When that knot in my stomach wakes me up, I lie there in bed, considering each of the things that might reasonably be the cause. Almost always, something turns up that makes the knot far more intense.

Then I make a plan for dealing with that particular issue. Once I've worked out a plan, i find I go back to sleep. If I don't follow up on my plan, a few days later, the anxiety wakes me up again, as a reminder to get with the plan.

While I still do occasionally wake up during the night, there are no more knots in my stomach. That makes it a little more difficult to identify the problem, but the method still works.

So that works for anxiety. As for ants; I've concluded I need to get used to living with lots of life forms I'd rather not have to share my home with. Here in Taiwan, we keep pretty much everything edible in sealed containers. The natives have mostly made peace with that and I, as an American Expat, try to do the same.

One thing I done is to set up a honey feeding station for ants in a place away from food. It seems that ants CAN be bribed.

One of the hit albums of 1969 was titled "Switched-On Bach," by the artist known at the time as Walter Carlos, who later became Wendy Carlos. It consisted of Moog synthesizer realizations of J. S. In my limited experience with cancer, the problems with cancer treatment aren't a lack of drugs for early-stage cancers (which are generally get first-line standard treatment based upon cancers of that particular subtype).

A real issue is that there is insufficient priority placed upon rapid diagnosis and treatment. Britain instituted a "Two Week Rule" regarding suspected melanoma, where suspected melanoma are subjected to a full and complete excision, most usually immediately, but always by this rule, within two weeks of detection. Studies performed in Britain as well as those written up by the NIH have demonstrated 5-year survival rates that have cut the percentage of fatalities in half because of this rule. (82% survival compared to 62%) Nevertheless, even though Britain has made this the standard of care in 2000, fifteen years later, the US has failed to take this rule up.

I recently had a loved one found with a suspected melanoma, and we as a family struggled with the US medical system to get it treated according to this British standard of care. It was impossible, because doctors don't give priority to suspected melanoma, so we waited for treatment behind patients that had more definitive diagnoses, and because the suspected melanoma was diagnosed with a punch biopsy that provides insufficient information for precise staging based upon Breslow thickness and fails to remove tumors that may still metastasize while waiting for definitive treatment.

The flaws with the 401k programs are that 1) tax benefits strongly favor highest income households, 2) they aren't offered by many employers, 3) many of the plans that are offered have excessive fees and 4) there is no automatic savings discipline in the IRA alternative.

If everyone enjoyed the equivalent of a tax deferral in the 33% to 39% range for dollars saved as current high income workers do, there would be a lot more savers.

If all employers who don't offer 401Ks had to offer automatic contribution to IRAs just as they withhold taxes today, there would be a lot more savers, especially if the default was a small contribution amount.

If there were some simple low fee portfolio models of index funds based on risk preference, there would be a lot better long term investment gains on those savings.

While it is difficult for many households to save, the longest line in the grocery store is to buy lottery tickets and the casinos seem to be doing a steady business. When people believe their best chance of getting ahead is one of those two options, something is very badly wrong.

The privacy puzzle has three different aspects
- what the device actually does
- what the device can do
- what the public perceives the device as doing / being able to do.
The public perception is hard to control, especially because it's very difficult to get people to trust your assertions that what the device actually does is much much less than what it could be doing, and as with most technology, what it actually does probably is less than what many of the users would like it to be able to do.
Is there a network connection? Then it could be uploading every picture it takes and every sound it records (and there are applications, like Black Lives Matter protest recording and similar journalism where you'd want it to.)
Is there enough horsepower in the device you carry to actually do the voice transcription and imaging recognition, or does it upload them to a server in the cloud to do the hard work, like Siri and Android apparently do? If it gets to a server, the server can save anything it wants, but even if it's doing voice transcription on the phone, it could be uploading that very efficiently.

The big differences between this and Google Glass are that it's less visible to the people you might be observing (but a cellphone in your shirt pocket or on a jogging armband can do that too) and that the information it provides to the user is audio rather than visual (much cheaper to do, not always as useful.) Basically, it doesn't look like _bragging_, and Glass did.

As long as we're on the topic of pronouns and apostrophes, a story:

People at Sony Pictures Entertainment (a big movie studio) use email to communicate with people inside and outside SPE. Sometimes, the email accounts are "hacked" and the emails are released to the public.

This is a crime and should not be countenanced.

Anyway, some time back, a NYT Op-Ed columnist was preparing a thorough piece about gender discrimination in "Hollywood". She had an email exchange with the then-head of SPE, whose husband used to be a NYT reporter; both husband and wife are friends with the columnist. (For details, see the Public Editor's Journal entry for Dec. 12, 2014.)

In concluding their exchange, the head of the movie studio emailed the columnist, "I HOPE YOUR HAPPY!!!" along with affectionate personal remarks. The columnist wrote back, repeating the affectionate personal remarks, but writing, "I hope you're happy".

That exchange illustrates that NYT writers not only know how to spell contractions, but also that they resist using all caps when they write emails about gender discrimination.

I just tried this and it was a disaster. The original recipe by Rachel Allen has a hydration (water divided by flour) of 67%, which is pretty standard. This one is 74%, which is like a wet ciabatta dough. I followed the directions and the dough was soup; it never came together. I added another 52 g flour to make it at least cohesive.

It's even worse than that - the egg (another 60g) and even sugar count as liquid too.

Vs. Allen recipe they lost a few grams here and there in the conversions from metric to English and back to metric . She mentions that this is a very wet dough. But the main difference is that she calls for "strong" flour rather than all purpose. Strong flour is the UK equivalent of bread flour. Bread flour will result in a somewhat stiffer dough but it's still gonna be wet.

I'm wondering if first coating the flour with the butter somehow interfered with gluten development. That's a technique in making pastry, which I know nothing about, but I am an experienced bread-baker.

Conservatives are dishonest about Social Security.
They want to reduce benefits but not the payroll tax.
In other words they want to steal SS payroll tax dollars to pay for tax cuts for the rich.
In the 1980’s the SS retirement age was raised and some benefits were made taxable.
SS began running huge surpluses but Bush used that SS surplus money to cut taxes for the rich.
Instead of cutting SS benefits let’s raise revenue by taxing all dividends and capital gains as ordinary income and tax unrealized capital gains at death [elimination of step up in basis]. These two together would raise over
200 B /year.

See http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2013/03/17/business/tax-breaks-mostly...

Let’s collect at least some of the 400 B /year in income tax due under the present tax code that is now uncollected.

When parents became outraged over Reforms that turned schools into testing factories and saw their children showing signs of anxiety, they started the Opt-Out Movement.

In a recent radio interview Nancy Carlsson-Paige, professor of early childhood, stated:

"I could not have foreseen in my wildest dreams that we would have to fight for classrooms for young kids that are developmentally appropriate. Instead of active, hands-on learning, children now sit in chairs for far too much time getting drilled on letters and numbers. Stress levels are up among young kids. Parents and teachers tell me: children worry that they don’t know the right answers; they have nightmares, they pull out their eyelashes, they cry because they don’t want to go to school. Some people call this child abuse and I can’t disagree."

'children worry that they don’t know the right answers'

This may pinpoint a common problem with our underlying pedagogical approach. The flaw in our emphasis on a perfect string of high grades is that your mistakes are what you learn from! (Do you watch Jeopardy? I do. Years later, I remember the answers to Final Jeopardy questions I got wrong.) Wrong answers tell you what you need to learn; figuring out why your answer was wrong teaches you. A perfect grade tells you nothing but what you already know. An endless series of 100s and A+s on tests means your child is learning nothing, treading water in the shallows.

And why really should wanting a break be a disqualifier? When in heavens name was it written that one could not take a break from traditional employment during this short life of ours to seek enriching experience for a time period to exceed  the average vacation time?

A big part of the discrimination agains older people is insurance rates. I worked for a small nonprofit and our insurance rates were negotiated every year. Every year we were asked what medications we were on as that was part of the rate negotiated. Since we had a high number of people over 50 in our organization our heath insurance cost was high since, in general, people over 50 take more medications than those  under 50.

I agree with your assessment, Paul, but I am speak as a 59-year old woman.

I have a theory about where the prejudice comes from but you may find it very strange. Women after menopause are viewed as crones. We don't use the word anymore but what I'm getting at is that society does not view us as sexual creatures. And this attitude crosses into the business world which is fueled so much by testosterone. Women at my age simply become invisible. I don't feel this way personally and within our families we are more important than ever - and wield enormous influence. But not so in the business world. I warned you - it's a bizarre theory! But I'd love to know if any research has been done on psychological attitudes toward older women in the workforce!

In 2 1/2 years of diligent researching and networking, I've applied for >700 professionally relevant jobs, completing online forms, writing essays, etc. For each one, I tailor a resume and cover letter addressed to the appropriate company executive. Often, I express mail the originals.
The results to date --
•• 99.9%: no acknowledgement.
•• .07%: route computer rejection email.
•• .02%: a phone interview.
••• 99% of .02:%: the interviewer is unaware of the job qualifications and/or s/he sounds "put out" or distracted. (E.g., one Fortune 100 recruiter was vacuuming at home while conducting the phone interview.)
•• .01%:, in-person interviews. (In these, I have been stared up and down, demanded to provide excessive personal information, and interrogated with Gatling guns.) After each, I followed up with prompt thank you notes and cautiously timed calls.
••• 75% of the .01% went dead silent.
••• 10% of the .01% proved pre-selected.
••• 15% of .01% hired a (younger) candidate with less experience.
I keep myself together.
For groceries, I competed for a$9/hour seasonal job where I get "hit on" by 30 year olds.
To keep a roof over my head, I drained my retirement savings.
Did I mention that I am a woman over 50 with an advanced degree, a strong professional background, and a great sense of humor?
What a world!
In retrospect, I should have had more fun as a kid!

These posts demonstrate how pervasive and destructive age discrimination has become. Why don't we hear more about these pernicious practices and their victims? One reason: gag provisions in separation contracts.

To obtain their severance and benefits, employees are forced to sign contracts in which they promise not to disclose the terms of their settlements and, further, not to "disparage" their former employers. Disparagement doesn't merely mean defamation; the employees give up the right to criticize their employer in any way that might harm his business, a provision that is broadly interpreted to include all comments regarding what the employee may have believed to be illegal discrimination. Moreover, the contracts also contains provisions that declare, in advance, that any breach of the agreement will "irreparably harm" (a legal term) the employee. The employee is effectively silenced by such contracts.

First, gag orders and non-disparagement clauses should be nullified as coercive. Even when represented by counsel, employees usually have no choice but to sign, because they need severance pay and medical benefits. The provisions are one-sided, and unfair.

Second, such clauses should be declared void as a matter of public policy. As these posts demonstrate, we need to hear from victims -- and from one another -- that age discrimination is pervasive, pernicious and deadly. We cannot address the issues if everyone is blackmailed into shutting up.

The conservatives' position on the SS payroll tax is hypocritical.
Is the SS tax a separate tax or is it just an addition to the general income tax.
If the SS tax is just an addition to the general income tax then the statement that about 50% of households pay no federal income tax is misleading.
If the SS tax is a separate tax then the SS trust fund exists and that payroll tax money can not be embezzled to pay for tax cuts for the rich.

Section 201(d) of the Social Security Act says that:

“Each obligation issued for purchase by the Trust Funds shall be evidenced by a bond, note, or certificate of indebtedness setting forth the principal amount, date of maturity, and interest rate of the obligation and stating on its face that the obligation shall be supported by the FULL FAITH AND CREDIT OF THE UNITED STATES, and that the United States is pledged to the payment of the obligation with respect to both principal and interest.”

The fact is that when ALL taxes are included , income payroll, sales, taxes passed along by landlords as higher rent, corporate taxes passed along as higher prices, all income groups pay about the same percentage of their income as taxes.

We are living in a society that values youth, beauty and money above all else.  And this goes big time for the workplace, too.  Blame it on the worship of the celebrity culture and all that comes with it.  Turn on the TV and that's what is there.  How many advertisements in the media do we see for plastic surgery?   How many of our doctors are plastic surgeons vs. general practitioners?  There's big money to be made in plastic surgery.  Not so much for general practitioners.  Unfortunately, women 50 and over are seen as "throw-aways." A wrinkle here and there.  Perhaps a little overweight.  Why do you see so many trying to look young?  Try the dating scene where youth and beauty reign supreme.  We are bombarded every day with images of impossible physical ideals and youthful perfection.  So, in summary, when you add this societal discrimination to the mix of bottom-line corporate profits, technological change and post-recession downsizing attitudes, you've got one hekkuva problem and a very scary future for our country.  If we stay on this current path, you will see poverty and pestilence that will rival any Dickens novel.

This article is a totally accurate depiction of the the workforce for women over 50. My mother was laid-off in 2008 after being employed in banking for over 30 years. Some employers are unfortunately looking for applicants with less experience who they see as easier to train and transition into their workplace culture. Experience is looked upon now as being "stubborn" and/or "set in your ways". My siblings and I have supported my mother through this period as she continues to look for employment. She has taken temp positions as well as retail positions working weekends,holidays and sometimes until 2am, just to make ends meet. I will continue to support my mother until she is back in the workforce but employers need to do a better job at recruiting not only college graduates but also experienced workers who are looking to return to the workforce.

Unless you're a c-level superstar, you're not going to retire from your corporate job on your terms.  Think about it:  how many people who have staff-level corporate jobs retire gracefully nowadays?  You'll probably be swept up in a larger reorganization, left to find a new job at a time when no one really wants you.  Sorry to sound harsh, but ageism exists, for both men and women. You definitely need a plan B if you need to keep working.  Chances are that plan b will involve self-employment.

The more advanced technology gets the less we are all needed. When I look back through the years, I remember the newspaper's were full of ads  for woman and men, especially the Sunday paper. Good paying jobs with benefits were a dime a dozen. No more.

Holden nails it: this film melds a coming-of-age comedy with a pervasive undertone of disconnection, instability, anxiety and dread.

Brooke, the character played by Greta Gerwig, claims the same ground as a Fitzgerald heroine: glittering on the outside, crumbling on the inside. Tracy, played by Lola Kirke, is Gatsby to Brooke's Daisy, capturing her on paper in what is perhaps a betrayal.

That these themes are skillfully embedded in a light comedy is engaging and intellectually intriguing, The segment set in Greenwich, Connecticut is hilarious and itself worth the price of admission.

Rent or buy for at-home viewing as of December 2015.

There I feel better now.

You are mistaken about the interpretation of laws in physical science. No physicist believes most of the known laws don't have intrinsic reality. Quantum mechanics is the only important partial exception.

There is a large difference between laws and assumptions. Laws can be tested and modified or discarded. Assumptions can be, but are less likely to be. I think this difference is extreme in social science. Here we tend to agree. Assumptions like people being rational, self interested actors are pretty weak and a theory based on them doesn't actually work. But in economics the political side is too dominant to let that discredit such theories, except to a few mavericks.

I cannot imagine how this "bean to bar" chocolate can be adequately refined -- without a true manufacturing process -- which would require more equipment than boutique operations are able to have.
My favorite American chocolate, Wilbur Chocolate of Lititz, PA -- not only grinds beans finely, but refines the ground particles to pieces of less than .004 inches. This takes patented machinery and know-how. And their best varieties use only cocoa butter; no other oils.
I have seen various expensive bars that appear unrefined and contain other oils -- nonsense!
The best are available at http://www.wilburbuds.com.

I don't quite understand what you're getting at.  Are you saying these "Bean to Bar" companies don't have the proper equipment to adequately process/refine the cacao beans?  That's being a bit naive, this isn't the 19th century.  Grenada Chocolate Company, a company i mentioned in an earlier posting, started from scratch here in the U.S.   I was friends with 2 of the 3 founders, late founders to be more specific.  They hand built most of the machines but had to buy other equipment from Belgium to adequately refine the chocolate.  If you have the money or credit, you can do it. Along with a dedicated owners and staff.

This cake is so fast and easy to whip up that I made three of them last week. As my 12 year old said, it's not a birthday cake, but it's still a decent dessert. These are the tweaks that I make:
- Whole wheat flour
- Full fat milk and yogurt (no need for cornstarch)
- A little more apple
- 1/2 cup sugar in the cake. Sprinkle a little on top.
- Lemon instead of orange rind
- Butter to grease the pan (gives such a nice flavor)
- Adjust heat and baking time. (I do 160°C for 1 hour.)

I typically use the skillet method described below but tried this recipe to compare. The results weren't good, as others noted. The pasta wasn't hot enough to melt the cheese properly and the olive oil coated the pasta, preventing the cheese from sticking to it. I ended up with globs of half-melted cheese instead of a gooey sauce. The amount of pepper should be reduced by at least half. It may be possible to get good results with these instructions, but it's certainly not obvious.

Someone asked about adding vegetables. I reduced chicken by half and added julienned carrots, celery, red pepper, asparagus and onions. Stir fry these first until tender crisp and remove to a platter. Follow the recipe as written. Throw in some sliced water chestnuts after the sauce has reduced. Add the veggies back in. Yum.

How do you cut a ham bone in half without damaging your knives?  I have a leftover ham bone from Christmas I would like to use.  I don't have a cleaver in my kitchen or a local butcher I can ask to cut the bone in twos or threes.  I tried looking online to no avail.  I wondered if anyone else encounter this and how they dealt with a leftover bone.  Anyone?
I just use my ham bone whole instead of worrying about cutting it up. It seems to work just as well in my experience.
Sounds kinda gross, but I used a hacksaw from the garage - washed and sanitized the blade first  - but cut right through it.  Now I have 2 bones with which to play!

The CCP is the proverbial child with the finger in the dike. The U.S. and other countries in Asia must take a principled without being pulled into a game of manipulated domestic perception forming which is being carefully controlled and played out by the Politburo in Zhongnanhai.

The goal is clear. Increasing diversity at selective universities will foster future leaders who will better represent the emerging national demographic. A diverse cadre of leaders can further policies and implement strategies within their communities aimed at decreasing disparity. As much as we like to see it otherwise, one of the chief goals of higher education is to develop leaders of tomorrow. And these leaders need to be diverse.

For states that have derailed Affirmative Action, ongoing data will inform more potent and specific recruitment strategies. The data seems to show that each state and each flagship school has its own private school competitors, its own incentives systems, and its unique existing school/student relationship. Ann Arbor will experience more competition from competitive private schools than Austin, hence, their strategy was to scale 'yield'. Austin will have to come up with their own strategy. There is no size that fits all. Informed by a good needs assessment, the solution will be adequately tailored to the school.

It is hopeful to see Michigan successfully increase class diversity. It will be a harder task to move beyond the controlled environment of the college campus to the real world. How can we translate university diversity to improved societal equity?

Saudi Arabia did not keep oil prices down. It kept them stable. It helped keep them stable at a higher level, one which was also profitable for US domestic oil production.

Apart from that, they have never been a real ally, reliable or otherwise. Most of the time they have done nothing at all as an ally except oil pricing.

Recently they became active in ways they had never been, when they have launched off on their own agenda. They are not our ally in doing that. It has nothing to do with US interests.

It is Saudi interests, to keep the deal between the Saud family and the wacko religious groups that support its autocracy in Arabia under the Wahhabi doctrines. That is "Sunni" only in so far as it is Wahhabi. Anyone who doesn't follow Saudi extremism with their Wahhabi deal is not on side, no matter if they are Sunni.

XYZ123 -- Yes, they did just "flood the market and crash it." That did hurt Iran, and Russia too. I'm sure their own reasons had more to do with hurting Iran than hurting Russia.

However, it is not "economic suicide." They also took market share, which is a long term profit, and they are undermining the high cost competition that was cutting into their market share. Once they've stopped the new high-cost operations, they can run up the price again. It is classic monopoly behavior, not suicidal at all. Who will put more billions into something the Saudis can and will wreck as they just did?

Their pain is short term. Their gain is long term.

I'm sure our Cold Warriors were delighted to bash on Russia, which is a myopic response to this. And I agree that Obama has been too much captured by the Cold Warriors. But I doubt this was done because Obama and Kerry wanted it. The Saudis wanted it, and the US high cost oil extraction is one of their targets.

Dr. M -- There are 18 million Saudis, with another 9 million foreign workers. There are over 80 million Iranians, over 4 times as many. If Iran has executed more, it has not been four times more.

The numbers for both nations are in dispute. To take the high for one compared to the low for the other would be misleading. That is not a defense of Iran, but they are not worse than the Saudis.

I also notice the US falling behind in executions, but in the running.

The whole business of executions is disgusting and plain wrong.

What matters here is that this one particular execution of a leading political figure was done to inflame the region and contribute to war. Wars are even worse than executions.

Zman -- You assume that hurting Iran was "to make Iran accept the nuke agreement." That does not seem to be the case. They did not want and likely did not expect an actual agreement. They hurt Iran on the way to hurting Iran even more, by war waged by others in their hopes and dreams.

There is a pipeline issue at play: there simply aren't enough kids getting into and out of K-12. Expecting universities to remedy a problem that the entirety of society has not solved seems disingenuous. Universities with -- most typically -- their millions aren't sufficiently resourced to solve a problem which society and its billions has not?

Our society and our economy are not equipped to address the poverty faced by kids who fail to finish the K-12 path. There will never be a society equitable enough to ensure that all groups will have a shot at the sort of equity and social justice in the preceding generation such that they are properly fed, clothed and housed. Without that fundamental/foundational equity, kids simply won't get through the pipeline in sufficient numbers to ensure a generational succession of access into opportunity.

But to deal with that problem we'd have to truly talk about race, social justice, and intergenerational equity. America is not ready for that conversation, so it engages in a canard, it pretends that it is addressing the problem by asking the wrong question: "Why cannot universities succeed where all of society has failed?" This strikes me as a fundamentally flawed premise and a distraction from the issue of prejudice.

The Supremes offered up a temporizing construct in the Michigan related cases...roughly along the lines of: "Preferences should solve the problem in 25 years or so.". Good one. They then dropped the mic and went home.

It is indeed possible for a premiere school to achieve diversity - real diversity, not just the limited quota-based kind that can be achieved through check boxes on an application form - without resorting to discrimination, that is, traditional affirmative action.

Michigan fought hard to keep affirmative action. It vigorously litigated the 2003 lawsuits described here, losing one, but, crucially, narrowly winning the other.

And when the electorate of Michigan voted to ban race-based AA, then-UM president Mary Sue Coleman strongly hinted the school would disobey the ballot's mandate, only later reluctantly succumbing to legal and political realities.

Next, the school fought another expensive legal battle to have the voter's mandate overruled in court, only to have the US Supreme Court declare the new requirement Constitutional.

So, the school is now "stuck" with a necessity imposed by the people and taxpayers of Michigan, that it must implement admissions without race-based affirmative action.

And lo, things may not be so bad after all. If present trends at UM continue, living in conformity with the equal protection clause of our Constitution may be palatable, even to liberals, after all.

I still believe that most forms of racial preferences are wrong, including basing financial aid on race rather than need, but at least there are approaches that may avoid the blatant discrimination that is the essence of Affirmative Action.

If "educating all of our children well" is important, as you say, then you must face the fact that every major educator in the country thinks that exposure to people of diverse backgrounds is tremendously important. Universities are producing our future leaders. What kind of job are they doing if the students they turn out have absolutely no clue what people different from them are thinking or valuing?

Why can't a college be allowed to have a racially and culturally diverse student body? The other side is to a have a test results based selection criterium, which will exclude the creative thinking, artistic applicants in favor of the "study for test" high scoring achievers. What would be the selection criterion then, to ensure that race has nothing to do with the selection process?

Any type of social policy that equitably rights the wrongs of America's entrenched legacy of discriminatory racial practices will come at the expense of the majority. That is the real reason why the masses oppose AA - it threatens white America's sense of entitlement, the feeling that they've "earned" a seat at the table. Never mind the centuries of policies enacted to rig the system in their favor.

The alternative to AA, and admittedly the best solution, is to radically reform America's K-12 education system; specifically by eliminating property taxes as the main funding source for school districts. How is it fair that high-income districts get to have the best school systems, keep all their resources to themselves, and severely restrict households with section-8 housing vouchers from living in their affluent school district? In order to level the playing field, we need to redistribute funding and talent (teachers) to underperforming schools. But capitalists would never support such drastic social justice measures, and so we have AA.

Actually I think you are mistaken. The graduation rate for these minorities is quite high. If the colleges were as interested in that it would be better. They don't care once the minorities are accepted, it matters not if they graduate or if they have dropped down to an easier major.

This is actually a good point. Asians have suffered the same kind of discrimination as blacks in the past, from being barred from professions and schools to lynchings. Asians were not eligible for citizenship, either. In the early 20th century Palmer made a list, a hierarchy of immigrants, and south Asians were at the very bottom, the most undesirable.

Transparency would weed out incompetent, dishonest doctors with out-of-date skills and reduce medical costs via enabling consumers to comparison price shop for medical care. My surgeon was a medical fraud who instead of performing the consented to and long planned modern, minimally-invasive surgery, just did an old-fashioned, open procedure, butcher job for no medical or anatomical reason. She did it because she fraudulently misrepresented her skills and experience. My surgeon's hospital then billed thousands of dollars to my health insurance company for the unused laparoscopic surgery tools and materials that just sat in the OR in their wrapping while my doctor butchered me with her scalpel, breaching my consent. I often reflect on property ownership as I drive along the beautiful lakes and waterways where I live and must strain to find a view among the competing architectural altars to each owner's success story. Small slivers of "public access" points do exist, but are pathetically inadequate.

Homeowners along one lake took it upon themselves to appropriate publicly-owned former railroad land along one entire side of a lake, and when the county initiated plans to convert the rails to a trail for public use, the homeowners were enraged that their illegally appropriated public property was repatriated, and that the "public" would be walking near their waterfront homes. They became so aggressive, that County officials brought police with them when they went to survey the property.

The rapid appropriation and sense of entitlement by the elites of our most scenic areas--and political influence that allowed this, is a tragic visual reminder of our rapidly failing Democracy.

Excellent comment.  In fact, most of the land in this country is not "our land" at all.  We spend our lives on a few tiny patches of land, connected by thin ribbons of public access (roads and highways).  Private ownership of vast tracts of land effectively removes it from being "ours" and greatly restricts any "freedom" we might think we have.

This is a great comment.  The same thought occurs to me every day as I cycle a narrow public trail squeezed behind empty, zillion dollar Mcmansions circling Lake Washington. Our most treasured public resources are literally fenced in by the few who can afford it, but rarely appreciate it.

Ownership has its limits, but that does not necessitate the elimination of ownership altogether.

Through representatives society can legislate the limit of ownership to prevent an individual from amassing wealth or industry or property to an extent that oppresses the majority. Anti-monopoly laws were created to address that concern.

To 'eliminate' private property is, in reality, to place it under the private control of select politicians, bureaucrats, and their cronies. This is how human nature actually works, and a quick read through Orwell's novel, Animal Farm, is a primer for consideration of this fact. More folks are killed in traffic accidents than in gun violence. I believe that many of these accidents result from a distracted driver using a cell phone.

In his last MLB season Puazza returned with the Oakland A's to play the Mets.  He hit a home run in his first at-bat. My late father was an original Mets fan, he arrived from Ireland in 1957 and despite the rampant discrimination against the Irish, he worked incredibly hard and loved the NY Mets from day 1. His life was work every day and the Mets on the radio and then on TV whenever possible. When they won the Series in 1969, he came home with turf from Shea, we never forgot how happy he was. He died in 1996, and we kept going to Shea to carry on his legacy as a fan. So we were honored to be there to see Mike Piazza play, and the thrill of that will stay with us for our lifetimes.  We will never forget the first game at Shea after 9/11, when we needed hope, Mike was there. We miss so many good things - we miss Dad, we miss Shea, we miss watching Mike play - and we are so happy to see a true gentleman and great player get into the Hall today. Thank you, Mr. Piazza - and many congratulations on this well deserved honor. Know that you make all Mets fans, the ones here and the ones in the Shea in the Sky, very happy today and always. When you go to Cooperstown, we'll follow you there to see your plaque - you will be the reason we go there. That's how much you mean to us.

Thank you for sharing these wonderful memories. I grew up in Queens and, before leaving NY must have gone by Shea thousands of times on the Flushing IRT and the highway. Your descriptions are very evocative of another time.

If Bonds, Clemens, or any of the others are ever elected to the HOF, they should take the sign down and close the doors forever. The last thing baseball needs after this long, sordid era is a Hall of Shame populated with steroid cheats.

The fundamental flaw in the logic of this article, and the reason so many Nobel-level economists have been wrong in their predictions over the past decade...

...is that there is really no such thing as a "stand alone national economy" any more.

Most economic models are based on "nodes" of "national economies" with thin links of "trade" between those nodes. This article assumes that the US "node" has some extraordinary power vis-a-vis all the other national nodes on Earth.

The reality is that supra-node physical trade, and free-flowing finance among 100+ country nodes is now the dominant force of a unified global economy, and the national nodes have relatively little influence.

The Chinese stock markets are flipping around, but China still has the largest single physical production engine on Earth, and it has more than 150,000,000 expat citizens who either control or influence more than 50% of the physical commodities on Earth - and can ship them anywhere on short notice.

India has the largest and most diverse commercial democracy on Earth and can use barter, not government controlled currency to absorb economic shocks.

7 billion mobile phones, with 90% per capital penetration in the poorest regions of Earth, transmit more than $400 billion of "remittances" among guest workers of the world.

The "Tinkertoy" economic models of the 20th Century are now as obsolete as the land line telephone.

It is the single most pressing issue for this connected younger generation.

Whenever I read a piece about antioxidants I wonder if the proponents have any idea what they are talking about. I am an organic chemist, and yes I understand that compounds that are highly colored often have multiple double bonds that are highly reactive with radicals, but under what conditions? Oh sure the colored compounds react with radicals when you deliberately mix them together, but what I mean is how do these radical scavenger molecules manage to get into the body and travel to the cellular location where they might usefully interact. Everything that you eat goes first to the liver via the portal vein, before it can go anywhere else. Do you know how the liver functions - lots of oxidation reactions. I seriously question whether any of these wonderful "antioxidants" ever gets past the liver. Just because something is an antioxidant  in vitro, or has anti cancer properties, or antibiotic or antiviral properties in vitro, does not mean it is useful in vivo, because it has to be able to get to the proper site in the body before it can do anything useful....and most of them don't.

I would add, too, that many of the same people who praise naturally occurring antioxidants think that food preservatives are akin to poison... and yet many preservatives are antioxidants, added to food to keep the oils and fats in them from turning rancid through oxidation.

I'm an organic chemist also and there's plenty of research out there on the subject.  Recent findings show that dietary free radical inhibitors aren't all they've been cracked up to be but the beneficial effects of the antioxidants cited must be due to something

To Alias:
You are confusing between issues and issues. First, please look at the borders of Bangladesh (BD) with Myanmar. These two countries share very few miles of border. Myanmar borders India, so does BD. It is extremely unlikely that significant numbers of BD refugees in 1971 went to Myanmar - they didn't.
Second, international borders like now are relatively recent phenomenon. There were always some Rohingyas in Myanmar, just as there are Nagas and others ethnically close to some Myanmar tribes in India. Rohingyas are predominantly Burmese citizens, or should be.
Third, yes, during the British period some Indian Muslims from what is today's BD did go over to Myanmar and they were ethnically the same as the Rohingyas. But even that is a 100 yrs back. Hence by all accounts Rohingyas are people of the land of Myanmar.
Now, I do not know if Suu Kyi is not keeping deliberately silent about the Rohingyas so as not to lose power, which would be disastrous for Myanmar, since power would shift to the military again. The lack of attention to the Rohingya in the U.S. media is the rule when it comes to S.E. Asia. (The exception is Al Jazeera, which has been broadcasting about the plight of the Rohingya for years.)

How much do most American know about the half million Indonesians who were killed after Suharto came to power in 1965? Or the needless deaths, estimated at 100,000, in East Timor over the two to three decades before it finally achieved its independence in 1999? The U.S. didn't just ignore these tragedies, but actively supported the wrong side.

Neither Indonesia's Bali nor Burma actually fits the comfortable narrative of exotic tourist destinations filled with spiritual, peaceful Hindu and Buddhist peoples. After the 1985 coup in Indonesia, 80,000 Balinese, five percent Bali's population, were killed (see Geoffrey Robinson's book, "The Dark Side of Paradise").

In Burma, the most outspoken advocates for violence against the Rohingya are Buddhist monks, who are no better than thugs. George Orwell, who as a young man was a colonial police officer in Burma, wrote with vigor about how much he disposed British colonialism, yet had very little kind to say about Burma's monks.

U.S. apathy toward, and ignorance of S.E. Asia has a way of coming back to bite us. Remember when the French were defeated in their colonial war by the Viet Minh at Dien Bien Phu in 1954? That one came back to haunt us, too.

I agree with most of what you say here, and I get annoyed when people speak of Burmese monks or Tibetans as all being perfect, enlightened role-models. "The growth of the job market while this statistic remains week is simply due to population growth..."

Actually, none of the growth of the job market is due to population growth since babies and toddlers don't work. Since it is is simply wrong to mix together people who want jobs and those who don't, the best measure is appropriately called "not in the labor force, want a job now" (BLS series ID LNS15026639). Last I checked (last month) the percentage of people in this category was lower than it was at comparable points following the milder recessions of 1981-82 and 1990-91. And that is true whether the denominator is the labor force or the Civilian Noninstitutional Population.

So, the question is: following the worst recession since the Great Depression, how is it that we are doing better when it comes to people who aren't in the labor force even though they want jobs than we did following two recent milder recessions?

comments.commentBody: So, the weapons have to be big and destroy lots of stuff -- always -- for the Federation of American Scientists to sign on.  So the B83 it is, for city busters are the way to go.

If the lowest setting of this new device is 2% of the explosion at Hiroshima, is this not a mission that could be accomplished with conventional weapons?  To me, there has not been a convincing case made that this is necessary.

The WWII bombs were around 20kT (thousand tons) of TNT equivalent. 2% of that is 400 tons of TNT equivalent. There are no 400 ton conventional weapons, nor a way to deliver them, so your short answer is no. The largest conventional weapons (e.g., https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GBU-43/B_Massive_Ordnance_Air_Blast are around 10 tons TNT equivalent.)

The Hiroshima bomb was the equivalent of 20,000 tons of TNT. Two percent of that is 400 tons. A B-52 can carry up to 35 tons and we have 85 of them.
Yes, this could be done with conventional explosives, but you would be risking a large percentage of your strategic air force on a single mission.

Don't kid yourself. The Hiroshima bomb was 13 kilotons. 2% of that is 0.26 kilotons. That's 260 TONS of TNT equivalent. Think about that.

No conventional bomb approaches that level of destructiveness..

@Jesse Marioneaux,
One small little problem with your comment. Question, did we use nuclear weapons on Hiroshima and Nagasaki to start a war with Japan? Simple question, it only requires a yes or a no.

I recommend John McPhee's "The Curve of Binding Energy" for knowledge of how Ted Taylor, engineering genius, built some amazing gadgets for the DoD. His "Davy Crockett" weighed 50 pounds! There were once nuclear artillery shells too. But that was then, in the Cold War.

As McPhee reported, Taylor saw the big picture and realized that nuclear proliferation could not be enforced by secrecy, since any competent nuclear physics graduate student, with financial backing, could build a primitive "gun-type" weapon (the Hiroshima bomb). By controlling access to special nuclear materials, many countries (and a number of other groups) could be prevented from building devices that, although likely to fizzle, would cause radioactive damage and mass hysteria. He was able to convince the US government of this, and the US carried the ball further into international agreements.

This book is not for the technological elite, although the reader will learn what the title means, a thing to know. It's more about people and processes at the time that McPhee wrote the book in 1974. It is an excellent but sobering read.

The gun type weapon requires a *lot* of nearly pure U-235, which is not easy to obtain. It requires massive infrastructure. But assuming you had enough of the stuff, it wouldn't take a graduate student to build the bomb.
Really? Who's calculator are you using? Mine says around $3,330 per person. Hardly poverty solved....  :-(

This sort of weapons development does at least 4 things:
1) Because the size of the weapon is much smaller and less able to kill a million, it will be easier to justify its use.
2) If the US does this, China will follow and can afford it, while Russia will go broke trying and become even more unstable as a result.
3) No future enemy will be confident the US has not used a nuclear weapon and will feel justified in using its own much larger nukes in retaliation.
4) This would change the nuclear calculation from one of mutually assured destruction (MAD) in which it is mad to use a nuclear weapon to one where one side could use a small nuclear weapon and have the other pull the MAD trigger to everyone's detriment.

comments.commentBody: "Once knowledge and goodness were divorced, scientists could be regarded as experts, but there are no morals or lessons to be drawn from their work. Science derives its authority from impersonal structures and methods, not the superior character of the scientist. The individual scientist is no different from the average Joe; he or she has, as Shapin has written, “no special authority to pronounce on what ought to be done.” For many, science became a paycheck, and the scientist became a “de-moralized” tool enlisted in the service of power, bureaucracy and commerce." Naturally, professors are referred to as instructors, if not customer service reps, while students are consumers, customers, and fans. No wonder tribalistic college sports, not knowledge, seems the strongest "glue" and "unity" cohering the diverse academic units, creating a sense of self-worth and identity. I feel that we need philosophers in every corner on and off campus more than ever to restore the beliefs and values that led to the birth of universities in the first place during the Dark Ages.

According to Wikipedia, at least, the first university was chartered in the 1150's. That puts the earliest universities in the High Middle Ages, which are reckoned from 1000. The Dark Ages, if the phrase has a meaning today, are the Early Middle Ages, from the late 400's to 1000, called dark because of the relative paucity of primary sources (dark = unknown).

Read some history, D'Alien.

Before anyone says "pot, meet kettle" because I cited Wikipedia, I was looking for a date or two on which to anchor my claim that universities were a product of the High Middle Ages, before the thread closed. D'Alien's comment should really have been answered by a specialist in medieval history. What I'm protesting against is the facile, ill-informed claim that the entire span of time from 476 (when the last Roman emperor in the West died) to the beginning of the Renaissance was "dark," meaning shrouded in ignorance.

If philosophers were "in every corner on and off campus...to restore beliefs and values that led to the birth of universities" what beliefs and values would be appropriate with today's society? To my knowledge there is no definite right or wrong answer to a person's philosophy, it comes from ones perspective. You may have one idea that i completely disagree with but that does not make either of us wrong, so if philosophers were all around who has the right to determine what each philosopher should demonstrate? What standard would we hold these philosophers to or are they free to explain their own ideals of their philosophy? I do agree there needs to be more of a place for philosohy, but I feel that society is not ready to accept what current philosophers have to offer.

Although one may blame the modern university as the cause of this "way-losing", I don't believe anyone has mentioned the handful of
large bulls which entered the china shop of philosophy about two centuries ago, namely:
* materialism--the belief that human thought and values are purely mechanistic phenomena--undercut any notion that people have
insight into reality, but only sense perceptions of it;
* radical relativism/subjectivism in support of radical individualism, which made it nearly impossible to talk about the actual truth or falsity of anything, PARTICULARLY anything which must be based on teleological concepts such as human nature;
* utilitarianism, which reduced things to the algebra of value propositions identical to the calculations done by insurance companies to set premiums; and
* and a cluster of closely related, highly reductive approaches which assess ideas not only by their content, but by the social group, ethnic background, skin color, and gender of the people expressing them.

These four areas, above, have driven philosophy away from its former roots, driven a wedge between it and common sense, and enthroned each individual as having the ultimate authority to define the truth to be whatever he needs it to be.

Proof of this last point can be seen in the comments on this article, in which there is a great variety of ideas about what philosophy actually is.

comments.commentBody: The KROQ studio was decorated and darkly lit for Halloween. Bowie and Nine Ince Nails were soon to play the Los Angeles Forum. And here I was was finally meeting --- and interviewing --- my idol, David Bowie. Generous and gracious, and willing to help me with my new clean time. My most memorable on-air question for him was, "Have you ever been fat?" He thought it was funny, but decided to take it seriously, giving compliments to his wife Iman whom he said was a fantastic cook. One of my Halloween decorations was a battery-operated throbbing heart. It was lying on the studio furniture. While I wasn't looking, David, with this macabre device activated, stuffed it down his pants. He had to nudge me before I saw it. I laughed like a madman.

Hailing from a deeply conservative middle-class Mexican family, my first purchase of a Bowie album became the ultimate act of transgression. I was about 10 years old when I finally decided to set foot at the nearby shopping mall’s record store, bent on buying a record with my meager savings. The first bars of ‘Life On Mars?’ caught my ear as soon as I entered the store… and they never let go. At that stage I could barely understand basic English, and was way too young to fully grasp the lyrics, but something about the song moved me to head straight for the DJ booth and meekly ask for the album.

When I proudly emerged from the store, with an empty velcro wallet in my pocket but an imported vinyl pressing of Hunky Dory held firmly between my grubby little hands, I felt the rush of having done something by myself, something grownups did on a regular basis. It felt good. My parents were horrified. My dad scolded me for wasting money on “stupid rock music”, my mom wanted to take me to church as soon as she found out that the curious-looking being on the album art was actually a dude. Thankfully the store had a strict “no refunds policy”, so my record was confiscated for a few days until I managed to get it back from its hiding place. In the end, David Bowie found a way to stay with me. I guess you can say he taught me more about English, music, tolerance, originality, uniqueness and independence than my parents ever could.

I think a lot of people are missing the point. By making Harvard free, admissions would no longer be motivated to admit wealthier students. The percentage of wealthy students in the class would fall, perhaps dramatically. As it is now, the school uses a number of proxies to assure a large percentage of wealthy students - admitting legacies, admitting from prep schools and big cities, and so on. No doubt the expectation of tuition from these folks is a huge motivator.

In addition, I think it's great that people are finally waking up to the fact that white males are not the only ones suffering from affirmative action. In fact, Asians are probably the biggest losers from this policy and from the admissions of places like Harvard in general, which allot a certain number of spots for rich kids and a certain number of spots for minority kids and very few spots to middle-class non-minority over-achievers, who are disproportionately Asian. I'd love to see some data on which race has lost the most due to affirmative action.

Ohana,

Asian kids are suffering if you believe grades should be the only determining factor in admitting kids into college. Isn't college more than just a place for education but also a place to grow and discover ourselves.
Wrong. Wealthy families contribute as donors, not just payers of tuition. One might argue that making Harvard tuition-free would increase pressure to admit children of potential donor families.

Harvard is already free for students from families with an income under $65K and students from families with and income between $65K and $150K are expected to contribute 0-10% of the cost.

https://college.harvard.edu/financial-aid/how-aid-works/cost-attendance

Legacies?

Not that I recall (having attended Harvard Law School in the early Seventies). AFTER being admitted, I did get a long letter listing numerous "scholarships" that apparently reflected bequests from dead alumni. Most of them offered, say, $100 if you happened to be descended from, say, a family with the surname of Ziffelschwartz from the central Pennsylvani town of Ziffelschwartzville. I didn't meet any of the requirements, and so I got nothing.

But I emphasize: That was AFTER admission, and so it had nothing to do with the admission decision. Possibly legacies counted for more in undergraduate admissions, though I doubt it was much different. And if legacies did matter back then, my impression is that they've mattered less and less over the past several decades.

This is not to say that discrimination against Asian-Americans isn't occurring -- only to suggest that, if that discrimination is occurring, "legacies" aren't the reason for that.

Andrea: Sad to hear you judged people by their home address. Perhaps you would have been happier with a Somali, a Pole, an Irishman and an Aussie, in your music class. Just joking. But, most colleges and universities draw from their geographic area as that is what people can afford. I lived next to Great Neck and went to UCLA - - and was relieved to get away from all those Great Neck-ers. And, Bostonians.
Andrea: There are kids named Chin and Tang from Oregon, who do not live in the cities. We live in a mixed nation.  I think Harvard will have to come up with a better excuse than that.

Harvard is betting that the smartest kid from Oregon has a better chance of becoming a US Senator than an equally smart kid from the East Coast. It's not about the kids, it's about the power and influence of Harvard. "Granted, you won't have the connections you'd get at an Ivy, but so what?"

There's a prevalent notion that "connections" can get your kid into Harvard (or Yale, or wherever). Frankly, I very seriously doubt that. I went to Harvard (Law) and certainly had no "connections." More important, my three kids all went to elite private elementary and high schools, and even the suggestion that someone would use "connections" is considered highly inappropriate. Even more important, the prospect that anyone in the admissions department at an elite university would pay any attention to "connections" these days strikes me as highly unlikely. All I've ever heard is that admissions personnel are very strongly opposed to showing any favoritism on that basis, and that they are so zealous about that that anyone even THINKING about trying to exploit "connections" will very quickly recognize that any such effort is more likely to HURT than to help their child's chances.

We do have a friend who's on the Board of Trustees of an Ivy League School, and she has two sons attending that school (actually, one already graduated). That might seem to disprove my point above, but the fact is that both of those students would have been admitted to that school (and any other school they might have chosen) based entirely on their own merits.

I, too went to Harvard with no connections. That doesn't mean that kids with connections don't have an advantage. When I was at Harvard, there were kids who clearly were admitted because their families were potential future donors to Harvard. I'm not even sure I have such a big problem with that--someone has to pay the tuition for folks like me who can't afford school otherwise.

But if you do the data analysis, there is simply no way to confirm that both her children would have been admitted. The standards are currently quite subjective, and many students with impeccable scores, grades, and qualifications are declined. What differentiates are factors like diversity, legacy, and yes, connections. To assert that you can prove the negative is ludicrous - buttressed by you having provided evidence to negate your own thesis.

To MyTwoCents--Your points are good, but you misunderstood the quote you cited.

"You won't have the connections you'd get at an Ivy" means that if you attend a non-Ivy college/university, your classmates will tend not to be wealthy or pre-wealthy kids. After graduation, "Ivy" pals and their parents can recommend you for jobs with stratospheric salaries, mentor you, offer stock market advice (some of it not illegal insider info, LOL), and so on.

Your State University classmates, by and large, will be helping you with an largely different set of connections..

"But Mr. Unz says that even with potential aid, prospective low-income applicants may be discouraged by the published tuition of $45,000 a year."

I very seriously doubt that. Keep in mind: Just because you get admitted to Harvard doesn't mean you have to accept. On the off chance that you get admitted and don't manage to figure out that gobs and gobs of financial aid are available at Harvard, maybe the $45,000 sticker price may dissuade you. But, seriously, what are the odds that someone is sharp enough to get into Harvard but not sharp enough to figure out that you won't really have to pay for it if you can't afford to?

I'll wager that no high school senior in the history of the world has decided not to apply to Harvard because of the $45,000 tuition.

I'm pretty sure you would lose that bet!  Many students don't even look at Harvard and other Ivies because of the cost.   Working class and middle class whites and blacks are so discouraged by the tuition and other costs they don't even look.  Articles appear frequently in the public press including the NYT telling them they won't do well at these schools because they won't fit in.  It's infuriating.     Students are constantly bombarded with articles that allege that some people should just accept reality and not even think about college.  Insidious and true.  It's a subtle and sometimes not so subtle reminder that some people just should remember their place.  We have marched backward in time and it's not pretty.

This comment comes from the perspective of privilege. It's probably true that students with educationally-minded parents and/or who attend a high school with a proactive and informed guidance office do know about Harvard's financial aid package. However how many underrepresented students, both economically and racially, do you think actually have these advantages? I can tell you from personal experience as someone who has advised high school seniors that many students have no clue and have a great deal of difficulty navigating the complex process of college applications. Students of privilege often have an abundance of help in this area. To name just a few: SAT tutors, college advisers, strong in-school advising offices and highly involved parents. The student who can apply to and get into Harvard without this kind of assistance is rare... My son, who went to Williams, was advised by his guidance counselor to only apply to our local community college.

To NLP: If you peel the tough skin from the stems (it's usually so thick that I actually slice it off with a knife) and then chop up the core of the stem, you have a lovely crisp vegetable. I usually just cook it up with the rest of the broccoli when I'm having broccoli as a side dish, and it's just as tasty as the florets.

What a shame all the way around.  What I'd like to know is how Chipotle treats, not their salaried managers,  but their hourly serving staff.   Paid sick leave protocol?  Hourly pay ranges?  Vacation and personal time?  Is Chipotle cutting corners and creating hostile workplaces where upset or angry or ill servers are taking their frustrations out on the products/customers?  Inquiring minds and caring consumers want to know.   These kinds of sanitation problems are not unique to Chipotle but it is also why I rarely dine out much anymore if at all.
Or maybe they just don't enforce health safety standards?

Reluctance to seek help will only increase as mental illness, rather than easy availability of guns, is disproportionately blamed for tragedies in the US. Stigmatizing people with what, for many, is a mere chemical imbalance that is easily correctable makes no sense. Rather than avoiding him or her, I'd rather see a physician whose personal experience may very well make that person a more compassionate, more sensitive, and more considerate individual, particularly with respect to the millions of patients in this country who may, at some time or another of their lives, be faced with extreme life stresses or crises, not to mention hormone imbalances, having the potential to precipitate depression or some other mood disorder.

It sounds as if some of Dr. Carroll's colleagues need to get over themselves, by the way. The fact that patients, as lay persons with respect to their area of expertise, defer to their medical knowledge is by no means an indication that they are regarded as otherwise perfect or superior. Not everyone aspires to or is interested in medical school; in fact, some of my colleagues whose fathers were doctors told me that they had been specifically warned away from that line of work, and I know of several physicians whose grades and test scores were lower than those of my children (some of whom have doctorates, but are not medical doctors) when they were classmates at school. I do hope these younger doctors bring a more enlightened attitude to work.

A kid whose father was shot outside his front door, whose mother won't let him venture out to the library, who spends his time playing internet chess,  becomes a grandmaster, and is widely proclaimed a genius, has all the drive it takes to learn and grow.  But he doesn't have the opportunity.  And you would deny it to him because he does not fit your preconceived notion of who should be admitted to an elite school.  Genius comes in all sizes and flavors, not just medium vanilla.

I can't agree with Kristof's statement that Syria is Obama's 'single biggest failing.' The mess in Syria is the fault of the Syrian people, who have torn their own country to pieces over a mix of religious and sectarian grievances. Keeping America out of that quagmire is a sensible goal.

I suspect several of the candidates in the debate would send in 100,000 American ground troops to destroy ISIS. Then we would have to administer Syria, which is the real problem.

I agree that Kristoff's remark that Syria is Obama's "single biggest failing" is way off the mark.  Obama didn't invade Iraq, nor did he start a civil war in Syria.  Nor is he responsible for the fact that the region is occupied by three Arab factions that have been at each other's throats for centuries, which W and his cronies never picked up on.  Syria is the size of the State of Washington.  And the Russians are now in Syria in force as are the Iranians.  100,000 troops?  Maybe.  Or maybe 250,000.  And the likelihood of starting a major conflagration with disastrous consequences.  And what other country is willing to put boots on the ground to support such an invasion?  I have heard absolutely no one articulate specifically how Obama is supposed to solve this situation, but, like Kristoff, they're eager to blame him for not fixing it.  Obama should in fact be given great credit for the restraint he has shown.

We do walk a balanced beam by blaming the people, but the cold, hard fact, is that societies fail when they fail to break the bonds of tribalism and find a way to deeply integrate across color, religious, and ethnic boundaries.

The lack of integration (and ultimately the sense of social acceptance and unity) seems to provide a major opportunity for exploitation by strong despot leaders.

In a world where the obvious solution to human success if 'global unity', tribalism, and it's pan-tribal political equivalent, religion, are major obstacles to human progress, and also, unfortunately, a major driver of human conflict and suffering.

Republicans have apparently learned nothing. They are ready to charge in with no forethought, no planning, and no fiscal responsibility. All they know how to do is offer their hollow prayers to those who paid the price for Republican recklessness.

There is scads of research showing that those things are excellent measures of success at the post-secondary level.
But your idea of merit must not be related to academic success.
Your idea of Harvard giving away the money that people give to Harvard, for Harvard would not sit well with those who choose Harvard as the recipient of these endowments.

Unrelated to music Friday. On inequality. Darwin: "If the misery of the poor be caused not by the laws of nature, but by our institutions, great is our sin."

Yes, our institutions. Adam Smith: "The difference of natural talents in different men is, in reality, much less than we are aware of... The difference between the most dissimilar characters, between a philosopher and a common street porter, for example, seems to arise not so much from nature as from habit, custom, and education. When they came into the world, and for the first six or eight years of their existence, they were, perhaps, very much alike, and neither their parents nor playfellows could perceive any remarkable difference. About that age, or soon after, they come to be employed in very different occupations. The difference of talents comes then to be taken notice of, and widens by degrees, till at last the vanity of the philosopher is willing to acknowledge scarce any resemblance."

Human diversity is inevitable. Social inequality, a hierarchical social order is not, and increasingly it is morally intolerable. Just like different skin color cannot justify the enslavement of ones by others or sexual differences cannot justify patriarchy and gender exploitation, differences in physical propensities or modes of learning, often reinforced by historical inequities that pass from generation to generation, are unacceptable as alibis for a vertical social order.

The problem of maintaining cognitive functioning throughout life was solved thousands of years ago, when humans developed meditation techniques that have you focus on your breathing.

The "trick" is in continually noticing when your attention wanders, and then bringing your mind back to following your breath. Not forcing your breathing, just watching it. This form of meditation trains the mind to be grounded in the the present and fosters mental clarity.

My preferred practice is "standing zen" meditation, but there are any number of eastern meditation disciplines that work, too.

And they don't need to cost you anything.

Hi Jon P,
Its good to hear from someone else who values meditation.
I googled "meditation and cognitive enhancement" and
a raft of websites showed up, to include scholarly articles, that support my argument.

In my opinion, the effect of regular practice is an overall clarity. In addition to daily meditative practice, I read widely (literary as well as technical and scientific subjects), study chess, do woodworking, exercise, and do lots of other things that require me to think.

In my seventh decade of life, yes, I have of late noticed that sometimes I grope for a word, but I consider meditation to be
a very effective tool in my quest to think as clearly as I ever did throughout my life.

"But where's the proof that it will maintain our cognitive function throughout life? Are there studies that show meditation prevents dementia or even normal memory loss caused by aging of the brain?"

Where is the proof that what Lumosity promises to do for a monthly fee is superior to what meditation promises to do at no charge?

Note that _Lumosity_ is a registered trademark, whereas _meditation_ is just a random word, free for use by anyone and everyone.
Evidence, please. I don’t doubt you “feel” better with your practice, but is the evidence there? I am talking about high-quality trials with published results.

I have to wonder the motive for some psychologists and neuroscientists objecting.  I mean,  either way these games can't hurt.  Plenty of folks young  and old pay for various electronic forms of entertainment.  Maybe their claims stretched a bit,  but better to give your brain any kind of activity than none at all.  Maybe some in the industry feared Lumosity really might  help, and then their crony pharma friends might find less people paying for their drugs???

Hi Lisa.  I'm a School Psychologist -  The reason they object is because simply determining what intelligence and cognition are is a task in and of itself.   The issue is not with the games themselves; it is with billing them as a way to affect dementia/forgetfulness or whatever other disorder they claimed it would help.  False, very very false, advertising.    Certainly it's best to use your brain.  The Dana Foundation has published good work on this - you can best hedge against dementia with a couple of activities: If you don't play an instrument, learn how and get proficient (really proficient) in music.  Might get you a postponement of about 6 years.  Or learn a language you don't know.  Neither of these things is typically seen as "entertainment" and that's the key - things that may help will involve real cognitive work - we all know learning a language is not a play project.

"Plenty of folks young and old pay for various electronic forms of entertainment."

But the "science of Lumosity" is not advertised as a mere "game." Rather, Lumosity is a "science." You know, like physics or chemistry or biology.

Learning a new language can be lots of fun particularly if done with other people. As for music, only a music lover would put alll that time and effort to learn to play an instrument and so it too would be enjoyable.

Learning at any age can be fun.
There are many such auto-billing plans, and not just targeted at the elderly.  NYT online subscription anyone?  ;-)
