If one looks at the comments posted in the WSJ's election articles, their readers blame President Obama for everything, and seem very content with both Mr. Trump and Mr. Cruz. What gets lost in most commentaries is that this country is split rather close to 50-50 between Republicans and Democrats, and while those of us left of center keep hoping that a more centrist alternative to the extreme Right candidates will arise, the other half of the country is rather happy with their options.

My take on this election cycle;
Fox secretly wants a democrat to win the White House. They have made a fortune beating up and kicking around President Obama for the past eight years. Think of all those conspiracies they'd miss stirring up like they did with Ebola virus, Jade Helm, etc.

If we want better candidates that resemble America, we should change the primary schedule.  We do not need three conservative small states two of which are mainly white to start off the primaries.  Our country has changed and more people live in the cities and suburbs among a diverse population.  We need a big state or one with a big city and diverse population.Then we would have less donalds and more normals.

You nailed it:  after 7 years of racism, hate, homophobia, sexism, insane conspiracies, unprecedented treason, obstruction and absolutely no respect for the country or the office of the President, FrankenTrump = the Republican party.  That's how vile they've gotten.

The Republican party is in the process of splitting into two different parties. This will happen this election or the next. for sure.
This division is not over which is the most "conservative". That is the standard left/right fallacy of politics.

If you want to understand politics, you have to go beyond this one-dimensional left/right categorization, and understand that there is a second political dimension, which does not have a name, but which might be called the Social (authoritarian) /Individualistic dimension

Trump and Cruz are battling on this second dimension. Trump is the authoritarian; Cruz is the individualist. (aka Libertarian).

What is the intent of the Framers with respect to the phrase "natural born citizen?"

I submit that the intent of the Framers is that the qualifications for citizenship for the purposes of being President of the United States was to be held to a higher standard than the qualifications for mere citizenship.

My reading of the correspondence and discussion that went into the phrase lead me to believe that the phrase is grounded in the English Common Law of Colonial and Revolutionary America - born of two citizens subject to the Crown and in a jurisdiction subject to the Crown.

Cruz is prohibited from being President of the United States by Article 2 for two reasons - born of (a) non citizen parent(s) in a foreign jurisdiction.

My question is purely hypothetical and was posted to try to understand the law. Mt daughter has no interest in politics. Having said that, I am very proud for having served and your comment is unnecessarily personal.

I watch these debates like people watch horrible car accidents, unable to turn away. Let's face it, this is a horror show. The only thing worse than these two candidates are the crowds who cheer, hoot, whistle and shout for them.

What will happen to our country after President Trump or President Cruz is elected?

1. The defunded and denigrated school systems created two universes by producing a "less informed" electorate that fails recognize demagogary.

They have nothing to say about the reality of being the Commander in Chief, only things like, "I'm great! That guy's a loser!" or "His birth certificate would disqualify him!"

Candidates should speak in specific terms with clear examples of what they would do about things that are happening every day from now until the election.

Why does the headline read, in part, "G.O.P. Looks for an Alternate"?  You mean the GOP establishment, which isn't the party.  I'm no fan of the GOP clowns, but your characterization removes the "democracy" part of the democratic process.  They'll nominate a candidate that fits the mood of their membership, not one chosen in a smoke-filled room.
Of *course* he's un-American: with a Cuban father and a mother who, by voting in Canadian elections, effectively renounced her US citizenship.

I don't see why anyone would watch a political debate.  I can get more than enough information from the media reports on what happened at the debate.  Actually watching it?  I'd rather get waterboarded at Abu Ghraib

Oh, yes! Marco, the reasoned voice of the moderate republican conservatives. As my friend best said, here is the Marco agenda......

I don't know how these alternate universes were created but they scare the hell out of me.  These Republican debates are a snippet of a nursery school argument.

Perhaps but he's still an ethically loose, lying, bigoted, misogynistic, narcissism, bombastic buffoon.....and all of the above were truly the kindest things I could come up with.

The author should be working towards mitigating the resentment that he speaks about among fellow Indian-Americans, not fan it with easy cynicism.  We all have started in one place and ended in another place, many times over in our lives; in fact, it's the rule rather than the exception. He's going to be pleasantly surprised.

Instead of trying to limit the availability of guns on the market, the effort should be at keeping them out of the hands of the grossly irresponsible, morally incorrigible, criminally inclined, and mentally disturbed. This requires more stringent licensing of gun owners, and not guns themselves.

Unfortunately, uninformed liberals want to limit the number of guns in public hands. That is like trying to have safer roads and highways by making it harder to buy a car. We need better licensing of the owners.
r

Trying to limit guns and control guns, is tantamount to trying to solve drunk driving, by making it harder for legal car owners to buy cars. If an irresponsible person drives drunk and gets into an accident, people blame the person. No one tries to ban or make it harder to buy alcohol or cars.
But if the same irresponsible person accidentally kills a person, all of a sudden, liberals target the gun, instead of the persons.

The article reminds me of what the late Harry Golden said when Barry Goldwater became the GOP nominee in 1964.  "I always knew that the first Jewish President would be an Episcopalian."
I think I'd rather let my child play and otherwise interact with other kids in a kindergarten than making them sit quietly through days of watching boring adults in meetings.

It is the option (of being able to take your baby to work) that counts. Naturally not everyone has a big corner office like Marisa Mayer that has enough space for big playpen for her kids while she's working, but that's really beside the point. There are days like snow days or kids not feeling well, but you have to keep going at work, the option to be able to bring the kids to work, even just for a few hours of work, goes a long way. Here, we're not talking about kindergarten kids because when kids get to that age, they're WAY too active to be docile in office for hours. Kids that age should be in school already. But we're talking about babies that mostly just eat, sleep, and poop.
"Eat, sleep and poop". this describes the lives of quite a number of adults as well.

"Nearly every week for four years, Vittoria traveled with her mother to Strasbourg, France, or Brussels, where she sat through thousands of debates and votes." So her child was at one point at least four years old.

I brought my firstborn to work during his first year when I came back to work after a two month maternity leave. I pumped breast milk at work, I carried my baby in carrier close to my chest everywhere I go, I also worked in a place where I'm the only woman at work.

One would think it might pose problems, but everything - and I truly mean everything - worked out. My boss and colleagues and I go about our work without any interruptions. (I should say too that I'm blessed with a baby that doesn't fuss or cry much, he's a happy baby.) I might also be blessed for the fact that I could almost always have the ladies bathroom all by myself for pumping breast milk or changing diapers. More importantly, I don't need "accommodation" from others because of the baby. We all have work to do, and I don't need anyone to do anything differently just because of I have a baby, as that would not be fair to them.

Still, I'm thankful for how open-minded and understanding my colleagues and boss were, and now, all these men can see for themselves a different world in which women with children can do the work just as well, and more. That first year allows me time to look for other options of childcare (which we eventually opted for group daycare), the time to bond with my baby, all without sacrificing my career.

It takes open-mindedness, and it might not be for everyone's situation (including job type, baby health and temperament). I am thus doubtful if this can be codified into policy.
You were very lucky.  Just as many businesses aren't in a position to stop production to accommodate Muslim prayers, most businesses aren't in a position to accommodate infants in the workplace.
@Avocats, Yes indeed. That's why I don't think that can be codified into effective policy. As a woman, if you don't ask (your boss), you would never know if it can be done, or not.

"a growing number of businesses allow parents to take infants until they begin to crawl. "  How many businesses would that be?   I imagine it would be less than .005%.  In the non-online world, I have never heard a single person say that they were allowed to take their child to work. In the USA not all workers even have any sort of paid time off.  There are more workplaces that allow dogs to come to work than children.

Not all businesses and not all job types can accommodate this, that's why it'll be impossible to codify this practice into policy or law. Let's say, you work in a warehouse, or if you're a bank teller, it'll be impossible to bring your baby to work without work stoppage.

I've been bringing my babies (over the years 8 babies in total) with me first to dental school and then to work with me until they started solids so I could exclusively breastfeed them. I brought my baby and a babysitter to watch in between feedings. I would tell my bosses my intention and reassure them that the sitter would take the baby outside if it fussed so as not to disturb anyone. Since I have never had paid maternity leave it enabled me to go back to work as soon as I needed to start earning again, while still spending time with my baby.

It is terrific you were able to do that, but am I understanding correctly that you worked as a dentist while doing this? That would make such an arrangement feasible, with the baby and babysitter either in the examining room with you or in a nearby room (receptionist area, waiting area, empty examination room?) throughout the day. In a typical office job, this would not work, as you have coworkers' desks nearby,

I halved all the sugars and skipped the maple syrup. I doubled the fresh ginger and was generous with the dried. I used white whole wheat because I didn't see any good reason not to. I bought my cranberries a while ago and they were a little dehydrated from the fridge. This made my syrup something less than syrupy. And it meant many of the cranberries hung out on top of the cake. They were chewy and crispy as a result. I don't know how I'd get that again, but I wasn't sorry.
Don' forget the anchovies! One can, drained, early on.

To be fair, Sanders has always been a clean campaigner. He'd rather lose than fight dirty, and he's shown time and time again that when he's attacked, he wins.

This is one of those dishes where the whole is definitely greater than the sum of its parts. Delicious. Like Zoe, I would add a little bit more broth the next time, but not much more, a scant cup. Mine had more of a stew-ish consistancy, but that was okay. Added a parsnip and my canned tomatoes were the fire roasted type. Other than that followed recipe exactly. Will make again.
Get it at Trader Joe's, very reasonable (like $6 or $7 I think?)

Read articles carefully. I checked the assertion that a Harvard study CONFIRMED that 40% of firearms are acquired without background checks.
The article cited is only a report on the study, which, as I read the article, has not been completed. The article makes it clear that the "study" was a survey (always suspect for accuracy) of just over 2000 firearms owners. That is a small number in relation to the number of firearms in the US. I am not even sure that this small sample group would rise to any meaningful statistical significance. Even given that the survey only found that the LAST firearm acquired by each of the 2072 who answered the survey no background check was performed. SO if each owner had 2 firearms (probably a low number) the percentage of all firearms owned by this population could be as low as 20% acquired without background checks or as high as 70%. The result is meaningless. Not a very specific study, especially from Harvard. And there is no indication to how many, iWhere any of the 800 firearms acquired used for any criminal activity. Without such correlation the result is again essentially meaningless. There is no indication how the population was chosen leaving questions as to statistical bias. Each state has different requirements for back ground checks so unless the survey population was carefully chosen the study could be seriously flawed.
This makes everything in the article suspect for accuracy.

While yes, Kristof shouldn't have used an unpubloshed study (or been more careful about reporting it), 2000 people is a lot of people for such a study. Most polling's conducted on about half that.

And you should be careful about speculation too, since you've no idea about any of the flaws you claim are there.

Wait and read the study.

I applaud your instinct to check statistical accuracy! That said, there are some errors in your reasoning.
"That is a small number in relation to the number of firearms in the US" ~ size of sample in relation to total population does not matter if sample is unbiased and reasonably large.
"I am not even sure that this small sample group would rise to any meaningful statistical significance" ~ not sure what you mean by statistical significance, but the errorbars on the 40% figure (assuming a Bernoulli variable with n = 2000, p = 40%) are +/- 1%.
"if each owner had 2 firearms (probably a low number) the percentage of all firearms owned by this population could be as low as 20% acquired without background checks or as high as 70%. The result is meaningless" ~ even though 40% of people are getting THEIR FIRST GUN without a background check, 100% might be getting THEIR SECOND GUN with one? Seems implausible; we'd expect gun acquiring methods + background check rates to be similar. Regardless, we can still say that 40% OF THE POPULATION has acquired a gun without a background check...and you really only need one gun to kill people.
"Not a very specific study, especially from Harvard" ~ full methodology has not yet been released.
"The result is again essentially meaningless" ~ criminal activity is not the focus of the study.

Two final points: a) result agrees with previous survey; b) if you do not like surveys and want more research, support gov-funded gun research!

Martin -

You posted: "We don't call the animal a mutton...."

I love Cryptics! The process of solving them is way fun -- gives the stodgy brain a good jolt or eight in new directions, the way a regular crossword just doesn't do. I work regular crosswords every day, and solving them gives me pleasure, but solving a Cryptic is much more satisfying.
I work puzzles out on paper, no timer, no record-keeping. I'm obsessed enough without going THAT route!

Yes, Clinton is unrivaled in the depth and breath of her knowledge. But she is also unrivaled in her willingness to distort the positions of her key opponent: her efforts to tar Sanders on his health care and gun control positions were downright dishonest.

Clinton's unwarranted attacks on Sanders contrast poorly with Sanders' efforts to agree with Clinton whenever appropriate.

Game, set, match to the gentleman from Vermont.

While I agree that Hillary is making a mistake when she gets too negative towards Bernie, I think this tweet from Kristof is more important:

"Hillary Clinton excels when the debate is about wonky policy issues, or governing."

I dislike it when Hillary goes negative, but I pay much more attention to the substance of the policies than the manner in which they are presented, which is why I believe Hillary is the better candidate.

I'd like to see Bernie run the Senate Finance Committee and try to push through his agenda through Congress. But if he's President, he'll be bogged down with foreign policy and national security issues from day one, and his economic plan will end up taking a back seat.

I think a combo of Hillary in the White House and Bernie running Finance is the most efficient allocation of their respective talents.

Bernie may win the charm contest, but I don't think the Democrats ought to be electing the nicer candidate any more than I think that Republicans ought to be nominating the most boorish.

The main reason to vote for Sanders is to discipline the Democratic party into actually supporting liberal policy proposals, instead of ignoring its voters and continuing to support pro-business and moderately conservative policies. I'm not sure how that aim is diminished if Sander's healthcare proposal isn't ready to be adopted on the first day of his presidency. If incrementalism is the right way forward, why isn't Hillary Clinton laying out incremental steps toward single-payer healthcare or some comparable arrangement?

That said, I think a candidate like Sanders is rightly criticizable if, as is charged, his policy really does rely on magic asterisks and is deflects attention from its actual implications. But even if that is all true, he's facing opponents who are more than wiling to do the same thing. It's one thing to say that politicians shouldn't fudge numbers in proposals to voters. It's another thing to say that my favored candidate shouldn't fudge numbers in their proposals, given that all of the other candidates fudge on their major proposals and never seem to suffer significant setbacks in their candidacy for doing so. Perhaps Americans should be persuaded that not all ineffective treatments should be part of the health system. But perhaps it's asking a lot to say that a candidate should be the one persuade them shortly before the first primary.
I support Bernie, but magical asterisks In a plan are bad, always and everywhere.

When Roger extolls diplomacy as delivering, he forgets Syria, where diplomacy merely delivered President Obama from needing to admit that his bluff on a red-line had been called. Very big deals were made of Assad’s surrender of chemical weapons that observers certified were all he had, and the destruction of those weapons.

Then what happened? Assad turned around and gassed his own people again and again with those chemical weapons that he was supposed to have turned over and that had been destroyed with such relieved enthusiasm that “diplomacy works”.

Don’t imagine that the world and particularly our adversaries have the slightest respect for a U.S. red-line. Has that increased or reduced our ability to support global stability?

“A big nation is open for business again, back in the global financial system and world oil market.” Whatever in the world makes that a GOOD thing, when that big nation unambiguously seeks its own caliphate, destabilizes the region in Syria, Yemen and elsewhere, arrays itself against Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey and Israel on RELIGIOUS grounds, of all incendiary pretexts?

Another set of international observers, operating under strict limitations despite Roger’s claim that they’re the best ever negotiated, has certified Iran’s compliance with the deal. Why should people believe that they are any more accurate than they were in Syria?

Sanctions were diplomacy that was working. What we have here looks disturbingly like appeasement.

How do you know how much resettlement costs? Not too much. Much of this work is outsourced to groups like Catholic Charities and furniture, etc. is largely donated. The issue is the relationship of the uplift cost of oil to the price it can be sold for. As jburnich commented, the "easy oil" is declining in availability. Many of the newer wells have an uplift cost well in excess of what the costs were in the 1990s. If the price continues to drop, the more costly wells will be capped. Uplift costs in Saudi Arabia average around $10, so it is to the Saudi's benefit to keep producing as that helps its national budget (but the benefit is far less than before due the price decline).

The high cost of crude in 2008 was caused in part by "paper oil," traders who neither produced nor consumed crude and were purely speculators. Changes in regulation and exchange rules have greatly reduced the level of paper oil traded. That is one, but not the only, reason for the decline in the price of oil. A major factor today, as noted by others here, is a significant and continuing excess of crude production over consumption.

She just became the mayor; she has no responsibility for this.

None. Not sure if you read the article, but 1) the emergency manager makes the decisions 2) another mayor, Dayne Walling, was mayor during the switch over process (but again, not his decision) and 3) the woman mayor, Karen Weaver, was elected fairly recently after the whole thing started to get addressed. I guess you could say she's on the cleanup and mitigation, which is kind of what women get to do all the time anyway, since you mention it.
None.  She was just elected.

The lower level government doesn't share blame because they are predominantly black... ::SHAKE MY HEAD:::

The water supply contract is made at the state level. It has nothing to do with race. Also you (and your fellow Republicans) always cry about EPA regulations being bad for economy. So you kicked them out and now you got your wish. You and your poisoned well.

This is another prime example of deluded poor and uneducated people voting against their interest and pretending to be surprised at the outcome.

Snyder stacked all of the departments with fellow like-minded Republican lackeys, so no surprises that they were dismissive of the complaints and made comments that the complaints were politically motivated.  Those lackeys of his are anti-environmental, and pro corporate stooges. He should resign and take all of his stooges with him.. Sounds like Bush and his "Brownie" from the Katrina disaster.
Money, money, money.....It's the corporations and politicians vs the people.

Thanks Dylan because without you bringing it up I would never have know this stuff about your city living here in Upstate New York. Your generation has a lot of work ahead of it rebuilding the world my generation and others are leaving you after treating in badly. My guess is you are going to do fine at the task.

"It was not until late in 2015, after months of complaints, that state officials finally conceded......

That's not good enough.

This is a present example of ordinary people voting against their interest and being surprised at being poisoned.

You kicked out the EPA, federal regulation, and any outside accountability. Now you want our federal government to help undo the mess?

Hey Michigan you did this to yourself. Your Republican governor got cozy with unethical businessmen and kicked out people who could have at least kept an eye on them. No one cares about your problems. STOP ASKING FOR HANDOUTS.

Dracula, you are being quite unfair. It's Michigan that did it to Flint. Not Flint to Flint or Michigan to Michigan.

Michigan/Snyder did other things to Michigan. And I smell the smell of Kochs in the election of Snyder as in that of Walker, both liars who violated their pre-election pledges the moment they were in office.
Yeah Dracula, I'm waiting on the speech about "personal responsibility" when it comes to making a billion dollar error that poisoned people.
A handout like irreparable brain damage and a life trajectory permanently altered for the worse? These are innocent children and it's a pretty sure bet their parents did not vote for the key players.

It is simply beyond belief the damage that has been done to a generation of children in Flint who will be permanently developmentally disabled because of lead in their bodies. The callous response of politicians and administrators in Michigan to the months and months of actual notice they had of citizens being poisoned by lead contaminated water has brought the nightmare of Kafka's fictional world to reality.

This is the logical result of Koch brothers styled libertarianism where governmental regulations pertaining to the environment and the health and safety of citizens are somehow seen as abridging the "liberty" that the Founding Fathers envisioned for our country. The situation in Flint also results from the ethos created by the Koch's and like minded reactionary billionaires that scientific facts that impinge on a corporation's bottom line are to be impugned at all costs with magical thinking disinformation such as climate change denial.

When the evil screed of the far right robs children of their ability to live healthy lives such as in Flint, the perpetrators should go to jail for a very long time.
Thank You  Reaganomics.  All to save a few dollars in cost.
It's the conservatives stupid!!! That's what's wrong with America today....
It's the reduction of all ideas, controversies, principles and viewpoints into a few stultifying catch phrases, stupid!
Thank God for the Conservatives......otherwise you'd be living in Greece.
at least not a Republican accountant.

Michael Moore is asking people to sign a petition calling for the resignation and prosecution of Gov. Snyder. That may be a nice solution for people seeking retribution, but it doesn't do much to purify the water in Flint, Michigan. There also is a petition asking the City not to terminate water service to people who are delinquent in paying their water bills. That doesn't help anything either. What should occur is a movement to have all the people of Flint stop paying their water bills, and leave the City without any revenue for its water utility. It is absolutely criminal to ask people to pay for the delivery of toxic water they can only use to poison themselves and their children. If citizens shut off all water and stop paying for it, people in Flint will be surprised how fast the problem will get fixed. The money saved can be used to buy and distribute purified water; and many other related solutions are possible. Paying the City for poisoned water constitutes consent to municipal extortion, and condones the criminal conduct of those responsible for contaminating the water.

Ed Spievack

I have to disagree.  If someone is prosecuted and put in jail, other officials in similar circumstances might think twice next time when it comes to cutting corners and skirting the law.  Otherwise you get a crisis like what happened in the last financial meltdown.  Big Corporations paid fines, which they rationalized as a cost of doing business.  Putting some of them in jail might have well curtailed some of their criminal malfeasance.

Criminal prosecution of the governor would be a powerful message to the next politician on the verge of abusing his or her public trust and doing damage to citizens out of political or economic self-interest. Likewise, prosecution of the Wall Street bankers who caused the near-collapse of the world's financial system in 2008 would have done more to prevent the next scam than fines in the millions or even billions levied against investment banks. But it didn't happen. Officials at Volkswagen should go to jail for their faking of emission test results. It's called accountability. And it is long overdue.

Americans are tired of those in power and all Wall Street ruining our lives. Nobody of importance on Wall Street spent a day in prison for ruining our economy and the world's economy. But a black teenager spends years in prison for possession of a joint.
What Michael Moore is doing is necessary to stop the raping of America by the top 1% and their Tea Party sycophants. Only jail time will work. Snyder and his appointed dictator of Flint need to rot ... only then will the Tea Party agenda be stopped.
I remember Dr. K. once writing about a case of mistaken identity.  Someone in a public place asked him, "aren't you Thomas Friedman?"  That person wasn't mistaken, he just had a premonition.

The point is with Sanders you know what your getting. Whether there is single payer or not, the voter will know that he worked to get the most for the health care dollar for the voter. With Clinton, the source of her power is her ability to gain favor the top 1%. By top I refer to those who influential either in high wrung political circles or with the media.

Ms Clinton has a plan that PK thinks is better but does it really matter where the starting point is since the outcome is limited by what can overcome Republican obstruction. Since Obama tried to placate Republicans and we know that does not work, why should a voter support someone who is asking for less, does not have the trust of many even on the left and who IMHO is not as electable, if Trump is the opponent.

I would think that the way to go to single payer in the U.S. would be to increase Medicare/Medicaid coverage incrementally, e.g. by extending Medicare to any unemployed person over 55 or 60, increasing the income eligibility level for Medicaid.  Wait a minute, didn't Obamacare do the latter?

Blze: Extend Medicare to spouse and children as well?

Ultimately universal care has to come down to a pay what-you-can-afford system. What someone can afford depends upon a combination of family income and family wealth. The only way to have accurate data is to tax both income and wealth. Taxing wealth becomes practical and fair only if it is done inversely. Consider a choice of income rates between 8% and 28% paired with a net wealth tax of 2% descending to zero. One formula provides the same choice for rich, middle class and poor. The one-page tax form would also supply accurate data for a needs based Public Care system.

Private insurance would be competitive as Public Care fees increase based on higher personal income and wealth. The more one has at risk the more one is likely to purchase health insurance – and that is the way all insurance should work. Health insurers should set rates on real costs for real services for real people. Health insurers should not be forced to equalize rates for young and old, men and women and those with extraordinary health conditions.

To sweeten the pie for providers, the government would guarantee full and easy payment to providers that accepted a fair share of Public Care patents. To help insurers, all prescription drugs would be free (reducing the cost of insurance).
It's hard to believe that Paul Krugman has joined Hillary's (and the NY Times') republican light camp. What happened to this liberal's conscience?

Let's not forget almost all prominent Democrats distanced themselves from the ACA for years. I agree with the idea that ACA is ok for now, and pursuing other pressing progressive issues is the best way forward at this time.

The cause of the market collapse is the intentional over production of oil by Saudi Arabia aimed at driving American shale producers out of business. The OPEC leader has driven the price of oil down from over a hundred dollars a barrel to around twenty seven-dollars a barrel. As it has done before the Saudi's and OPEC are engaging in economic warfare against the United States, and the world economy. Trillions of dollars have disappeared from the world's stock markets. Retirement and pension plans have been depleted. In pursuit of their objective of maintaining their world oil market share the Saudi's have demonstrated a disregard even for the needs of fellow OPEC members.
No country has attempted to counter their behavior. One way would be to impose an import tax on every barrel of OPEC oil of fifty dollars. That would put a halt to their excess production, and at the same time raise the price of our shale produced oil to a profitable level. That would save many banks loan losses, and enable our oil producers to avoid bankruptcy.
Baloney, Saudi has cut its prices to stick it to Russia and Iran. its working. Not everything is reflected in the glow of the USA.

Yes, but it's keeping the Russian bear in its cage, aiding the American economy through lower fuel costs as Winter bites, and keeping the Chinese economy from tanking. In a perfect world, the Saudis would lose so much money they'd be unable to continue funding ISIS in their proxy war with Iran - and when Iranian production comes back online, that war is going to heat up.

Not just Saudi Arabia.  Here.  For years there have been stories in the financial press that oil storage capacity is maxed out, and that energy producers were unwilling to stop producing even though they were running out of a place to put the stuff.  Our own over-production, along with Saudi Arabia's intention to maintain market share in spite of dropping prices, and Iran (with the world's 5th largest reserves) preparing to come on-line, created this oil price situation.

comments.commentBody:
Isn't it obvious by now that our approach to managing the economy is primitive and ineffective? We remain irrationally reticent about developing innovative means for organizing economic activity and so we remain subject to unpredictable fluctuations.

We clearly need to develop a balance between free enterprise and rational economic management. We still believe that management is necessarily stifling and oppressive. The solution to this is plain. If management of the economy is made entirely transparent and truly democratic then it will be responsive to the full range of considerations. It will be the antithesis of stifling and oppressive. It will in fact bring a substantial measure of economic justice to our system while at the same time ensuring economic activity that is both robust and rational.

This approach can be termed Participatory Economic Management, parallel to Participatory Democracy (a a growing political innovation). It's time to give serious thought to the design of such systems. Technology will certainly play a key role, making it possible for large number of people to participate in the gathering and processing of economic and political data and in deliberation and decision making.

Our current system, as contentious and stumbling as it is, has been remarkably effective in some ways. The next system will inevitably be a dramatic improvement, just as capitalism and socialism were dramatic improvements in their times.

This article overemphasizes cheap gasoline as the main economic benefit from low oil prices. We must keep in mind that oil is not only a source of energy, but is also the primary lubricant and a raw material for such industries as plastics, synthetic rubber tires, petrochemicals, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals and many other industries. Consumers and corporations benefit from lower transportation costs (ships, airplanes, trucks, taxis), lower heating oil bills, and reduced cost pressures in industries using oil as a raw material.

Ever since the first oil shock in 1973, every recession has been preceded by a spike in oil prices prompting inflation and tight money -- none of which conditions exist today. Conversely, no recession has been preceded by record low oil prices, negligible inflation and near-zero interest rates.

Earth to chicken littles: the sky is not falling.
Ah, if we're gonna use cliches, "There's a first time for everything."

Inflation is out of control.  What do you mean it doesn't exist today?  Inflation is worse than its ever been.  Through false market manipulation we now have inflation and deflation at the same time.  Raw materials deflating as money inflates.

I've read that falling oil prices as
1 - lost jobs in the oil industry
2 - increased savings for all of us in lower gas prices
Should the goal then be to raise cost to the middle class so that oil industry profits grow? What has happened to our country?

It seems that from an economist's point of view, we all benefit from Exxon-Mobile's profits. The feudal estate system is normal, and when it is threatened it is interpreted as economically damaging. Their models are based on reality. The reality is an economy based on debt slavery. Their models are not based on ideals or on a positive correlation between labor and value. Their models are based on now... banksters, tax dodgers, and coin clippers. Any change will be perceived as bad.
I don't doubt that Trump's popularity is an effect of this inequity. It is horribly ironic, but the horribly uneducated can do some stupid stuff.
I'm sure you've all guessed it by now. "Sanders!"

W.A.S. writes of "significant increase in their profits - which means more jobs and higher wages."

Or it may simply mean more profits for corporate managers and the investor class with no increase in jobs or wages.

The latter seems just as likely if not more so, based on recent corporate behavior.

Why are you only referencing the drop in oil prices to only "gasoline prices" since lower oil prices should have a positive impact on other areas of the economy such as the cost of the deliver goods and services, production costs, and other operating expenses with "fuel" prices lower?

The real question is whether the lower fuel cost will be past on in other areas of the economy other than gasoline prices.

It is amazing how the stock market has been frantic the past several months, which suggests the lack of confidence. For awhile analysts were contributing this to China's economic slow down, however the Chinese economy is still growing at just under 7% , while the US economic growth is less than half of China.

So rather mentioning the weak US economic policies , which contributes to the confidence of consumer and businesses spending, blame China and falling oil prices as well.....

Funny how the readers commenting in this section seems to have a clearer understanding of why the economy is stuck in neutral than do the economic "experts." To paraphrase Bill Clinton in 1992, "It's the stagnant wages, stupid!"
Oil price low, economy good and worker can benefit. It can only be true if workers are getting paid fairly. Your underlying assumptions is untrue and the result is unexpected as well.

Thirty-six years ago as a student I toured Versailles. I remember looking out the palace windows wondering how those dumb satin-fannied aristocrats could be so out of touch with the people that they neither knew or cared about the misery of the populance. Irony-of-ironies I now live in a time where this history is repeating itself. Why don't we spend? Are you kidding me! For 40 years the working people have had just everything taken away from them: secure jobs with benefits, affordable health care and education, and pensions to  name a few. Forty years of Ayn Rand loving neocon scams have emptied the coffers of federal, state, and county treasuries.  The 99% see what money remains fueling endless wars and of course continuing to stuff the overflowing pockets of the 1%. So, I suggest if you want to get economy rolling you go talk to those folks. Who knows maybe they can onshore a little of their I'll-gotten gains from their many offshore accounts to help the nation out. Yet, I highly doubt it, because they only take care of themselves.

Imagine what this country would look like today if the tax rates that existed under Eisenhower remained in place through the present day. How this country and its people would have benefited. Our infrastructure, including high-speed rail, would be second to none. We'd still have the top education system. We could have had a low cost, single payer healthcare system. And we could be much farther along on the development of renewable energies. Those evil taxes.

I am one American who is at least $200,000 poorer on stock valuation losses. There are a few of us in this camp who aren't in the 1%.
Fuel savings? I drive where I drive, regardless.
Lastly, some Americans may actually pay down debts or save.

JM,
It is unfortunate that your stocks went down. MIne did too. But if you have 200 K in stocks, you may not be 1%, but you are close.

I do not have the inclination to pay more for gas and oil so someone else's stock portfolio remains growing.

Matt

Which makes your *claimed* net worth - what - $2 million?

Here's a tip for next time: If your belief system compels you to brag, make the brag big. And add significant figures. Here, I'll fix it for you:

"I am . . . $798,000 poorer . . . "

See? Much more credible. And far more impressive.

Glad I could help - have a blessed day!

Oil is entering the beginning stages of its death throes.  Supply is plentiful and growing while demand is declining, especially in the US.  No wonder oil price declines are not impacting the economy in a robust way as in the past.  Oil represents the past, the old economy.  I don't even think the new generation of drivers is as enamored with cars as previous generations.  The availability of ride sharing services and the expense of buying a car is causing a paradigm shift in attitudes. for all except baby boomers and older Americans who have still have a mostly strong affinity to car ownership.  In previous decades, when oil prices declined, airlines would regularly pass along the savings through widely discounted airfares.  That is no longer the case as the major airlines pocket the huge savings in their fuel costs.

Rather than a "trickle-down" economy, we are finally face to face with the reality of a Vampire Economy - one that sucks every input, positive or negative, into its black heart with deadly efficiency.

The world wasted $650 Billion last year alone investing in more Oil Addiction and even more on the roots of Oil Addiction - Auto Addiction. This $650 Billion could have funded Green Transit Rail, bicycling and walkable communities which would have permanently reduced the wasteful burning of precious petroleum for Auto Addiction. Auto Addiction consumes 70% of US oil usage and is directly responsible for 35% of US greenhouse emissions. Besides the toxicity of fracking for oil, the earthquakes, the vast amounts of precious water consumed, of course worst of all is the effect on global warming and Climate Change. 2015 was the hottest year on record following upon 2014 as the hottest year on record. Last week we just had unprecedented January Hurricanes in both the Atlantic AND the Pacific!
When are we gonna wakeup that we cannot afford wasting $1 Trillion per year on the endless Wars with the Pentagon the world's biggest polluter, or trillions on Auto Addiction killing 30,000 a year, destroying 10 times the land of Rail, costing Americans 3x the cost of transit in Europe and Japan.
We need to run Green public transit as much as we can or we are not going to survive in a civilized manner

If you live outside of NYC public transit doesn't really work.  US doesn't have the density to make rail feasible now either.  Just ask Elon Musk.  He was against the high-speed rail investments in CA, said they were a waste of money.

Lower oil prices are often view as a harbinger of a slowing economy, where as higher prices indicate a hot economy. As oil is such a basic commodity of the world, low prices can mean low demand. Less ships shipping commodities, less trucks delivering imports and exports, less planes delivering people and goods. I don't think it's just about whether the family is going to visit grandma or not, or if they'll spend the savings on other things. I'd like to think that we're less reliant on oil as a basis of our economy, and the producers are opening the taps to try and ward off other options and stay relevant.

The difference between the effects of the oil price drop "then" and "now" comes from the low stateside production costs "then" (when the price dropped, extra money instead of being Exxon's extra profit margin was spent by the consumer on American-produced goods) and high costs now (when the price dropped, domestic producers are closing shop, so consumers' savings come directly at the expense of [former] oil workers' incomes - and are used to buy Chinese goods, or add to the glut of savings).
"Glut of savings?" You mean necessary and strongly recommended saving for retirement and "capital preservation"?

I think one of the main grips Republicans have against President Obama is his focus on reducing US dependence on oil. At the same time he's for more exploration and removing sanctions on Iran this will have the effect of driving down oil prices. Contrast this to President Bush who was from an oil background and sowed chaos in the Middle East which had the effect of raising oil prices (until the 2008 recession). Sure, there are other factors like a slowing Chimese economy, but on the whole these differences are about economics and the competing interests of consumers vs. producers, etc.
All Obama did was to fight the increase in oil production in the USA in every way he could. The credit goes to all of the hard working and skilled oil production companies in the USA.
We are so brow beaten. We fully accepted price increases when gas prices were rising and  passed on, yet we don't demand a similar rollback when the energy prices fall--from taxis to Con-Ed.

@Paul Easton,
Its also been said that Saudi Arabia is trying to stick to Iran and Russia as oil revenues are 30-50% of Iran's monetary intake and the Russian ruble is also taking a hit. it could be conspiracy theory, but it's interesting that as the deal was nearing to drop the sanctions oil prices plummeted. That said the IMF has said that Saudi Arabia economy could in trouble in the next 5 years or so. One thing I do know is the trouble in China and oil prices isn't doing my portfolio a lot of good.

I realize that the price of crude is not the only factor in the price of gasoline: location of crude and extraction, transportation of crude and finished product, its refining, and delivery to the end customer are some factors. But it still seems to me that there should be more correlation of pump and well prices.
There seems to me to be too much swing between the recent high prices and the present low prices to be accounted for by supply and demand!
Don't forget to add State and Local taxes. I assure you those haven't gone on vacation, and they haven't gone down, very likely just the opposite.

@Scott W

You have explained things pretty well. Higher prices on oil or health care or anything else means higher GDP. So unless higher price constrain other parts of the economy higher is better.

After years of paying through the nose for gas, it has been a shock to my eyes to see gas so cheap.   Notice I said to my eyes, not to my wallet.   Personally, I think the states that put all their eggs into the oil basket should have seen it coming.   The GOP governors and the Texas Wildcat CEO's pushed drill baby drill.  Even where they were not wanted.   Renewable energy jobs are the key, but big oil will not loosen it's desperate hold easily.
As soon as renewable energy can actually replace oil those jobs will be there.  Probably at least 5 years away, most likely 20.

Are you suggesting that we should leave the money on the table when an industry is volatile?

Also, "renewable energy jobs" are mostly a myth. Coal power is labor intensive... it requires continuous mining, transportation of the coal, operation of the power plant, all of which requires a fair amount of manpower. Solar power is not very labor intensive. The panels are manufactured (which involves fairly little human labor, anyway), shipped and installed one time and that provides a location with a decade of power with virtually no human work required. The number of jobs created is a bad metric for the economic sense of things... using labor inefficiently isn't usually beneficial. But, the idea that we should push "green" technologies for the jobs is absurd.

Higher input costs (refining), higher state taxes (depending on your state).

Also, gas wasn't that cheap in 2003. According to the U.S. Energy Information Administration, regular gasoline on the Gulf Coast (you're in Texas) sold for between $1.30 and $1.60 throughout 2003. The last time the average retail price for gas in your region was under $1 was in early 1999, though you may have found some gas for less than $1 in late 2001/early 2002, when the average fell to $1.01.

When the IEA says falling demand they mean a decline in the rate of growth. Oil consumption is still growing, 70% of oil goes into transportation, and the Chinese still want cars.
Is it possible that oil has become a fully competitive market, thanks to American disruption? We are used to the paradigm of an artificial price, controlled by others. We have been taught this kind of energy is finite.
We know there is shale all over the world and thanks to American technology it is now accessible quickly and without great capital. Perhaps our Malthusian view doesn't hold, and we need to reframe the way we think about energy, more like manufacturing than a resource business.

Linder, I think this is absolutely true. Humanity now has a virtually unlimited supply of oil and the proof of concept was demonstrated in the US. Whenever the price of oil rises, fracking and shale oil become more cost-effective and so just the US itself can drive the price of oil down again. This will be true for many countries going forward.

Luckily for addressing climate change, wind power and solar have gotten a tailwind from the former high price of oil. Let's hope we continue to promote them and renewable energy costs continue to drop.

Let's open up Anwar!  Rockefeller's ghost will not leave us alone until the last drop of oil is gone... Is anyone else embarrassed that we are still heating our homes with the same basic technology the romans used?
You think that what we have been taught is not true? You think that there is an infinite quantity of oil in the ground? Really?
Money fuels the economy only when it is spent on goods and services.  Money does not fuel the economy when it is just set aside or used to pay down debt.
When the price of oil drops, the petro industry always blames "refining capacity" and "seasonal formula adjustments" for gasoline price spikes.

comments.commentBody: WNYC was a public radio station.

The mean-spiritedness comes from those who haven't had their basic needs met, and that's not in terms of milk, bread and honey.   We're speaking of a lack of love, caring and happiness in their lives and in their circumstances.  Have you seen people who "get it"?  They hug each other whenever they get off the bus or train, no matter how tough their day had been.  There's a grace in their souls that no disaster, man made or otherwise, can ever take away.

Trump looks and sounds disgusting. He's an angry man that hates everyone. So we change the TV when he appears. Then we change the TV when Hillary Clinton appears. And we change when Sanders or Cruz come on. What is one supposed to do when the likely contenders for the Presidency are all unworthy of the Office?

Oh my. It all makes my head spin to think that one of these people on their way to the top of their respective pile will be our President. I feel extremely uneasy voting for any of them. Is this the best we can do as a nation? I think not. But so much must change if the dignity can return. And just to be clear, I do not favor the Tea Party or the group that has control over politics at the moment. Stating that a great deal must change doesn't mean I'd like to shut down the government or get rid of everyone and all the laws.

But I haven’t had the urge to vote since about 1976. Looking at the news, I am not likely to do so in the near future either. Thank you for your time in reading this.

"Decisions are made by those who show up."
[Martin Sheen in character as Pres. Bartlet on the TV show, "The West Wing."]

Not voting - Is voting...to keep the screwed-up and dysfunctional status quo. Declining to vote is eschewing the chance at change, even if having to hold the nose while filling out the ballot. (Granting and granted, Nixon's resignation soured a lot of folks on politics, many made speedily recoveries after Carter got elected however)
I would never, ever urge anyone to vote. By all means, sit this one out and leave it to those who feel strongly about it. But don't complain about the result!

What I've done in my mind is choose the one most likely to do a good job for the country.  Based on experience, record, and evident ability to work with others who will be a part of government, that person among all those seeking the office is Hillary Clinton.  In fact, that was not a hard decision, though I like Sander's positions.  He, like Cruz, has a hard time working with others.

Here in San Francisco, the house next door to me was lovely, old-fashioned, all wood, built-in bookcases, etc. They ruined it by gutting the entire interior and making it "modern". It sickens me to think what they did to that house. Just to up the price.... Now I have to live next door to the people who bought it. Yuck.

Sorry but your opinion, especially since it's the interior and not the exterior of the house, matters not to the past or current owners. It's none of your business if you neither were selling or intending to buy it. It's just personal taste if there are no regulations applying to that property which says that certain aspects must be maintained. And I say this as someone who loves all types of architecture/ built-ins and lives in the Bay area.

I might have been more creative when naming residents of Buffalo “Buffalonians”.

But when I read cautionaries about excessive activity during blizzards I can’t help considering an exploding global population in the teeth of global climate change that is tied to the industrial activity and waste products of billions of human beings. Consider what staying indoors for days might mean in the inevitable appearance nine months later of an excessive cohort of “Baffalonians”, all of them eventually driving big SAVs (suburban assault vehicles) and eating beef, requiring coal-fired electricity and generally creating so many additional carbon footprints simply by breathing in and out for eighty or ninety years.

In this light, are heart attacks from over-exertion and car-crash fatalities ALL bad?
Crested Beauticians have no quarrel with Buffalonians.
Most of the year, they're Buffalonians, but during a blizzard, they're Buffaloafers.

Some day you might be shoveling  snow  and get a heart attack or die in a car accident. You must be in a  bad place to think another person death  isn't a bad thing. Because of the sin of large  carbon foot print? Find yourself a different religion. You know one with compassion for others.

By the 68% percent majority, the authors must be suggesting that their interviewees are approximately that age.  Best I can tell, the youngest interviewee featured in the article is 63, which is hardly representative of the population at large.  It certainly falls short of a claim that "the significant majority of Republican voters here [are] immune to Mr. Trump's charms...."  If "civility" is truly a meaningful consideration, a broader understanding of what the American population expects of that term is necessary.

It takes wisdom accumulated through the years for intellect to temper youthful idealism.

Acknowledging that some still do not - it is fervently believed that most of the "American population" knows full well exactly what is implied and expected when "civility" is mentioned...even though some habitually eschew it.
Since 32% respond to pollsters that they support Trump, and essentially none say they don't know, then 68% don't support him.  Is that too hard to recognize as a "significant majority"?

Maybe 10 years ago. Today, pollsters are well aware of cell phone usage and how to contact people to get a distribution of responses that reflect the population.

(That being said: most polls are slanted to get the results the pollsters would prefer....it is easy to twist questions...i.e., "have you stopped beating your wife?".)

NOTE: the idea that "old folks" have landlines and not cellphones is really outdated. All my senior relatives (over 80) have and use only cellphones. The AARP sells cellphones. It is not just young people who use them -- not anymore.

This really scares me because it is so delusional. How could he possibly think that even most Democrats would put this plan into effect, let alone Republicans? I don't condemn the idea of a single payer, but making such vast changes in American health care needs full cooperation from all concerned - not only including politicians but physicians, big pharma, and the whole list of people who now benefit from the current system. The reason I'm scared is because he stands a chance of being nominated as the Democratic presidential nominee. This plan will guarantee putting a Republican in office. Can you imagine the party Republicans would have with this?

What people say and what they do are not the same things.

Often polls about election results are quite wrong. What happens inside the secrecy of the voting booth is still secret, and that's a good thing.

Actually, yes. A quota system was suggested.

A boycott of the awards because no Blacks were nominated was also suggested.

Some white people who are older are being targeted as racists because they disagreed with one of both of those suggestions.

So far this century, African American actors have made up a slightly larger percentage of best-actor/actress Oscar nomination than they do of the U.S. population, but it’s not surprising none were nominated this year. For example, African American males make up about 6 percent of the U.S. population, but probably less than 3 percent of actors eligible for best actor nominations. (The Oscars only go to actors in English-language films made anywhere in the world. This excludes most films made in Asia, Africa and Latin America. ) A black male nominated for best actor would take up 20 percent of best actor nominations. It’s unrealistic to expect 20 percent of best actor award nominations go to such a small segment of eligible actors every year. The same is true for actresses, directors and screenwriters.

Hatred and racism as a response to differences is ultimately alienating and separating whether expressed by Roxane Gay or Donald Trump. Most stark in this discourse as with Ta-Nehisi Coates and others is equating inherently "human experience" as exclusive to race and color identity. In my parents "conversations" between 7-10 I was warned about the dangers of the street, the building, its' elevator, the basement, child molesters and strangers, the subway, etcetera. I too was poor: parents slept in living room, shared bedroom with brother, landlord came looking for the rent. Not every injustice and failure to get what you want, to be liked, acknowledged or recognized is due to skin color or poverty. The depth of hatred, the retrograde tone toward "white" skin and privilege is both revelation and reminder. Emotionally steeped in deep hatred whatever apparently moves in your favor yet you still lose. Love, appreciation and acceptance cannot be legislated. What is the need in the cry to be nominated? Will a quota calm your heart, ease your pain? If seeking love and recognition is the game, hatred and anger are ultimately an ill conceived strategy whether you are black, brown, cream, ochre, yellow, alabaster or white, with or without privilege. Aggression and hatred veiled as true expression denigrate the viable human aspirations for inclusion and unity, ironically create more of the separation you decry. Wishing you well on your personal journey to wholeness.

Can we just get it over with and pass a law requiring that all professions, all institutions, and the distribution of prestigious awards must reflect the racial and ethnic makeup of society? Those who bemoan "underrepresentation" are often inconsistent and unprincipled, as they want select races or one gender to be at least proportionally represented, but not all or both. They want what they want for members of the tribes they favor, and that's it.

In my line of work, academia, in the absence of such a law, we routinely bend over backwards to hire female and minority graduate students with little or no teaching or publishing experience over highly accomplished white male PhD's for the few tenure track jobs that even exist any more. If the ads simply said, e.g., "no white males need apply, we already have people who look like you," at least it would be honest. We would no longer be treating people as we would never consent to be treated ourselves - being unemployed, seeing a job we'd love to have, getting our hopes up, putting great time and effort into applying for it, not knowing the whole time that we have no chance of getting it because of the race and/or gender into which we were born.

If Ms. Gay is going to insinuate that social justice demands proportional representation by race and ethnicity across the board, I look forward to her advocacy of such a law. A lot of Jews, for example, will lose their jobs, but I'm sure Ms. Gay will be fine with that.

The NFL.  Sometimes you deflate the ball, sometimes the ball deflates you.  Goodbye Patriots.

Read the facts....Planned parenthood was NOT selling fetus tissue...they declined to sell it to the lying religious zealot trying to create a situation that wasn't there....Sting gone wrong...Religious zealots AND Republicans caught again trying to create a perception not based on fact or reality....

But when was the last time Republicans cared about truth and reality....

There is certainly no law that says you cannot make an allegation and use a doctored (or fabricated) video to back up your claim. Nor should there be. You are responsible for your own critical thinking to determine if their claim is correct. Woe are us if you bae your decision on just one side and do no research (which apparently so many ill informed people have done)....

It IS a crime however, to fake doscuments and present yourself as someone with a governement certification of some sort (like a Dr) to mislead someone basing THEIR decisions on your falsified credentials.
Thank you for calling this out!

Your side got caught cheating. You have no claim to truth when you have to manufacture it under false pretenses.

It is unfortunate that you decide to double down on the dishonesty instead of being humble in learning a lesson.

Since he sent an email to Planned Parenthood offering to buy fetal tissue, he clearly violated this law; the grand jury investigation found no evidence that Planned Parenthood ever attempted to sell fetal tissue in the first place, or in response to Daleiden's offer, and in fact cleared Planned Parenthood of any allegation that they did so..

I don't know that I've ever eaten tis dish under the listed name, but I easily familiar with it. Outstanding stuff and thank you Mr. Sifton. If my edition is slightly different, the only significant difference is my preference for fresh, homemade, rolled and torn noodles. What I end up using is essentially very eggy papadelli (sp?), consisting of only semolina, egg (+egg yolk) and a little salt. I get enough egg and extra yolk in there to eliminate any need for water. Overkill? Of course it is. (My Egg Lady is but eight miles away and has an apparently endless supply. In exchange for the odd favor or two, including a little sitting and visiting, I have as many 'free range' eggs as I can use. What can I say? It works for us!
The beef roast method itself is fine, although I use a lot more garlic. The stringy appearance does not trouble my table at all. With a green veggie or a hefty salad, Mr. Sifton's formula becomes the ideal mid-winter supper and one that I can make without commercial power, if necessary. Picture it: the ideal, tasty beef roast, made and consumed with only candlelight and a little wine (or plane cider for us), while watching the snow fall.

comments.commentBody: Martin, I had lunch today with Charles. It was our last lunch before he retires officially. Before lunch, however, I went to our common barber, Sam, located in the Civic Opera Building. Sam was actually introduced to me by my friend George back when I worked across the street. It was purely coincidental that Charles and I wound up with the same barber. Sam works with two or three other barbers, depending on their business. Apparently they just hired a new barber. Some young man in a suit came in and asked about getting a haircut. Sam greeted him and immediately sat him in the empty chair next to mine. A few minutes later the new barber returned with some coffee and immediately went over to the stranger. They started a conversation and I couldn't help overhearing some of it. The customer introduced himself. His name was DYLAN. He spelled it out.
Very cool.  What year was that?  (Sound of creaking door.)

.
This guy was always welcome in the valley, as a guest.

Echoes of Ross Perot! I remember when Perot briefly halted his third-party bid for the presidency in 1992, because he was unhappy with some potential media coverage of family issues. The menacing stories either did or didn't happen -- and then Perot tried to get back in the race. But the Perot bubble had popped, and he never got it reflated.

Being the President is a nonstop job. There's no end of irritants and indignities that may come the way of our Commander in Chief. The best presidents rise above it. Even the not-so-good ones press on, somehow. Business people may talk a tough game, but when the ups and downs of a campaign turn them into no-shows, their ability to win over voters disintegrates.

The doc wasn't biased at all? Then when mentioning the cat incident why didn't they mention that he had first poured gas on the cat and thrown it in the fire instead of letting it slide that he was tossing the cat and it just happened to catch fire? The interrogation of Dassey was an atrocity? You realize that they showed like 3 minutes out of a 4 hour interview right? You do also realize that he went into a ton of detail about what happened including detail that matched the physical evidence? So asking him questions and saying they didn't feel he was being honest is an atrocity? How exactly would you expect an interrogation to go then?

Then 'unbiased' doc also cut out part of the phone conversation that Dassey had with his mom where he tells her that he was afraid of Avery and that Avery had sexual abused him and another family member before. They showed part of this conversation on the doc, so what other reason would they have to not include that portion of the conversation other than to not make Avery look worse?

Or how about the blood vial with the hole in it? The doc left out the part of the trial where it's explained that these vials are supposed to have holes in them because they poke the needle into the hole to get the blood into them. What reason would there be to leave that part out other than to leave the thought in the head of the viewer that the vial had been tampered with? There's plenty more besides that even.

Actually his initial confession lined up with a lot of the physical evidence.  They didn't use his confession at the trial because in order to use it the defense would have the right to cross examine him, and since he refused to make a deal to testify against Avery and was not saying that he lied during the confession the prosecution couldn't exactly call him to testify.  That's not to mention that Dassey had his own trial coming up after this one.  Amazing that yet another person who watched the documentary doesn't have their facts straight... And you're complaining that someone is getting all of their information for Nancy Grace and didn't watch the documentary?  That's pretty ironic considering most of the Avery supporters know nothing about this case other than what they saw on the documentary.  Maybe the original poster has just actually taken the time to read more into the case? Re: Krugman working for Reagan

Can't comment on Ronnie's SOP, but friend of mine was interviewed for a purely technocrat job by Bush.
Hint it was deep in CS (computer science )

First question was: how do you feel about abortion?

From which I learned, that at leadt under Bush you didn't get even the most technical jobs without passing the ideological purity test.

Can't imagine St. Ronnie was more lenient.

As to my friend , he failed.

Within a year of the U.S. entering WW2, Roosevelt established a new US Army division (roughly 10,000 - 15,000 men) composed entirely of people with knowledge and experience at building and developing infrastructure. People like engineers, architects, carpenters, plumbers, electricians, road builders, etc. They spent almost four years preparing for the day they'd go to Germany, and other nations, to rebuild what was destroyed by war.
At no time, did anyone have to answer questions about their loyalty to a political party, to Roosevelt personally, or on subjects having nothing to do with their jobs (like abortion).

Fast forward to 2003. We conquered Iraq, and now had to rebuild it. But according to a multitude of books looking into it, turns out the people put in charge of putting together the rebuilding staffers all came from places like the Federalist Society, the Cato Institute and other rightwing thinktanks. And the first questions they asked anyone seeking to help rebuild Iraq had nothing to do with skills or training. No, they asked questions about whether or not you felt personal loyalty to President Bush; did you believe that only a totally unregulated free-market economy could work; your views on abortion, etc.

Turned out, the people chosen to rebuild Iraq almost never had the basic skills necessary to do the job, but were instead political apparatchiks chosen for their GOP loyalty and their ideological purity. No wonder Iraq collapsed as it did...
And your point is what? That Paul Krugman has been a Secret Agent for the GOP's Right Wing for the past 30 years?

My understanding is that Shrub's administration was by far worse than prior ones (even Ronnie's) in terms of doctrinal purity.  (After all, even though Ronnie went the anti-abortion result because that became the Repub party's mantra), he did sign the most liberal abortion law in the country whilst governor of California.)

I am a woman near Hillary's age and I'm a staunch supporter and admirer since she first came on the national political scene in the early '90s, and especially since she ran for Senator from New York in 2000. I am thrilled that she is running for President, not only because of the prospect of having a woman in the Oval Office -- although that is a big part of it for me -- but mostly because she is the most qualified of any of the candidates running on either Party ticket. As for Bernie, in my view he is a delusional wingnut who is not close enough to Hillary in experience, savvy, strength, knowledge -- especially in the areas of foreign policy, healthcare and reforming the financial industry -- to breathe the same air.

Every woman who has lived long and experienced what women have over the past half century know that it takes women longer than men to climb the ladder. Hillary has made that climb brilliantly. In our deeply troubled times -- in which President Obama has done a remarkable job in leading us out of the catastrophic situation caused by the Bush Administration -- Hillary is the only one with the head on her shoulders to lead the nation so that we can solve our domestic problems while continuing to stand tall on the global stage. And she's the only one who will allow me to sleep at night, without one eye open.
Foreign policy - Iraq war.  Healthcare - ACA vs single payer.  Financial industry - has taken huge dollars from Wall street.  Who do you think she is going to regulate?

@Jeanne,
You (seem to) express contempt for Sanders, while Hilary expressed respect for him during the Town Hall in Iowa. Of course you've a right to express your opinion. Unless the nomination and the election have both been rigged, there's always a chance that Sanders will win. If Sanders gets the nomination and wins the White House, will you be an insomniac for the next four years?

1-30-16@1:26 am et

Fiddlehead ferns make a delicious salad. You have to blanch them to get rid of some nasty bitter alkaloids. You are right about the Democrats' shooting themselves in the foot.  But Trump offers even less than Reagan, and his wall that he wants built is ludicrous in concept.  Trump's just in it for the "deal".

@Arnold Ripkin: Republicans (Trump is a Republican) can enact legislation to jail CEOs who hire illegal immigrants.  Of course they will not do that.  It will never happen of course.  Hypocrisy is the bedrock of the modern GOP.

I was thinking the same thing about the Democrats, as they've been paying nothing but lip service to labor for the last forty years. And if Democrats are such big fans of labor, why is the president -- their leader -- pushing for the Trans Pacific Partnership so hard?

It's NAFTA on steroids.

I am glad many Democrats recognize that Hillary is on the take from the big corporations.

If you read articles and do your own thinking, you will see that by raising the minimum wage while keeping all salaries and per hour pay at the same rate, this decreases the spending power of everybody.

Raising the minimum wage will not fix anything. this just makes the cost of business go up, and prices go up. This kind of Policy change is pure inflation. This idea that raising the minimum wage will help, is a deception. That will cause fewer jobs and make it even harder for young people to find a entry level job.

It may be time to re-evaluate Trump. It seems that lots of people like what he is saying and find him charismatic. I would never have foreseen it. But politics can reveal things that come as a surprise. I find it a little scary but the people get to decide and it looks like more and more of them like the casino mogul from Fifth Avenue.

Maybe it's time to go non politician. Politicians are slick & rehersed & say all the right things. Trump never says all the right things. He would have a hard time lying because he is off the cuff. I think a Vice President with a business background also.
David -- perhaps the cause is the lack of education and intellectual reasoning (cause, effect) among rank and file union members.  Or, to put it as Trump may "you are poor because you are stupid"

It pretty much says it all: union leadership is more concerned with getting invited to Washington cocktail parties, than doing right by the members. If Labor rank and file go for Sanders, they are signing the death warrant for the labor movement. And maybe they can't say that because they don't deliver.

There are some notable exceptions, like the Ironworkers, who succeed in being hired by steel erection contractors, despite their high rate for collective bargaining determined remuneration and benefits, because they deliver superior quality work, coming in under deadline, and lower injuries that significantly lower the cost of the projects they work on.

If Labor leaders can't get across to their rank and file that Trump will do his best to make them follow the path of the dinosaurs, they are incompetent and deserve to be fired.
