The internet is becoming more & more crucial to our way of life just like electricity & water. Companies like Comcast & AT&T are holding back development of higher speed internet and making existing internet services costlier every year.

It is true that companies are ripping us off. But this is a huge profit center -- not unlike cable TV.

Once any company knows you "want it bad", they know they can jack up prices to the moon. (See: health care.) They have a captive audience!

" Companies like Comcast & AT&T are holding back development of higher speed internet and making existing internet services costlier every year."

Just last week the Times and Wall Street Journal ran a story on the massive investment AT&T is making Internet speed faster and the service itself more available. Nothing was said of Comcast but I would assume they are in the same race with AT&T and GOOGLE.

John, perhaps you are a tad out of touch. I am glad that you got through college in the 90's by being in the library and labs late into the night.  Sorry, but middle school and high school kids should be at home, not wandering the streets looking for internet late into the night. I agree that students should be aware of ways to research on the internet, but for teachers to fail to provide alternatives to students without these resources is just plain lazy on the part of those teachers.

Seymour Cray of Cray Computer more or less invented high speed computing in this country. Mr. Cray had access to personal computers, but did almost all of his programming and design in longhand on a legal tablet.

This idea that elementary students need access to digital instruments all the time to do the work of learning fundamentals is absolute nonsense. The transmission of basic knowledge into long term memory is not a function of speed, it is more associated with contemplation and thinking of how the elements come together.

They don't. Children can clearly learn and thrive without computers, because EVERYONE IN THE WORLD did so until about 20 years ago. Even just 10 years ago, it was rare for a CHILD to have a cellphone -- let alone a smart phone, as they were not even invented until around 2007.

Many of had internet via "dial up service" until just a decade or so ago, and it ran at glacial speeds -- impossible to download movies or anything but simple text -- just reading at that speed was slow.

I don't see anything here but lazy spoiled teachers, who are using "technology" as an excuse to not xerox homework assignments for POOR KIDS. How clueless can they be? how insensitive to economic reality? WHY HAVE NO PARENTS SPOKEN UP?

@Concerned Citizen,
You asked why no parents have spoken? Ms. Maria Ruiz, the mother of Tony and Isabella Ruiz, expressed her concern about the situation in the fifth paragraph of this article.

2-23-16@12:56 pm

I can't quite figure out how public school teachers would assign homework which requires internet access. How about more traditional homework assignments, and the teachers and students use the internet while in class together, if it is indeed that essential to education. Some people are losing sight that most of the  amazing stuff that has graced our lives, including computers and the internet, have come to be without the use of a computer.

Or that countless millions of us graduated high school -- graduated college -- even grad school and medical school -- WITHOUT COMPUTERS -- and we have managed to run the world just fine.

I love my computer, clearly am typing here on one and sacrifice to pay for internet service. We gave up OTHER THINGS to get internet, including having cable TV with 200 stations. How many of those "poor folks" in this article would agree to do that? How about giving up cigarettes? Beer? Pot? Lotto tickets?

There is certainly quite a lot which can be done without a computer but it's easy to forget how most technical fields now rely on computers and Internet access if you don't work in those fields or are a decade or more out of school. The public school teachers I know are quite sensitive to this issue and try to avoid making it a regular dependency but by the same token the students are missing out if the assumption is that progress ended somewhere around the 1970s.

It's incredibly cool that high school biology student can see the data and often even use the same analysis tools as the scientists who published a paper which was covered in class, and interacting with the data will give a depth of understanding which is otherwise hard to accomplish. All of the major scientific funding agencies, major universities, etc. have placed huge amounts of information and interactive tools online, which is incredible for those of us who remember being limited to low-quality excerpts in a textbook and having questions which couldn't be answered unless you knew someone with access to a university library.

I think the right approach is to accelerate roughly what's happening: let teachers be sensitive to this issue and ensure that students have options but also as a country recognize the importance of making access to the defining technology of our century available to everyone.

I, too, taught at a large university. These institutions have more resources to provide students living on or off campus with a variety of ways to connect through 24/7 access to computer labs or laptops available for free. We might learn from this model, especially how to provide spaces for students without access to the internet or computers. Public libraries are one place, but I think it's a limited remedy for all sorts of reasons.

Teachers should give students an option of receiving the homework via paper or online. The web access should not be a default mode of delivery unless everyone has access to the internet.

"We cannot hold back .." is nonsense. Not every homework has to be delivered on line. Technology skills are important, but anyone who ever done any research or reading on-line knows that internet has limitations, not to mention that it gives the illusion that "everything' is online, which is also not true.

Wireless (W-Fi) or wired internet access should be available in all schools and public places like libraries for the benefit of all students – regardless of their economic class. It should be free as the common utilities - water, electricity etc. Some of the students enabled by access will go on to achieve great success for themselves and the country. No reason to hold them back.

But it IS -- it would be an exceedingly rare school or library that did not have wi fi internet access.

My own library system had this 20 years ago. It is not new, nor rocket science.

The issue is AT HOME. And it seems nearly every kid today has his or her own smartphone, and they are VERY expensive with monthly charges of $40 or more EACH -- yet they are screaming they can't get homework assignments? Call the teacher, demand the assignments to be xeroxed and handed out, and all students allowed to hand in paper assignments. PROBLEM SOLVED and for zero money.

The US is pretty skimpy when it comes to free Internet access. In some cities around the world, free wi-fi hotspots or even city-wide access is available. For example, see Taipei, Taiwan where subway stations, city buildings, etc. automatically have wi-fi and Canberra, Australia, with city-wide wi-fi.

http://www.tpe-free.taipei.gov.tw/tpe/index_en.aspx

http://digitalcanberra.com.au/projects/canberra-public-wi-fi-strategy-2/...

"It should be free as the common utilities - water, electricity "

Electricity is most certainly NOT free as is city water unless one steals it from a nearby building.
I am typing this onto a video display, of course.  Next to me lie several books and magazines waiting to be read.
Do they wait longer today than they once did?
i followed the recipe exactly and my ribs never browned or caramelized like it looks in the photo. there was also a lot of liquid left behind.

A classic baked up by a master chef. Love the stacked answers and the great cluing. CHEESE was actually the last of the theme words I got, but I did indeed smile when I got it.

Brava!
Cooked Feb 20 2016. Excellent but the sauce was too thin. Reducved the sauce for about 5 mins. and it was fine

Progressives might have to look to the future for inspiration.  If this becomes a brokered convention for Hillary, progressives will abandon the party in November and republicans will win.  It has to be that way, so next time they won't do it again.  The Democratic establishment will no longer take its core for granted after that.

I do not understand.
Politico says the delegate count today is

Clinton 52 Sanders 51

The NY Times page A1 says the delegate count is

Clinton 502 Sanders 70

You may notice there is a difference. Any idea why?

Duane Campbell
Great idea.
Ms Wright Edelman criticized the Clinton welfare reform policies and her husband Mr Edelman resigned his position on the Clinton administration in protest.
Thank you for saying it.

If a judge had Clinton's level of financial attachment to Wall Street - between her and her husband receiving $100 million from firms over the years in financial contributions, the judge would have to recuse her or himself from any proceeding because of compromised impartiality. From her track record, receiving $600,000 from Goldman Sachs for 3 speeches after being Secretary of State, we must conclude she would be getting many millions after being president. Can she be the peoples' advocate? Is there no conflict of interest?

If the popular vote goes to Bernie (as it is now 151,000 - 95,000) but the nomination goes to Hillary via super-delegates, make no mistake: the uprising in the streets will make all the marches of Occupy Wall Street look like a picnic. People are sick and tired of being disenfranchised. People are voting for Bernie because he is our only hope of restoring any semblance of democracy in this country right now. How will he do it? We are all paying attention to the local elections as well... the House is up for re-election and it's Berning.

I am not a Super Delegate but I have elected 21 of them .  They are the Chair & Vice Chair Of the California Democratic Party & our 19 DNC members. Any registered California Democrat can run to be a DNC member. We are now in the midst of the election for the next group of DNC Members(Super Delegates for 2020). We will elect them in June- 20 this time(10 men,10 women) then we will have state party officer elections in the Spring of 2017. Other states have similar processes & procedures.

To better court the black vote Sanders must say the CIVIL RIGHTS REVOLUTION IS AN ONGOING REVOLUTION: it started with equality for blacks, which paved the way for women's rights; this generation's challenge is to apply that ongoing struggle & legacy in the economic sphere. Civil rights movement asserted the Babiyar message "if I am not for others, who will be for me? If not now, when?" Civil rights struggle was always about redressing exclusions/ marginalizations, non-fulfillment of the Declaration & Constitution vision. In the wake of civil rights legislation gender discrimination was challenged. The civil rights legacy is honored & continued by economic fairness revolution, the natural extension & renewal of the original cause.

comments.commentBody:
If you follow the link, you'll see that the bonuses were given at Northern Manhattan Perinatal Partnership (NMPP).
I agree with you about heads rolling - should but won't.
And why not?

You will grant though that as of now, nothing prevented Apple for manufacturing or selling this device just as the store that sold the semi-automatic weapons to these nut-jobs did so legally. If that is so, how is it that Apple is supposed to solve the FBI's problem?  I don't really object to them opening a device of a dead person or even of a live person provided that person has been given notice and a meaningful opportunity to argue that the phone should not be opened up. I do, however, see many reasons why law abiding individuals have good reasons to prevent both open and surreptitious inspection of their information.

The Bureau seems to want Apple to disable the ten-tries-and-you're-erased feature of its operating system. That would enable them to "brute force" a password - to keep guessing the password until they guess right. That requires a very simple piece of code that endlessly repeats; the only variable is how fast your computer cycles. NSA's hot rods could do it in a second or two - China, Russia, Japan, Israel, most of the EU and a few other countries could do the same. Big corporations could do it a bit slower, as could Al Quaeda or ISIS. The bratty nerd next door could, though he might have to tie up his laptop for a few days. With WiFi and 4G, it could be done remotely, though that would take a little higher-level coding skills. As far as the disable code itself, I'm surprised it isn't already floating around the Darkweb - you just need familiarity with the programming language and access to a sophisticated enough decompiler to know where to insert the code.

What the government is asking for, then, is not a front or back door, or a way to hack into the operating system. They would simply open up the whole shebang and hang up an "Enter Here" sign on every device with Apple software. And don't think those few lines of disable code will remain secret for long. The days when software was written by one or two unwashed misfits are long gone - it's done by committee with multiple layers of approvals, and it will leak.

Reason No. 1001 why we don't trust government.

From Techdirt: "Pew Asks Stupid Misleading Question About FBI Apple Fight, Gets Stupid Misleading Answers"

The PEW survey questions - Apple:
(1) Should unlock the iPhone (2) Should not unlock the iPhone (3) Don’t Know.

Apple CANNOT unlock the suspect iPhone and so the FBI now has a court order to force Apple to engineer a new iPhone operating system, one that does not currently exist, and incidentally compromises the safety and security of ALL iPhones, so that the FBI can then hack into the one suspect iPhone. That's different than "Apple should unlock the iPhone."

Apple is simply doing what all corporations do, protecting their "brand", which is based on its technology and the security it built into its phone. This is about money. Cook and the rest of the Silicon Valley geeks actually believe that their products are advancing civilization and therefore ipso facto anything that messes with their business model can be labeled unethical. So great Cook, you've told every terrorist in the world you're gonna do what it takes to make sure nobody can crack open an I-Phone 6. Should be good for sales. Yep it's about $$$ Cook, we know it, even us unwashed masses that toil in other less enlightened workplaces.
A hammer is a tool for criminals. Maybe every hammer manufacturer should be charged under RICO anytime a hammer is used in a crime?

I just crack up when I hear these corporate executives talk about higher purpose and moral obligations. "Do no evil" (from Google). "If all you are interested in is ROI, you need to find another company to invest in". Hogwash. They spout higher purposes as a hook to get better ROI.

If Apple wanted to be a good corporate citizen not maniacally devoted to ROI, it wouldn't be paying slave wages to Chinese laborers while charging a small fortune in the US for phones they say are innovative by...having increased the screen size.

Apple may have jumped the shark here. It isn't bigger than the US government. It may have legitimate, ROI tinctured reasons for refusing to unlock the phone. But moral reasons? Give me a break.

Steve Jobs was the most cynical manipulator of craven human attributes the world has ever seen. Tim Cook is following along lockstep.

The truly higher moral ground would be to help the FBI unlock this particular phone and not try to stand on principles that Apple doesn't have and never had. Instead, it is, as usual, touting moral principles for one purpose and one purpose only--maximizing ROI. Milton Friedman would be proud.

What happens if  the phone contains evidence that there are other terrorist planning terrorist attack? Then what? Sorry relatives of those killed? Maybe if one of those killed is a relative of Cook, would he change his mind? Or its not my relative so who cares????

rlk: The difference between a bank president giving safe deposit keys to the police with a valid warrant and this case is: Apple does not have the keys. There are no keys. The court is basically requiring a company to start trying to make keys that might work. Big difference, right? Is there even a precedent for this?
Thanks for the concise information. Now I understand it. Maybe you should write for the Times.

Frederick Northrop - "Apple initially assisted the F.B.I., but is now fighting a government order directing it to create a new piece of software to open the phone," - certainly sounds like a warrant, an order from a judge. Perhaps we have to find out if the judge is a Republican or a Democrat first?
Remember the right wing saying, "guns don't kill people, people do, so stop obsessing about guns." How about, "phones don't kill, people do, so stop obsessing about phones."

Speaking as a Canadian, from a country whose constitution, unlike that of the United States, is not sunk in words written over two centuries ago, but is a live interpretation involving common law, I must say that I have gratitude that I do not live in a country where people write and get recommended for writing "our proven to be not-so-responsible government".  What's so scary about a succession of judicially obtained warrants to open other phones?

Dr. Bob: It's about time someone pointed that out.
I'm not a i-anything user because I want to be able to get my entertainment files from any vendor not to be forced to buy from Apple. I want to see what is available from iTunes before I sign up and give any personal information. Exactly how does this protect MY privacy?
If you had to pay ISIS a fortune to ensure that your daughter lived, you probably would do so, most of us would. That doesn't mean it's the right thing to do.

I am still of the opinion that Apple needs to do whatever it takes to assist in opening the terrorists phone. That said, I think we need more honesty form both sides: the FBI now wants MORE phones hacked, and Apple says it can't help any more.
This stalemate is no different from the one we currently have in congress, both the democrats and the republicans are likely equally to blame for where we are today. We need the children posing as adults to stop immediately. You are not there to play your games, you are there to take care of the nation on behalf of all the citizens.
In the same vein, Apple and the FBI are both now responsible for the security of the nations citizens--Apple with its now terrorist-friendly phone, and the FBI (among others) which has intruded into all of our lives without hesitation.
I hope that all parties involved in all the issues will find some middle ground so that the people of America--the "Americans" that everyone glibly talks to--can once again have a nation that is both secure and of which we can all be proud.

this from somewhere else in the media:
" Apple makes that they do not want to open a back door to all iPhones is also technically incorrect according to a very well-known IOS hacker Will Strafach.
Mr. Strafach points out that the main issue is Apple not wanting to set precedents for future unlocking requests. Strafach states: "This is not describing a technical issue, but is instead directly related to the later-mentioned issue of setting a precedent. On a technical level, Apple could carry out the order by creating a RAM disk signed by the company’s production certificate for the specific ECID of the suspect’s iPhone. This solution would allow Apple to use existing technologies in the firmware file format to grant access to the phone ensuring that there is no possible way the same solution would work on another device."
I don't know enough to say whether this is correct but at least one hacker thinks it a possible way for Apple to assist.

Do you have any evidence that illegal aliens use more tax dollars than say, Wal-mart employees?  All the government services you mention (except food and housing, which frankly I don't believe are given except perhaps as free school lunches and access to low income housing projects ) are also open to every low income resident.  My impression is that illegal aliens actually use far fewer government services per capita than citizens; however, it may be  a larger fraction of their total income because they tend to be low income.

there are already laws on the books about technology transfer. China has a new fighter jet, the North Koreans have bombs, Jeff Bezos has rockets, and Richard Branson has his spaceplane.
somehow I have the feeling that we are just kidding ourselves about "secure" phones, but it sounds good for business. There a lots of very smart people around the world who are likely as good as anything Apple has.

Actually, Alan, it boils down to whether U.S. citizens have a right to securely communicate and engage in commerce. When the government forces Apple to break encryption protocols and create backdoors, we all become less secure from attacks. Maybe the FBI will only use this on criminals' phones, but Chinese and Russian hackers will have no such qualms.

And why doesn't the FBI with a watcher just give the phone to Apple, let Apple get the info off of it without providing the FBI with special sw or tools, and everyone is happy?
If you have a warrant to search my house because a roommate unknown to me had drugs, I don't tmk have to give you a copy of my key. I let you in and you do your business, but you then have no unfettered access to my house in the future.

I'm with Apple here. You can't crack "just this one" iPhone. Once the software exists, every iPhone is at risk. The DOJ admitted that there are another 14 iPhones they want to crack, and there are countless other local authorities who want to do the same. At this point I don't care if Apple is acting out of concern for our rights or a sheer commercial reason. Either way, they are on the right side.

If the FBI wants to try to crack the encryption, more power to them. But they can't commandeer the help of a private company to do so. Once Apple has opened the back door, the Chinese, Russians, and every other nefarious government will want access to it.

I'm a contrarian here at the NY Times, but I support Tim Cook here. Apple should not be compelled to compromise my security just to try to get some data of likely dubious data from Syed the terrorist's work iPhone. Once there is a back door, people with bad intentions will want access to it.

comments.commentBody: Charlie B for President 2016 !

This is not an antitrust issue. Apple has maybe 6 or 7% of the computer market and its android competition (Samsung, Google, LG, etc.) is healthy and produce very good phones. Same could be said for tablets and even smart watches. If the JD tries to attack Apple with that they will lose.

Back around 1988, I was working in a professional position in Newark NJ. I had planned a three week self directed tour of Egypt, Jordan, Jerusalem, and back home. Some of my associates were dismayed that I would plan such a trip. "Don't you think that will be dangerous?" they asked.

My response was "Three weeks in the Middle East is no more dangerous than than Three weeks in Newark."

That is probably no longer true. But it was then.

Just don't plan tours of North Korea or Iran. Going there voluntarily is just nuts.

and all the interesting personal story aside -(is it better to b e crazy than to have a bankruptcy or a drunken brawl?) the real scandal has been how US economists have been reporting about Europe.

As now Bernie (still) has such a hard time to suggesting just the basics of a decent democracy BE-cause there is all this crazy and misleading nonsense out there.
Like the example I presented - which makes it possible that crazy American conservatives can insist that 'the country never will elect a 'socialist'.
And then there are 'our' economists on the so called Left who drummed all this simplistic GDP valuating nonsense into American minds - like Europes Social democracies don't grow that fast - implying that have the lesser succesful 'models' - and completely forgetting to thell the American people that if the workers in these social democracies would work the amount of hours as the exhausted and poorly payed workers in the US - the simplistic growth statisitcs would be turned on their heads.

Every time we give up more freedom and rights for security we end up with fewer freedom and rights and no more security, but at least we do get a far more expensive government with far more power over us.

Interesting so many people are defending Apple on their claim they are defending a phone users "privacy."

However, from this same group of "privacy" ideologues there is not a peep of outrage when it comes to Apple, Google or any other high tech company tracking one's phone or internet usage, collecting personal data and marketing such data in a less than ethical and transparent manner.

Simply put, Apple views "privacy" simply as a crass marketing tool to sell its phones to the unthinking consumer, the misguided privacy ideologue and the anti-government libertarian type who cannot see that Apple is not only viewing the consumer as rubes, but the rest of us as pawns in a despicable game of chicken with our government who are only trying to do their job - to keep the general public safe from harm.

I just want to point out how completely wrong you are about Apple being in the data brokerage business.

Google and many other companies track obscene amounts of data about people and I can agree with your disapproval of the opaque nature in which they do that. Apple is not one of those companies. Their bread and butter is hardware not data.

I won't argue your other points at this time, but I just wanted to correct that falsehood.

This is the danger of lumping all companies in the same basket. Google and Apple might both be well known Silicon Valley companies in the phone business but they are radically different, especially in their approach to privacy. Google lives of your data. Apple lives of selling hardware. They have VERY different incentives with respect to your privacy.

I work on mobile security and it is a very big difference Apple and Android phones. As a software developer it can actually be quite frustrating to program iOS devices because so much common user data is completely inaccessible to a developer. E.g. there is no way for me as a software developer to create a program that reads of the email address a user has stored on his/her phone. Seems like a rather trivial bit of data right? But even that is locked down.
Proof?

This case has nothing to do with the 4th Amendment, as the government sought and obtained a court of order as well as the consent of the owner (it is a company phone).

Look: The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.

I find it troubling that your second recommendation is an ad blocker, especially when digital journalism relies on mobile ad revenue to survive. I understand that ads drain battery. But they also allow users to access nearly all content on the Internet for free.  If ad blocker adoption continues at this rate, digital publishers will be forced to institute paywalls - per month or per article payments to enjoy content you currently access for free. I for one choose slightly lower mobile web load times and battery drains over this inevitable alternative.
Which big online newspaper sites don't already have paywalls?

Sorry, Brad, but when most content that I pay to download ends up being ads, and those ads are so intrusive that they prevent me from reading the content itself, consumers are forced into using an ad blocker. A more judicious placement of ads, and elimination of obnoxious autoplay  video ads, would obviate the need for blockers.

If the Black community looks into Clinton’s record on racial justice they will find it to be problematic. Sanders came out with a detailed plan in July, while Clinton released hers recently. And it goes without say that Sanders’ economic plan would greatly benefit the Black community as it is superior to that of Clinton’s.

Black Lives Matter Activists Interrupt Hillary Clinton At Private Event In South Carolina
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/clinton-black-lives-matter-south-car...

Ashley Williams: “Hillary Clinton has a pattern of throwing the Black community under the bus when it serves her politically. She called our boys ‘super-predators’ in ’96, then she race-baited when running against Obama in ‘08, now she’s a lifelong civil rights activist. I just want to know which Hillary is running for President, the one from ’96, ’08, or the new Hillary?”

“Williams, who is from Charlotte, North Carolina, said she was motivated to protest because policies during President Bill Clinton’s administration led to an increase in mass incarceration that mostly affected black communities. She pointed to three-strike federal sentencing laws, the elimination of rehabilitative programs for drug abuse and an emphasis on prison construction as part of the destructive Clinton legacy on crime.”

Clinton stopped taking campaign money from private prison companies and their lobbyists in October only after civil rights and immigrant groups urged her to stop accepting the contributions. Last May, Clinton said she was against having immigrant detention centers run by for-profit companies. Yet, her Ready for Hillary PAC accepted $133,000 from lobbying firms working for GEO Group and Corrections Corporation of America.

Sanders doesn’t just talk the talk, he walks the walk. He has introduced a bill to ban government contracts for private prisons and immigrant detention facilities. And he doesn’t take money from the prison lobby or other corporate interests. He never has during his time in office.

DNC Chair Debbie Wasserman Schulz has accepted money from lobbyists representing CCA - Corrections Corporation of American, which pushes laws that criminalize black Americans and migrants - to profit private prisons.  Wasserman Schulz/the DNC tried to rig the nominating process in favor of Hillary.

You mean there were once rehabilitative programs for drug abuse? We should hear more about that, just to see some contrast. Bill C said the era of big govt is over (but not for prisons). Prisons are a bigger vote getter than drug rehab.
And they'll say, think of the jobs created by prison construction. And by jobs for prison guards.

What the article doesn't address is that the "truly" rich people (not those in debt and with lots of toys) are rich because they spend wisely (look at the old book, the Millionaire Next Door). They know a smart bargain, or to look for sales. And a lot of lower middle class and poor are people lacking financial common sense who don't differentiate needs from wants - with low income they have expensive cell phone plans, cable TV, tattoos, cigarette habits, eat out, etc. The "rich" the article speaks of seem to me to be those with decent incomes but little financial common sense who charge more than they should - the people who got in trouble in the last housing crisis by getting second and third loans to buy more toys.

trw - let Melville speak for me:

"Of all the preposterous assumptions of humanity over humanity, nothing exceeds most of the criticisms made on the habits of the poor by the well-housed, well- warmed, and well-fed.”

Hart, thanks for the good quote (I'll be using it) but the truth is that we all spend money and each person can spend smart or spend dumb.  They can make good choices or they can make bad choices.  They can improve their lives or they can make it worst.  This is true no matter what social/economic level they are at.  Years ago the NYT had an article about an executive who had made over $300,000 a year and recently they had an article about a coal miner who had made $1500 a week (in a very poor section of America).  Both guys made bad choices with their money.  The executive was working as a clerk at the time of the article and the coal miner was on public assistance.  You may not control everything in your life, but you have more than people give you credit for.

I have been very happy with my (Apple) Smart Battery Case!
One (lightning) cord to charge the case and phone simultaneously.
No more mid-afternoon battery refills!
I did have trouble adjusting to seeing 100% whenever I checked the battery level on my phone but, after a few months, I lost the habit of constantly glancing at the upper right corner of my screen.
she probably didn't know their number ... it was stored in her phone's memory - not HER memory

Law enforcement has been trying for decades to get such a law, and have congress has (correctly) refused to give it to them. Not even with the PATRIOT act.  One big problem with such a law is that it *can't* work.  Strong encryption isn't that hard to implement, and third parties will supply it if Apple won't.  Even third parties from outside the country, which is what happened back when export of encryption was much more heavily restricted as a "munition".  The other problem is that it will kill foreign sales for US hardware and software, and cause development of strong encryption in the US to lag behind the rest of the world, ultimately damaging US national security substantially more than the inability to get into the phone of a couple of dead workplace shooters.
IKR???? Why doesn't every corporation?  They should pass a law, or something...

For perspective, I would note that I am one who has an ample set of Fed files resulting from being bugged, followed, burgled, etc. due to my political activities. I have absolutely no illusions about the Feds or how they operate.

Nonetheless, for all its imperfections, the American government is somewhat accountable to the American people. Apple and other large corporations have no such accountability. Their only interest is profit, as they park their money and most of their jobs abroad. We the people get to elect our representatives, and though they are sometimes bought by the likes of Apple, at least their seats go up for renewal. The American people do not get to elect a new C.E.O. of Apple, if they do not like its policies. There is no equivalent accountability for Apple, nor is there even the limited transparency the Freedom Of Information Act provides regarding the workings of government.

The Feds may collect info you rather they not have, but at least, unlike Apple and other corporations, they are not in the business of selling that information to others who may use it in seriously harmful ways. At any given time the Feds idea of national security may or may not align with your own, but at least American security is an essential part of their mandate. Apple and their ilk have no such interest.

Apple's CEO is only responsible to corporate investors. Our President is responsible to the American people. I will take the Feds over a mega-corporation any day of the week.

Fankuchen? Pancake? :) I liked that.

Come on Steve, Apple stockholders elect the board and the board appoints the CEO. It is a democratic form of governance. But you're right in sating private corporations are in fact private and not everyone gets a vote. They still have obligations to customers though and it appears they take those seriously.

Look at it this way; it would be significantly cheaper for them to have simply complied. An extended legal battle that may end up in the US Supreme Court is far from cheap.

In principle yes. But you can't decide without any considerations to practical realities who you trust. Putin was elected. Do you trust his government? It is all in the details.

In principle companies only care about profits, but companies are run by people and people usually have a set of values. Those values might be bad, good or indifferent to the company operation.

I believe Tim Cook genuinely cares about this issue. Apple does not have a history of placating every whim of the share holders.
This is ridiculous. I used to love my IPhone, but I will reconsider what brand I buy next time. I don't understand why Apple is protecting criminals and terrorists.

That is like saying you protect a criminal because you stand up for their right to free speech or lawyer? I am Sure you can understand the significance of standing up for a principle.

Anyway in this particular case this phone isn't protecting any criminals. This is not the phone used by the terrorists for their operations. It is a work phone one of them had. Nothing they have retrieved so far indicates anything of significance to the case. You are being deceived on by the FBI on the significance of this phone.
I disagree. There's nothing to protect anymore. We give away our privacy every day to marketers that track our behavior on websites and thru credit card purchases.
But do they have the pics that may have been on the phone?
I am reading comments that state "the government needs to get a search warrant" so what did I miss.  Last time I read about this the FBI had a court order allowing the search of the phone.
In this case, they are asking Apple to modify their product. It is also akin to asking Swiss bank to open up their vault when their business model is about protecting the privacy of their customers.

Well that person is wrong of course. FBI is free to search the phone. The issue is of course to what degree that allows them to make demands on Apple. Apple has already cooperated a lot with FBI to help them get the data. Put Apple is setting the limit at developing custom software to deliberately weaken their own security.

You missed a lot. First, a search warrant is not  needed in this case. The iPhone in question was a work phone. It is owned by the California state agency for which the shooter worked. This agency has given its  permission to have the phone searched, thus there is no 4th Amendment issue.  The order by the Magistrate (not an Article III judge) is under the All Writs Act,  s part of the Judiciary Act of 1789 that authorizes the United States federal courts to "issue all writs necessary or appropriate in aid of their respective jurisdictions and agreeable to the usages and principles of law." The Government seeks to use this Act to conscript Apple into manufacturing a product that it currently does not possess.  Everything Apple currently possesses, including iCloud backup data, has been given to the Government.  The Magistrste's order is a huge overreach of the power given to the Government by the All Writs Act and will hopefully be overturned.

The government doesn'the know if there is anything worthwhile on that phone or not.  It's a snipe hunt by law enforcement and their lackey , the courts, that endangers our protections under our Constitution.

Though my sympathies are very much with Apple on this, I have to correct a misperception about the code the FBI wants created. The code, in either source or binary form, would be irrelevant. In source form it could be modified and compiled to operate on any iPhone, but it could not actually be loaded or run on the phone because the binary would be unsigned. In binary form it could only operate on the single phone at issue (because that's how the program would be written; see the judge's order), so even if the binary was "leaked" to the world it would have no practical use. Only Apple would be able to render the tool usable on any iPhone (unless code signing is cracked).

(I recognize that this puts incredible pressure on the company to keep its signing key safe, but that was true even before this episode.)

The "weakness" is actually the legal precedent that would be set were Apple to be compelled to cooperate. It would essentially render the company the handmaiden of every police agency in the world.

Because we all know terrorists need their privacy, right?  The FBI is seeking to know if there are more terrorists out there that were in contact with these two; Apple is about selling iPhones because they're "more secure."
Sure, I'll turn over my phone if subpoenaed. Tell me, am I also obligated to remember my passcode? :-)
I bet you have a pin lock number on your phone yea?

The police have never traditionally had the ability to conscript persons who have nothing to do with a case and are not on police payroll to perform forensic functions, at all, let alone in a fishing expedition.

Does anybody actually believe Apple is busily making hack-proof devices rather than devices only Apple can hack? Would those people care to purchase for $100/acre some ocean-front property in Arizona formerly owned by George Strait that I have for sale?

Yeah, I think so now. It's to Apple's business advantage, given their prior marketing strategy to position themselves as leaders in privacy protection and need to differentiate themselves from Android et al. There may also be advantages in litigation. And if the feds dared to forbid sales of devices with such advanced security, they would surely lose politically, since they could not possibly keep it secret.

Remember also: Apple is primarily a product company, its business model not nearly so dependent on gathering customer information as Google or Facebook.

Making phones which apple can hack and sell them as unhackable would be too risky for business. You to to realize there are a lot of smart people who are able to analyze the system independently of apple and figure out whether the phone could be accessible to Apple.

It is stated right before your eyes and you didn'the even see it......their persons, houses, papers and EFFECTS. Their EFFECTS is to say 'everything else that is theirs'
It appears that the folks who wrote that were smart

Dick Diamond, by your logic gun and bullet manufacturers should be held accountable for those killed by gunshots. The car manufacturers should have been held accountable for allowing Bonnie and Clyde to outrun the police. Any tool can be misused.

Moreover, in your frustration you missed the chicken-and-egg problem at the heart of this argument: we simply don't know whether the phone contains any information about the attacks. Ergo your second condition ("Apple's iphone has information regarding the crime") can't be met.

The problem isn't as simple as you'd like to portray it.

Apple is protecting your personal safety by refusing to create new tools that certainly would end up being used by terrorists. As this case illustrates, government officials in the course of their of their duty to protect us, are also using this technology. Do you want terrorists to know where all of the police in a given city live? How about the whereabouts of the nuke plant staff? This isn't about protecting somebody's photos of their lunch or the government staying out of our flirtatious phone calls.  This is about preventing access to our real-time locations, plans, habits, routes, finances and conversations by the people would end up with it: terrorists, violent ex husbands, tyrannical leaders of countries who want to silence dissent or track American visitors, and on and on. We call them phones,  but they can be harnessed by people who mean us harm to track movements, record and transmit photos, videos, conversations, messages, without our knowlege or consent. Creating a key to millions of these devices for use by the "good guys" sounds great, but who will end up with it? How will they use it? It is kind of like the atom bomb. We have spent every minute since we invented it trying to keep everyone else from getting it.

An excellent way to do this is by not having a smartphone. You think you need it? If your answer is yes -- you're lying in a grand way to yourself.

But you say "no .. I just want it". You're still lying to yourself. You have talked yourself into needing and wanting it -- for whatever reason.

Why am I so certain? a. we lived millenia w/o them. b. many of us don't buy in. c. cell phone towers. d. incredible repository of your time and money. e. they interrupt, cubed. f. dependency is never good.

Break your cellphone-opiate habit!

Why? My phone gives me tremendous quality of life benefits. I have my schedule at my fingertips. I can easily communicate with my loved ones and colleagues. I've made wonderful real-life friends, and broadened my world view enormously, via Twitter. Lay off, Luddites. The holier than thou attitude isn't cute.
With point c being the unexplained "cell phone towers", is that an aesthetic complaint or a vague implication at health consequences?

The people that respond to this comment  mix up smart phones with dumb phones.    The entire subject of this article the short battery life of a smart phone goes away with a dumb phone that goes many  days on one charge.

comments.commentBody: Rubio did great tonight; however, he does not come across as a leader.  Nobody can picture him as president. Granted, it's been a while, but there have been some fine Republican presidents. Two that come immediately to mind are Abraham Lincoln, arguably our best, and Dwight David Eisenhower, a man who served this nation long and well.

to put it quite mildly

The purpose of the clown car and these debates is to distract us from the important issues.

There are two important issues. They are inheritance and redistricting. Until inherited fortunes are outlawed we will have people like the Koch brothers, who inherited several billion dollars each, subverting democracy with cash. What to do? Go to YouTube watch Comedy Party Platform and Benton-Comedy2, each under 3 minutes. It's not rocket science but it takes understanding and courage. Then help level the playing field by sending a buck to Bernie Sanders, and invite me to speak. Thanks! Good luck, America!

Public education decimated, both K-12 and higher ed, huge number of adults with no jobs.  Young adults are fleeing the state, as they should.  If you want to buy a 4 bedroom house, next to a beautiful park with gardens and lakes designed by Olmstead, for under $50,000 come to Youngstown OH. I agree!

Marco uses too many soundbites.

I support candidates with original lines like, "We will build the middle class like president Obama has done for the past wight years!" - Billary.

While the middle class shrinks.....

I don't really know what is happening to the suicidal Republican party, but I do know that if Trump is elected as their presidential candidate all hell will break lose for them. The GOP is going through a full blown identity crisis and they better get their act together or ---- shut up -- for the next five years bc they are doing so, so, so much damage to their party, but also to the American party in general.

Intelligent, Moderate Republicans are aghast and running in flocks away from the current radical ignorant, arrogant GOP party of stupid.

Or would that be a bridge too far for a "moderate republican" when it comes to preventing damage to the "American party"?

comments.commentBody: Erin...you hit the nail on the head. The station has been coopted and the Morning Joe has become an enemy encampment within what was a liberal safe haven. Mika has been compromised, Donny Deutsch has been silenced and anytime Barnacle sasses Joe he is on vacay for the next few days. They have stolen our voice.

While I consider some of Gates analysis and solutions regarding energy, health, and education questionable, he seems head and shoulders above the Facebook, Google, and other billionaires who appear to lack the humility that is necessary for those with great power to effect positive change rather than do damage, even if the damage is just from unintended consequences.

As to energy, while Gates acknowledge full-cycle costs as pertinent to the consideration of biofuels, such an approach is needed across the board. For example: what is the true full-cycle environmental cost of buying a new car that gets 3 m.p.g. better gas mileage than the one it is replacing? One must factor in the pollution of all sorts that comes from extracting the raw materials, processing them, transporting those products to a vehicle assembly facility, and the creation of the vehicle itself. In addition, one must add the environmental costs of disposing of the old vehicle.

Should one keep a '72 that gets 14 m.p.g. or buy a new one that gets 17, 25, or 30 m.p.g.? Even if you should dump it now in favor of a 2016 car that gets 33 m.p.g., does that mean you should or should not have dumped it in 1980 for 17 m.p.g., in 1990 for a 23 m.p.g., or 2000 or a 28 m.p.g. car?

So far, the research has not been done to answer these questions. Without knowing the full-cycle story across the board, we are left potentially making feel-good decisions on no sound basis and with questionably beneficial effects.

Thought I'd reply to this at the risk of being repetitive.

The full-cycle carbon emissions cost of a particular product or technology could be a topic for research to address. But consider that a price on fossil-derived carbon would in effect do the research for you.

By attaching a cost to fossil fuels, in proportion to the amount of CO2 they release when combusted, the suppliers of fossil fuels and of goods which are fossil fuel intensive to produce will have to incorporate the increased cost into their products, if they want to stay in business. No economic research is needed since the full-cycle environmental costs would be incorporated into pricing. That would steer small and large decisions of what to buy and where to invest.

As a policy prescription, this is about as good as it gets - it steers the economy into more sustainable technologies in a way which naturally incorporates the full-cycle climate (CO2) impacts which your post raises. Given the risks which increasing atmospheric CO2 poses to the climate of the only planet we have, it's critical that we reward the best technologies for the long run by adopting some form of pricing of fossil carbon. The policy proposed by Citizens' Climate Lobby, called Carbon Fee & Dividend, does this while preserving a robust economy and protecting low income Americans. There's more information about this at www.citizensclimatelobby.org.

Yes it does, if one thinks that the 2 °C is to be achieved. I don't think it will. I also think that BECS and negative anthropogenic CO2 fluxes are ridiculous false hopes unless/until the world population is much lower than today's ... the loss of food production they require cannot be afforded.

Nothing that Bill Gate's big-idea funding (like magical mini-nukes etc) can be ready to roll in less than 20 years ... and then there's the build out.

We need to run with wind and solar, because it is in fact economic right now and it IS SCALING, scaling really great in fact. If 'magic" happens, then great .. but there's a issue that as wind and solar scale they get cheaper and cheaper ... very reasonable forecasts put the LCOE of wind below 3 c/KWH (from favorable sites) SOON, with solar below 4 c/KWH ditto.

The same problem that the renewables had for so many years, how to gain entry and scale to be competitive against an entrenched technology that was cheaper, will then apply to the new technology. Being "no CO2" won't be a reason to subsidize it through its scaling transition ... it will need to bring that AND some other big advantage.

I wouldn't waste a nickel on next-gen nukes for grid electric power -- never going to catch renewables. I think the idea of ship-propulsion from mini-nukes might be a winner in a CO2-constrained world though.

And then money spent on improved batteries (or reversible energy storage technologies generally) and transmission: no brainers.

I want to thank the NYT for allowing timely debate. My original post above was placed yesterday, Thursday, within minutes of Dr. Lemons post. For those that question my education or sanity I would recommend the following read in Nature from Feb 24th.

http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/global-warming-hiatus-debate-f...
No matter what you do or how much of your loot you return you can never buy your soul back
You might think twice about putting people whose ideas about testing and quality gave you those "blue screens of death" in charge of nuclear power.

I see we're playing the old "POPULATION! i don't wanna talk except about POPULATION! game."

Beyond suspecting that a lot of these are from right-wingrs who what Them pruned back, and the fact that that's not what the column's about, the inconvenient truths are these:

1. First World babies chew up a LOT more resources, and create a LOT more pollution than Third World babies.

2. First World birthrates have been dropping like rocks. China's, too. Primarily we see high birthrates in poor countries.

3. Want to see birthrates drop? Provide the basics of food, water, energy and economic security and opportunity. Especially help with education, and ESPECIALLY of girls.

It really is the silver bullet, as a fictional President once said.

Now what's Gates talking about, again?

Yes, changing deeply normal human instincts is not going to happen. We can empower and educate women and make birth control free and widely available, or at least inexpensive.

People have fallen in love and wanted children forever, and the Chinese are having problems with their one child policy. Short of a dictatorship and forced sterilization, this is not practical.

So here we all are, and what are we going to do about it? One thing we can do is get the Republicans and their abstinence only and love the "pure" unborn (as opposed to real children and mothers, whom they won't support, "takers" as they call them) out of office. Bush got birth control out of international aid.

These older white men seem to be for sperm's rights and want their women to be chattels. Nothing new there.

No, ACTUAL reality check: like the agreements in Paris, Gates is talking about changing things in the context of actual political and economic realities.

I realize that you boys like to portray everybody who disagrees with you as silly greeners and all, but the actual reality is, we're way, way more hard-headed and realistic than you are.

I mean, we don't go flying under the kivvers and muttering about Vast Conspiracy every time we look at the NOAA website.

You mean the subsidies that are a fraction of what oil, gas and coal get?

You know...the tax breaks and credits and designed loopholes, not to mention the billions taxpayers shell out to pick up the health care check for that stuff? And to mop up after you guys?

Kip -- refrigeration is one of the easiest loads to adapt to intermittency well, provided you aren't talking about little beer coolers you insist on plugging into the cigarette-lighter socket of your car.

You "store cooth." Works great. Already being done in many areas, is mandated by code for HVAC in large buildings in some more progressive urban areas, to shift/shave the peak loads that air-conditioning demands generate.

In the US, peak power loads are UNIVERSALLY driven by air-conditioning (not food refrigeration!) in heat-waves. Solar power correlates very well but there is the "duck-curve" problem: the air-conditioning demand lingers on into the evening.

Coolth-storage fixes that. It also allows excess night-time capacity (from wind e.g.) to deliver the next day's AC.

Also just mentioning it ... look at the distribution of wind turbines in Texas: the really good wind resource is out in west texas ... lots of turbines out there and more going in. But there are a swath of turbines along the coast from Corpus Cristi down to Browsville ... why is that? It's not as good wind-resource as west texas.

It's because in heat-waves the sea-breeze circulation turns on strongly -- these wind-turbines correlate beautifully with peak demand .. .they are effectively renewable 'peaker plants' selling the electricity they generate in the high-price market at that time. Think about that....

Easy --

1. It's over, big time.

2. It wasn't remarkable, there was a bigger/longer one starting about the end of WW II

3. You want a physics answer? Heat storage and release from coupled atmosphere/ocean oscillations.

Hey, wimmers: do Deformed Rabbit, it's my favorite.

Sorry and all, but mockery is the only rational response to this sort of nonsense.

well said, drollere
i could not agree more
What makes Bill Gates thoughts so worthy of our attention that we are invited to ask him for his thoughts? Is he a philosopher citizen, a Renaissance man? Or just quite, quite wealthy?

He made a lot of money.  And as much as it concerns me, Money is at the top of the hierarchy of order, it has replaced the sovereign or governments and religion as how humanity achieves order.  I am pleased that Mr. Gates has the altruistic motivations to help our species survive.  I am an old military guy but I welcome that my Grandson, who is in his late 20s idolizes Bill Gates.

Forget all of this 'expert' verbiage.  The only problem is overpopulation.
gates is in bed with monsanto AND cargill, and yesterday backed the FBI over Apple.   hardly a leader to follow

wmar - you and Adrian simply lie about the data sets since you never present proof against them. Or present us the peer-reviewed analysis and code for the UAH team as they continue to stagger through endless beta versions of their 6th attempt to get their stuff right.

Sea level - every tide gauge station has land motion elements, global sea level rise elements, and local ocean trend elements. But here's a recent study that sheds some light on why the sea levels are currently rising when global temperatures peaked 6000 years ago and HAD BEEN declining since then.

"Temperature-driven global sea-level variability in the Common Era"

"We present the first, to our knowledge, estimate of global sea-level (GSL) change over the last ∼3,000 years that is based upon statistical synthesis of a global database of regional sea-level reconstructions. GSL varied by ∼±8 cm over the pre-Industrial Common Era, with a notable decline over 1000–1400 CE coinciding with ∼0.2 °C of global cooling. The 20th century rise was extremely likely faster than during any of the 27 previous centuries."

http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2016/02/17/1517056113

And you continue to err with "pause". Warming at the surface was at a slower rate, but continued. Oceans continued unabated warming during the same period. So the rate of warming at the surface slowed for a bit. Natural cycles are part of the climate still. Heat was going into ocean depths. But greenhouse warming trends move cycle endpoints up.
Didn't Adrian have a role in the Monty Python gang's "Spamalot"?
Why not just close your eyes and stop up your ears?

Writ like someone who knows how well that works, Ads. Hey, that methane plume showed up a treat in the infrared, dontcha think?

Oh, right. Sorry. You wouldn't have seen that, of course.

After making huge money off a bunch of products that were so riddled with flaws they were frequently unusable, and stealing many ideas from other companies, this charlatan continues to spew forth nonsense on energy and eating.

He might be famous, and a nice title that will get people to read this article, but he is no expert, nor someone I can trust.

If you're going to interview someone, please interview and expert in their field and not a typical politically-motivated big money guy that's retired and interested in talking to the media.

If we're going to have information technology billionaires investing in addressing our pollution and climate issues, how about they do some of the following, which could and should be deployed faster than it would take to build (plan, permit, environment study, gain right of way, construct, etc.) the physical grid enhancements.

1 - fund lots of work with IEEE and other standards organizations on non-proprietary, secure, encrypted data and control protocols for the grid and affiliated systems

2 - ditto on hardening computer and communications systems for our increasingly computerized transportation systems - cars, planes, rail, road signage, etc. Again, with open, non-proprietary protocols focused on security and interoperability.

3 - same again for Internet of Things.

There's a lot of money being made in computerizing all this stuff. Let's not have individual companies pushing their profitable proprietary approaches while nobody focuses on making it all as reliable and hack-proof as possible.

Elon Musk pushing self-driving capability out to the cars he sold, then expressing dismay that some owners actually didn't follow his "of course, you'll just use this on your private property" advice, is one of the beginning signs that we have to really think through how technology gets out there - don't let vendors of large dangerous objects treat the world as a beta test or as a playground for hackers.
Bill Gates' house in Washington is a hot mess of a carbon foot-print. A while ago MIT reported that Bill uses 10,000 times the energy of the average American.
Getting rich off other people's code (dos) does not make one a climate expert.
Those arguing for right-sizing the population never say how we get there.

Why are there 15 types of Cheerios? Cereal manufacturers count on public gullibility. Fruity Cheerios are Froot Loops. Apple Cinnamon Cheerios are nutritionally void Apple Jacks. It's called "ribbonizing".  Tradition suggests that as a food company you want as many SKU's (basically shelf positions by product) as possible.  Basically, you want your own "wall of brands" so you can own your category aisle...or as much as possible. To achieve this you make brand extensions to support your positions the retailers plan-o-gram (blueprint for products on shelf). 8 years after the financial crisis and with 4.9% unemployment and guess what progressives are calling for? More stimulus, what else.  If that doesn't prove perma-stimulus is the true progressive desire then nothing will.  It will always be "obvious" to those who benefit most from expanding government that we need more government spending on something.  Meanwhile our highest in the developed world corporate tax rate continues to erode private capital investment   and the wealth creating productivity that comes from that investment.  You can count on government to funnel infrastructure dollars not to where they will do the most good but to where 1) they work to someone's best political advantage and where 2) there is already the greatest failure of progressive policy.  In this latter case the infrastructure spending will actually be counterproductive since it will just prolong the suffering and delay needed structural economic reforms, wasting all of our hard earned tax dollars in the process.

"More stimulus"??

What stimulus spending has there been? Oh, sure, we had a little bit back in 2009 and 2010, but most of that came in the form of tax cuts, not actual spending. In fact, the very brief stimulus we had halted the economic collapse and the economy did begin to recover. But slowly, way too slowly! And the effects of that stimulus has long since evaporated.

By the way, did you know that currently most government spending is directed into Republican/conservative states? In Mississippi, for example, literally 47% of the state's annual budget is in fact paid for by Federal tax dollars. The not-liberal Tax Foundation has several times over the last decade detailed how progressive states actually pay far more in Federal tax dollars than they receive in any Federal spending, causing a net loss of billions. Simultaneously, conservative states receive far more in Federal spending than they ever pay in Federal tax dollars, giving them a net gain, thanks to progressives.

And I assume you didn't actually read the column, as conservatives rarely do. Quite clearly, Dr. Krugman pointed out that the Keynesian economic principle is that you implement austerity (aka pay down the debt) at the economic boom times, but you borrow and spend during the slump to boost the economy. Note too, under Clinton we were doing exactly that, quite well. Remember the paid off debt predictions in 2000? Then we got GOP tax cuts and spending...and the debts took off again!

Economists are criticized for giving different solution at different times or situations. Like a physician prescribes different medications for different diagnoses and stages of treatments. Conservative ideologues prescribe the same cures for any problem: cut taxes and regs and repeat as often as possible while blaming the government for all ills. W's tax cuts were designed to sunset at the end of the last decade just to get a foot in the door. It took all Obama's efforts and budget brinksmanship to finally end the 3 years late. So it's no wonder that whatever your side is guilty of is projected onto the other side.

The original stimulus was far too small, and primarily dedicated to tax cuts (almost all of which went into personal savings, as predicted) and federal grants to the bankrupt states (forced to cut spending and raise taxes, sending the nation into free fall). The shortfall in infrastructure from the Stimulus was a known accounting amount. You knew it, too. In fact, predictions of waste in shovel-ready investment projects were dead wrong. We know that construction is notoriously the most inefficient in our economy and bid rigging is endemic. Yet these projects were an amazing exception (perhaps because so many firms and workers were so desperate for contracts).

By the way, economists know those federal spending programs (as opposed to the tax cuts) were absolutely free! Why? Because there was zero crowding out of private construction, which was at record lows.
Hey, ain't Kansas, Wisconsin and Louisiana lookin' great these days? Fabbalous showcases for the far right's theores, huh?

Your own faith-based values are, in effect, specific only to you and should not be imposed legislatively on other women who belong to the Catholic Church or to other faiths or to no faith at all.

Sanders is close to done, and now it is easy to see why. Anger at Wall Street just doesn't seem to resonate much among black Democratic voters. Anger at Wall Street is issue number one for Sanders. Nothing else really comes close for him. Despite Clinton's reputation for being a puppet of Wall Street, that reputation apparently didn't hurt her among blacks in South Carolina.

Wall Street is problematic. There is no doubt in my mind that a lot of the people who work there are malignant sociopaths. But the results in South Carolina show that black Democrats don't prioritize that issue above everything else as Sanders does. This spells trouble for Sanders. Black turnout in November must be high to give Democrats any chance of retaining the White House or making gains in Congress.

In South Carolina, an economy heavily dependent on the manufacturing sector has been devastated by the loss of jobs in the textiles industry. If there was one state where black Democrats were more likely to be attracted to the anti-Wall Street message of Bernie Sanders, South Carolina was it. Because obviously Wall Street is the main culprit in pushing for the de-industrialization of the United States.

In other southern states with more advanced economies and where more black Democratic voters are employed in the tertiary sector as part of the professional managerial classes (Virginia, North Carolina, Georgia) I just don't see Sanders making large inroads with them in a bid to woo them away from Clinton.

Voting on the basis of hostility to the financial services industry is still a stretch for a lot of people, including African-Americans who have seen their jobs and livelihoods taken away by the vagaries of globalization and shareholder capitalism. Sanders has largely built his campaign around that very understandable theme, but the results in South Carolina are not encouraging for him.

I did NOT write that Wall Street is of no interest to black Democratic voters. It is merely my perception that black Democrats are not as likely to prioritize reforming Wall Street above everything else as is clearly the case with Sanders.

For the record, as far as I'm concerned President Obama should have nationalized the country's biggest investment banks on January 20, 2009. It was a huge missed opportunity during a moment of acute awareness of the destructive behavior of financial institutions and their executive-level employees. The author, Katalan Balog, writes, "Much of Kierkegaard’s philosophy is a warning against the tendency...to take an increasingly objective, abstract perspective on the world. While the paradigm example of this is science, it is most problematic when applied to one’s own life and existence."

I am inclined to disagree as to what constitutes the most problematic implication of increased "objectivity." Balog appears to juxtapose the extremes of universal truths -- science -- with individual perception and experience. This seems much too limited a view of the real world. "Objectivity" is only knowable through the subjectivity of the individual. At the same time, "subjectivity" is governed by universal truths, whether we are aware of them or not.

I would think that what is most problematic is not increased "objectivity" but, rather, the confusion of "objectivity" and "subjectivity" or, perhaps, the cloaking of subjectivity in the mantle of objectivity. It has become common to to take claims of hope, fear, belief, and faith and state them as facts, as objective truths. We see this not merely in the current political environment but also in everyday life in such "controversies" as vaccines and anthropogenic global warming.

In a previous age, science had to be cloaked in faith. By contrast, in our current age, faith seemingly needs to be cloaked in science.

I agree there's both subjectivity & objectivity in every human life. But at the end it is exactly like that: it's life, which in a Gestalt viewpoint means it goes beyond subject & object. Life, as long as it's human, is more related to Nietzsche' wille und vorstellung through insight, so that we shouldn't forget that science & 'objectivity' are just words to define a method to make world understandable in the most inner space of our mind, so we can afford to deal with nature & survive as individuals first, as species then. Kierkegaard' work is pointing out to give value to our lives (all lives matter), allowing us to recognize virtue from sin, and that's always done through language, language creates reality ('objective' outer world), as it all started one million years B.P. in the way of myth, to help us to understand for surviving, it is an intrinsic (genetic maybe?) property of mankind to get an agreement, a social consensus, on behalf of each individual' goal: autopoiesis (to reproduce him/herself).

Agree with everything in your post, but (my apologies for being a pendant): the notion of the world-as-will-and-presentation was Schopenhauer's, not Nietzsche's. Although, of course, the latter stole this one from the former, as he did with so many things.

If Marx was Hegel stood on his head, Nietzsche was Schopenhauer turned inside out.

We are speaking on behalf of the millions of people, worldwide, who suffer lifetime's filled with constant ‘vertigo’ from a little known and very misunderstood disease, known as Meniere's disease.

Meniere’s disease steals lives, leaving those unable to function as they once did. Many sufferers are reduced to bystanders to their own existence, unable to work, drive, attend family gatherings, or simply play with their kids. Meniere’s causes dizziness, severe vertigo, tinnitus, sensitivity to light and sounds and other normal everyday activities. Meniere’s attacks leave their victims so dizzy and unable to walk or balance, with even the slightest movement bringing hours of nausea and vomiting. If that wasn’t enough, most Meniere’s sufferers develop hearing loss and many go completely deaf.

Additionally, in a 2009 study on post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) performed by Kirby, S.E. and Yardley, L. it was found that the incidence of (PTSD) and health anxiety is much higher than in non-sufferers. Nearly one in eight people with Ménière’s were found to meet the criteria for full PTSD, compared to the general population where just one in sixty has PTSD. Yet, Meniere’s remains relatively unknown worldwide and dramatically underfunded when it comes to crucial research dollars.

Please help by signing our petition for U2 Meniere's Awareness:

https://www.change.org/p/bono-and-u2-meniere-s-disease-raise-awareness
The U.S. government will always step in to keep the wealthy from becoming non-wealthy. This is the way it has been for the last 50 years. Why would someone even question the notion.

The vertigo I experienced was a diagnosed by my doctor, a neuro otologist. He did a quick exam and told me what it was and sent me off to a Physical Therapist that specializes in treatment of BPPV. The PT laid me on a table and moved my head in a few specific ways more or less rolling it a bit very gently and within 10 minutes I felt amazing.  I think she referred to it as an Epley maneuver. This was maybe 10 years ago and I've never had a reoccurrence of the vertigo. BTW I am a long ago sufferer of Menieres Disease which the same doctor "cured" me of with injections of gentamiacin. I suffered from Menieres off and on for 25 years and those shots virtually took the symptoms away. I am a blessed man
Ok, I will. Thank you!

I was diagnosed with BPPV and got some relief with these maneuvers.  The symptoms persisted, though were much milder, but turned out to be related to a brain tumor.  I suggest that anyone who doesn't get complete and permanent relief discuss this possibility with their MD.

I suffer from this, and am 46.  I developed this after a car accident 10 years ago; I'd wake from sleep and grab the bed, certain that it was spinning fast enough to throw me against the wall.  Doctors suggested drugs, and never mentioned this as a potential solution.  Every emergency room doctor needs to be trained in this procedure - it changes lives.  I suffered for 6 months before I found out about the Epley maneuver on my own, and immediately knew it was working as I performed the movements.  Thanks, internet!
Its great to see an article about a simple, free and effective way to treat an ailment. Can you write another one, about the Friggy flip?

While we ER physicians use the Epley maneuver often, my experience is that it works far less than 90% of the time reported in the literature; I've asked my colleagues and I'm not alone. It's also important that dangerous causes of vertigo be ruled out. This can only be done by a trained physician and is no easy task. Many strokes are missed, as the article mentions. But vertigo can be caused by "central" causes like tumors or MS. Even diabetic crises can cause vertigo. So, please see a doctor. Sometimes imaging will be necessary, and sometimes not. But don't do Epley or 1/2 somersault until BPPV has been diagnosed by a physician. Thanks everyone.

"But don't do Epley or 1/2 somersault until BPPV has been diagnosed by a physician,"

Why not? What harm, other than possibly depriving a will be done by trying this? Depriving a physician of a fee?

Thank you.  I was misdiagnosed with BPPV (!) after a battery of tests all came back negative, but the doctor insisted that I had vertigo.  Turns out migraine aura was what I was actually experiencing (very similar symptoms.)  Some great drugs and an even better neurologist has me straightened out.  Haven't had the same symptoms in YEARS.

I don't understand. If the Epley maneuver or similar relieves the symptoms, and the symptoms don't recur, doesn't that indicate that the problem is solved, or manageable?

Does it make any sense that a tumor or MS could induce vertigo and that the Epley maneuver could stop the vertigo.

Never was taught this in medical school.  Heard about it from a non-physician friend about 15 years ago, who had been lucky to have a doctor who referred her to PT for the Epley maneuver when she had sudden onset of vertigo.  Years later, I used it on my spouse when he awoke with sudden severe vertigo.  It worked immediately.  You can find numerous videos on youtube showing the procedure.  Ever since I found out about it, it's my first step in a workup of vertigo, before any other treatments or tests, since it's harmless, and only costs an additional ten minutes of office time.

This article by Ms. Correal, and the photos by Mr. Cobo are of current activity and don't unearth anything about the Carrera Septima or Bogota' and its past. The corner where most shots were taken is the intersection of the Carrera Septima and the Avenida Jimenez. The Central Bank is El Banco de la Republica. The building where El Tiempo used to be was designed by an Italian architect, Bruno Violi. Opposite El Banco de La Republica is La Iglesia de San Francisco, and below that was the Gobernacion de Cundinamarca with a statue of Gonzalo Jimenez de Quesada, the city founder. Going North on the Carrera Septima, just past El Banco de La Republica is El Parque de Santander. Beyond that is the Avianca tower which in years past housed the main post office. A few blocks South of Carrera Septima and Avenida Jimenez is La Plaza de Bolivar, Bogota's main square where the Catedral Primada and the Congress building are...

Right, George Blackford. It's simple math: if money is drained out of the demand system by people who don't spend (i.e., billionaires and sub-billionaires), it won't be spent on demand and demand will be reduced. If the people who aren't getting that money already had enough and wouldn't be spending it anyway, there would be no reduction in demand. By looking at the world, or just the U.S., as it is, any person can see that people who are losing money to the drainage are losing money they would mostly spend.

It follows that we have to take back our money from the (sub)billionaires. If we elect real people instead of greed robots, we can make that happen. Aye, there's the rub!

It was a no win situation, I think she did what she thought was the right thing to do. All the critics have 20-20 hindsight, but we do not know what they would have don in the same position. It is easy to criticize when you do not have to make the decision.

An outstanding article like this, which lays out what happened very clearly, makes if VERY EASY to think that the correct path was obvious at the time, and that Clinton's choices are simply born of ignorance, stupidity, hubris, etc. instead of doing the best she could while beset by intractable obstacles on every side (including from her boss). If you want hubris and stupidity, look to GWB and his gang. This article shows that, in his wake, the US can't really act effectively at all.
