I am unmoved by Wenar's argument. It is facile. Like Steven Pinker, he is an apologist for a thoroughly corrupt human civilization. The society we have built is morally despicable, demented in a million ways. Anyone with any sentience at all can feel how rapacious and brutal it is, in matters both big and small. It destroys any sense of well-being and health at almost every turn of ordinary living. It has become intolerable. Putting an optimistic spin on it all is an exercise in contorted perception, and fools no one. His argument implodes on his pet phrase,"at least this far," used repeatedly. Mr. Wenar, wake up! We've created a monstrous culture, and it is eating itself. From the historical record, it couldn't be clearer that we are a failed species. In the decades to come, we will get what we deserve. And the earth and its non-human survivors will be delivered from the scourge of the diseased animal, the ill-named homo sapiens.

It's quite horrifying, but for the first time in six decades, I no longer feel Americans have the will, the intellect or the spiritual core to save this country from a disaster on its way. When I was in elementary school, I was in an underfunded district in what was then one of the poorer states of the US. The curriculum was by and large stifling, the atmosphere misogynistic. An awkward, unathletic kid, I was bullied routinely.  If anyone had tried to test me on joy, I would have failed miserably -- or I would have received a placeholder grade in lieu of failure, as I did in one subset of the conduct marks.  At the very least, I would have found it patronizing. My prospects in life changed overnight when we moved to a different district, a more affluent and less rigid one in the same state. It is all well and good to preach about grit and to encourage perseverance, but don't forget that the most important factors are genuine opportunity for all learners, social and economic equity, support for diverse types of families,  and a commitment to ending discrimination.

Indeed, I can think of a reason Sanders did as well as he did in Colorado that has gone completely unmentioned: Sanders supports the federal full legalization of marijuana, and Colorado has been living with a state-wide legalization now for a few years. That means that marijuana growers and distributors in Colorado are in an odd spot where they are legal in the state, except if the feds change their minds and decide to go after them (Obama has directed the FBI to not go after marijuana in places where there is compliance with state law, but the next president could change that). Because of that legal ambiguity, everyone in the industry is unable to, for example, open up bank accounts for their business.

Policy matters in political races. Horse-race reporting doesn't acknowledge that simple fact.

I'm not an active math guy, but used an excel sheet to help me.  First column, first row had a starting number of my choice.  Second column subtracted the correct number of pearls based on the specific daughter (1 through whatever).  Third column calculated the remaining number of pearls.  Fourth column always divided by 7.  Fifth column was the value of dividing the remaining pearls by 7.  Sixth column added the number of pearls subtracted in column 2 to the number of pearls in column 5.  The number in column 6 was subtracted from the number in column 1 and then placed into the next row of column 1, and all of the formulas were duplicated, adjusting only for the number of subtracted pearls.  I knew I needed numbers that were always divisible by 7 in column 3.  Not very pretty, but neither am I.  I know nothing of slopes or mathematical formulas.  The point is I used some creative thought and tools I understand to get the correct answer by simply manipulating the value in first column of the first row.  I went as high as 200 in row 1 column 1 before I realized he only had a reasonable number of daughters.  Now I'm going to bed.

Way to go Dan! One should never feel ashamed to use a tool -- any tool -- to solve a problem. I know someone with a PhD in physics who shows middle and high school students how to use Excel to simulate diffusion, a thermodynamics concept. Since part of the school year I help 5th grade students learn how to use a spreadsheet, I will now add your solution to my repertoire of examples. So thank you very much! GOP--the party of obstructionism, vote suppression, birther movement, rebellion against authority (such as the president’s), and other unpleasant activities—is now reaping what it has sown: it’s rank and file members are supporting two candidates reviled by the GOP establishment, Trump and Cruz.

Marco Rubio, the latest GOP establishment choice for the party nomination, hasn’t won a primary yet, at least as of 11PM on March 1st, demonstrating how out of touch the party leadership is with its members.

It is all well and good that the party has a majority in the Congress and a majority of the state houses, but winning by pitting one group against another hasn’t done anything to win the hearts and minds of its own members.

Perhaps it is finally time for the GOP to try to become the party of Lincoln that it was before it further erodes what little respect the party has left among the public at large.

Can't help with the rest. Don't even want to see "ipad" in crosswords! Apple is a good company only if famous drummer is a quarter-owner.

I did it on my iPhone using the NYT app and it worked when I just entered the across part of the rebus. For example, for 65-across, I entered "GSHARP" in the last square and the app saw it as correct.

I had no difficulty figuring out the enharmonic theme. I just couldn't figure out how to enter it on my iPad. I used the rebus key, of course, and tried entering them both separated by a slash, and then I tried reversing the order. Nothing worked. Anybody know how to solve my problem?

I was wondering how to enter and wrote it out----across/down and it seemed to work, although it told me I had finished with F/ESHARP, and in fact, seemed to be happy with just an F and nothing else.  Regardless, this was an awful lot of fun.

Foraging is a frivolous luxury relevant only to the bourgeoise. There's no way for inefficient methods like foraging to support even a fraction of the Earth's population, yet inexplicably, it continues to be treated with seriousness, not contempt.

"To me, Foucault and his followers seemed impossibly naïve, even complacent. Had they ever encountered severe obsessive-compulsive disorder or suicidal depression?"

Foucault experienced such suicidal moments himself. And before he turned to philosophical inquiry, he was trained in psychology, and worked in St Anne's hospital in Paris. See the new book on Foucault in Münsterlinger Asylum for more details about his 'insider' knowledge in the psychiatric world, where he dealt with patients, before he became critical of the profession. His position derived from his experiences; he was far from naïve.

I am a member of the Bay Grape wine club and love the education I am getting from Stevie and Josiah.  I have tried and loved many bottles selected by them that I never would have considered on my own.  And the warm, neighborhood feel makes it a joy to frequent. We are blessed here in Northern CA with an abundance of fabulous wine store options.  I'll also put in a plug for the Downtown Wine Merchant, in Oakland as well. They too have a friendly,  knowledgeable staff and some delicious nibbles to boot.

I adore this place. Truly worth a journey (which I make here at least twice a
year.) I love the atmosphere and unhurried pace. I hope it will continue
for many years. Agree that the lunch is one of the bargains of the western
world. Lovely food and, always, an uplifting experience.

So I "won," but don't feel like a winner.

comments.commentBody:
I only hope when the dust settles and the Democratic/Republican candidates are formally nominated, the Presidential debates are more civil and substantive. That rules are set in place to prevent name calling, insults and snide remarks and moderators have more control. The Republican debates have been a travesty. It would be funny if this weren't so serious (and pathetic).
I think the American public deserves better than having candidates "act like damn fools."
Totally eliminate studio audiences.
The Democratic debates have been civil and substantial.
they act exactly as their supporters do.

It would be near tolerable if the debates were limited to broadcast within the U.S., but this Punch and Judy show is being played out on the international stage. I hope the rest of the viewing world can distinguish the difference between the totally bat-guano crazy Ugly Republican American and the rest of us.

Please, if you travel abroad this summer leave your red "Making America Great Again" baseball caps at home; that, or don't eat the soup.
Would it be snooty of me to suggest that Trump supporters, as a demographic, are unlikely to be travelling abroad?

Not just snooty but snarky as well. But it's a typical response from the left. when in doubt resort to name calling because it shows just how mature you can be. That'll show 'em.

Keep believing the rhetoric from the left that all Trump supporters are lacking an education and are not very sophisticated. I feel sorry for your ilk.

To Gus.
Been there and done that.
There is only one thing worse than travel abroad "this summer".

It was travel abroad in Europe when the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, with its torture and abuse practices, hit the international fan.
We were there at the time on a bicycle trip.
All flags, tee shirts with identifying information, hats, etc. were eliminated and our group dejected demeanor was debilitating.
So today's political activities could be much worse ...... but not by much.
Glad someone gets the picture Charlie.
@Cassandra G: Let's just call it politiporn.
Obviously.

“...each host has to be conversant in his or her topics in order to fact-check and question candidates’ assertions immediately.”

And just WHO is going to do the fact-checking and from what source?

Biggest laugh I’ve had in a long time--Faux Noise fact-check and question assertions. Right! Can’t wait for Trump to say “I have the best memory in the world!” Take it Mr. Baier!
A debate in Fox News ... that's how they are calling Jerry Springer's show nowadays?
Jerry Springer?  That's all that's missing!  Fox should just drop the pretense of these being actual serious debates among adults and put Jerry in charge.

Yep. I'm with the crowd. Thought it was bland. I MIGHT make it again and tweak the recipe, but I like my risotto recipe much better. I'm deleting this from my recipe box.
The veggie-resistant boyfriend and I ate this like fries. Double it.

This cake certainly was easy to make but the outcome was a bit disappointing.  The cake wasn't moist and the flavor just didn't hit the spot.
more republican slight of hand and gibberish.

Yes, let's talk about bankruptcies due to medical bills.

"Bankruptcies resulting from unpaid medical bills will affect nearly 2 million people this year—making health care the No. 1 cause of such filings, and outpacing bankruptcies due to credit-card bills or unpaid mortgages, according to new data.
AND even having health insurance doesn't buffer consumers against financial hardship."

CNBC 2014.

Because of having to work with health insurance companies some families have a $5,000 deductible to pay even before they can get needed surgery or treatment.

Health Insurance Companies had WAY too much pull in the design of the ACA. As a health care provider I see every day how folks didn't get Medicaid expansion because GOP governors REFUSED federal monies. I see patients suffer as they can't afford the deductible. I volunteer my time in the clinic and convinced a 40 y/o private business owner to buy Obamacare. She needed surgery but didn't have the deductible. I felt so bad that I gave her the $1500.

I'm 67 y/o and on a fixed income...I can't do this again. It HURTS to see my patients hurt! I so HATE the GOP. They might as well wear NASCAR jump suits with the names of the companies embroidered on patches on them. Then we can see EXACTLY which corporations OWN them.

The "People" you describe are the pick-up truck driving, ignorant masses, who don't believe in reality, refuse to educate themselves by reading FACTS, and clearly engage in magical thinking, imagining that a reality star who lies to them and tells them what they want to hear can be their savior. It's pathetic. At present those people are simply a vocal MINORITY.  And if the rest of the people don't get out and vote, they will decide the fate of this country. It is truly SCARY.

I don't think it's true that the concentration camp Sonderkommando (not to be confused with the SS Sonderkommando) "helped herd people to the gas chambers". According to wikipedia, that's not true. All they did was dispose of the bodies after removing valuables. They had a choice of doing this or being killed. And they were usually killed after a few months anyway, to prevent them bearing witness to the atrocities. They were no less victims than any of the others murdered in the camps.
No offense. But it's probably safe to assume that you are not Mexican, Muslim, or African-American.
Well written! : )

I like Starbucks and drink their coffee at home that I purchase at the supermarket. I don't live near a store so frequenting one is not an option however when I travel I will find a local Starbucks for my morning coffee and look for one at the airport and even bring a bag with me. I have enjoyed the rewards program. It is great to be appreciated for being a customer and being brand loyal by corporate America. I don't drink the fancy drinks to many calories and silliness I prefer my coffee straight up.

But if customers are double dipping by splitting up purchases or ripping tags off of bags and it hurts profit margins then I get it. It is still important for employees to make a living wage and have health insurance. And Starbucks is still better coffee then DD or McD and many people hang out all day using the wifi and the bathrooms so there you have it -- it costs money to keep a business open.

I haven't tried this recipe yet, but I've tried others, and I end up with the same result:  deflated bit of popcorn.  Anyone know what causes that and how to avoid it?

This recipe was delicious, but I thought it called for way too much salt. Next time I'll start by adding half the amount, and seeing how that goes.
I also added some pre-cooked chicken at the end for extra protein.
Great recipe!  I had a 1lb 10oz cauliflower, it cooked in 1 our and 15 minutes.  I am not sure what kind of anchovies is needed for the sauce, I used a 2oz can of anchovies without their oil.

I lived under Nixon's presidency but was not alive under McCarthy....

It would be interesting to know whether the Select Investigative Panel on Infant Lives has any intention of improving the lives of any actual infants or their families. Fetuses seem far more important to such people than full-fledged children.

"Select Investigative Panel on Infant Lives"

That was my first though too - the name of the panel is bitterly ironic. Would that these people actually interested themselves in infant lives!

Exactly. Food, housing, providing cheap, quality day care for working parents, parental leave, heating assistance, health care, education (pre-k through college) are all things that would benefit actual infants. Bernie supports them. The GOP could not care less.

Clint,

"Tamal" is a Spanish word. "Tamale" is the English word for tamal.
http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/tamale

I enjoyed getting this one by dint of brainwork alone. Jeb was actually my first fill, for what it's worth. I enjoyed the structure of this one especially.

The clue for Mennonite (I was surprised to read the constructor's note on it) is akin to (clue:) Utahan (fill:) Mormon. In other words, it don't pass muster. Martin's mileage will, of course, vary. I'll let him handle the hot tamales, btw.
Since the clue was "One speaking the language Plautdietsch" and not something like "Everyone who speaks Plautdietsch," I have no problem with this clue and its answer.
Please pass the mustard.

It's like having "one speaking French" with the answer "Catholic."

We attended an ecumenical service once in France. There were twelve Roman Catholic priests and one minister from the evangelical community - he was not given a "speaking role."
That sounds most unusual, LizB! They aren't Tauregs, are they? Or silver-drinkers?
Just another chapter in the irredeemability of bg time "revenue" college sports.
Not just in the university. In something like 40 states, the highest paid PUBLIC EMPLOYEE is a college coach.

Yet another article in which a small amount of light shineth of the awfulness of revenue generating sports at the collegiate level.

Here's the deal:

It is absurd to believe that any top 20-30 basketball recruit in the country would chose a school that exists in a minor conference and has a terrible history of producing NBA draft picks. If you can play, and you choose SMU, the public can be assured that someone (Aunt, Uncle, AAU coach, sister, brother, mom, dad, 6th removed Uncle) is getting paid. You also don't go to any West Coast school if you're any good - it should be an immediate yellow flag to any college basketball follower.

It is absurd to believe that it's not a sellers market - there's only so much talent out there. If you're a good player - a player that can have an immediate impact on program - you will be given whatever you want. It's just a question of what you want and how clean the transaction can be.

In the case of SMU, they danced with the devil and they're now facing the consequences - however, I can assure you there will be those within the SMU community who will believe they still came out on top.

So, when you read a top 10 kid "takes his talent" to a certain school, know that talent comes at a price for all.
Southern METHODIST University - a fact which adds yet another dimension to the betrayal of institutional values which this incident exposes.

I'm a former high school/college football and basketball official.I love both sports.This tragic story is only the tip of the iceberg.Although very rare,I have seen athletes who cannot even tell you their uniform numbers because they are that academically deficient.I have also seen football team captains who do not understand the basic options on a penalty which is either down or distance.These captains and now the referee look to the sideline for the coaches to make the decision.Yes,it is a big money environment.For clarity,my oldest daughter is an SMU grad.She received an outstanding education there.But for a University Provost to negate a do not accept decision is totally unethical and immoral.What's a solution?IMHO,pay the players,let everyone know they're not there for the diploma,and stop the charade the NCAA promulgates that they're student athletes there for an education.Sure there are some student athletes who receive a good education,but it's rare.SMU isn't the only highly regarded university doing this.If you want an eye opening experience,the NY Times should expose the admissions criteria for athletes at Army and Navy.
Wow. Army and Navy too? This is an ethical cesspool.

You apparently are not well informed about college basketball or you would not be questioning the basis.  Nobody can go directly to the NBA without spending a year doing something and the training you get at a college is essential not to mention the exposure.

Apparently you don't know that nobody forces them to attend college, they could go get a job doing something.  Now to play football you need the experience, training and coaching you get in college.  There is no substitute and the union rules require you to wait.  In men's basketball you have to wait one year and of course you can do that wherever you desire.  You don't have to go to college but there is a great benefit even if you don't get an education.  Surely if you work at a college you should understand this.  I bet many STEM majors might view your class in the same way, if they do the work they pass, if they don't they fail.  Simple!!!
The NBA union insists that you can't be in the league and it would be better if they made them wait three years as in football.  You are misinformed as usual.
You are welcome to support such a system, go for it.

But, yes it is about education. Why shouldn't these kids--whether they initially finish college or not--be required to have the most basic of academic skills? Go straight from high school to some kind of minor league, like baseball has, but know how to read well, write, do math and understand the scientific method and your society's history. Is that too much to demand?

We do not know Frazier's true academic capabilities because no one forced him to develop them. Even his mother seemed satisfied with the status quo. His story reminds me of the many stories in urban America. Kids will never get anywhere until they at least GO TO SCHOOL. And who else is better able to enforce that dictum than the kid's parents, relatives and clergy. The NCAA and its feeder schools have a lot to answer for but the kids, parents and school staff themselves know that what they are doing is wrong. Blame everyone involved not just the coaches.

I am shocked how un-shocked I am by this story. Everything I read perfectly fits the long-time narrative of corrupt big-time college sports. Winning and money, money and winning. That is ALL that matters.
Do you think Laura Bush vets every basketball recruit?  Be real.

Please...yes, the educational system is at fault if it was complicit in his academic failure. But his mom, his academically bottom-feeding school and Frazier himself bear some responsibility. He didn't know he should go to school? Study? A,student of any race knows that. A parent of any race knows that. My parents did not go to college. My grandparents had no high school diploma. My father was no academic star. But my grands and parents knew I was supposed to go to school and would have punished me if I cut. My father may not have been able to help with homework but he knew I should do it and made sure I did.

Frazier's mom is not so naive not to know he should have been going to school. She lied about her rent to put sports above academics. I have great empathy for kids who grow up in an environment that does not value academics. They have it harder than affluent kids. But they know right and wrong regarding school. They have teachers willing to put in extra hours to help them succeed.

My kid was no academic star, either. He went to school in the worst-performing school system in the state. But he had math and science teachers who tutored before and after school. I forced him to go. I encouraged the best preparation for any life endeavor: READ, READ, READ Public libraries are free. Couldn't Frazier's mom and he, himself, have used them? Lots of complicity here. Blaming only racism is itself racism that sells kids short without forcing them to try.

Big yip.  Be like me and don't watch.  Not that interesting anyway.  Brown builds great programs.  These players are unpaid professionals.  The NCAA is hogwash.  The system is disreputable.  Watch only Golden State Warriors games and relax.

"These athletes don't deserve to be there in the first place."  But they should have mentors to get them through.  Which is it?  Actually they do deserve to be there. But they should be encouraged, forced if necessary,  to perform academically well before college.  Yes, colleges capitalize on athletes but that capitalizing goes back way before college and includes way more than just coaches.  How many potential doctors, lawyers, teachers,cops end up on the trash heap because no one demanded they study and they did not demand that of themselves? Who knows what Frazier can accomplish?  And I don't just mean hoops, here.  And, you know what, it is not too late.  It will take a lot of work but he may not only be a great ball player but a potential teacher of other ball players, too.

It is time for the NBA and NFL to quit using "colleges" as their farm system.  It a 18 year old want to play a sport for a living, he should be able to do it, if he is good enough.  I'm pretty sure there is no degree requirement to play ball.
No degree required, but -4 years of semi-pro experience and physical growth are important.  That's what they get at college.

Don't blame Wall Street, business owners, stockholders or CEOs. Employees/workers have all the political power to refuse "buyer of labor" in the democratic society. The problem is that employees/workers don't exercise their political power in direct for a long time. Large number of Trump supporters are unfortunately those employees/workers that are comically or tragically confused.
Yes, but that was not an option. Woulda, coulda, shoulda isn't reality.

The responsibility for this, and hundreds of similar cases annually, rests with university presidents.   Unless and until they are willing to stand up to the boosters, fraudsters and tricksters who lurk at the fringes, and occupy the center, of college basketball, nothing is going to change.
Agreed. It seems that NU has not lost sight of this point. (I hope.)

The something you are missing is the development of the adolescent mind. These are not adults, their judgment is not mature -- and most of them have no economic standing to turn down what is on offer.

comments.commentBody: While most students from Babson will pursue business careers, it is far from the case that most will choose to maximize career earnings. Most of my ivy league friends went on to investment banking in the 2000s, yet I (as a Babson grad) chose to pursue a career in public education and went on to a PhD program at Columbia. While I agree that it is a dangerous trend to pursue money over, say, learning, I wouldn't belittle Babson for being Money's most visible rep for its rankings. It's highly rigorous liberal arts program is what taught me to be different from other business people and what led me to believing that I can use my skills for the greater good. Babson teaches students to think independently and entrepreneurially, and students have both been highly successful in business and elsewhere with those mindsets. And while I would love for those who do not know what Babson represents to learn more about the school other than just saying "Oh It's a business school," I realize that people will often speak in stereotypes rather than learning the truth in discourse.

W.A. Spitzer:

You build and repair infrastructure employing robots and very few human overseers. You improve public education in part by standardizing and elevating its quality through MOOCs (Massively Open Online Courses) moderated by our best educators, cutting countless less-gifted teachers out of the loop. Basic research certainly can be performed anywhere, and, in time, much of it can be automated. Healthcare and food distribution as well can be automated to a far greater degree than at present, and it's getting there. Housing? Robots again.

I can't imagine that any likely solution to the challenges I've outlined will involve LESS spending and government; but your response fails to erect a single barrier to my reasoning.

stu:

Be realistic. What college student really expects to pay off his loans?

"where Obama is cool, articulate and substantive, Trump is blustery, speaks at a third grade level, and focuses on appearances."......You may have noticed that Trump does well among the "less well educated". First we had civil rights, then women's rights, followed by gay right's. Now we see the beginning of rights for people who are "dumb and proud of it." And that is why any rational argument you make to a Trump supporter does nothing but intensify their support. And unfortunately their numbers are prodigious.

The closest to a Republican grownup I've seen in the last decade was Jon Huntsman.

Not much chance of a "Draft Huntsman" movement happening at the GOP convention...
Yawn. Another inherited billionaire that walks around pretending that he scratched his way to success.

Susan:

How many terrorists need to come in among a horde of innocent refugees to blow up a piece of a power grid, drop poison into a water reservoir or just shoot up an employee gathering in San Bernardino?

And I'm not a follower of Jesus ... or any other reasonable facsimile of Big Juju.

C Wolfe:

The editors took Indiana and used it to tar the motivations of all the Republican governors who resisted resettlement. I understand what went on in Indiana, I understand the basis of this court's decision to block Pence's efforts, but I went straight to the generality without dealing at all with this specific case. The argument isn't in Indiana, it's broader.

Trump reminds me of a description of the appealing leader, as described in Le Bon's 'The Crowd', intuitively sensing that what the crowd wants, what the crowd needs, is a loud and insistent voice repeating the same mantra again and again, appealing to the crowd's basest emotions.

Le Bon sagely noted that large aggregations of people are not attracted to the leader who is the most balanced, intelligent and sensible, but to the one who incites their feelings. Trump plays that card very well, constantly appealing to fears of invasion from Mexico and the Middle East. Fears of a government said to be corrupt and inept, of leaders he and other Republicans say have failed, like that Kenyan Barack Obama.

Americans like their leaders bold and their leadership bolder, regardless of how ludicrous or dangerous the ideas or the actions. Many like the man or woman who speaks their language, as with G.W. Bush, a man they'd like to have a beer with.

Bill Maher has said over and over that Americans are stupid, P. T. Barnum said a 'sucker is born every minute', and the great huckster of our times, 'delicious' or not, is capturing the imagination ... or should we say for far too many, our lack of it.
Might I add: "No one ever lost a dime underestimating the intelligence of the American public"  H.L. Mencken

Good column Maureen, you show directly what hypocrites the GOP has fostered.

How they said one thing and now contradict themselves when it Comes to Trump. He has brought out the worst in them, they can see the end of their confidence game, Trump has made it plain just what fabricators of the truth they are.

The whole bunch of them engaging in self delusion, trying to convince themselves what wonderful people they are. Along with that their enablers are just as bad. Fro instance in the WSJ Friday 2/4 Bobby Jindal writes "President Obama Created Donal Trump." He goes on to say things like President Obama created the rancor he now rails against, by not working with congress. This is just one of many columns demeaning Mr. Obama that have been a constant theme of the WSJ. The only difference between them and Limbaugh slander, is they are written by people with a better English education.

Frequently I hear people who are right wing oriented. Their comment on how the country is being run is composed of this slander promulgated by the conservatives.

By the way, just what is a conservative? It seems as far as I can tell, whatever these nihilists think it is. Everyone from biker gangs, religious nuts, small business men, and neer do well wage earners, all with a ring in their nose so they can be led around by likes of Trump.

By the way, just what is a conservative? It seems as far as I can tell, whatever these nihilists think it is. Everyone from biker gangs, religious nuts, small business men, and neer do well wage earners, all with a ring in their nose so they can be led around by likes of Trump

And you accuse us of promulgating slander? Whose the hypocrite?

BTW I'm not a religous nut, don't have a nose ring, tattoos or a Harley.
You Sir however are self-important prig who should understand that the views of others ( even the neer do well wage earners) have the same value and right to be expressed as your excrement does.

What is a conservative? Authoritarian.

That is the personality trait that unites the disparate groups you mention.
Disingenuous Douthat deserves to be dismissed with a dollop of Trumpian disdain.

Is Kristof incapable of seeing what Trump represents? He is merely a vessel for the heartfelt bitterness many Americans are feeling over our failed foreign entanglements.

Just think:
> We have over sold our economy to foreign slavers for a surfeit of cheap goods at the expense of gainful employment for many.
> We have over stayed our welcome overseas by naively expecting our exceptional form of democracy to be welcomed with open arms.
> We have over extended our military with our interventionism and protection of our alleged allies, these efforts being ungratefully spurned by many who could not only care less, but are turning against us and each other.

For good or bad, expect this country to be entering a period of isolationism with elements of nativism and xenophobia.

Given that, Kristof is dreaming if he thinks Americans are willing to continue our post-WW II era of internationalism. Rather, expect a post-2016 America to be more akin to post-WW I where the nation rejected the League of Nations and turned inward.

This country will continue to be a beacon on a hill. Only now, that beacon will be guarded behind the walls of fortress America, its gates closed to many.

Posted: Round Midnight

Keep spinning for Clinton, New York Times. Yes, Clinton won Louisiana "commandingly", but Sanders' victories in Kansas and Nebraska, coming on the heels of his win in Minnesota, suggest that he may give Clinton pause in the Midwest. This is significant for the general election, as the Midwest is generally more important for Democrats than is the South.

My take is that while Cinton retains the Democratic lead, Sanders will cause her discomfort into the spring. If the Clinton e-mail investigation grows hotter, all bets are off.

Why is Hillary's win "commanding" at 71 Percent and his win in Kansas at 68 percent isn't mentioned. Is a three point difference all that much more wonderful? Bias, just bias. There is nothing more sincere than sincere denial.
All bets are off if it's a Trump win for the White House.
Kansas and Nebraska are not Illinois and Ohio. They are states with a 90% white population that hold caucuses. So far that us Sanders' only recipe for winning, and it is not sufficient.
Its not that Trump is so good.   Its that everyone else is a neo-con jerk.   Except Sanders, of course.
Richard, while you are at it, blame the political demise of John Boehner and Eric Cantor on Obama.  When spinning fables, the more fantastic, the better, don't you think?

Don't kid yourself, Trump is shrewd and calculating. He might have inherited a goodly sum of money, but he has parlayed that into becoming a $billionaire while taking the chumps for a ride. Worse yet, he seems to be able to get new chumps when the older ones realize they have been taken, and drop out.

As the saying goes "There's a sucker born every minutes,"and he knows how to mine them.

If you are a Republican and actually find yourself *relieved* to see Ted Cruz winning caucuses and primaries--well, that may be a sign your Grand Old Party is out to grand old lunch.

Cruz is a man, remember, who can be seen on YouTube at a shooting range firing a machine gun with bacon wrapped around the barrel. Don't be fooled by the man's academic pedigree, as so many people were by George W. Bush's academic pedigree. Cruz is only a slightly less ridiculous human being than Donald Trump.
Worse, Ted does not adhere to the principle of separation of church and state. He would turn us into a theocracy if he could, with himself as the savior, of coirse.
Cruz may be a "slightly less ridiculous human being than Donald Trump", but he's just as dangerous ...there's a reason for the 'Separation of Church and State'.

Test scores should only be a side thought. I have two successful daughters both with graduate degrees. My eldest had the same 4.5 GPA with multiple AP classes as my youngest daughter. The difference was daughter 1 had timed test anxiety and scored just over average at 1200 old SAT while daughter 2, although a perfectionist also, scored 250 points higher. My first got turned down at Amherst while daughter 2 was feted there as well as at several Ivies, one of which she graduated from. Both equally succeeded, one in medicine and one as a budget analyst, and both are highly successful in their professions. Perhaps universities should look at recommendations as well as face to face interviews to gain insight. Weigh these as importantly as test scores. Mine were lucky to have drive and support; others just as talented but perhaps from less advantaged backgrounds need a more humanistic holistic look as they apply to college.
Trump's work is incomplete: he hasn't yet made a monkey of Dowd.  Yes, she has it coming.

This is a perfect example of the failure of the 'green check' approved commenter system. . This is a meaningless and vaguely offensive comment that contributes nothing to the conversation. Can we please eliminate the green check comment system and let all comments be moderated?  Thank you!

Arun Gupta: Maureen makes a monkey of herself; she needs no help.  She makes Hamlet appear decisive - in particular, her 2012 presidential election columns waffled between the two candidates.  President Obama came into office with the worst recession in 80 years, two disasterous wars, no progress on climate change, and has had to contend with concerted efforts to demean , discredit and block him. The country is better off than it was, but Dowd continues her cheap shots.  She has no credibility, especially after she ate an entire cannabis-infused candy bar and seemed surprised at the negative effects.

Maureen has been doing a fine job of that herself as of late. Her ceaseless haranguing of the President does not offer insight, or even a counter view. It's just misplaced anger. One suspects Maureen, and her Tea Party brother Kevin, are no longer so far apart in their beliefs.  I loved re-reading the opening statement from Kevin's latest diatribe this past November, "While liberals and the mainstream media may regard the myriad Republican presidential candidates as a “house of crazies,” I see an embarrassment of riches. It is the ultimate irony that the Republican field blows the Democrats away on one of their favorite topics — diversity.". Apparently, they also "blow the Democrats away" on discussing genitalia size. Gotta love them Dowds.

I can only conclude that there are a considerable number of Americans who feel disenfranchised in order to believe Trump is a viable candidate.  Hilary spoke in Michigan about Nabisco who received tax breaks in Illinois yet cut six hundred American jobs and moved them off-shore.  Also Johnson controls who lobbied for and was rescued by the auto bailout yet merged with Tyco in a tax-inversion deal to avoid paying U.S. taxes.

The unions were the reason those companies left the USA - they wouldn't negotiate and in the face of globalization these companies ind they only way to survive is to move to the land of power labor costs. The Unions are just as culpable as anyone....

Hillary spoke about Nabisco only because Trump has been speaking about it and Carrier Corp moving jobs from Indiana to Mexico.  Hillary is late to the party and only now talking about it because she is playing not to lose.  Trump will eat Hillary alive on her shift on the trade deals.

Remember these incredibly accomplished students are being judged for decisions they made at 15, 16 and 17 years of age. Good for them for working hard and choosing wisely but this is disconcerting. Such little room to fail. Woe to those who won't hit their stride until their 20's.

Over the past few days, I think I have read enough frustrated Bernie supporter comments (my personal thoughts included), and enough NYT articles that I still swear slant the wording to Hillary Clinton's favor. I am glad I was able to vote for Bernie in my state's primary on Tuesday, and I am doing my best to convince myself to vote for Hillary in November should the premonitions end up true. I would really like to see Bernie stay in and be represented well, unlike some Clinton supporters who seem to believe, and hope that he will get demolished in some upcoming major primaries/caucuses. I think the stronger Bernie shows, the more Hillary will be pressed to address certain issues and policies.

As for the Republicans, I am far more concerned with someone like Cruz representing the US as president than I am with Trump as I find deeply "religious" individuals in power to be a very scary thing. However, and possibly following from that very thing, I also find the probability of Cruz winning a presidential general election considerably lower than I do Trump.

Just for the record. I've read many comments over the past days of reporting, but don't recall many comments where Clinton supporters outright "HOPE" that Sanders gets "demolished in some upcoming major primaries/ caucuses".
Look. There might be different ideologies between the candidates, but they're still not as bad as the Republicans......yet.
And as far as the Republicans are concerned, there's not one I would want to see in the White House.

Right you are about Cruz-a religious fanatic, and absolutely inflexible.

Trump is a conduit for forces out there that are fed up with it all-he could be pretty bad, he might surprise everyone, but as greatest function will be in over turning the whole system, which is not such a bad idea.

By the way George W. Bush scared me a lot more than Trump does
I, too, wonder how Sanders is going to lure minority voters from Trump.
If you want to rain on Bernie's parade, go ahead. Bernie is a once in a lifetime opportunity for this country. Too bad you don't recognize it and are unable to jump on board.
Interesting the dichotomy between the Readers' Picks and the NYT Picks. Listen to your readers once in a while, NYT, if you want us to listen to you!
NYT Readers are on the whole well informed and capable of making up their own minds regardless of the "Picks".

Diane, the NYT is a news source. The editors try to pick the best comments (most clearly articulated) that cover various viewpoints, They do not select by percentage of comments, in other words, a certain percentage for Bernie.

Let me guess, you're a Bernie supporter! Because you all are more cranky than he is.
Interesting the dichotomy between the reader's picks and the actual voting totals. Hillary has won 60% of them to Bernie's 40%. Flame off.

Childish?Have you been watching the reporting of this election? the media is blacklisting Sanders as much as they can. These reporters are only following orders, yes they are smart and well informed but they are not in charge of programming. Sanders is largely being ignored. He is a direct challenge to the networks. Just about every pundit they bring on is a Hillary supporter or from the Washington Post. They play what literally is a Hillary advertisement all day long. It's called one dimensional journalism. Hardly ever is there a rebuttal by the Sanders supporters. Time Warner is a major contributor to Mrs Cliinton's campaign. Jeesh, follow the money.

comments.commentBody: No need. Kitty Kelley said it better than I ever could.

Once again, Maggie Smith and Penelope Wilton steal the show. A wedding (predictable), the Bates Babe (predictable), Mary preggers (predictable), but  kidnapping a man from his family for romance--bravo!
Romance is a lovely excuse, but they were definitely out to rescue the man!
Not to mention Catherine in the 1973 West End production of Pippin.

Very nice final wrap for Louis Bayard.  The real drinking game is how many times does a character in the Crawley family say:  let's go through or let's go up.  As Jay65 (do not understand how my moniker got changed by NYTimes), I was happy to be right in predicting one central fact and one that is merely a wisp of a hint:  Bertie came back; Tom and Miss Evans will get together very soon.  I learned that a Marquis outranks an Earl, or does one.  What precisely did Mary inherit from Matthew:  not the title of course, not Downton itself in 1925, so, merely his personalty, securities etc?   Patricia Hodge not only played the adulterous wife in Betrayal, but also the smart female barrister partner in Rumpole of the Bailey, no?  I watched the fund-raiser afterward:  character most missed from the Memorial segment (cannot believe they had Vera Bates in there):  Sybil of course.  Goodbye to All That.

As Jay65 (do not understand how my moniker got changed by NYTimes),

Talk to the moniker maker, Monica. She makes monikers.

The British rank is: King/Queen > Prince/Princess > Duke/Duchess > Marquess/Marchioness > Earl/Countess > Viscount/Viscountess > Baron/Baroness > Baronet

So Edith, Marchioness of Hexham, outranked her parents and her sister. Mary was married to, lost and then bore the next male heir to Downton Abbey, who will become the new Earl of Grantham if he survives beyond Robert's death, but I believe she at least retained the honorific "the Lady Mary Talbot" even after after marrying Talbot, since the daughter of an earl who marries a commoner still retains that courtesy.

Thanks (got my old title back!).  Does anyone remember if the Dowager Countess was herself the daughter of an Earl -- she did refer to her own father in the last episode.  Assuming Lord Robert survives, does anyone know what would happen, upon Robert's eventual death, to the estate following the reform of British property law a few years later?  Mary's son with Matthew would become an Earl, but would she get the house and land?  Unfortunately young Master George is the right age to be a junior officer in WWII or an RAF pilot.  Hope poor old Barrow doesn't wind up with a chart of his young charges who don't survive (as in another English show:  To Serve Them etc).

Nicely tidied up. I was singing Auld Lang Syne along with the staff. I will miss them all.

Only thing I could have done without was Lady Rose giving life advice to Robert. Isn't she 19?

Thank you Mr. Bayard.

Actually, I think this was very characteristic of Rose's sweet, resourceful and helpful nature.

Recall her lightning-quick bailout of her father-in-law when his former mistress showed up?

In addition, the delicious plot to steal back the Prince of Wales' letter?

I was so glad Rose made it into the finale.
To me, Rose always seemed to over-intrude, and I didn't like it this time any more than all the others.  It became understandable why her mother came down on her so much.

I was definitely taken aback by Rose's presumed role with Robert.  That, with his gosh-shucks reaction was so hokey.  Not long ago, Rose was the juvenile delinquent in the house and in London.  They had to drag her out of bars, etc. to keep her from ruining her own London season.  For her to come barging in from across the ocean, no longer a household member, supplanting the daughters and all to undertake to set the head of the house straight ... really obnoxious.  Actually, it was the same cheek she always demonstrated.

Anna never confronted Lady Mary with her requirements for keeping the whole business about Mr. Pamook under wraps.   I'd been looking  forward to that scene all these years.  But thanks to you, Mr. Bayard, and the rest of your community of followers.
As a lady's maid, Anna was not in a position to demand requirements for keeping such a secret. Loyalty and discretion are inherent to her job.

If I were the writer of this article I would be embarrassed to show my face in the news room. Why? Because I obviously missed the story.

The story is, what's this kid, Fraizier, who's obviously no Einstein, doing in a physics class in High School. Solve that problem an you just about solve every other "problem" hyperbolicated in the article.

I thought I read this article fairly carefully. Somehow I missed the paragraph where Mr. Frazier takes some responsibility for his own academic and personal failures.
Coach Brown has a sleazy history which SMU was apparently comfortable with. No tears for the school or the team.
But the bottom line remains: we are all responsible for our own behavior and choices. This includes the players. Otherwise we're just patronizing and profiling them.

In the last few years, the NCAA has been disproportunately penal in acadenic misconduct cases, no matter if isolated, as the Fraiser matter, a single incident involving just one player. In Brown's case, the NCAA neither found Brown complicite in the act itself, nor for failing to report the incident ito the proper authorities, which he did. They punished him with a 9 game penalty for reporting the incident belatedly, and for lying during an NCAA interrogation , and then correcting his answer after consulting his arrorney .

Brown is not the only Big Time coach to get slammed for academic fraud violations recently. I don't mean to imply Brown was unfairly singled out (although I'd like to know who dropped the dime, and whether the dime included allegations of widespread violations for which there was no proof)

Either way, it seems undeniable that the NCAA has been quite vigilant and punative in recent times with respect to academic fraud, except if it's epidenic and the violator UNC ( wink).

My question is this. Is this vigilance essential to the NCAA's insistence that players who are obliged to work year-round are not emplouees, because they are STUDENT athletes, whatever that means, a claim that there seems to be consensus here is pure myth.

Without that vigilance, the NCAA's postion becomes a one-footed stool, right. So, is this more proof that the NCAA needs to go? "Not a soup question, now is it."

The article doesn't mention the role of concussions in snowboarding's fall in popularity. A lifetime skier, my concussion while learning to snowboard cost me a half-year's wages and took a toll on my family. (Yes, I was wearing a helmet). When you fall on a snowboard, it HURTS. The sport may be dangerous at any speed.
And dangerous to other skiers around them....

Sorry, and glad you lived through it.  My son compressed three vertebrae while snowboarding.  Still impacts his work ten years later.  He was not a beginner either.  He had skied and snowboarded for ten years before the accident.  Skied like a wild man and was never hurt.  Not even a muscle strain.
Though I am sorry to hear about your injury, it's tough to say that people choose skiing vs snowboarding based on risk of concussions. Wouldn't both present an equal risk?

Weather (and ridiculously high lift tickets) has definitely been an issue.

The bigger deal for snowboarding companies is lack of technology advancement. If you have modern boots with one of several types of speed laces, you're set (last 10 years). A modern board (high quality - 15 years), you're set. Bindings have gotten better recently (last 5 years you're set). Sure if you're boarding 100 days/year your replacement rate will be somewhat quicker. But most people are boarding less than 10 days/year and only need new equipment every 5-10 years (with lots of ebay used equipment available too).

I feel bad for the pros left out in the cold, but right now pro snowboarding (2-3 runs/day) has little relevance to the boards, boots, and bindings recreational boarders use for a 6 hour snow day.

the learning curve to snowboard is a fraction of what it takes to ski.

that was and is still the main attraction.

2 edges vs. 4

Not for me.  I ski raced for years when I was a kid, but when snowboarding came along, I found I enjoyed it more than skiing.  Maybe everyone is different, though I think the learning curve is shorter.
Ski touring and ski mountaineering is where it's at!
The same thing happened with sailboarding around 20 years ago. The equipment market always gets flooded when a new sport springs up from nowhere.

Kiteboarding came along and made windsurfing obsolete. The article doesn't explain why snowboarding declined and why skiing had a resurgence. They mention the lack of snow in the West from the drought, but wouldn't that have impacted skiing as well?

No one to blame here but the companies themselves. For years they've marketed the sport exclusively to 12-14 year olds looking to do extreme tricks. They never stopped to think that those kids would eventually grow up and not want noodley freestyle boards adorned with often insulting, adolescent graphics. If they expand their market segment and design equipment for where and how people actually ride--and that can keep up with the performance of modern, shaped skis--they might have a chance to keep the sport relevant.

For a 12-14 year old nothing kills off a lifestyle product faster than seeing your parents use it. Eeeeeewwwwww !
Snowboarding has been around long enough for that to happen.

Jones, Burton's Family Tree line, Gentem, United Shapes, Korua, Hightide, Venture, Prior, and more are all lines dedicated to making "all mountain" & freeride specific snowboards.

also, you're welcome for your modern shaped-ski performance.

When was the last time you looked at snowboard equipment? Every company now offers boards for every type of rider - new, young, older, everyone. Open your eyes and look around instead of typing what you want to believe!

totally lame, subjective sport
more of a hobby really
just skateboarding on ice

Skiing and snowboarding didn't used to be luxury sports. In the 70's we used to stay in a ski club bunkhouse in Vermont for $2 per night. Real estate development made a few people wealthy but ruined the sport for all but the very rich by jacking up the costs beyond reach for most people. Lift tickets are over $100/ day. Lodging is higher than that. The equipment is way overpriced.

Forget it. It's just not that much fun to drive that far and spend that much for a few runs under what are often poor weather and snow conditions. It's too bad because it was fun when it didn't cost a fortune. The whole industry jumped the shark.

He's a strong centrist candidate that may have retained a lot of votes on the far left, from people that cannot forgive Clinton for her many blunders, seeming insincerity and/or for the fact that her last name is Clinton.

To lead is to make the occasional blunder. To sit on the sidelines as Bernie has done for thirty odd years, that isn't leadership, nor is it gaining any clear understanding of what leadership actually entails.

"To lead is to make the occasional blunder."
Please, to let us be sure, that assertion was in reference to...?

Leigh: The occasional blunder? The occasional blunder? She voted for the Iraq War. I'd call that more than a blunder. I'd call her vote a colossal failure, a complete collapse of wisdom. In the months leading up to that vote, I read several New Yorker articles where high-level military officials and inspectors were quoted as saying, "There are no Weapons of Mass Destruction. There is no link to 9/11." Somebody was paying attention, because half of the Democratic Senators voted against that war, but all the Democratic Senators with presidential aspirations (Kerry, Edwards and Clinton) voted for it because they didn't want to appear weak on defense, like the Democrats who voted against the first Gulf War. She voted for that war, not because she actually believed there were WMD's and a link, but because she thought it was the best path to the White House. She was wrong. Her horrible, wrong-headed vote helped pave the way to horror, debt and catastrophe. And it cost her the White House in 2008. Will it cost her again this year?

These numbers get discussed and analyzed so frequently, and the results so ignored, that to cover them again seems pointless.

From the beginning of WWII until 1945 our debt-to-GDP rose from 50% to 117%, and increase of 203%, but for every period until Ronald Reagan, debt-to-GDP fell even while the national debt expanded. Despite expected periodic recessions the U.S. overall flourished as infrastructure was constructed, schools and colleges built, and government investment in academic and federal research, and space exploration, expanded.

Excepting a 4 year period during the Nixon - Ford administration the ratio of deb-to-GDP fell the whole time, showing that government spending was healthy for the economy, NOT TRICKLE DOWN tax cuts and austerity policy.

And here we are with yet another plea to increase spending on the public, repeatedly shown to work, in the face of the very kind of moronic, irresponsible economic and fiscal policy repeatedly shown to fail.

Put it this way, Republicans labored for years to show there had to be a connection between Hillary Clinton and tragedy in Benghazi when no such evidence exists.

Yet supplied with an inexhaustible data showing the constructive effects of expanded government spending world governments try repeatedly, in the absence of data, to show that Reaganomics just has to work.

Even the IMF has shown it doesn't ("Causes and Consequences of Income Inequality," June 15, 2015).

If everyone is a philosopher then we might as well say no one is a philosopher because it amounts to the same thing. Philosophy is not just about asking questions it's about asking questions with a profound commitment to the truth no matter where that truth leads, and in order for anyone to call themselves a philosopher, they must at the very least be acquainted with that which has been common to all Philosophy since Aristotle and that is the method of logically valid  inference. It may very well be that doing this is in fact something that is natural to all people. But if that is the case then it behooves those who believe so to explain why that method is clearly not followed by the vast majority of people.

I think a certain amount of cherry picking is going on here.

To be sure there have been eminent researchers in other disciplines who have been philosophically inclined in their thinking. Soames names some. Whether this was a necessary condition of their contributions is at best unclear (since it does not follow that had they not exhibited philosophical proclivities that they would not have made the contributions they actually did).

In the 20th century at least, philosophers typically had little knowledge of other disciplines (hence the "cherry picking"charge). What they did was to use their intelligence to manufacture a priori arguments and theories that bore no relation to empirical research. Not merely that, most of them were openly disparaging of many of the efforts of empirical researchers on grounds of supposed lack of analytical rigor.

Stunningly, the basis of this discounting was an unconditional faith in the epistemological efficacy of their own reflective thought, unaided by the empirical theories of the period. Thought experiments, idiosyncratic analytical intuitions and arguments rooted in"folk psychology" or "common sense physics" (i.e. that which is accessible from everyday life), etc were the intellectual currency of the day - and that has still not changed that much. To be sure there are some exceptions and as mentioned, Soames identifies a few of these practitioners.

But these still are exceptions - and a priori wheel spinning is not good enough.

@pogo No but it is very very easy to get a doctor to prescribe you oxys, you only have to say you "have pain". It's morally wrong for those doctors to knowingly supply addicts with drugs but they do it because they get kickbacks from the pharmaceutical companies.

Dale Huckeby. I'm sorry to say that you are mistaken about the non-existence of physics in the 17th century. There was a great deal of work on physics, with early work by Sr. G. G. and culminating in the work of Sir I. N., both names you will recognize. It was not called "Physics" and it wasn't conceived as a separate subject, but don't let names mislead you.

Thanks, R&E.
I only watched the clip now, coming home late from a day out of town. Magnificent. I had never seen it. Thank you for  posting it!

Don't you think it worth mentioning that most of the states Clinton has won are almost certain to stay red in November? And that Sanders is winning the states Dems need to win in November, and outpolling her dramatically among independents everywhere? Still think she's most "electable"?

The comment that Clinton had seemed to have locked up the Democratic race last Tuesday is laughable now, but it was also way out of line last week. The idea that superdelegates will stay with Clinton if she falls measurably behind in the popular vote is very questionable. Adding them now to her delegate total makes sense if you're trying to create a perception of inevitability for the candidate you've endorsed. Wake up, Times analysts. She's not inevitable any more than she was in 2008.
Thanks for this perceptive comment; as Yogi Berra once said, "It Ain't Over Till It's Over"
This argument assumes that Clinton would lose the states Sanders has won.  She wouldn't.

Yes, and it's not just the NYT. CNN was showing Clinton's combined pledged-delegate + super-delegate total every few minutes yesterday evening, with little explanation, if any. It makes Bernie's situation seem dire, while it really isn't at all.

For the record, as of Wednesday March 9th, Hillary has 760 pledged delegates to Bernie's 546 pledged delegates, a substantial lead but hardly insuperable. Hers come almost entirely from states no Democrat can win in November, while Bernie's come from states Democrats must win in November. Hillary does well with demographics that always lean Democratic, while Bernie excels with independents and younger voters, who can go either way. The 461 unpledged "super delegates" -- the party establishment -- can vote for either candidate at convention time.

If Bernie can win a few more big, traditionally Democratic states -- New York and California spring to mind -- and comes into the convention with momentum... Hmmmm....

Well, I guess the Democrats, in that case, could choose self-destruction and insist on Hillary, or they could go for a Bernie-led progressive landslide that just might lead to a Democratic Congress.

Not Impossible. Could happen.

We should all be alarmed that Don Trump has swept the southern states, home of black hatred, won by a bigot focusing that culture of bigotry at new victims, the Hispanics. How else could a man from the Northeast dominate a region so opposed to the north for such a long time. Don Trump is appealing to hatred and anger. Everyone should be alarmed at the rise of Don Trump. Thank you brave Republican leaders and Congressmen who recognized this growing grave danger to our nation and the world, but it may be too late.

The mass media helped create Trump's momentum, and they perpetuate his
nonsense with all the free air time he gets. So they will have to do a lot in the general election to make up for that massive malpractice.

does no one see the irony of everyone saying "Trump NEVER lies! Trump never lies! he really IS the racist fascist he portrays on tv! he would NEVER lie or scam to seal a deal".

news flash:

he's lying. he's not building any wall nor rounding up 12 million immigrants.

he's doing what he always does: playing suckers. (GOP voters.)

and he's succeeding at it.

even the GOP doesn't care, as long as he's not the dead and failed status quo.

Either Democrat's chance of carrying Mississippi and/or South Carolina...they made a movie about that...

"Less than Zero"

Finally, the NYT breaking headline got it right: "Bernie Sanders won the Democratic primary in Michigan in a significant upset over Hillary Clinton".

But of course, the Times continues to spin for Clinton, noting her strong support among black voters. That is accurate, up to a point: Clinton has triumphed in the South due to strong black support, tonight in Mississippi (where she took all demographic groups) and in Louisiana over the weekend.

But the Times fails to point out that Sanders is outperforming Clinton in other regions as shown by his wins in Kansas, Nebraska, Maine and Michigan. Sanders is also making inroads among minorities. A Washington Post analysis of the Michigan results concludes that although Clinton won Michigan's black vote by 20 points, she dominated less strongly than expected. As a result, she lost the state.

The Times also fails to mention that Sanders overcame significant polling deficits to win Michigan, a sign that he is gaining momentum.

Is it possible that Clinton's deficits in the Midwest, in the North and among white voters will prove to be a weakness? Unfortunately, the Times does not even raise that possibility for its readers.

Well stated. CNN, CBS, NYTimes all in the can for Hillary.
CBSN's last night coverage of the caucus repeatedly ran videos of the failure that is Rubio, while ignoring Bernie. Shameful.
And that makes me wonder how many other things they distort.  I am very disapointed  in the Times

significant upset !!!
it's just getting by, eeking by

Bernie Sanders49.8%65
Hillary Clinton48.3%68

Close study of the county-by-county results in Michigan makes it look better for both Bernie and Trump.

Bernie was strong all over the map, and had a good 40% even in weak spots.

Hillary did well only among blacks. She did not do overwhelmingly well even with them. Her blue spots on the map are isolated in a sea of Bernie counties, and even those blue spots were only 60:40 for her.

Meanwhile Trump was strong all over the map.

Cruz did well only on the Lake Michigan coastline, our own little Bible Belt.

Kasich did well only in the university towns and in a narrow suburban strip north of Detroit that is our educated flight from Detroit proper. He was unknown elsewhere as was Cruz away from Lake Michigan.

Rubio disappeared as completely as Jeb. He's not there anywhere. Just single digits.

Bernie and Trump did not just carry Michigan, they both did well in all of the state. Their opponents had only isolated spots of support, and even that was not overwhelming.

In a very real way, both Bernie and Trump thoroughly and truly won Michigan, all of it.

What Clinton learned (hat tip to Ms. Brazile) is that black voters in the North, especially the young, are not as obedient as black voters in the South. She's going to find herself in a world of hurt now that the southern states are mostly behind us. She also learned tonight that too many people think she'll say anything to win, and they discounted her phony flip-flop on the TPP.

What the media learned tonight is not to rely on polls or on received wisdom shilled by access journalists.
Hop: your "obedient" statement is just offensive
hop sing -- Your phrase "access journalists" captures a very large part of the problem with reporting this election. It is how the two party machines are manipulating reporting.

I wonder how many others took this until recently banned drug - I am amazed at all the whining that she took something that was legal for so long. I think that if at this point in her carrier - if she wanted to truly game the system that she would have used a masking agent (if available) and would not continue taking something that would be detected.

Started with ORPHANED, and NATURE PRESERVES came fairly quickly, but I forgot there was supposed to be a theme until after I finished the puzzle. I was that caught up in the plethora of interesting words and clues and slightly chuffed at getting LADY MARMALADE from just LADE. Tickled by ID mail (which I didn't get until I had _OISE). Favorite was Robin Hood's target, THE RICH. [thwangggg]

Holy smokes!

Hillary was supposed to win by 20 points. The Bern man won by two. Here's what I think happened.

Bernie keeps hammering about bad trade deals. The upper midwest has been decimated by offshoring. That message rings true to the voters. They have suffered terribly from factory closings.

Bernie's stand on the gun issue is a brilliant move. The upper midwest, Kansas and Missouri included, have large numbers of hunters. I have known many who like to go hunting. These people do not walk around with pistols or hoard assault weapons. They often keep their rifles locked in gun safes. Hunting is a family and community tradition. The NRA does not represent them. All they want is to be left alone. Bernie's position is viewed by them as "reasonable". That is music to their ears.

Once out of the deep south, Bernie should keep racking up wins. He could win Ohio. He could win in Missouri. Next Tuesday, I'll get to cast my ballot.

The western states should also go for him as well as the big northeast states also.

Trump will win the GOP, no question. Bernie has always polled better than Hillary against Trump.

We have ourselves a real race! This is exciting and just the thing to wake up the electorate and get people to go to the polls in Nov.

The old rules no longer apply. We are all fed up, both left and right. Anything can happen now.

Interesting perspective. The AR-15 type rifle, often dismissed in the NYT as an "assault weapon" is the most popular rifle for hunting and target shooting in the Midwest. Having one at home is about as surprising as owning a Ford truck. Bernie's less hysterical position about guns in the past may be helping gun owning democrats choose him.

It was a pleasure to read a comment so reflective of the American voter's thinking. We are, indeed, completely fed up with both Democrat and Republican establishment politics and the corporate media that only reports what both parties would like the electorate to hear. My twist on Gandi's quote for the press and the two parties alike is: First we believe you, then we suspect you and finally we ignore you. And that is the real story in this election. Better start covering it!

Republican Eligible Voter Turnout: 17.3% . . . Democrat Eligible Voter Turnout: 11.7% . . . (so far) . . . "we are all fed up" I beg to differ with your opinion! How is that a true picture of the General Election of 130+ million eligible voters? These primary results have no real meaning beyond determining the final two candidates . . . so much for an"angry electorate!!"

I don't know how anyone can support someone who voted against TARP (and yes in the end when it mattered most, he voted with the republicans to block the funds that were needed for the auto bailout).

Love it or hate it, the lessons of the Great Depression showed us that TARP and the auto bailout were very necessary and helped to diminish the scope of the collapse which as history showed us could have been even far far worse.

Talk about a lack of judgement on the part of Sanders (who by the way did vote for regime change on a couple of occasions, even in Iraq back in the earlier days of conflicts).

Bernie, who certainly is honest about how he feels about his ideas (some of them good), is very dishonest when it comes to himself and his voting record. It is not really something to be proud of in regards to some very serious occasions.

It is quite scary to thing what would have happened had he been in charge during or right after the collapse in 2008 - another Great Depression is quite likely.
Trump, Sanders! Trump, Sanders! Trump, Sanders! The American people have spoken. Special interest groups are doomed.

Did the writers read their own article? Or maybe because there were two writers they each only read and wrote half:

"But Mr. Sanders has yet to show that he can prevail in several of the populous, racially diverse swing states that the Democratic nominee will seek to win in November, while Mrs. Clinton has done so in states like Nevada and Virginia."

Last time I checked Michigan was pretty diverse. Did it turn all white between the polls on Monday and the primaries today?

I used to live in Michigan in the mid-90's. The cities are either diverse or majority African American, but some of the rural areas were very white.  There was a population of Hispanic migrant farm workers and I'm sure that has grown, but I don't what percentage are U.S. citizens over 18 and therefore eligible to vote. Michigan as a whole maybe diverse, but not necessarily the rural areas.

We'll see how great an American he is in the general election campaign.  If he wins the primaries he has to win the general.  If he loses the primaries he has to go all in 110% with Hillary.   I'm withholding my judgement.
Cranky old white men have been running things for far too long.  Not voting for Sanders.

While I share your concern, Hillary is just not well loved.

In Michigan...feeling the Bern!

Hillary is in a lot more trouble than the annoyingly assertive media declarations of victory would have everyone believe. The south is not going to vote  democratic in November.  It will vote for Trump. Her victories in the south are not a sign of strength especially considering Sanders victories across every northern and midwestern state so far (except Massachusetts.)
Which he didnt lose by much; just like he was competitive in Iowa, which was claimed as a flat-out victory by the Clinton campaign and its sycophants.
So Hillary won in Mississippi,  Georgia,  etc.  So what?  Those states will go 80/20 Republican in November.  Things will really be up in the air after Bernie takes California.

Bernie's "revolution" cannot actually happen unless he sweeps progressives to power in at least some of those states you casually dismiss as meaningless, not to mention that he would need to align with progressives to remove many *Democratic* incumbents, too.

There's no sign of that wave happening.
now would be the time for Elizabeth Warren to come out as Bernie's VP.

Black votes, schmack votes, who cares? It's not like they can do anything for Bernie anyway.

Is that really how you see it? How depressing. I will be happy to give my vote to A DEMOCRAT. Either one.

We are used to dividing people into Democrats and Republicans, but the real division this year is between people who feel left behind by all the standard rhetoric on job creation, trade, and so on, and those who are benefiting from it. Those who are for the status quo and those who want a change.

As a Bernie Sanders supporter, I abhor Trump, but Trump's supporters are worth listening to. I mean really listening.
Tet Offensive style victory for Bernie.
You know who won that battle, right?

...a tactical defeat at enormous cost and shocked North Vietnam with their massive casualty rate?
'
Well, the Sanders campaign *did* invest heavily in Michigan, without getting a substantial edge in delegates considering that there are no winner-take-all states in the Democratic primary, so perhaps there's something to that analogy.

We don't need to do anything except support the best candidate in the primaries. Once they're over, we'll support the party, but Sanders has proven himself to be a worthy candidate and so no bandwagon yet.
Welcome to Rage Against the Machine.
duh they are democrats as well
We'll see 'bout that.

The Sanders message is sincere and directly responsive to the issues that most impact us.  That is what makes him stand apart from Mrs. Clinton.  I listen to him and am convinced he wants to right our course; I listen to her and am sure she wants to live in the White House again.

I'm not even sure it's LEGAL for Hillary and Bill to take over the White House again.

think about it:

it clearly defeats the entire point of term limits, does it not?

had they (back then) considered that famous presidents could run their now-famous wives to skirt the LAW, they would've included this in the actual Bill of Rights amendment, no question about it.

if media were honest, we'd be having this conversation.

Funny, I listen to Clinton and hear how she wants to make the lives of ordinary Americans better and how she plans to do it. I listen to Bernie and hear a guy who knows what we should do, but without any details on how to accomplish it.

Of course she wants to live in the White House. They all do. Because that's where Presidents live and they ALL want to be President. Attributing only Clinton's ambition to just "wanting to live in the White House" comes off as sexist and dismissive. She has a long history of public service.

I am sorry you missed my point.  I recognize Secretary Clinton's record and if she is the nominee I will be voting for her.  However, I do question her sincerity and I think Senator Sanders is an open book.  I have listened to his detailed plans and I support them.  Regarding "sexist" and "dismissive," though I accept it somehow sounds this way to you, neither is my feeling.  We can otherwise agree to disagree about which of these candidates best speaks our interests.
