comments.commentBody:
these are 2 questions that bother me about Bernie. Is there any way to get an answer?
1. In the case of free tuition what will control the money? If it is the states what is to prevent states from controlling the class material? If the federal government how will that be addressed?
2. It seems to me that getting free health care and free tuition will be difficult to get thru congress. What are you willing to give in order to get the needed votes?

Mary Ann – there are 34 seats up for election in November; 24 are Republicans running for reelection. Democrats need to gain 5 of those seats.
Illinois has a good shot at picking up a Dem seat with Tammy Duckworth.
(btw, our current Repub Sen isn't one of the bad guys, but he's a Repub, so we've gotta vote him out.) This appears to be doable.
GOTV!

Chris- the other economically advanced countries do not attempt to act as the world's policeman, either.  If we finally relinquish that role we could probably cut our military expenditures by at least a half, and what the resulting billions could pay for in the civilian sector would boggle the mind! And it wouldn't hurt to return to the tax structure of the Eisenhower years, where the highest marginal rate was about 90%.  Would any of this get past congress? Of course not.  The Rs have an unbreakable gerrymandered stranglehold on the House. Perhaps we should petition the UN to oversee our elections.  There seems to be no other way out of this intractable situation.

trk, he is not saying "free" health care.  He is saying we could, and should, have the same kind of health care that most Western nations enjoy.  Medicare is not free.  It's not very expensive, but not free.  If it's open to all, it will be much cheaper for those not yet in retirement, but not free.  And, yes, taxes will have to be raised.  There's no free lunch.  But it especially has to be raised for those who have not been paying their fair share.  Nothing is perfect, but with single payer or Medicare for all, we would be a helluva lot better off than we are now.

these are 2 questions that bother me about Bernie. Is there any way to get an answer?
1. In the case of free tuition what will control the money? If it is the states what is to prevent states from controlling the class material? If the federal government how will that be addressed?
2. It seems to me that getting free health care and free tuition will be difficult to get thru congress. What are you willing to give in order to get the needed votes?
But as Blow explains, current data does not show this, so why is it a relevant hypothesis?

What data? Surely not polling data since it is so unreliable. Btw if a committed democrat, start learning  to say President Trump. If it makes your blood pressure rise, vote for the Democrat, no matter who is nominated.

In case of free tuition, it wasn't that long ago (or at least, it doesn't seem that way to me) that virtually free tuition was available in California - the California State Universities, and the great University of California system were affordable to someone working at minimum wage (me) - the numbers I recall (this was in the 70's) are about $90/semester for Cal State, and $210/quarter for UCLA. Somehow that was doable then, paid by state taxes. Why is it impossible now?

As far as paying for health care, our current system, dominated by for profit insurers, is more expensive - not less - than the health care system of all other first world countries who provide universal health care.

As far as the "needed votes," as long as we have a Tea party/Republican dominated Congress, it is unlikely that these, or anything, will get done by ANY Democratic president. But we can at least move the conversation to the left so the public has some sense of what is at stake that actually impacts them.

It is so refreshing to see adults disagree over policy without resorting to personal insults, completely generic feel good statements, or spew right wing hate.

We can only hope as a country that one of the two who debated tonight will be our next commander-in-chief.

One is six years older than Reagan was, never got a steady paycheck until elected at age 40, after 25 years in WashDC has led only one law's making and has a reputation of being "cranky."

The other has 100 FBI agents going through her records and more than 60% of Americans called her "dishonest" after 35 years in "public service."

We are the only "hope" in this equation.

Were you actually watching the debate? My 9 year old son commented how 'unbelievably rude' the candidates were - shouting each other down, ignoring the moderators, lying through her teeth.  No better than Trump/Rubio.  There all abominations - except ... well, no exceptions.
We all know who that one is too.
I fail to see the optimism you attribute to Bernie Sanders.
Arno, the allegiance is in the nearly double popular vote count.

It's Bernie's choice if he wants to support the eventual (fixed) Democratic ticket. But I will vote for Dr. Jill Stein, a woman!, if Bernie is not the Dem nominee. I don't owe the Dems my vote and they don't own it.
I'd say that's your fault, not Sanders'.

As someone who voted for Obama twice but now supports Trump, I'm not sure who would be easier to beat. Once he turns his attention to it, Trump can easily define them.

Hillary would be the lying Wall St. puppet who should get indicted. Sanders would be the socialist who will raise everyone's taxes to be like Europe (a failing continent).

Laurette, you post this all the time, emphasizing quality of life where you live, but you live in Greece, and your "quality of life" has left that country insolvent. Do you really suggest the U.S. follow that lead?
Sorry, makes sense to me.
When do you turn 8, Laurette?

Hillary Clinton did very poorly in this debate. She could not answer a question straight and was very general in her prescription for what this country needs.
Her message lacked conviction and enthusiasm.

Bernie Sanders was consistent and honest. He did not back down from his record, dove deeper into the details, and was confident.
Sanders provided details?  What channel were you watching?  I saw a different debate. I thought there was only one last night...

The first thing that jumps into my head is, would this be an effective treatment for autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, lupus, and etc. I am sure the people who developed the desensitization technique have already thought about this; and if I was a science reporter, it would have been among the very first questions I would have asked.
I have a family member who was diagnosed with Lupus and thought of the same exact question.

The procedure they are talking about is called plasmapheresis. This procedure has been used for decades now for many different conditions, some autoimmune diseases included. I am a physician who performs plasmapheresis, and we have already used this for desensitization for heart transplants. I think it's great that its use can be expanded to kidney transplant, but there also needs to be more awareness in the medical community about all of the other indications and potential benefits of plasmapheresis.

The procedure they are referring to that removes the antibodies is called plasmapheresis.  Plasmapheresis has been used for decades now to treat a wide variety of conditions, some autoimmune diseases among them.  I am a physician who works in a plasmapheresis service, and we have used it for desensitization for potential heart transplant patients.  It is also often used to treat certain types of organ transplant rejection after transplant.  I think it's great that we can expand the use of plasmapheresis to kidney transplant desensitization.  We also need to do our best to make the medical community more aware of the many uses and benefits of plasmapheresis.

Bernie has the edge in 2 critical ways. This campaign is all about inspiring voters about a better future. Bernie does that much better than Hillary. But more importantly, Bernie is defining what it means to be a progressive in 2016 America, and all Hillary can do is follow and copy.
I'd love to know what Cubans would say, wouldn't you? A hint: they left in droves.

And that is precisely the problem with Hillary; she is telling us what she will 'TRY" to do.

Never will she commit, since she must first check with the individuals who own her.
Mel, how about this: Hillary knows what she wants to do, and she hopes she will be able to shepherd those programs through. Bernie says it will happen...fairytales.

A decent, honest person against a greedy dishonest one. How are the Clintons still on the stage after all we've seen of them?

I don't agree with all Sanders says on the economic front, but he says what he believes and has for his entire career. Clinton will say anything to anyone for a vote. The country needs to restore decency and integrity to the office of the president. Sanders is the only one running who can do that.
Mel, why don't you to something Bernie does not do: state specifically what Secretary Clinton has done to earn your mistrust.
I would find the accusations and innuendo against the Clintons more credible if they had a source other than the Republican Party.
How's Myra?

Passionate debate and strong performances by both candidates.

That said, Senator Sanders shone. His authenticity and strong advocacy for ordinary Americans far outstrip Secretary Clinton's pallid centralism.

It was clear in this debate that Secretary Clinton's policies are pale copies of Senator Sanders'. If halfway measures appeal, Secretary Clinton is your candidate. If you want the real deal, support Senator Sanders.

Eileen, maybe living in the UK has distorted your view. The Bernie Bros are wholly a creation of Hillary's campaign. When an article bashing them came out there were two examples: One was a hillary supporter, the other was  a Republican. She did it to Obama, to, calling them Obama boys. She can spin any threat into sexism.

He's accomplished quite a lot.   He sponsored an amendment providing $100 million in additional funding to community health centers.  He did his part to help prevent child labor by passing an amendment which stopped the US from appropriating funds for the importation of goods made by the hands of minors. He sponsored (and helped to pass) an amendment which increased low-income home energy assistance and a related weatherization assistance program by $22 million, which helped heat the homes of poor households.  The list goes on and on (google is your friend; feel free to learn more.)  I'd say that's more than talk.
He was a conscientious objector, he was not prescient. He will always vote against war, which may play havoc with existing treaties.

Bernie is an elderly idealist, who believes his own mantra. It will take him two long years, as it did Obama, to learn what he can and can't do – in particular that he can't tear up these trade agreements. As evidence, look how long it took him to understand what was really going on at the VA – as reported recently by The Times: http://tinyurl.com/j4mzv9e .

By then he'll be 78, an age when we all slow down. Will he have the energy to regroup and start all over again with a new plan, even if he remains in good health? We can't afford another presidential learning curve.

Whether it's Bernie or Hillary in the Oval Office, not much big legislation will likely pass the Republican Congress. Most of the action will be in the foreign policy arena. Can anyone with a straight face claim that Bernie is ready for the mad provocations of Vlad Putin or Ali Khamenei?

Hillary may have problems of authenticity and trustworthiness. Bernie, who believes his own false promises, has a huge problem of credibility. Older voters have seen this movie before, and simply don't believe him. Myself, I find his detachment from reality scary. I'll take Hillary.

I learned from reading David McCullough's book "Truman" many years ago and everything I've read, seen or heard ever since confirms that the Presidency is essentially a job of decision making. Day in, day out, tons of decisions have to be made.

The Obama presidency confirms this: judgment, the ability to make good decisions is more important than experience. Obama had much of the former and almost none of the latter - though in truth his biggest mistake appears to be that he thought Congress would be reasonable in their dealings with him.

So, I am asking you, or Prof. Krugman, or any other Hillary supporter to please, please, please, provide for us all a list of good decisions that Hillary has made.

We all know about the ton of bad decisions she has made: from the decision to give overly high paid speeches to the Banksters/BigMoney on the eve of running for President, to voting for the war, to backing trade agreements, to backing deregulation, to backing 3 strikes & your out (which packed America's prisons to levels higher than any other nation), to welfare reform, etc..

Whereas Bernie has a track record of making decisions on the right side history going back to the 1960s civil rights era.

We are voting for decision maker in chief. She couldn't turn down bankster money out of foresight for something happening only a year & a half away in time? Hillary lost in 2008 because she was all tactics & no strategy. So I have no faith in her decision making ability. Help me out.

Consider this, at the time for voting for the Iraq war the American people didn't yet know our Republican administration was lying did they? So if you agree that was the case and regardless of how our media and CIA failed us, was it bad judgement to vote for the war, if an immediate threat were to exist? Forgive me, but in many peoples opinion that was bad judgement, but only in reflection, a lucky decision for him. Second, as a private citizen, your saying Hillary shouldn't make money because of who it came from or because you felt she made to much? And on the crime bill from decades ago, you blame her for the  levels of incarceration. Try this, where were all of the Bernie fans before he up and decides he wants to be President? why has there been no massive increase in voting for the revolution? where were they in 2010, in 2012, in 2014 when Obama needed liberals the most to vote? They were sitting on their backsides complaining about how bad things were while they didn't bother voting. So the Congress flipped Republican and we get no active governance at all. So Hillary was out making a fortune speaking so she would have a lot of money to run for office, well that's just awful right? How about the fight for campaign finance reform that will help to end the influence of the very few - where have all the Bernie fans been? Don't get me wrong, Bernie has a lot of good ideas, and 93% of time Hillary voted the same way. but who is the fighter and who is the dreamer.

Reply to Tim Kane,
What does it say about Bernie's judgment that he has built an entire campaign around grandiose promises that any second grader knows he can't keep?

Sanders is an old fox of a politician, playing dirty by smearing Clinton with unfounded accusations. He almost sounds jealous she made that much money from speeches, when he only has ripped millions from his government paycheck over decades, which by the way puts him in the top 3% in terms of income.

I never voted for her. I remember when they told all other candidates during the primary to stand down and get out of her way. It was as if the NY U.S. Senate seat was owed to her in exchange for something, maybe her agreeing to not not divorce her husband after the Lewinsky scandal or something, and the NY voter was just collateral damage.

Yiannis, Sanders didn't smear Clinton with unfounded accusations. You can't "smear" someone with the truth. And where in the world did you get your idea that he "ripped millions from his government paycheck over decades, which by the way puts him in the top 3% in terms of income."? His net worth is among the lowest in Congress at under $700,000. http://moneynation.com/bernie-sanders-net-worth/ He is scrupulously ethical and honest.

Jay, Hillary was a good senator, we all know that. Wall St was among her constituents when senator, would you have had her ignore them? To date, there is no evidence that she is "in the pocket of Wall St", instead, there is evidence that she is not. Honesty, ethics, she can stand toe to toe with anyone. If you have something real to say, do it, otherwise stop slinging mud.

If Clinton wants to convince the large proportion of Americans who do not find her trustworthy she can release the transcripts of her Wall Street speeches instead of telling us how hurt she is that she is accused of not being trustworthy.
yes, we do cowboy, and that's why we support Bernie Sanders
She has stated, and rightly so in my view, that she will release all her paid speeches when all other presidential candidates do too. Fair is fair. Same rules for all.
When Bernie and Hillary served together in the US Senate their voting records were 93% the same.

I watched the debate, and I thought Bernie Sanders was much more honest and direct with voters.  Hillary Clinton cannot answer a direct question to save her life.  She also repeatedly disrespected Sanders and the moderators with her monopolizing, paternalizing speeches that went on and on, well over the time limit.  Sanders still hasn't blamed Clinton for her role in accepting the Honduran military coup in 2009, and she needs to be called out on this.  Also, we cannot understand the immigration flows across our borders without understanding much of the migrant flow--especially from Central America--is a direct result of US foreign policy in the 1980s and '90s, and then let's throw  in the impact of NAFTA on Mexico. She represents the past policies of the US against Latin America, where he offers a much better future.  Sanders' won the debate tonight, just like he did Michigan!
Bernie got a standing ovation at the end. He had the crowd in his pocket from he time he said that he was "dangerous - to Wall Street."
NO HE DID NOT.  That was applause for the end of the debate.
" Sanders still hasn't blamed Clinton for her role in accepting the Honduran military coup in 2009,"....It was cloudy today, it must be Hillary's fault.

The reason it wasn't set up that way is because there is a huge disparity between the costs of different groups. It would have made a lot more sense to implement that rule rather than the individual mandate. Too bad Ocare wasn't designed well.

They are not the only ones exempt for the individual mandate.  When Obama decided to allow non compliant plans to continue when the exchanges failed, a large number of healthy people stayed in their old plans and new healthy people opted for the health rated lower cost non-compliant plans.  It is one of the reasons for the death spiral.
Said by a non-believer.  Yours was the first comment that made me laugh out loud.  Thank you.

"but the ACA system won't work if families join it only when they need it, and need it badly."

But it goes on anyway and it's easy because there are about 30 different excuses to avoid the penalty for not signing up in the enrollment period.
A free lance writer for the times recently wrote an article about her marriage after being divorced for 25 years. Two years into the marriage it was discovered that her lawyer husband had pancreatic cancer. She thanked the ACA for their ability to buy health insurance despite his pre-existing condition. The insurance paid for a very expensive Whipple procedure which typically runs 10-12 hours cleaning out the tumors and affected lymph nodes.
If the well educated and well to do aren't buying health insurance how can we expect the average person to do so. At least the Christians are making an effort to have coverage.

If you object to these people not joining the 11 million people who are in the ObamaCare pool of the old and sick, how do you feel about the 50% of the population who are outside of the pool by virtue of having employer provided health insurance.  Shouldn't they have to give up their employer provided health insurance so they can subsidize others in the pool?
Half of the Co-ops formed by Ocare have failed, leaving the people who paid premiums with unpaid bills.  How about the government address those insurers and leave these cost sharing groups alone?
The answer to your question is: Both. To many on the Left, government IS their god, and they absolutely hate anyone who doesn't place their faith in the almighty capital.

Since they have over half a million participants, it is very likely that they have had members with cancer and heart attacks.  That they have a normal maximum of $250,000 and voluntary contributions to cover overages, they have until now apparently survived.  Which would be  a better track record than the co-ops set up by ocare.

We definitely need a full explanation from the IRS of their counterfactual decision in the Crossroads GPS case.  And promptly.  The only way to stop the right-wing politicization of the IRS is to publicize what's going on behind the scenes.  Who has the authority to extract such an explanation?  I would think it's President Obama.  Oh.  Well, maybe next year ...?

This is the tip of the iceberg. From when the Koch brothers initially started to figure out how to inject massive amounts of "dark money" into the electoral process to the disastrous Citizens United decision, the citizens of this country have been woefully unaware and willfully ignorant. The Social Welfare 501s that allow these people to hide money, much of it with tax benefits, are a huge fraud.
The press.  Whistle blowers.  Average people who watch these agencies.  The press.

California is an anomaly. The reform was implemented reasonably there, i.e., with resources provided to each school, no high stakes testing in advance of availability of adequate resources, no RTTT arm-twisting. New York was the opposite, and many other states had subsets of the problems New York experienced. The biggest issue -- whether the reform is implemented thoughtfully or not -- is that there is no evidence that the CC or similar reforms reforms are worth their substantial bankroll (and yes, the federal government did support the reform, e.g., by underwriting the $360+ million cost of CC aligned tests). Achievement trends and gaps have not been shifted by these reforms (NAEP scores are largely down this year, though that's just one data point). One justification may be how much money is shifted toward various chunks of the education market place, e.g., technology companies, publishers, testing companies, and a swath of think tanks whose funding bends them, directly or (somewhat) subliminally, toward supporting the reform.

I have looked at Sanders's twitter feed several times and seen only posts by Sanders and campaign re-tweets of news items, etc, all of which was above board.

I just looked again and noticed something for the first time, since I am not a twitter user. Some posts have a link to "view converation." Hitting that link opens up a thread of posts by all the lunkheads who use twitter. Welcome to cesspool of the internet.

There are multiples ugly posts in those conversations on the Sanders feed. Thing is, if you go to the Clinton feed and find her posts with "view conversation links, you land in the same cesspool.

The feeds by the campaigns are more or less like the debates. Similar charges and countercharges.

The posts by internet trolls are the cesspool of the internet, and that has no more to do with Sanders than it does Clinton. Open an unmoderated comment section and expect behavior that makes Trump seem like Miss Manners.

So it is not exactly the smear I thought Krugman was making. It is a slightly different smear: "Sanders invented the bad parts of the internet!" Kind of like how Al Gore invented the whole thing

We would be targets by his provocative language.  Me as a mother and worker would not wish to bring this unleashing of reaction to our people.  I look to the future and Trump in his eagerness to gain power forgot that the world watches.  A Trump presidency would risk all our sons and daughters in future wars brought on by his racist language.  What brought me courage were the Obamas and the Trudeau families peacefully mixing in wonderful elegance.  That vision is what I hold onto for my family's future. Notre Dame did not betray any association nor did it violate any agreement by signing with NBC. Your assertion is false.

The reason that UConn has little success in football is that northeasterners don't follow them.  The most popular college team in New York City is Notre Dame, which happens to be in Indiana.  If fans don't care, they won't support a local team.  That is UConn's fate.  A premier program would exist if the fans cared.  And folks who think that makes northeasterners high-minded don't know what this is really about.  UConn has no football rivalries, it's got no history of success, and it exists in an area where three  prominent NFL teams are all well-supported.  The northeast is big football country, it just isn't college football country.

UConn belongs in the ACC. Big East is now all private Catholic universities (except Butler, which is also Christian). What would make the most sense is to pair it with another AAC school, say Memphis, and expand the ACC to 16 schools and 2 8-school divisions for football. But since everything about conference expansion has made no sense lately, that probably won't happen...

Nebraska had already been kicked out of the AAU before the Big Ten offered membership to Rutgers, so that cannot be a deciding factor. What was a deciding factor was the fact that Rutgers is in the NYC media market and UCONN is not, allowing the Big Ten Network to negotiate capitation rates for including the channel in cable and dish packages in the greater NYC area. That's a lot harder argument to make with UCONN.

I did my Masters (1985) at UConn and remember Cliff Robinson shooting foul shots in the field house.  There were no facilities.  Since then, only magic - and most of it basketball magic. As with most things in childhood (and college is part of childhood), once the adults and boosters got involved, they have done their best to ruin the university experience.  Still UConn basketball is an amazing thing.  Rejoin the Big East and let the magic continue!  Go Huskies!

The primary reason the football stadium is not on campus is the roads. It would be gridlock for every football game. The folks who live in the area (Mansfield and Coventry) were opposed to widening the roads.

The basis of your logic is not sound.  Rutgers made its way into the Big 10 with a historically weak football program.  The driving factor was access to a lucrative media market.  Connecticut offers very lucrative media market in terms of size and demographics.  Abandoning football would be nonsensical and would forfeit any chance for P5 entry and the economic benefits that follow.  UConn is not some sleepy old Yankee Conference school.  It is a top 20 national university, and it will find a spot in the Big 10 unless the Big 12 grabs it sooner.  The market is simply to attractive to ignore, and the school is academically superior.  The only question will be whether the Big 10 recognizes that by taking UConn they preemptively lock up the Northeast.

On its face, this might seem sensible. But, think again. Suppose an athlete were taking drugs for bipolar disorder, depression, to decrease cravings for alcohol? Or for another disorder the acknowledgement of which the athlete does not owe the public? Do we want athletes not to seek treatment for disorders that carry some kind of stigma? Not all athletes are millionaires like Sharapova. Do you really think a journeyman minor leaguer who may never make it to the big leagues owes the public this information? How about a college athlete?

If the meds the the athletes are taking are accurately reported to sports authorities that should be enough.

ST, suppose that the doctor concludes that her complaints are due to over exhaustion caused by training at a level her body cannot sustain. Then if meldonium allows her to continue, then it is indeed a performance enhancing drug. But as long as it is not banned, one cannot object to this on ethical grounds any more than a tennis player who repeatedly needs knee surgery or other treatments.

You can well imagine that the WADA could impose limits on the number of sports related surgeries you can have in some time frame and still be allowed to compete. The whole point of the anti doping regulations is to make sure people who have a body physique that just isn't good enough should not patch up their bodies using nontrivial medical interventions in order to be able to compete.

Finesse and artistry, yes, but athleticism has not been eliminated from the game. I would argue that the technologies have enabled brute athleticism to dominate the game. Especially women's tennis, which is a boring baseline game waiting for an unforced error.

Social media, which projects a billion voices with a billion opinions and counterpoints, is in fact a much richer source of information. News media outlets, on the other hand, are controlled by a handful of corporations with agendas of their own, so I'd say, you and your ilk are the ones who are poorly informed.

And most of these individuals didn't even know Bernie Sanders from Colonel Sanders a year ago. It wasn't until word got out there was a politician who was pushing for free college education they even took and interest in Sanders, and then by attrition, they probably figured this guy would be getting all student loan debt forgiven. But selling papers and online advertising matter more to today’s media than thoughtful discussions of thing like income equality. So the loud mouth bully has gotten the lion’s share of the media attention and he’s almost certainly going to be the GOP nominee.

I am a Sanders supporter who has been carefully and meticulously following and listening to the anger of the citizenry over the last eight or nine months. The discontent on both the right and left is unlike anything I have seen in the past 40 years.

I expect the overwhelming majority of the GOP leadership to cave and support Trump in the self serving hope that his victory will protect and even advance their own personal career and financial interests.

Clinton's base of support is, by contrast, exceedingly thin. Nor can it be overstressed that her most powerful message in November will be “I am better than the alternative.” If Clinton was once "likable enough", she isn't anymore. Indeed the level of vitriol felt against Clinton by those on the right and center (and with Sanders’ presumed defeat some of the left as well) is beyond frightening.

Needless to say, I am anticipating a Trump victory in November.

We are not talking innuendo, we are talking voting record and recorded comments. Hillary has changed her tune on so many issues, and her record of accomplishments so thin, that yes, this criticism is warranted.

The idea that anyone can predict Clinton's strength in November based upon her strength in the Democratic primaries (many of which were closed) strikes me as bizarre.

I have zero problem accepting that Clinton has sewn up the Demcratic nomination. Part of the reason for my post was to warn folks that I actually think she is very vulnerable IN NOVEMBER.

This has absolutely nothing to do with my favoring Sanders. It has everything to do with my not wanting to see Trump become president.

But rather than acknowledge that Secretary Clinton may have a tough road after the convention, the folks commenting here accuse me of being a Trump supporter.

THIS is exactly why Clinton is at risk of losing-- because you all think someone like me is the enemy for saying what ought to be a common sense concern. If you think the Sandernistas have been hard on Clinton, you are clearly completely clueless for what is coming after the conventions. Moreover, unlike Sanders, the GOP will have hundreds of millions in PAC money to spread their far more hateful messages.

As to NSH, taking Sanders out of the picture, of course HRC is the best candidate. But that doesn't mean her current campaign has her on a trajectory to win.

Finally, while I share FSMLives! presumed abhorrence with likability being a factor in choosing a president, it unfortunately influences a great many voters. (Remember the November election is not going to be determined by the folks who read the New York Times every day.)

One last thought which nobody will read either.

The whole point of my original post was what I had observed from reading tens of thousands of blog posts. Maybe they weren't scientifically chosen (the vast majority were found here at the New York Times) but they were passionate and as near as I could tell in most cases sincere. THAT was the primary reason for my making my prediction.

Nobody here even addressed the fact that my conclusion that Trump was likely to win was based on listening to actual voters and hearing their anger.

Hillary's $675,000 in for speaking to Goldman Sachs tell the whole story while the $14 million earned after leaving the State Department cast her allegiances in cement.

As a group, if we can't vote for Bernie to be president, we certainly won't vote for Hillary. Perhaps voting for Donald Trump will force the DNC to play fair with Democratic candidates next time instead of letting Debbie Disaster run a black ops campaign.

Bill -- Bernie is losing the vote.  The people voting in the Democratic primaries don't agree with your claims.  So go vote for Trump.  Stop acting like you are anything other than that.  We knew that's what most of you are.
The women in your lives will know who to thank when they lose their reproductive rights. Nice going.

You know, if you Bernie supporters spent half as much time building Bernie up instead of trashing Hillary, you might garner more support.

Outside of pointing out that millions have supported Bernie, you present zero positives for why I, or anyone else, should be supporting Bernie.

Instead, you bring out the trope about how Bill & Hillary have 'sold out' the middle class to fund the Clinton Foundation. You say it's 'well documented' but provide no source material. Maybe it's 'well documented' on far left liberal blogs or far right blogs but it's not well documented in the real world.

And again with the infantile 'If Bernie isn't the nominee, I'm voting Trump' nonsense. You would destroy all the progressive achievements of Obama and possible destroy the country out of spite.

You truly cannot call yourself progressive if you are willing to vote for Trump.

Aside, the DNC owes Bernie about $1,000 worth of support. That's all he helped fund raise for them last year. I would think he has gotten far more in value from the DNC than $1,000.
I was just going to link to the same piece. It does seem that the NYT is clearly in HR's pocket.as the RS piece points oat, some of the NYT coverage could have been written by HRC.

If anything the media should point out over and over Bernie's lack of concise policies he can enact. Folks should see that he is not credible in his ability to get much done. It should be pointed out he is pulling a fast one over these young voters, it's a shame.
Great reply Frank, from a fellow 60 year old.
The difference is that Bernie has spent years pontificating and haranguing in Congress with what exactly to his credit and our profit?
Well I'm in my late sixties with advanced degrees in STEM. Sanders hasn't pulled the wool over my eyes. Perhaps Clinton has pulled the wool over yours.

Ever since The Times editorial board wrote that it was supporting Hilary, it has become as though each and every columnist lost all free will and had to support that editorial.
Your first line says that Hilary TROUNCED Bernie. Unfair for weeks.
Isnt winning 5 states being "trounced"?
Not even "since" then...they have been writing glowing opinion and *news* articles about Clinton well before.

Hillary won 3,713,033 votes on March 15th. Bernie won 2,821,094 votes.

Hillary bested him in all five states by 891,939 votes.

More importantly, Hillary won 371 delegates to Bernie's 271. She won 100 more delegates than Bernie increasing her total to 1,139 to his 825, a difference of 314 delegates.

By all metrics, yeah, one could say that Bernie was, indeed, trounced.
like on carson the demagogue...i kind of wanted to say, like from men on film, cept men on gop, you and bruni, "don't get mad'.

comments.commentBody:
Why no revolution? Because you say there won't be?

Fight, fight, fight! (said Churchill).
It's not spin. The parallel has a connotation, it is insinuating, and Obama is too smart to make such a subtly derisive parallel without knowing how the comparison plays out. Newspeak.

We respect that you like and admire Hillary Clinton. There's no doubt that there are many Democrats that feel the same.

Now, it's your turn to respect that as strongly as you feel in favor of her, there is a Democrat and two Republicans that believe the demonization and despise her.

Why would you nominate a candidate who starts out with a ceiling of support? Is she THAT good?
Waiting in Wisconsin to vote for Bernie. It will  be difficult if not impossible to vote without gagging for someone one who consults Henry Kissinger.

Why are all of you Hillary bots always speaking in terms of the present congress? A Bernie win in the general (more likely than a Hillary win against Trump) would flip the senate next year, and could flip the house in two. Bernie said he can't do it alone, which is where the two diverge, as maintaining the status quo is something Hillary can easily do on her own.

In 2008, after Super Tuesday then, Hillary was around 100 delegates behind Obama. In 2016, Bernie was about 200 delegates behind.

Hillary maintained that 100 delegate gap through the entire primary and wound up 102 delegates behind Obama. Had some of her Super Delegates not switched sides, she would have won the nomination. But, the Supers saw that Obama was ahead in delegates and decided to go there, which was the correct decision and I say that as a Hillary supporter then and now.

Bernie is now over 300 delegates behind. If Hillary couldn't overcome a small 100 delegate deficit, how can Bernie over a 300 delegate deficit? How would need to win every single election going forward by 60-40 margins at least to secure the nomination.

That is not going to happen. The caucus states do not award that many delegates to begin with. And the primary elections he's won, outside of Vermont and New Hampshire, have been by rather small margins.

Bernie needed to win OH, IL and MO to remain viable and he lost all three, OH by a decent margin.

At this time last year, Hillary's campaign was in far better shape than Bernie is now. Remember, she won OH, CA, PA, NY, NJ and CT in the homestretch but it still wasn't enough.

It is time for Democrats to grow up and get over this this complaint that Clinton is "beholden to the donor class". That complaint was authored by the GOP, lap dog of the Koch brothers. Donors are important; yes, their money may win influence, but it also funds the broader fight against the the GOP and their campaign of hate, fear, and ignorance.

Sanders is simply 2016 Jimmy Carter, a wonderful man but no leader. Anyone can see this, and his continued candidacy is nothing but narcissism, a gift offered to the Republican Party, who know that to choose Sanders would be to choose the GOP.
Waitaminnit ... didn't Jimmy Carter WIN?

How odd that the electorate is backing someone who's wealth and experience was generated though influence peddling.  And I'm talking on both sides of the ticket this year.  Sanders has always said the same things since the day he left college. Kasich is a moderate that would be a better choice than you know who. The electorate however is buying the lies put forth by the front runners, as usual.

@dakotagirl

"Sanders has always said the same things since he left college"
I doubt that!
That would suggest a mind that is incapable of growth and for all of Bernie's faults I highly doubt that is one of them.

I wonder how the Sanders supporters would feel if all the Hillary supporters started slandering Bernie? We have not done that but Bernie definitely  has his weaknesses. If he ever became the final Democratic candidate, I fear that Donald would pull out all that hasn't been said yet. Bernie has his vulnerabilities, too.

National polls are irrelevant at this point, and period as it is the Electoral College that votes for the president.

Most importantly, voters don't know Sanders. And once the GOP Attack Machine goes all in and equates him with such socialists as Castro, Chavez, Lenin, Stalin and, of course, Hitler, he's toast.

Americans that support Sanders are exactly the voters that Obama turned against even though they voted for him and put him in office. Put me on the list of voters that can't find anything that Obama has done that has helped me survive. Hillary should think long about whether to publicly accept his support. There's an extra large ego there, it needs to just go away.
you would feel the same way or worse about sanders after he failed to accomplish anything, which is what would happen. he has been accomplishing nothing for decades.

Does the Republican party send out "talking points" or directives on "special words to use" for those who plan to post on forums?
The "ego" charge has been making the rounds now for about 5-6 weeks...
Two weeks from now there will be another "new word"

Sen. Rubio was accused of repeating the same words or phrases but clearly he's not the only Republican doing it...
This president has been a disappointment from the beginning. This sorry statement doesn't surprise me. Democratic practice is too inconvenient for this aspirant to the ruling class.

I agree with you, Arthur Birnbaum, except for where you call Obama an aspirant to the ruling class. I think being elected 2X as president makes him part of the ruling class.

I loathe what he just did to Bernie in that $33K a head private fundraiser, showing undue favoritism to Hillary. Obama's maniplative private speech just pushes me further away from the Dems come November.

But he is not an aspirant to the ruling class. He sits atop it, the publicly visible part of it.

The votes that count are the one that the candidate gets in the actual election.  I don't believe HRC is that candidate.  Votes in Southern states, other "red" states--they account for nothing.  She has to carry all traditional "blue states" as well as some other big vote states like Ohio to win.  I have no confidence that she'll be able to do this.

I'm not surprised Obama did this, but I am surprised that his statement to donors seemed to turn on the argument that "W was also seemed to be authentic." The vapidity of that statement escapes commentary.

Many of the states where Hillary Clinton has won primaries will not likely go for the Democratic candidate in November.  Conversely, not only does Bernie Sanders have a solid chance of winning a majority of the remaining contests, but those states will form the foundation of a Democratic victory in the general election.

Obama has been a disappointment in many areas, and one suspects he's as disappointed as any of us that he was unable to achieve more. But he did achieve a lot.
I for one still think the US is in much better shape now than it would have been under a McCain or Romney presidency. He will be missed no matter who wins in Nov.

I admire Hillary Clinton for her perseverance, intelligence, years of public service - and the fact that she's tough and warm at the same time. When people bring up to me all the criticisms about her in the news media, I remind them of the importance of weeding out fact from fiction. Regarding Obama's comments, I trust that he had good reasons to make them, although I'm not sure I entirely agree with them. I don't think he was trying to imply that she's his clone and will carry out his agenda. But she does support a lot of the work he's done (so do I!), so it makes sense for her to continue supporting that work.

First of all, he's not a Democrat - he's in it for the money and the publicity, his words, not mine. Secondly, thanks forth spewing the never ending lies and misinformation about a woman, who once she steps outside "this great nation of ours" is honored and revered around the world for all she has done for women, equality and the less fortunate.

The true democrat is HRC - Bernie Sanders by his own words does not hold any allegiance to the Democratic party and the way he is thinking of going forward with his forlorn campaign, proves that point.

I'd like to know where people get the idea that Sanders is going to effect these big changes in the US -- besides the fact that he says so. Trump says he's going to do a lot of things, too. There is no evidence that either has done anything effective except appear on tv and make noise.

Sanders has been in Congress for years. What change has he effected? Where has he been, besides appearing on Real Time? That's where he became a celebrity and mastered the sound bite. If Sanders had any kind of a record of action (besides making Bill Maher purr), I'd consider him a serious cabdidate. But he's no more than any other favorite guest on talking head shows.

I'm not being rhetorical when I say I want to know why anyone thinks a man who has been quietly ineffectual in the house and senate for decades is suddenly going to roar to life as president and bring about societal change. How do you possibly see this happening? Especially explain how he can accomplish this in view of who writes legislation.
a million times this

I am that "anyone" willing to answer your "non rhetorical" question.
Sanders has been "ineffectual" because his beliefs (please check his voting record from the early 1990s, unfiltered ) were often not shared by special interest politicians. Forget about the Iraq war, check his interview with Greenspan in 2003, way before the great recession.
He has "roared" to life because some voters are finally ready to hear him, but he has been alive in his beliefs and actions for a long time.
He is not naive, and it is not about Bernie doing it alone. He believes and says aloud over and over that if (and when) people come out and vote (not just every 4 years), the politicians they elect will have to govern for their constituents and not just for special interest folks who pay for their campaign. That is the "social change" (or revolution) he talks about. If people don't exercise their power by not voting, they will continue to be governed by the "few" and for the "few"
How can he accomplish anything? For a starter he would continue to advocate for the things the public vote him for, he would continue to engage with congress, senate and the populace, and call out obstructionists . He would not be "compromiser in chief" when compromise is only in the interest of the "few".
He would be the president of the people, for the people, and by the people.

I believe Obama was hope & change, authentically so. He came in with the naive idea that he could work with republicans. It took a long time for him to realize they never had any intention of working with him, nor would they, in any way, shape, or form. It was my worry about Ibama during the primaries in 2008--he was not understanding the prior 20 years' worth of GOP behavior, particularly obvious under Bill Clinton's presidency. Leaving aside the ridiculousness of that GOP position and the insidious bases behind it, I believe Obama was unable, due to the makeup of Congress & the completely insane forces driving the decisions of the right  (now personified by Trump), to accomplish more than he has. His "establishment-ness" is nothing more than the end result of trying to legislate "hope & change" with a crowd of unintelligent & unempathetic legislators  who couldn't care less about the people they're meant to serve. The blame for not getting  the "hope & change" we voted for--by a landslide in 2012--lies with Congress, not Obama. The same exact thing is going to happen to Sanders if elected (and Clinton too), unless a whole lot of people vote their congressional representatives out. But the track record for that is not good.
Obama never had a chance after the GOP swept Congress in 2010 and then the Senate in 2014. Wonder how that happened?

Benghazi: accusations of not adequately defending our embassy, this after the Republican Congress repeatedly refused to pass legislation to bolster defenses of our overseas embassies.

E-mail servers: Trumped up charges that Hillary was wrong to use private servers at her home while Secretary of state, even though Republican Cabinet Members Colin Powell and Condoleezza Rice, serving in the same capacity, did the same exact thing.
If Clinton is a true democrat, she will suspend her race and join forces with Bernie.  Being pragmatic and Defeating the threat of Trump must take precedence over abstract ideological struggles.

I don't understand this whole idea.  Why should Bernie bow out, even if there were mathematically no way for him to win the nomination (which isn't true). He represents a true alternative to Clinton, and many, many millions of people haven't had a chance to vote yet.  Shouldn't they get a chance to make their voices heard?  Why shouldn't Clinton be forced to acknowledge that Bernie has millions of supporters and his ideas and policies need to be addressed.  How does Bernie dropping out "help" the Republicans?  To me smacks of "me thinks the lady doth protest too much-ism" - Hillary-Obama-$33K donors are worried that Bernie staying in the race actually exposes Hillary's weaknesses; that's why they want Bernie out.  No way.  The fat lady remains stubbornly silent.  Bernie for President.

@m

OMG, are this people stupid?? Do they even read the articles before they rush forward blaming Obama and Hillary for everything imaginable?

It's beyond ridiculous that RAC purposely confuses what Obama said to make some absurd twisted point. These are tactics the Republicans have been using for decades and now the Bernie Bros are using them. When will it end!

Get used to it Bernie Bros: Hillary is going to be our next president.
Why can't he make public statements what ever he has to say. The very private dinners for fund raising are the root cause for rigged economy.
Well the Democratic candidates want to overturn Citizens United, the GOP wants to keep it. The choice is yours.

comments.commentBody:
Gail Collins correctly reported that Trump said that his most important foreign policy adviser was himself. He presumably talks to himself when he seeks edification on international affairs.

He is patently as mad as a hatter. As we all know, his narcissism knows no bounds. In many circumstances a man with such an aberrant conception of himself and the world would be deposited in an institution. However, this man is lauded and adored by the media and he is well on his way toward capturing a party which once nominated Abraham Lincoln.
Why does he fare so well. Because he is filthy rich. And what does this prove? This proves that Capitalism is often a grotesque system because it posits a perfect correlation between monetary wealth and inherent worth, i.e., if you are very rich, you are deemed to be intrinsically morally and intellectually superior. Actually, Harvard proved the falsity of Capitalism's assumption that great wealth was indicative of inherent superiority. IN 1968, that school's psychology department found that the variable that correlated most strongly with financial wealth was the ability to look someone in the eye and lie at the same time. That, my friend, is the art of the deal.
Feel the Bern.

Davis Gottfried, you say, "...if you are very rich, you are deemed to be intrinsically morally and intellectually superior."

I think that may be only in the United States, the place where many people get their education from TV. If it's on TV it must be true and all those well dressed people on the tube must be smart. TV is the medium that, well not a certain bridge in Brooklyn, but it can sell anything to the dolts who tune in.

Oh, yeah, we are in big trouble. Trump is the king of the boop-tube and the boops are voting.
Maybe Trump's foreign policy advisors are his wife and those beautiful contestants from Miss Universe!

Amanda Cohen, how dare you say my darling cauliflower is bland! I recently decided that my childhood had too little cauliflower and I can now make up for that. When I was growing up cauliflower must have been more expensive than cabbage, zucchini, or (gag) succotash, so I rarely got it. While raising our own children we've eaten megatons of broccoli since my daughter decided it was da bomb. But she has since moved out and eats her own broccoli at least once a day. It is my time  to enjoy a paler, tastier cruciferous vegie. If others find it to be bland, I say, "Tough, that leaves more for me!"

"minus the fryer"

Again the Times won't listen to it's own reporting about fat in general. Home cooks will be using canola, better if they use peanut, better if it is organic, but they will not be using commercial deep fryer fat (like McDonalds, etc.). So no, the fat here is absolutely NOT the problem, but rather the worse thing in the recipe is the panko bread crumbs and whatever flour gets used and however much sugar is in the tartar sauce. But, that said, fry up you fish: the flour panko and sugar is not all that much compared other common dietary foodstuffs in terms of making people overweight and messing with their blood sugar.

But seriously, It's really waaaay past time that the Times stops adhering to the "fat is bad" mantra and passes along the memo to all the food-section staff.
I didn't read "fat is bad" anywhere in the article, m. I believe Melissa was concerned with the time and mess that frying involves.

I think the larger issue here is the mess and inconvenience of frying. I requires much more attention than simply prepping the food and putting it in the oven and makes a far greater mess than oven baking. Additionally it can stink up the house and is a much bigger mess to clean up. I rarely fry anything at home and certainly not on a weeknight. This is a recipe I would easily tackle during the week though.

The recipe didn't call for a deep fryer so your tempest is misplaced. Comments in recipes are a strange place for your crusade. Better to suggest omitting the flour and panko if worried about carb/sugars. No tartar sauce us listed either so what us all this crying about?
Count me as one more Yale alumnus who only recently learned of the team's entry into the tournament, and who is very charmed, indeed. Well done, gentlemen. Boola! Boola!

Come on Yalies at least comment on this article, geez!  Get with the spirit please!  This UConn fan would like nothing better than a Yale victory over Duke!  Go Bulldogs!  FYI that's your schools nickname

As a Yale class of '71 graduate, who also never followed our basketball team--that was the era of Yale football excellence, with the likes of Calvin Hill (father or NBA star Grant Hill) and Brian Dowling (later "B.D." in Doonesbury by Yalie Gary Trudeau)--it's fun to cheer on this group of tall and buff Elis. Fwiw, it also made me recall a factoid that I'd forgotten: Duke was my "safety" school. May the best team win.

WHY is this in the "Sports" section? What utterly fatuous fluff! The idea seems to wave in shout-outs to a bizarre group of Yalies (perhaps the writer's buds?) instead of saying anything of interest.

How about writing about SPORTS and leaving this filler in the "Styles" Section?

Good article. I liked the quotes, especially “We became very intense fans, cheering every free throw Yale made, even though I could not name a single player on the team.”

But we've all jumped on a bandwagon at some point or another, yes? I admit I liked another perspective at USA Today, which I found quite accurate - "Duke-Yale is the most insufferable college basketball game imaginable"

http://ftw.usatoday.com/2016/03/duke-yale-is-the-most-insufferable-colle...

"...we’re left with the choice of rooting for one of these teams. It’s a nightmare. I can’t stand it. I’m going to go for a long walk during this game, admire the sunshine, and pretend basketball was never invented."

"Insufferable"? Why? Because both of these school maintain academic standards for players and expect them to attend class, do their own work, take their own exams and graduate with real degrees?

The USAToday writer admits his loathing is driven by simply jealousy, then does on to spew a bunch of cliches about how every Duke or Yale grad makes huge amounts of money, is selfish, elitist and entitled.

This Dukie does not "make so much money it would make me physically sick if I saw your bank account" - in fact, a Duke magna cum laude degree is no proof against being laid off during the recession and then falling victim to age discrimination. I am revolted by Duke's recent spending and elasticity of the rules in pursuit of football prowess and think the fetishization of the hoops team is stupid and crass. However, the resentment and "hatred" toward students who can perform at high levels both academically and athletically, and the anger at schools that demand that they do so, is ugly and destructive.

The only thing 'insufferable' about the prospect of a Duke-Yale match up is that a pairing of such true student-athletes happens so very infrequently.
That author of that article is a Tulane alumnus, writing as if Tulane were not in the same safety school league as Duke.
Who wouldn't be charmed by a team coming together to defend a rapist?
Actually in this country one is presumed innocent until proven guilty you can ask the Duke lacrosse team about that for starters

A worthy person to defend since important due process rights were denied the young man in the name of social justice.

Yale is not the state and, therefore, doesn't need to follow the Constitution's pronouncements on criminal due process. But, it should. It's Yale.

While I'm thrilled for the basketball team, the university and its authoritarian politically-correct culture have become an embarrassment to many reasonable alumni including myself.  I can only hope that a few members of the 2006 Duke Lacrosse team attend the game and sit in solidarity with Jack Montague.

As easy as it would appear to be to hate on Williams and side completely with LaRouche in this matter, you have to be fair and say that what Williams said makes a lot of sense. Namely, what other job do you see where a 14 yr old boy goes to work with his father EVERY DAY for the WHOLE DAY? Exactly, none. They wanted him to scale it back, and he refused to compromise. They didn't release him...he quit. I give him credit for not going all Lawyer on them and trying to sue for breach of contract. We should just chalk it up to a clash of beliefs and let it go. Now he can spend his time home-schooling 365 days a year and coach his sons teams. Everybody wins...except maybe the White Sox locker room, which seems full of dissension.
Don't kid yourself, I'm sure the lockerroom is relieved.
We do not know if there was "no issue." Kids hanging around a baseball field with flying balls and bats and 100s of unknown employees does not seem like the ideal learning ground.
Yeah.  Must be why his teammates were going to boycott a scheduled exhibition game until Ventura pleaded with them not to.

Kudos to LaRoche. However, he was in a position where he had some leverage, substantial money in the bank (I assume) and a previous oral contract likely being violated. I can't help but think of all the fathers who would like to take their kids to work, whose work would not be affected by the kid's presence, but have no leverage other than a willingness to be fired and have his kid go hungry.
I'm happy for the Laroches.  When you're dead, you are going to be dead for a VERY long time.  Enjoying your time on earth with the people you love trumps everything else--.
This could have been handled better by all the adults

Instead of a weepy portrait of Laroche's dedication to his son, why not mention that LaRoche has said "we're not big on school" and that Drake will get a better education in the clubhouse than in class. So he's basically denying his son's human right to education.  What a joke.

Home-schooled kids usually are more socially adapted than most public school kids.  I know that seems counter-intuitive, but it's true for most home-schooled kids. Therefore, it comes as no surprise the lad was appreciated by the players.  Trust me; I work with home-schooled kids and previously taught for 25+ years in public schools.  Education and school can be two separate issues.

CKent.....

The boy "very well may be getting a better education than he'd get in a public school." Perhaps, but we don't know, since the regulation of home schooling in most states is very lax. And if the concern is specifically about public schools, consider that LaRoche should have plenty of money to put his son in a first-rate private school.

My experience over several decades as an educator is that home-schooled youth tend to lack substantive breadth - they are knowledgeable in one or two areas, but are clueless in many others - and have weak critical-thinking skills, in part because they often are philosophically rigid.
A very succinct and pointed reply to LaRoche -- well done and keep it up!

It seems appalling no self-respecting republican is willing to mount the courage to say Enough Already, and not lend support to any of the two wild, and unacceptable, candidates remaining. That Trump is unpredictable, prejudiced and ignorant, and a bully (hence, a coward) is a well known fact. But Ted Cruz is the most dangerous and hated individual no one can stand, as he is a religiously- motivated dogmatic, spewing lies, and adamant at destroying the very construct of the country's democratic process. Although unpalatable, there is one way out: vote for the democratic candidate, so reason may prevail, reality recognized for what it is, so that politics may recognize 'compromise' as a necessary and welcome tool to get things done. Otherwise, all those that have condemned Trump and Cruz as bigots...and worse, and now supporting either one, may deserve, in all justice, to be called hypocrites, cowards, and lacking the power of their convictions.

Much as I despise The Donald I can't honestly blame him for reading the GOP "establishment" the Riot Act.  If he does come in to the convention with many more delegates than anyone else (i.e., Cruz and Kasich) he will have done so fair and square.  If the Party leaders then turn away from him and hand the nomination to one of the others- or to Paul Ryan or Mitt Romney- they'll truly deserve to have a riot on their hands.  At the very least, the Reichsfuhrer will lead his untermenschen out the front door, establish a third party candidacy and hand the general election to Hillary (or Bernie).  Having gone this far to win over "hearts" and "minds," he's not going to do something completely out of character, like go gently into that good night.  Nor should he.

If Trump arrives at the Convention with more delegates than anyone else, but less than 50% of the total, he hasn't yet won the nomination "fair and square".  If Trump fails to win an absolute majority of votes in the first ballot at the Convention, it would be perfectly fair and reasonable (and in accordance with rules that Trump has accepted by competing for the GOP nomination) for delegates to vote for and select some other candidate in a subsequent ballot.  If this were not the case, what is the point of conducting votes at the Convention?

I have always thought that The Donald's plan was to make a deal for, say, a billion $$, to bow out and support whomever the GOP controllers designated. He would have agreed to keep the terms private. Of course, after a few months (say in October) he would find some reason to publicize the deal, show himself to be a winner and the GOP to be inept chumps.
But now, I'm not so sure. He may believe that he can actually govern.
This is more fun than professional wrestling.

.
@ idzach

The rise of Donald Trump should drive many Americans -- certainly, our historians, philosophers, psychologists, clergy, and scholars of electoral politics -- to carefully and unblinkingly examine who we are and why we vote the way we vote. So epic is the cache of hidden traits that have been uncovered by that living, breathing, short-fingered Rohrshach Test.

But that is not a sign that he can win the 2016 presidential election. In my opinion, he cannot. Ahead of him are numerous speeches and appearances, debates, delegate-selection events, encounters with State law and rules, a party Convention, more campaigning, more debates, attacks on him by PACs, financial realities, more encounters with State law and rules, voting, election litigation, and the Electoral College process.

At one of those junctures, he will be thwarted. Either his pursuit of office will actually end (he will fail to qualify for the ballot in enough states, e.g.) or it will figuratively grind to a halt (as happened to the unqualified Marco Rubio when his adopted home state did not support him for nomination).

We have tremendous cause for worry about our nation. There are unknowns which could turn out to be immensely disturbing. But our worries need not include the chance of Donald Trump taking the Presidential Oath next January.

The two families are in the same order, which makes them relatives. It's like saying two genera in the same family are relatives or two species in the same genus are relatives.

I'm not sure what the order of families in your reference signifies, but it seems a bit out of date. For instance, Commelinaceae and Pontederiaceae have been moved to a different order, Commelinales while Cyperaceae and Juncaceae remain in Poales.

I'm not at all disappointed with this clue.

Even if the Republicans manage to get rid of Il Trumpe, they have no one qualified to run fo0r president of the USA.

Ted Cruz? Gov. Kasich? Mitt Romney? Paul Ryan? Extreme right-wing ideologues all.

The Republican party is a racist, classist, sexist dinosaur fit for nothing higher than the dustbin of history. The sooner it arrives there the better, starting first and foremost with their idiotic Senate leader, Mitch McConnell, the most cynical man in Washington.
A standing ovation for this comment!

As for your comment about Mitch McConnell, it reminds me of the old Rodney Dangerfield joke.
Doctor to Mitch: You're cynical.
Mitch: I want a second opinion.
Doctor: Ok, you're ugly, too.

Now wait a minute. There are decent people among the Republicans.

Just not enough to move the party towards decency.

There's lot of funny stuff to say here, but think about what you're really saying.

The situation is that the establishment politicians have done such an abysmal job of looking out for their constituents, for decades now, that the electorate is furious and ready to "throw the bums out."

The consensus among the upper classes seems to be that it's perfectly okay for the Republican elites to take the steering wheel away from the voters when they don't like who the voters are likely to elect.

On the Democratic side, this has largely been achieved pre-emptively by the DNC and the Clinton Machine co-opting the entire main stream media. Their view was: we're picking Hillary, don't give the voters any other choice. And because of the utter failure of the Fourth Estate to do its job, and instead becoming the mouthpiece of the Clinton Campaign, they have largely succeeded in making it extremely difficult for a different candidate to get basic airtime and serious consideration.

The Repubs on the other hand, are just going to do a brazen, late-in-the-game power grab.

Given JFK's words: "Those who would make a peaceful revolution impossible, make a violent revolution inevitable", wouldn't it be wiser for the elite/establishment/1% to reconsider their game plan of seizing power in whatever undemocratic way they can, and start working for the American People instead of Wall Street and the Koch Brothers?
I am worried about Bill tho. Lately he seems encumbered emotionally!
I thought the 1% were the Hell's Angels.  Or are they now the elite in the US?

I'd be more inclined to agree if the people also seemed to be willing to throw all the other bums out--specifically the highly overcompensated do-nothings masquerading as congresspeople.

But apparently the "they're all corrupt" mentality doesn't extend to people's individual legislators ("s/he seems nice").

Though I wish it would be, I don't think 2016 qualifies as a wave election year yet. Trump's popularity represents the sour grapes of a contingent of scared xenophobic working class conservatives--who DO have legitimate economic problems--who think that blowing a raspberry toward Washington is an effective way to register their displeasure. But these conservatives don't seem to have any decent ideas about how to fix what they deem to be broken, or how getting the rot out of Congress, and local legislatures, might be a first step; they just want the good feeling that comes with being angry and denigrating, because that's about all the pleasure they can afford these days.

(If they had any sense, and weren't so easy to lead into the divide and conquer trap set up by cynical plutocrats, they might consider voting for Bernie. But "you're getting what you don't deserve" seems to Trump--pun intended--"we're all in this together" every time.)

The old white male "regulars" of the GOP are not happy with the current choices of Donald, Ted, and John. For 7 plus years the GOP has voted against the ACA forever and followed Ted to close down the government and ruin American's vacations to National Parks and cost the government they hate millions. Seven years and no higher minimum wage, no additional spending on infrastructure (jobs, jobs, jobs and much needed improvements-even Donald recognizes our airports need work!), no support for women's health, no tax reduction for the middle class & lower, no help with education expenses, no support for renewable energy,  ... Nothing has been done to improve anyone's life. And this party of white men wonder why there is a fire in the party they cannot control or suffocate? Their racist attitude toward Pres. Obama has diminished their party and hurt our nation. Unfortunately, those supporting the current GOP candidates are still blaming the wrong people. Rather than attacking immigrants and Muslims and every other group they don't like, these followers need to attack the regulars of the party who have done nothing for 7 plus years.
You forget that they all lie when they say that climate change is a hoax.
That's what the vote for Trump is, an attack on the regulars. The voters are trying to frag the officers.
And they need to blame the corporations that off-shored their jobs.

Gail, Trump is well-prepared for victory and has a tremendous group of advisers waiting in the wings after he gets elected:

Melania Trump (wife), First Lady
Donald Trump Jr. (son), White House Chief of Staff
Ivanka Trump (daughter), Secretary of State
Robert Trump (brother), Secretary of the Treasury
Maryanne Trump, (sister), Supreme Court Justice
Elizabeth Trump (sister), Secretary of Commerce
Eric Trump (son), Secretary of Labor
Tiffany Trump (daughter), White House spokeswoman
Barron Trump (son), Secretary of Agriculture. He's a preteen, but who knows or cares what a Secretary of Agriculture does? He'll be tremendous in the position. In addition to being the president, Trump will assume the roles of Attorney General, Secretary of Defense, Secretary of Transportation, and Director of Homeland Security. The Trump family will be tremendous for all of us.

I like that way better than a President Jeb Bush, with all the advisers and sycophants who helped to destroy the country and its economy under a President George W. Bush.

Why just 8 years ago, we hated Bush for what he did to our country. We elected Obama for the change he promised, but could not deliver.

A Change is Gonna Come...
don't let gail collins convince you that another Bush presidency would be a good thing. For her stock portfolio perhaps, but not for American lives and workers and young people.
SKJ:  Who will be his vice president?
No!  Trump has but one advisor, he himself with his great brain and the best words.
The Donald is hardly a Bolshevik.  He's more like a Bolsh'ik artist.  Actually it's Il Duce who comes to mind (he was good at making silly faces, too).

It sounds like your religious views are letting you confuse the medical difference between a child and a fetus.  It also sounds like you don't understand the legal separation of church and state.   I was going to mention the fact that, in the same way I don't get to impose my belief that until you become clear about the difference, you should have a vasectomy, you don't get to dictate what a woman does with her body.
