comments.commentBody:
>>>>

The whole objective of drones is non-transparency.

The loss of democracy may be a gradual process of erosion....like torture, the more you do it, the more acceptable it becomes.

The less people think about Guantanamo, the less upsetting it seems.

Drones are so wonderfully clean and clinical...the bodies are left behind and soon out of mind.

Trump says he will do more torture, not less. With leadership like that, soon there will be little cultural resistance left to calling just about all military murder in the national interest!

Our drones generally target terrorist training centers or their meeting cells. Any "civilian" losses are usually other would-be terrorists, their families and supporters. Whether that is collateral damage is debatable.

However, using drones outside of war zones or in clandestine operations is immoral and unconstitutional. Areas where drones are used must be declared war zones, and use of drones must be approved by the Congress. That will set us on a moral high ground to preach and deter other countries and rogue nations from abusing this powerful technology.
That doesn't explain things like wedding parties.

Declared war zones? Sorry, the US has not declared war since right after Pearl Harbor. The post 9/11 half measures aren't close to the real deal.

And I'm sure you have proof that civilian casualties are "would be terrorists." The government has provided none to date. Even if they were terrorists, our constitution proscribes summary execution. Due process, speedy trial, the right to confront one's accuser. All the things we disposed of at Guantanamo.

Bhaskar, I agree completely with your second paragraph. There is no legal justification for drone warfare outside actual war zones (not self-declared by Obama). Any purported justification is at the same legal level as the twisted torture memos of the Bush administration--that is, it is fraudulent. Secret "legal" memos that cannot be disclosed also cannot be believed--that is, if we are democracy.

But I cannot agree with your first paragraph. You have no reason to believe those things except claims by our government, which is unwilling and apparently afraid to let anyone see their alleged reasoning.

We complain loudly and bitterly about the very rare terrorist attacks on our soil. But when we kill innocents not on the battlefield, how is that NOT terrorism?
The constitution is very clear about President Obama's "kill list." We do not impose guilt and summarily execute people without due process of law. "Because Obama says so" is woefully short of that standard.

My apologies if I seem obtuse, but I cannot find any meaning whatever in your use of the word "battlefield " in this context. Are not New York City, London, Madrid, Paris, Bali et. al. battlefields in a global war of terror?

It must be painful to look in the face of Donald J. Trump and realize he's the true face of the Republican Party and the outcome of the last 7 years of malice and obstruction.  Both parties have played their part in the destruction of the economic and social life of the majority of American in their varying roles in widening the gulf between haves, have less and have nots.  There's nothing Republicans won't give to taker Corporations, to subsidize stock manipulators and nothing they won't take from everyone else.  I don't know that Jack Kemp made any lasting contribution to the philosophy or practice of governance and Paul Ryan, in my view, is a laughable tyro.  Mitch McConnell, John Boehner, Eric Cantor and Paul Ryan are the bacilli that grew the tumor of paralysis.  Donald J. Trump is an outcome as was Hitler because of the paralysis of Weimar Germany.  The commonweal has been left to rot and drift and that tills the soil for growing the totalitarian plant.

There are no political or moral principles left in the governing class: holding on to office is the only imperative.  In the end, they'll all boost Trump if it means keeping office.  There are a lot of Chris Christi toadies about.

Jennifer Steinhauer's original article was a factual account of Sanders' adroit use of the amendment process in enacting his desired policies.

The post-publication revisions of the piece by Times editors speculated on the probability that Sanders' platform will be passed by Congress should he be elected president. Such speculation belongs on the opinion pages, not in the news pages.

Unfortunately, the Times' news coverage of the Sanders campaign has shown negative bias throughout. Readers and other journalists have noticed. The Times' credibility has been badly undercut.
I didn't see the first version.  Did it mention any of his skullduggery on guns?
How about showing that Nation comes first and just not fielding a candidate.  Cancel the convention and the rest of the primaries.
That doesn't explain things like wedding parties.
I only wish I were comfortable in the thought that Trump will lose.  Hillary Clinton, like Romney and Perry, is a recycled reject.

Richard, I'm open to correction but I believe that that one result of ending the Fairness Doctrine was that the networks changed the business model for their news divisions. News was previously a "loss leader" that the networks were required to provide as a public service in exchange for free use of the airwaves.

Once the FD was gone, news as a public service went with it and it became a profit center instead. Now, I know much has changed since then because of cable and the internet, but it seems to me that a precedent was set by that cultural upheaval, and we are paying the price to this day. I'm not saying that road-kill stories would have been absent today, but surely the fascination with them would have been held in check.

For the first six months have the teenager drive you all the places you used to drive her or him. You were driving your child to school and practices anyway. Just do it for six more months with the kid driving. Time with an experienced driver helps a new driver develop traffic awareness.

There's another good side to this. If a child lives a long way from school and has been driven there, when the teen starts driving, time that was used for a bit of extra study or sleep is replaced with the tension of driving in traffic. It's a pain for the adult who has been looking forward to not being a chauffeur, but take over the driving a day or two a week until the teen adjusts to the change.

Great observation that this type of reporting is what we expect from Fox News, not the supposed "paper of record". It's also what we'd expect in a society with no tradition of objectivity in news reporting.

How low the Times has sunk.

"The hawk might pass. It might."

Let's hope it doesn't pass.

How to tell your kids that sex,that is the physical aspects of it can be the most intense pleasure, or the most painful depending on who and how it is done with.

The problem being if it is good experience you do not want to stop, and if it is not you will resist it for a long time. And to go along with that the emotional attachment the develops between couples, and the anger and resentment that comes when one of them wants to stop. The psychology of sex is just as addictive as the physical is.

Porn is just an example of what can be done physically, but it does not convey the emotions involved, and emotions are the driving force behind mans/womans behavior in life. It takes practice and experience, but the great number of young people do not want a partner that is experienced, they have the belief that experience means lose morals.

The best partners are ones that know what they like and how to achieve it, and that takes more than a raunchy film. Good love stories help, but they can foster unrealistic expectations. too. When I was in the military the most sexually repressed men I observed, were from New England, I think it was mostly due to religion.

NA

That's true enough, but Cruz is no less problematic and pulling the rug from under Trump will not go down quietly. Either way, the GOP is in a huge quandary with no clean way out.
If it talks like Il Duce, looks like Il Duce, acts like Il  Duce, it might be the reincarnation of Il Duce.
I checked. Trump was born about 15 months after Mussolini's death. Could be.
How'd you get a little green check with snarky remarks like this, David? How can I get one?

I live in a place like you've described. Reports of fatal traffic accidents often conclude, "speed and alcohol were a factor."

Changes are coming. A few years ago four kids died on prom night: drinking, speed, no seatbelts. Shortly after a girl drove off a curve. Her phone was found in her hand with a half finished text message. These accidents were a wakeup call for parents. Schools started emphasizing not drinking or texting and driving.

Ryan's optimistic rhetoric hides numbers that do not add up and a belief in the enervating effects of the welfare state that is contradicted by his own life history.    The Kempian vision did not work and Republicans have been playing footsie with white racists since 1980, but in ways that preserve deniability for those with a need to be gullible.  The establishment vision gets us huge budget deficits, useful as ammunition against the New Deal.  The Tea Party vision sees only governments as limiting individual freedom; their dislike and suspicion toward big business and high finance does not see these as limiting individual freedom (except by using government to do so).

you have neatly summed up in one paragraph why the current party is in trouble. Contradictions and an inability to smooth over some clearly glaring disconnects. The horse has finally broken down and the likes of Ryan keep trying to beat it to get it moving again. Good luck with that.
1980? I'd say 1964. Before that, it was principally the Democrats who played footsie with White racists. LBJ sent them to the Republicans, who gave them a warm welcome.

So William Kristol, editor of The Weekly Standard, has a plan.  His plans, and those of the other "operatives" for BIG democracy-destroying "conservative" money masters have backfired.  Don't you people get it?  The vast majority of Americans do not want your crash and burn America agenda.  Rick Perry?  Tom Coburn?  Really?  Why not just run David Koch - they're all about as popular as the plague.  DT serves you right because he proves that all the money in the world cannot buy America.  Fear Not.  WE progressives, democrats and independents will get rid of him and elect Ms. Hillary Rodham Clinton as the next President of the United States.  Then we will make sure that groups of money masters like you can never get control of America again.
Clinton is owned by Wall Street and the banking industry. Another false god.
Hillary Clinton, the Goldman Sachs cheerleader?

Sure, let's elect Clinton,a woman who has committed federal crimes against the US. People have been sent to prison for less. Where have our values gone?  If she was deceitful as Secretary of State, imagine what she'll do as president.  Some back door deal with China or Iran. You'll wake up one morning and we'll be another  $10 trillion in debt, wait,  that already happened.  The current administration has failed on all levels, billions of dollars promised to Iran if they play nice, which they have not.  $7 billion to support the infrastructure of Africa to provide electricity to the desert.  WAKE UP AMERICA!

comments.commentBody: This is a perfect example of the corrupt consequences of unregulated wealth.  Finally, on November 8 and every election before and after, WE can bring the damage of insatiable, unregulated greed to an end.
Regulated wealth will be even more corrupt. A bigger incentive to buy government.

While Mr. Kepner is glorifying the father-son baseball tradition, I find it just bizarre that he completely leaves daughters (and perhaps mothers?) out of the story. In 2016? Really?
And I highly doubt that keeping your children out of school and imposing your son on your work colleagues (regardless of how much they say they 'love' him) on a daily basis is something to be emulated. Instead, it's the worst kind of arrogance and parental indulgence.
Big Boohoo. Get a life.

How many of us have made a tenth what LaRoche has made in twelve years? It's easy to take early retirement when you have millions to live on. Lots of families would be ecstatic to live forever on what he made just last year.

Quitting your lavishly paid job because you can't bring your son to work with you? Sounds kinda spoiled, to me.

What is strange is your need to attribute some dysfunction to a highly successful father who is invested in his family and despite a profession that separates men from their wives and children for most of the year, and often requires disruptive moves to new team locations, his career achievements and potential positive impact for a team gave him leverage to have his son with him.  Most fathers use the excuse of work to treat their families like accessories and prefer to hang with the guys playing golf or indulging their drug of choice.  Equally strange is your notion of schools being ideal, nurturing environments for kids.  Must be why we spend billions trying to combat bullying, reduce horrendous drop out rates, fight drug abuse and once or twice a year shake our heads when one of the fun kids comes with an UZI and sprays murder and mayhem.  And that's before actual educational issues such as schools that simply warehouse kids and they come out functionally illiterate.  Majority of comments today reflect men who feel defensive about their sham relationship to their families and feel better twisting a caring father's decision into some dark perversity.  That's truly creepy.

and Elke

The rest of my time was used to create a H(U)MAN T(R)ASH HEAP-
mostly prune and apricot, a few poppy seed.

ADIEU.
If it were LAFFITE it might be an ore mined by comics.

If your clothes are UNTIDY, you can slough off that problem by achieving its anagram.

.
I think of your guy as Jedediah, the same name as the President on The West Wing. That POTUS's last name was Bartlett. The next head of the NYT Editorial Board is named "Bennet". His brother is a Colorado Senator who used to head the fundraising committee for Democratic Senate candidates. The brother has endorsed Hillary Clinton, but I imagine those family ties will bother no one.

JFC, a year ago your Golden Age Bulls were the only NBA team with 44 consecutive home-court wins. Now there are 3; and the Spurs have a very winnable game on the day after an off-day, so they can go on to 45 pretty smoothly. Meanwhile, some here may be happy at what TAMU did (and to whom).

The Knicks could sorely use Walkup who plays with more guts and passion than their entire team.
Walkup will make any NBA team better immediately. The Knicks could certainly use him as an example of how to play the game of basketball.
the knicks need way more than a walkup.  They need an owner who knows basketball, or who knows enough to stay away.  And the knicks are so yesterday.  Golden State!

Hell ofa game, hell ofa finish, the lumberjacks also won tonite.

A great game, the Lumberjacks won the night and Thomas Walkup will be a great addition to any NBA team. Congratulations.

the losses are so tough for these young men, but the pride i would hope they carry can last a lifetime. i'm an athlete so I don't talk trash here - the heartbreak is real, but the accomplishments are MORE real. tough to lose, good to win, but, best to put it all out there bewteen the whistles and the lines.
A very succinct and pointed reply to LaRoche -- well done and keep it up!

"There is something wrong with someone who home-schools their child, then decides that the schooling will consist of taking the kid with them every day. Home schooled children rarely do well in life - for one thing, most kids are home schooled because their parents are religious crazies who don't want their children polluted with devilish ideas like science, evolution, history, sex ed. "

I'd like to see your evidence for your assertions. Opinion presented as fact is mere Trumpery, and we've had far too much of that in recent months.

This article is one example of sports writers not waiting and spending more time around a story. First, several members of the White Sox told management they were uncomfortable having a 14 year old kid always in the clubhouse, even in meetings. Second, LaRoche blowtorched Williams, Reinsdorf, White Sox management, and a result, his own teammates with his entitled self-absorption.

Don't agree? This is from one of the top beat writers covering the Chisox. Read and understand LaRoche's skewed, entitled perspective: http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20160319/sports/160318552/?utm_source...

All of you holier-than-thou commenters are missing one crucial point: Williams lied to everyone, telling players the coaches were to blame, telling coaches was the players, and telling the press is was the owner. If LaRoche used time with his kid as a condition in his contract, he has every right. If he felt that condition was unfairly revoked, he has every right as well to retire (or sue, which he decided not to do).

How many here ignore the ham-fisted way Williams handled this situation, and readily pass judgment on LaRoche's parenting skills, is beyond my keen.

Well, it ought to be interesting. United has the better youngsters coming in and established, but Mourinho has no use for kids. Chel$ki had dominant youth teams that Mourinho promised to use, but somehow never did. Van Gaal set in motion the young core of Bayern that is playing for Guardiola. The question is, does DeGea head for Madrid for real this time. If Mourinho is coming in, it will be the first time since Porto that he didn't inherit a team ready to win immediately. Can he build a team from scratch? He hasn't in over a decade.

On the other hand, Guardiola, like Van Gaal, values youth, and is about to take over the oldest team in the Premier League. It would be hilarious if both Manchester teams welcomed the biggest name managers with Europa League Thursday Nights. At least Guardiola will be spared the indignity of following a second lame duck manager to win a treble before he takes over.

Golden States presents as playing smarter than the other guys. Not last night; Boris Diaw was in the house, and when, as in the case now, he is fit, he elevates the Spurs to a whole other level.

All I've read and heard from the experts was Aldridge and Leonard. All I know is is that, without Diaw,had no chance. The defense was superb, but it was the Spurs ability to get what they wanted on offense, to create easy chances in the half court off multiple passes, unscripted riffs off a schematic, impossible to game for, that beat Golden State at its own game. It just might be that what we we saw last night is what Pop has decided to go with.

If so, it will be a work in progress, and all the taking thus far becomes irrelevant. Next play.

This game was an example of  late 90s/early 2000s basketball at its finest. The Spurs have realized that they only way to beat Golden State is to force them to play slow, grind-it-out and pound-it-inside basketball, combined with stifling anti-Curry perimeter defense. They will never blow out the Warriors that way, but they will make every game close. Aldridge is just too big for small-ball. If these two teams meet in the playoffs it will be a series for the ages.
Twice as many three point shots were taken in the game compared with the typical game in 2000.  Three point shooting has changed the game so much that no game today resembles any game 20 years ago.
A great game but both teams can loose to the other and still be good.

Regular season wins in the NBA are often tainted.  Playing a team in the second game of a back to back, when they're in the middle of a long road trip, or when their stars are sitting for minor injuries gives you an advantage.  This cuts both ways, off course.  But setting the record for regular season wins is not nearly as meaningful nor as important as winning in the playoffs.  Playoff basketball is a lot more intense than regular season games. Winning in the regular season is a sign that you excel when everybody is going 75%.  The Warriors are surely much more intent on winning the championship than beating the 1995-96 Bulls.
Chicago Guy:  I agree with neither assertion.

When I was young (born in 1945), America was indeed "the greatest country in the world" - at least for people like myself. I went to excellent public schools with lots of other middle income - not rich - kids. I had student loans in college, but the federal government paid for much of my graduate education in political science and Asian Studies. The economy and the plentitude of decent jobs made it possible to choose rather than just settle for things in our lives, and the intellectual and cultural atmosphere was serious, not trivial, due to the debate over the Vietnam War and the Civil Rights Movement - not to mention the earliest stages of feminism.

All of these things I was very lucky to experience. But now we live in the age of economic insecurity, political theocracy, Trump and Cruz. Etc. Everything nowadays is either dangerous or trivial. But given the benefits of being an American in my youth, I feel I have some obligation to stick it out in the States while we all go to hell in a hand basket.

Then again, if Ted "Torquemada" Cruz becomes President . . . well, that will be a real test!
Oh, they'd better not! We'd have a riot - sorry, protest - and push 'em into the ocean!

Conservative pundits live in a bubble of their own, just like pundits on the left. The difference is that they've come to the end of what they can do to keep the con going. The base no longer buys what they have to sell and Paul Ryan is the establishment.

Donald Trump very artfully found a way to repackage the con formula to his advantage. The idea of grabbing back all the loot Trump says the Chinese, Mexicans, Vietnamese, Japanese and others supposedly took from us is very alluring to jobless, underemployed, angry conservative members of the base. I am surprised pundits, on any side, has picked up on The Donald's promise to install Carl Icahn as his trade negotiator. Whose interests would he serve? We should be talking about who really took the loot and how trade agreements in recent decades have benefited a certain circle of robber barons.

Sound familiar? Yep! That's what Bernie talks about! without talking about grab, grab, grab... This, among many other reasons, is why he resonates to so many, including conservatives voters who won't vote for either Trump or Hillary and millions of Democrats who chose Bernie over Hillary in primaries which, by the way, we still are only halfway through.

We need to talk about the things voters care about: the precarious situation so many are in that pundits stopped talking about, and how it gets better.

--

On trade & the progressive/neoliberal split: http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-27p
Which Dem will Republicans pick? http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-27G

You may have pointed out the only saving grace of a Trump Presidency, but it is a big one.

I would not welcome his ascendence to the office, but I don't live with the fear or concern that others voice.

He is an American and he likes his country.

On top of everything else with a Jewish son-in-law he can't be all bad.

Ian,

So, in your book, he's a Jew by proxy and that's a good thing? That's a terrible way to like or dislike people... You know, the stuff about judging people by their character Martin Luther King talked about?

But that might actually backfire on the GOP since Trump's fanatical followers are dumb enough to believe that when Bernie says "Let them eat cake" he's actually referring to cake in the Betty Crocker sense of the term.

"We have learned what conditions make the prime environment for the rise of a demagogue: disaffection, demographic change, the demise of hope and opportunity and the dislocation of traditional power and privilege from automatic inheritance of prosperity."

Easy for you to say, Charles. Your peers made the real estate developer as they were doing their best to foil the boy from Brooklyn. Now, as we are at the halfway point of the election cycle and your peers insist on the victorious outcome of the presumptive queen, an image is emerging of a disaffected part of the Republican electorate that sees the queen in the same light as the Republican establishment and, in the absence of an acceptable Republican nominee, will trust Bernie Sanders more than Hillary Clinton.

As you pointed out last week, the media bias against Bernie Sanders has been more than apparent, including this paper's strange editing and eventual transformation of a piece on Sanders from positive to its polar opposite, over the objections of readers who noticed.

But the Times has hardly been alone in its dereliction of journalistic duty. So, along all the things you write about that we learned, we are also learning to disconnect from traditional media and going to trusted sources for news and analysis.

The media has become a bubble, disconnected from the suffering in the nation, hellbent on forcing its will. Will the people bend?
==

In Trump's America, Which Dem will Republicans pick? http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-27G

this guy still got promoted over the last 25 years across the media-plex because he generated ratings and mouse clicks - a rather perfect emblem of our society, the media, and ever constant genuflecting/ego stroking sought by 1%-ers and 1/10th%-ers, leveraged to the hilt in the CEO/billionaire class.

That is a truly bizarre accusation -- that Donald Trump owned a copy of a book of Hitler's speeches (or so says his EX-wife in DIVORCE testimony!)....and of course, that was 26 years ago.

When I was a kid, my father -- a Jew -- had a copy of a similar book (perhaps the same book). Are you saying that therefore, my Jewish father was a secret Nazi sympathizer? Or is it that Donald Trump read this book -- in the 1980s! -- and memorized it, but kept it completely secret for 26 years, while developing a career as a TV reality show host, only to spring it on the public in his 69th year????

And you have the nerve to accuse Republicans of making stuff up. Yeesh.

Is the Sun on the GOP setting?

Perhaps they will select Rick Perry

comments.commentBody: I am an avid tennis fan, and I was shocked by Mr. Moore's crude comments. Really? He is in charge of one of the finest combined men's and women's tournaments on the tour, yet he feels this way? He cannot stay in his position with that kind of appalling lack of judgment, apology notwithstanding. Statements have consequences.
Apologize? He was right.

The strange thing is that the article itself seems to prove he was right. Instead of attempting to establish that the women's game is currently on par with the men, it shows a photo of Chris and Martina from decades ago, as if to admit that the women are below par now, but defending on the grounds that men once were too. But the man wasn't talking about the past, only about the present. Can a reasoned argument be made that the women's game is as compelling as the men's right now? If so it certainly wasn't in this article.  And meanwhile, demanding equal pay the women do not demand to play matches of equal length, meaning the men can often deliver much more bang for the buck than the women.
That just shows your lack of ignorance about tennis. But, let's not digress from the debate here.
Who even cares about American men's tennis?  Everyone I know only watches women's tennis. This neanderthal should be fired for his sexist remarks!

Look: tennis is not a contact sport (although, even if it were, so what?) If women have a better game--if they've EVER had a better game--let them prove it. All purses, for male and female events, should be combined (the problem of disparate purses solved right there), and there should be no segregation of the genders. Let the best man or woman win. Until then, all this is politically correct bloviation and fulmination.

The only problem for women is that men would win a much larger portion of the combined purses and matches. If someone thinks this rank sexism, then get behind the movement to eliminate gender segregation. Put up or shut up.

Not following your logic there Marsha. Of course beginning players should earn less money than the stars. That's the way the system works. The issue is not that money is the central motive of owners and players. It is that, notwithstanding the protestations of letter writers in this forum, the men's game is objectively more popular than the women's game. I'm sorry, but facts are stubborn things.
Inexcusable comments from Moore.  Djokovic is certainly no "gentleman" either given such tone deaf remarks.  Sad all around.

"Lady players"?! Whatever his private opinions, why would Mr. Moore publicly proclaim such gratuitous nonsense? (More to the point, why is such a twit directing a major tournament?) And what does it say about tennis fans that Roger Federer, who is past his prime, is still such a favorite? Perhaps because we appreciate his "feminine" qualities of grace, balance and intelligence?

Meliflaw:
Since when are grace, balance and intelligence particularly feminine qualities? Do you really think that the reason we like to watch Federer is that he is in effect a "girly" man? You sound as sexist as Moore.

Obviously this guy should be fired. A tournament director should never say such things about his sport. I imagine that this will be arranged.

However, crudely he says it, there is a correct point underneath. There is women's soccer and women's basketball, whose athlete do not get even 10% of the men's sports. But they do not play in co-ed tournaments, where women can flat negotiate for equal everything.

I regret that other women's sports get such mammoth disrespect. They deserve better. However, in tennis, they get too much. Women's matches get less TV viewership, fewer on-court viewers and, at Grand Slam tournaments, provide less entertainment hours. Those are the currency of entertainment remuneration!

If tournaments were purely separate for tennis, as they are for other sports, women would be grossly underpaid in tennis too. I love to watch women's tennis -- I would rather they be overpaid than underpaid.

God bless Obama

I'm not arguing for complacency, but our current measures are extraordinary by any measure. We cannot let a single attack in Belgium, probably the most vulnerable state in Europe, dictate major security decisions and long-term strategy in the US. Our challenges are totally unique: An ocean separates us from Middle East conflicts, so we do not have droves of returning foreign fighters. We do monitor our borders - not perfectly, but they are nowhere near as porous as European nations. Our intelligence network and investment in homeland security dwarfs that in any other country on the planet; hundreds of Belgian professionals do the job that many thousands perform in the US and abroad. Take a look at the screening process for Syrian refugees relocating to the US, and tell me that it's anywhere NEAR as lax as refugee policies in Europe.

Our security policies since 2001 have either prevented or foiled every major organized terror plot involving foreign attackers. Conversely, we have demonstrated time and time again that we are vulnerable to radicalized lone-wolves already on our soil. Security measures that promote further radicalization will do more to hinder our goals than advance them.

I find myself in agreement with Art Kraus and -- possibly a first -- the Canadian duo of Robert and Robert (at least one of whom has a doctorate).

Mr./Dr. Kraus, you may submit a correction for photo captions any time they appear. Wordplay photo captions are corrected every now and then, although the only important one involved a photo of Brett Favre a few days after the Jets signed him.

I would submit the correction myself, but for the fact that I believe the Corrections Desk ignores my emails by now. They are not alone. I was flipping through the Pulitzer Prize website of an afternoon, trying to learn why there is no prize for crossword commentary, when I happened upon a photo with an inaccurate caption. I called in to the office at the journalism school that handles such matters, and reported the error. The person on the phone said she would inform "the tech". So a year later, I learned that the person in the photo was the top editor of a major paper. I checked the Pulitzer site to see if the photo was still there. It was, with the inaccurate caption. So I telephoned the major paper. I asked the person on the other end whether she would be able to transmit info to the editor. When she said yes, I gave her the URL of the photo and asked her to do whatever she wished with the information. It was, after all, her boss in the photo, not me.

Five hours later, I checked the photo. The caption had been fixed.

Darn!  I thoroughly enjoyed your recaps.  I'm fairly new to reading the Times online and just now discovered I could make a comment.

There is an excellent website called sourdo.com which sells sourdough cultures from all over the world. I use the one they got from a centuries old bakery on the Island of Ischia in Italy, and it makes great Italian bread and pizza that tastes like the stuff you get in Naples (I also use an oven that gets un to 900 degrees go it bakes in a few minutes the way they do it there). This is a sourdough which is not very sour. When on vacation in Brazil I have started my own culture by simply putting out a flour and water mixture out on the windowsill until it starts to bubble, and I made some tremendous bubbly focaccia using this culture. Sourdo.com was started by a pathologist who became interested in and collecting ancient sourdough cultures, and he also has a book which explains how to maintain and "wash" your cultures, and which has many recipes. One thing I learned from him is that activating your culture before you use it gives the best results- so take a cup out of your mother culture from the refrigerator, add a cup of flour and a half cup of spring or distilled (NOT city tap water), mix it and let it rise at room temperature (or a little higher if possible - 75-80 degrees) until it rises and froths (and it may overflow your bowl)- at that point the culture is maximally active, and if you use it to make dough it will cause it to rise very briskly and make great bread.
I have never been able to get a decent rise out of a sourdough starter even though I've had some supposedly well-established or even commercially available starters... thoughts, help?

The only thing I can suggest is making sure you are proofing at an adequate temperature.   Some ovens have a proofing mode, where the temperature is around 80 degrees.  You can also build a proofing box by using a low wattage light bulb with a dimmer switch and thermometer in a styrofoam container, and trying to proof at higher temperatures- experiment from 75-90 degrees.  When I made my own local sourdough starter in Brazil the temperature was probably in the 80s or higher which is one reason it did so well.  A room temperature of 68 or even 72 is too low to really get cultures fully activated.  When you activate your culture you should see it rise "exponentially" as it rises and bubbles up and peaks then starts shrinking down as it starts to run out of the sugar needed for growing with the shortest doubling time.

I was wondering if that guy was still around (at Sourdoughs International)!

I bought, via mail order in the late '80s, three of the packaged starters as offered by Sourdoughs International. Of the two starters I've still got going, one is the Russian starter offered on the sourdo.com website from that initial order. The other is a recipe using Champagne grapes I got from Steve Singleton's method as described in "Chez Panisse Cookbook," by Alice Waters.

I agree with both the article and commenters that started adopt and adapt to local ingredients and atmosphere. I must say, that my two starters, although fed from the same trough, bear distinct qualities: one is sweet and mildly sour, the other quite pungent and bolder (the Russian).

-- Randy

The clue for 35A is a bit of a stretch.  Baseball season does start in April and the DC team is the NATIONALS, so the Post might right about them.  Does that REALLY make a NAT a "figure" in the Post?

When I was younger, I was too. I know I've become more casual about my body and it helps that Asian people seem rather more casual than Americans in general.

Is there something here we can learn from the Asians?

Four of us had the bottle of La Gravitate de Certan during a meal of rewarmed fried chicken and sides. At the beginning of the meal, one of our party indicated that the nose on the wine was like the essence of good fruit. Later, as the meal progressed, another expressed how much he enjoyed the mouthfeel of the wine, describing how the tannins melted in one's mouth and seemed to seep deep into the tongue, coming back to life for a long lingering finish on every taste bud. Finally, at the end of the meal, we all agreed that the nose and taste of the wine seemed to grow in stature. It soldiered on and on. We look forward to trying more Pomerol wines in the near future.
Too many people think that everybody should believe what they believe.  It's a my way or the highway kind of world. People complain of religious intolerance.  Secular intolerance is no better.

The US needs more Protestants on SCOTUS. Germany has had similar problems with the opinions of Adenauer and his followers. With the reunification this has faded away. The East Germans are much more open to equality for women.
One can develop any make-believe and claim it's a religion, then get a tax exemption.  Millions in profiteering and crystal cathedrals anyone?  Laughing all the way to the bank!
It's just the way health insurance works.  It's no different from sharing the cost of your bypass surgery.

Yes it can be health care. My mother had 8 pregnancies resulting in 7 children and became ill after the last pregnancy. Her body was spent. Her doctor told her if she got pregnant again she would die. So my mother sought guidance from our (horrible) parish priest who said, "No Birth Control!" And yet, Catholic wives are supposed to be available for sex when ever the husband wants it. Go figure that one out! I told her that the world is not black and white like the parish priest seemed to think. It is gray and God gave us brains for a reason. He doesn't expect you to die and leave behind a husband and 7 children nor does he expect you to go without conjugal bliss. She went on birth control and is now 82, thank you very much! 'The Pill' is prescribed for many health related reasons, not just birth control (which I personally believe IS health care).

Actually Birth control IS healthcare. You are misinformed.  Many women need it for various medical reasons, as well as for being responsible about their lives.  Please get educated about this. Ignorance such as this is destructive.

The United States of America is one of the very few countries in the free world which continues to control women's bodies.  For all the spouting the politicians do about "freedom" and "democracy" and "rights", women remain left behind in USA.
Let the churches start paying taxes before they assert their "rights."
So women end up with a separate but equal insurance card for contraceptive coverage - what’s not to like?

Why don't we just get it over with and have a statute that lets people excuse themselves from any law with which they have a religious disagreement? Then we can have the theocratic system that Republicans seem to want.

No, what they are trying to do is penalize women who do not accept THEIR belief that contraception is immoral.  By refusing to participate in a program that allows their employees, whatever their own religion might be, freedom of choice and freedom to follow their own conscience, they are saying that women who choose to use contraceptives in violation of the beliefs of the Little Sisters will be punished by having to purchase contraception out of their own, perhaps limited, funds or do without no matter the consequences.  Whatever happened to their loving God?

Mr. Case, sir, the government isn't trying to force the poor little set upon church to pay for mortal sins.

They are asking them to fill out a form, which takes them off the hook for paying for mortal sins.

What about this don't you understand?

That was my first reaction to Alito's outlandish statement as well.  Isn't this provision exactly what he said was appropriate in the Hobby Lobby case?  Perhaps Adam Liptak could file another story on how exactly the provision under consideration here differs from what Justice Alito was seeking?

The nuns pay for it by having it taken from their paycheck but they are not paying out of pocket? What a liberal mindset you show. Even if the government picked up the tab we are still paying out of pocket. It's called taxes. But back to the point, just because it's taken before we can cash the check it is still out of pocket.

I simply cannot understand how allowing women access to birth control under their health insurance policy could somehow be considered a "moral wrong." Forcing women (especially impoverished young women) to bring unwanted lives into the world, when they are not emotionally or financially prepared to do so, seems like a much greater "moral wrong" to me. Not to mention that once you become a public employer, you should not be allowed to allow your religious views to block proper healthcare options for the people you employ.
But is seems religion is always given a "green light" to not pay taxes or cooperate in many other ways in American society.

How is it possible anyone can still be asking such a ridiculous question? Do you object when a man carrying the same insurance policy as yourself has his Cialis covered? Do you object when a fellow policyholder who is obese required diabetes care? Do you object when a fellow policyholder's dependent child requires nebulizer treatment? Do you nitpick over everyone else's minute healthcare details and obsess over which ones you deem worthy of the coverage your common insurance provides, and which ones you object to paying?
One might argue that every insurance payout is a form of coercion, except for the highly relevant fact that the very nature of insurance is a shared pool in which ALL are covered - whether they are women seeking contraception, men with ED, elderly persons on dementia medications, children with ADHD....the list is endless.
"Fairness" is a fairly irrelevant term to apply to insurance - and to health, for that matter. It isn't "fair" that someone can pay into insurance but never need it for more than an annual checkup. It isn't "fair" that a non smoker should get lung cancer. It isn't "fair" that drug prices increase so much, so rapidly.
If "fairness" is what one seeks in insurance, well - those people must find life terribly difficult to navigate. Unfairness everywhere!
Alito's comment that the "government's approach represented "an unprecedented threat to religious liberty in this country" strikes me as one of the stupidest things I have ever heard.
Alito may be one of the most stupid people ever appointed to the Supreme Court.
Especially when you consider how the government pressured the Mormons to renounce polygamy.

Indeed, Mr Alito is rabidly political and opposed to women's freedoms all his life. Even as a member of his Princeton Univ. eating club he opposed women members.  Including fellow Princeton students such as Justice Sotomayor!

Birth Control isn't prescribed ONLY to prevent conception, but rather for a variety of symptoms and diseases, including but not limited to: PMDD, endometriosis, and vertigo, which is the reason I take it. Some people will still be able to afford Birth Control without insurance, but many won't. For those that cannot afford it, this is the first step in a very dangerous spiral down to back alley abortions. If a woman cannot protect her ability to choose when or if she wants a child, and becomes pregnant, that same woman will undoubtedly run into serious problems with all of the new/recent TRAP laws. She'll have difficulty getting to a clinic that performs abortions, if there's one near her, and those TRAP laws will make her go through days or weeks of red tape. Until, of course, it's too late for a first trimester abortion, which is the purpose of the laws in the first place. Delay, delay, delay. She might be tempted by a back alley abortion, and she may not survive. But do the justices think about the future "her"? I imagine that they don't.

Most of those organizations that you mentioned did receive an exemption from the government. This suit is about filing a form. A form! The form registers their objection, so the insurance company handles it. So, what else can be done? This is ridiculous.
Those employees pay for their benefits. It's not free.

Doesn't it all just come down to: "Whose plan is it, anyway?" The conservative Justices seem to think the insurance policy is the school's or hospital's or nursing home's plan. But isn't it really the insurance company's plan to begin with, which the employer provides as part of the employee's compensation package? If so, how is it being "hijacked" from the employer. If the employer was an ordinary for-profit business corporation, it would receive a tax deduction for it's cost as a business expense: the the company doesn't buy it for itself, it buys the plan for its employees. Sounds like the insurance belongs to the employees. Whether for or non-profit, the employer could easily
provide a "flex-benefit" cash payment to each employee to buy insurance directly and thus not be taxed on the amount
-- would that cash payment somehow implicate the church-related proprietors in how the employee used that cash? There is no stateable limit to that sort of exception, unless we want to say religiously affiliated employers now must be exempted from the minimum wage or paying any wages at all given that the employees might do something sinful with that money.

Looking at the state of our infrastructure, rail system, decreasing quality of life for all but the 1%, and soaring income inequality, I'd say that it's past tense--they've ALREADY made us a third world nation!

I don't know where you live, but our polling stations in my small city are still open. We have no mandatory requirement to vote by mail

In the 40 years I've lived in several cities in the San Francisco Bay Area I've usually been able to walk to block or mile to my polling place. I see many of the same poll workers and they recognize me. I sometimes choose to vote by mail if I'm going to be out of town or out of the country on business.

(btw, there isn't an election in California until June)

Arizona DOES have early voting by mail in ballot. There is easy registration while at the MVD or even while accessing any of the state's official websites. Also, If you don't remove yourself from the roll, or lose your voting privilege you will be automatically registered and sent a ballot for all elections for which you are eligible to vote. I am frankly amazed that our republican controlled legislature enacted an early mail voting program as efficient and progressive as this is. Although counting the ballots... another issue entirely.

Fellow AZ voter, even if the mail-in ballot offers a convenient alternative to standing in line, voters (including myself) still prefers to go to a polling station and participate in our democracy through this medium. While waiting in line we were greater by activists, the media, and state legislatures championing their causes. But there is no excuse from the Arizona Election Commission for their incompetence in this. Cutting polling from 200 to 60 is an outrage. It took a national embarrassment for it to come to light the shadiness of our politics, and maybe we can see some movement to fair elections and a healthy debate on the current state of Arizona politics.

That is not correct. If you register as an Independent, you do NOT receive a ballot in "presidential preference" primaries unless you go through additional ridiculous processes to change your registration to R or D in time to receive an R or D ballot. MANY MANY registered Independents showed up at polling places in AZ to be told they were NOT eligible to vote. Since many independents are Sanders supporters, he lost thousands of votes in AZ.  I signed up for absentee ballots after almost being disenfranchised the second time I went to vote after moving to AZ in 2004. I had NOT been notified that my polling place had changed AND when I found the new polling place, they could not find my name on the list until I threw a total hissy fit. Despite being on the permanent mailing list, I call the voting registrar's office before EVERY election to make sure I am receiving the ballot and then call to be sure my signature was verified so my mailed-in vote was counted. There is NO REASON to trust voting in AZ no matter what county you reside in. The state is out to disenfranchise Democrats, independents, minorities, Latinos, and poor neighborhoods. It's corrupt and fighting to stay that way.

In many countries, e.g. Australia, it's a legally required duty.

The Democrats have the money to do what you suggest, but they seem to operate under a preconceived mix of messed up priorities. They lose not because they lack the issues but because they don't know how to use them. It could also be brought or funded by the DNC, but the DNC lacks the leadership to do much of anything worthwhile. Hope your view gets through.
Best, Ed Spievack

"But it was President Ronald Reagan who first turned an important scientific pursuit into a political issue (masquerading as a moral crusade).

In his second term Reagan imposed a moratorium on federal funding for research that utilized fetal tissue because such tissue came from terminated fetuses. He, and others who supported his decision, made truly insulting assertions that medical research created a “market” for fetal tissue and thus would encourage women to 1) get pregnant in order to 2) have an abortion so that they could 3) sell the fetal tissue to make money. She even wrote a (public) letter to Bush begging him to allow stem cell research to go forward."

Tell the truth here.  Cutting funding for Planned Parenthood is not just about ending a woman's right to choose.  The antichoice crowd led by Rep. Blackburn is anti-sex. They want to end use of contraceptives, and take us back to the good old days of morally upright America, where Mom and Dad had sex to have babies, period.  A fairytale world that someone made up in a church with a fairytale religion.  There ought to be a law alright, one that makes it illegal to run for office if you're crazy.

These are legitimate medical researchers including graduate students. Anti-abortion zealots have committed violence time and again against abortion clinics and doctors. They have bombed clinics and murdered the doctors. Recently people in the area were murdered by one of these zealots. This situation is exactly why I scrutinize and question law enforcement activity. In contemporary America, being arbitrarily arrested and/or detained for a few hours or even days may not seem like a big deal but as far as I'm concerned it is a big deal, for it is a perversion of the fundamental organizing principle of society - the exchange of natural rights for legal rights. And for what? Not being sufficiently deferential to the authority of law enforcement officers a/k/a "contempt of cop"? Does anyone even know or care where cops get their authority and power from and for what purpose it exists? Do you think the existence of individuals with power and authority over other individuals is "just the way it is" or a natural state of affairs? Given the universal recognition that all men are created equal, the answer is no, it is not. I am not anti-law enforcement. I just know that the authority of law enforcement is granted as part of a sacred agreement between the state and individuals, and its abuse, therefore, is nothing short of sacrilege, and must be diligently watched for and opposed.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_contract

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arbitrary_arrest_and_detention

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contempt_of_cop

Not to defend the cops, but the rest of the story is a young father of 2 kids 1 on the way was shot in the head on the street on 3/10.
Walk up Franklin Ave and see his memorial on the corner and then tell me the cops are over reacting.

That is irrelevant to a clearly unlawful arrest. Proximity to a recent murder scene ismt part of the context. Police by the nature of their work are often in proximity to crime ridden areas and have even more reason to behave civilly in those settings to avoid confrontations.
A cop is shot and instead of looking for gangbangers they spent their shift arresting the mailman! That's the context.
So Jack Oliver, arresting a postal worker in a mail truck is related to a neighborhood shooting? I'm sorry but I don't think there is even a remote connection between those two incidents.

Acts Considered Resisting Arrest

Resisting arrest is usually defined as intentionally preventing a police officer from lawfully arresting or handcuffing you or taking you to jail. Here are some things that can be considered resisting arrest:
•Physical acts, such as running away, hiding, or struggling with the officer
•Giving false identification, either verbally or by presenting a fake ID
•Trying to help another person avoid arrest
•Threatening the officer

Being slow to comply with an order or swearing at an officer is not, by itself, usually enough to warrant resisting arrest charges. Neither is questioning an officer's actions or authority before ultimately complying with requests.

Defenses Against Resisting Arrest Charges

The key to defending yourself against resisting arrest charges is to remember that such charges hinge on you resisting an officer of the law in the lawful execution of his or her duties. Here are some possible defenses, depending on your situation:
•Unlawful Arrest: If the arrest was not lawful to begin with, you did not do anything wrong even if you did resist. The officer was not performing his or her duties, since there is no duty to make an unlawful arrest. An example of this is resisting during an unlawful search of your home.

Disgusting! Absolutely disgusting! There appears to be no stopping the police brutality in the United States; they behave like old movie mafia. It has everything to do with recruitment and poor training, lack of education, and sheer ignorance. Police officers don't behave like this in other countries.
Ours in the USA have often been trained by blackwater tactics. Also, if youre too smart, forces don't want you! See Michael Moore's video from about 15-20 yrs ago.

File a Complaint with the U.S. Postal Service

Use the USPS website's Email Us form. ...

Call 1-800-ASK-USPS (1-800-275-8777) or TTY: 1-800-877-8339.

Speak to the station manager (postmaster) at a local post office.

Write to the U.S. Postal Service's Consumer Advocate office.

Wait, if the police are the law on the streets, why didn't they know that interfering with the delivery of the mail by a US Postal Service employee is a federal offense? The black man was working! Usually I see cops, postal workers, bus drivers, sanitation worker--all public servants--acknowledge each other with some mutual respect, regardless of color.  "Sorry, buddy" could have alleviated a lot of unnecessary pain & embarrassment. A little humility goes a long way.
What a sorry sight. The postal worker doing his duties and getting harassed by law enforcement. Nypd needs to place an ad in tomorrow's Ny times looking for 4 recruits to replace these knuckleheads.

We really don't need to replace these four cops. There clearly was no legitimate work that needed to be done since they had ample time to be out speeding, gallivanting and bullying. Replacing them would just amount to featherbedding. Also, we need the money we will save on four salaries medical benefits and pensions to settle the lawsuit that should be coming soon.

In New York, you are not required to carry ID, and you don’t have to show ID to a police officer.

Police may stop and briefly detain you only if there is reasonable suspicion that you committed, are committing or are about to commit a crime.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arbitrary_arrest_and_detention

Lynch does not represent Detectives and Lieutenants.

The headline should be, Police State Tactics Used Against Mailman.  Why does the Times continue reporting such incidents as if there is no real cause for concern?  Why don't we see editorials every day calling for a total overhaul of hiring and (never) firing practices for police officers?  NYPD police seem to behave as if  they have forgotten their role as public servants, first and foremost.  They have become a swaggering, militarized occupying force, acting with impunity to degrade all of our civil liberties every day, with total impunity.  The Times sadly seems incapable of reporting the self-evident character of these serial outrages.  No wonder we are the laughing stock of other first world countries, for the flagrant hypocrisy of our preaching about human rights and dignity.
really you think short guys a re the problem because they don't know there place

There they seem to get away with "murder", literally with no justice from the system. In fact it seems that the system does everything it can to protect them, not a good thing to see happen. And the column unfortunately is probably not being read by those who most need to read it with an open mind---Trump, Cruz, and Kasich supporters.

And it DOES have an impact on the rest of your life (background searches for employment, etc).  At it's core this is about police that think they can do whatever they want and nothing will happen.  That they are above the law themselves.   This has got to stop.  Police used to be seen as part of the community, as public servants. Just take a look at the case of Adrian Schoolcraft - this is coming from the top. But issue of what right women have to control their own bodies is a recent development. The GOP is returning to the 1700s when it comes to beliefs about sexual activities, and who does what to whom.

On top of that the attractiveness of these women takes place ahead of what they could contribute to the president. Makes me wonder which foreign female leader would come under their attack if they cold not work with them.

And yet they will get a substantial number of votes for engaging in such disgusting behavior. They reflect a particular segment of society, that people with manners and decency do not associate with.

comments.commentBody: One of the commentators on ESPN today suggested the tournament be renamed the "UCONN Invitational". Works for me!

I have never seen a college team who moves the way the UConn women do. They never receive a pass flat footed and always know where they are planning to go. Bill Bradley called this a "sense of where you are." They are a joy for any basketball aficionado to watch.

The top three women in college basketball start for UConn. In reality. the available top-quality talent is quite limited, and just a few teams monopolize recruiting at that level. This cannot be good for the game in the long run--we knew UConn was going to win it all at the beginning of the season. Contrast with the wacky men's tournament with many upsets because talent is both more plentiful and widely distributed.

The real solution is growing more talent in schools so more colleges can assemble competitive teams. Unfortunately, that emphasis will also bring with it a tendency to cut ethical corners, as happens so often in the men's game.

Coaches. You didn't mention coaches. It's not just the players out there.

I believe there are plenty of coaches who let players slip between the cracks, resulting in the team's chances to get to the Big Dance frittered away. And then there are coaches like Geno Auriemma, Muffet McGraw, and Tara Vendeveer.
The real answer is restrict the number of scholarships for the defending NCAA championship, and if a repeat winner, restrict even more.

Here, so you favor penalizing success? Not long ago, Auriemma won two NCs pkaying seven players. This tournament, he's gone 11 deep.
And boomer is wrong. Stewart, Jefferson and Tuck might be the three best players, but of those, only Stewart was among the highest ranked recruits of her year. Jefferson was a home schooled kid on an AAU team. Year after year, Notre Dame, Maryland, Stanford and Baylor have more highly acclaimed recruiting classes than UConn. Yesterday, the announcers kept lauding the four McDonalds HS All Americans on UCLA, at least until they crumbled in the second half against Tejas. No team, perhaps in NCAA history, no matter the sport or the gender, gets results closer to maximizing their potential than THIS UConn group. It starts on defense, which is where some stars take it easy. Not on UConn. Watch them dive for loose balls even up by 30 points. Watch them run the floor and box out, even though the game has been long decided. Other teams just don't do it that way. Not in basketball, not in other sports, not in the men's sports, either. This is a special group on the brink of a special achievement.

How dare any team like Duquesne think their opponents are beatable.  They should roll over I guess.   UConn women fans have no idea what a competitive sport even is.  Gene just belittled Woodens "pyramid of success"..by saying Wooden's pyramid was Alcindor and Walton even thought he pyramid was written long before.  A joke as is all woman's basketball..and I say this as a father of a good player and an uconn freshman player many years ago.

Yes, they're a great team...what is it, 71 in a row? And the last loss was to...Stanford - and no excuses, no one sick or injured, they just weren't up for it, and Stanford was....now Notre Dame loses to Stanford yesterday, I don't know....could be an exciting Championship...

If the final is Stanford-UConn, it will pit the only Uconn freshman starter, Katie Lou Samuelson, against her sister, whose threes helped sink a superior Notre Dame team. Also, the last team to beat UConn, and the last time UConn blew a second half lead, at Stanford early last season.
Not just because her sister is on UConn, but you can bet the house that Auriemma would never stand for his team letting Stanford's Samuelson sister to keep getting open looks for threes from the corner. It might happen once, with the team overrotating on defense. But consistently, as Notre Dame allowed? Never gonna happen. And THAT, is the difference between UConn and all the rest.

Each time I watch the Maryland and South Carolina Women play, it's so obvious how much Maryland's Brenda Frese and South Carolina's Dawn Staley's coaching styles fall short when compared to Connecticut's Geno Auriemma's.

Geno has has the unique ability to relate to his players (as individuals and then together as team) in a way that doesn't interfere with their learning curve but instead enriches it. This is his genius.

I don't get that sense with Dawn Staley and Brenda Frese. Dawn Staley's players appear to play scared, always anticipating being berated when they don't do something right, casting their eyes to the bench to grade Staley's level of disapproval.

And I can't imagine that frantic running around thing Brenda Frese does for so much of the game, how disruptive it must be to Maryland's players as they attempt to establish a flow to their game All that yelling she does, instructions or whatever can't instill too much confidence in her players, as if they can't figure things out on their own.

Geno will yell in a play, maybe get a player attention's that's close at hand, but seldom show any uncontrolled outbursts like Staley and Frese are guilty of. You just get that feeling he's always in control. Yeah, he may be exploding inside at times, but he won't let his team see it, unless of course he believes it could be a 'teaching moment.' Jerking out your starters without saying a word? Priceless. And shows his Genius.
More likely it has to do with being able to get his choice of players now that Pat Summit is gone.  That's really what kept UCLA going, before regular national TV spread the wealth ...

Funny how two people  can look at the same situation and draw two completely different conclusions.    The fact that the most dominant team in women's college basketball has a male coach tells me men are much better at coaching basketball than women.

It's a myth that Auriemma gets all the best players. In fact, in 21 years, there have been about six ultra top players who came through: Rebecca Lobo, Sue Bird, Diana Taurasi, Maya Moore, Tina Charles and Breanna Stewart.
The rest are good to excellent prospects who become great because they went to UConn.
At the start of every season, talk of how great the recruiting classes are at Maryland, South Carolina, Baylor, Notre Dame and Stanford. Geno adds one brick at a time. And yesterday, the announcers were getting damp over UCLAs four HS All Americans, until they blew the lead in the second half to Tejas.

Watch Stanford upset Notre Dame. ND kept letting Stanford's Samuelson get open in the corner for uncontested threes, a bunch of which she made, and it got Stanford across the line. You can bet your house that an Auriemma team wouldn't let that happen. And today, after using the same spot to hit big shots against Maryland and Kentucky, Stanford let Oshahor spot up for three point set shots(!), wide open. You can bet if Washington faces UConn in the final, that shot will NOT be open. Auriemma, Dailey and the staff are meticulous in scouting, defensive game planning, and making sure the team executes the best defense in the land. Failing to play best case defense is what sent South Carolina, Notre Dame and Stanford packing.

Both my 80 year old step-father and my 76 year old father never miss "the girls." They love watching them together and I love that these two sportsman love "their girls" because of the hard core athletes (and scholars) that they are.

But we take your word that these people even exist to be one of the handful of women't basketball rooters outside the Nutmeg State. And inside of Connecticut, I wonder if fan support would survive probation and three 16-20 seasons?

UConn fans have stayed loyal to the men's basketball team after mediocre play and suspensions. The best solution would be if UConn gave up on Div.1 football and got out of the AAC altogether. Then, other talented teams could encounter the Huskies during the regular season and perhaps reestablish some rivalries and closer games like the Big East days.
I love women's basketball and I am deeply impressed by the Huskies but I am looking forward to the end of their reign.

Seriously, Mr. Rhoden?  You are equating the class of Coach K with the antics of Bobby Knight? It's hard to imagine a more narrow minded point of view. I think you are the one that should offer an apology.
It makes perfect sense. Those two were thick as thieves, and K is not the least bit classy. He apologized because he got caught in a lie.

What is ignored by Nate Cone and the commenters is the women's' vote. In a general election match-up between Trump and Clinton, women will vote in a landslide for Hillary, especially when his misogynist comments are played over and over again in Democratic ads.

There were already rumblings of this in the March 15th voting.

Trump has not been vetted yet, politically, the way Clinton has. It is still early and many women (and men) have not yet given careful attention to the candidates. When they do, and realize just how anti-feminist Trump is, all hell will break lose.

Generational and partisan differences among women will disappear in their concerted effort to beat Trump. And beat him they will.
Making yet another ceiling for Trump eh? Well we have seen what he as done to these "ceilings". Keep it up, I'd love to see your face when the polls start changing.
Martin, you are baiting me but I'm not biting. Amy's problem is she lives in Chicago which is a dangerous place and destined to go belly up. Amy loves ESCAPISM.

Only thing more annoying than emperor reporters who take up space whining about emperor coaches, are emperor readers who opine from their couch potato thrones without taking the time to properly read what they choose to comment on.  Groden simply made a face (from what he says) and Knight caught an attitude, made haughty comments about the Times and the Big East and stormed off in a huff.

Sportsmanship? Let's not mistake the NCAA tournament or any of its participants (coaches to cameramen, athletes to announcers) for one of those uplifting commercials about NCAA values shown at halftimes. This is the big-money big-time, where the winners win big and the losers go home. Sure, some of the losers know from the start they are the designated losers and may be happy just for being part of the show, but most of the participants have the drive and  arrogance to think of themselves as winners, to win and be showered with adulation and then money. Arrogant men who are used to winning are not good losers.

Both Mr.Chyn and the author of this article are stating the obvious.  Yes, public housing projects contributed to the inability of minorities to earn more money and get a better education.  However there are many other reasons that make it difficult to leave the ghetto or barrio.  They are sub par schools, scarcity of good paying jobs, bad housing, politics, crime, negative role models, racism, etc.  Until these problems can be addressed and changed, the eradication of the projects has only a little more than a band aid effect.  We don't need more studies.  There has to be a sea change in thinking and caring. There is a reason why the majority of those locked up are black and latino.

Yes, the media helped make Trump, but not in the way that Kristof thinks. For years, the media has supported policies that have hurt the middle class while benefiting a wealthy corporate elite. The media promoted the wonders of free trade and globalization, claiming it would make everybody richer and that nothing could be done to stop it. The media blamed the ever growing trade deficit on incompetent American workers, who were allegedly incapable of producing anything the world wanted to buy.

The media lauded the hard work and entrepreneurship of immigrants, while subtly implying that native born Americans were lazy and stupid. The media talked up the benefits of mass immigration, even of the illegal variety.

And the media succeeded in serving the interests of their true masters. Corporations and the wealthy have reaped most of the gains from technological progress. Mass immigration and free trade have held down labor costs.

And now the middle class has had enough. Faced with a declining standard of living, people are voting for the candidate who sounds most serious about fixing the southern border and balancing trade flows. Not surprisingly, the media is horrified.
They can't all be gems.

Steve S:  Your reply to NCN makes no sense to me.  If the CEO gets a 100% increase (as in NCN's scenario) and the workers get a 2% increase, the median pay goes up by 2% and the gap between the CEO and the workers nearly doubles.  Please explain where I went wrong?  Thanks.

Martin, Rex started with: “Hey, it's my old pal, PB2.” He ended with: “I just kept waiting for this one to perk up, but it never did.”  And that is from a pal. Rex didn't allow whether his dinner was late.
@Jeff M:  You say you're not sure why PK says median income grew.  Then you describe growth.  This is strange.

Candidates and pundits have been talking economic inequality, but the voters are voting racial inequality.

White voters go for the candidates with a “white" agenda – Trump and Sanders. Non-white voters go for the candidate with a "non-white" agenda – Hillary Clinton.

This has little to do with racial “prejudice” in the conventional sense. It is the politics of identity.

We live in an age of identity turmoil, from Islamic fundamentalism to European far-right parties, to the Tea Party and Trumpism here at home.

Economic distress triggers the identity turmoil, but the latter goes on to live a life of its own.

Liberals don't seem to understand this. They keep wanting to talk about the top 1%. But that's not where most people are right now.

Most people are concerned with protecting their own turf. They are in a defensive crouch.

The candidate who understands this best will have the best chance of winning the Presidency.

We have just experienced 7 years of a President undergoing on the job training. Trump is much better qualified for the most important Executive position in the world than Obama was 7 years ago or now. Obama seems to be a slow learner.
He may not be politically correct and without warts, but I challenge anyone to say that Trump's ideas aren't a breath of fresh air. He has my vote.

Ok, they're not a breath of fresh air. They're hardly coherent. They're not even ideas. "Ideas" would display some evidence of complex thought and ability to learn, neither of which he has. He rambles about people he knows, about who's good to him, about how America is bad. His uncle, brilliant man, wrote something way back when about nuclear weapons, so that's all he needs to know about that. He couldn't even answer the cyberwar question because he obviously has no clue what he's talking about. He literally does not understand what sanctions are. He repeated a lie about Bin Laden that was conclusively debunked 4 months ago.
I guess I should be astonished that anyone could read this farrago of incoherence and ignorance and think that Trump should be anywhere near anything important, but by this point I'm just saddened and depressed.
Maybe fresh air to you; poison air to minorities, women, immigrants.
Amen!
Just stop it. Not only do we enforce our immigration laws, the Obama administration has deported more people than Bush ever did. Disagree with Obama if you will, but stop the lies.

@NI: Of course the Saudis will be able to find other buyers. Worldwide consumption of oil and oil products is about 100 mb/d, while the US imports only about 1 mb/d from Saudi Arabia. Oil is what is called a "fungible" commodity, which Trump, being a Wharton grad, ought to know very well. There would be some disruption in the short term, but in the long-term the price and availability of oil probably wouldn't change too much. (Iran is one example of how countries find new markets for their oil once the US stops buying.) Tim Holmes is basically correct.
The Saudi Arabians have the third largest air force in the world.  Like everywhere else, America is there because of their self-interest, not out of the goodness of their heart.
