comments.commentBody:
A "strident" atheist is one who says out loud that they don't believe in god. It's been my experience that stridency is much more prevalent among believers, including many priests, but only atheists get smeared with “strident.”

It is a false equivalency to say that certainty of a god is on a par with not believing in a god. If there is to be a contest, the onus is on believers to prove the insupportable things they are certain of. Typically, an atheist concedes that they will believe once someone produces evidence. Conversely, it is typical of believers that no amount of evidence contradicting their religion’s tenets could change their minds. Ben Carson, a physician(!), believes the earth is 5,000 years old. There is no equivalent absurdity among atheists. Religion carries on despite conflicting evidence. It is religion that needs repair, not atheism.

If believers want peace and comity with people who beliefs diverge from theirs, they ought to stop trying to impose their beliefs on others. But if they persist, they will get serious stridency in response. I am under no obligation—ethically, morally, or legally—to embrace anybody else’s beliefs, or to make concessions to them.

As an atheist, I really hate this essay. Don't tell me what I believe, and don't tell me that you know I have doubts about my atheism. I don't. I give the existence of some kind of God as much credence as Russel's orbiting export (or its latest incarnation, the FSM). As another commenter astutely said, claims advanced without evidence can be dismissed without evidence. The burden is on the believers to provide evidence for their ridiculous ideas.

There is no equivalence between making fantastic claims without evidence, and asking for evidence before believing the aforementioned fantastic claims.

I am an agnostic, and while I do not believe in any God, I do wonder sometimes if I am wrong about that.  I find it hard to credit either a believer or a prefessed non-believer who claims to be so certain of the rightness of his beliefs.

Actually, your sarcasm serves to make Donald Trump's points exactly. Americans have been told for decades that free trade would ultimately lift the U.S. economy. I am not a fan of Trump at all and, his reactionary tactics are absurd. However, the trade surpluses you cite are miniscle relative the the deficits with other countries while our overall collective deficit is unsustainable and can't be wished away to "greatness". You are ignoring the magnitude of the problem.

As the economic donut gets larger, so does its hole. And, into this hole we pour tremendous amounts of revenue (much of it borrowed) to pay for the "too good to be true" prices of cheap imported goods. Those hidden costs are reflected in crime, subsidies and social programs for the un/underemployed, welfare, food stamps, and community blight and my taxes, at least, are staggering.

The American people do not feel we have gotten a fair deal from free trade and despite some data to the contrary, the trendline outlook is not good. Yes, Donald is wrong and yes, not every one here is an economist but, your summary dismissal of their concerns is why Mr. Trump is doing as well as he is. I have not seen many comments suggesting simple solutions or, trade isolationism. For those who are un/underemployed, it is undeniable that we do need "a better deal" because the scorecard (reflected in our debt and deficit) says we are losing.

The US economy has been on a military footing since 1941. Look at the proportion of US GDP devoted to the military and the production of war material, and the subsidies to the companies involved. Look at figures for US arms and aircraft sales worldwide. Changing this model would plunge the US, and the world economy, into an abyss. The business of the US is war.

Trump's attitude toward international trade underscores the man's appeal, and his limitations. He's popular because of his simplistic solution to trade deficits--i.e., tariffs--which everyone can understand. Unfortunately, he's scary for the same reason. Tariffs cut both ways, which he fails to appreciate.

For a man who touts his business acumen, he's astoundingly ignorant of the repercussions of his proposals.

Balance is still very much needed. The only way we as a society can go on with this utterly indefensible hemorrhage of jobs is unequivocal redistribution of resources(a la Bernie Sanders). Bernie is great, but his policies are just a start.

And in the same breathe I would go go even further than Mr. Sanders as this wage shedding metastasizes throughout the entire 0-80% income bracket: a minimum income.

Jobs are a thing of the past if we keep heading in the direction we're going(and as stated not even Bernie Sanders would deviate us from this course), left to only the privileged few(software programmers, professional workers, "event planners", you get the idea...). If we do not address fluidity at the bottom and middle of all wage earners, well let's just say there will be blood. I hope only metaphorically, but perhaps not...

Martin, we had the kids over tonight. We had stone crabs, shrimp cocktail, Honey Baked Ham and all the sides and appetizers. After they were gone I started watching Easter Parade. I hate musicals and so does the Wife. But I love an artist like Astaire and once I started watching the Wife got hooked. So we are now watching that CLASSIC. I cannot believe the Wife and I are watching it together. I guess that’s what happens after 52 years of living together.

wow and to think I used to think Irwin knew his subject. while the basic framework of some of his arguments is correct, some of his other "logical" responses to say, where the chinese would choose to spend the money they make off of us, ie buying real estate here or t-bills instead of say, gold or other commodity is a typical economist "just-so" argument. and utterly preposterous. you want to fix the trade deficit overnight? here's how;

1. pass the I Love America and Cute Puppies Act of 2016. the act requires that ANY american corporation moving jobs overseas must also domicile at least 25 of their 100 highest paid management personnel in that country else corporate tax rate doubles. overnight.
2. pass the Apple Pie and I Love Mom Act of 2016. that act allows any american with overseas profits squirreled away (I'm talking to you Apple) they have until November 1, 2016 to repatriate the profits at the present tax rate. because on 2 Nov, the tax rate doubles.

chew on those points greedy, crooked corporate america. we dont need a trump to straighten these guys out. all we need is a congress with spine who are not full of bought and paid for corporate tools.

The one word I'll contend that Connie missed was "good" (jobs). Yes, there are lots of minimum wage jobs out there, not so many of the old middle-class manufacturing jobs.

That said, I'm not totally convinced (thanks in part to Irwin's article) that the problem is simply the trade deficit. Perhaps a more accurate contention is that the gains from the trade deficit (and automation) have mostly gone to the 1%.

There are gains from trade deficits (e.g. low interest rates, as the article pointed out). The problem, it strikes me, is that we wasted half that money on the 2000's building/refinance boom, and the other half has gone straight to the top (in terms of e.g. a higher stock market). Think of if instead we had invested that money in say infrastructure and research. We all might have been a lot better off. But heaven forbid that the Republicans let that happen.

I'm not sure, but it's at least an interesting contention.

Now I understand why American workers get the shaft: " In fact, trying to eliminate the trade deficit could mean giving up some of the key levers of power that allow the United States to get its way in international politics."

We have sold our nation down a rathole in order to play politics. It's easy to destroy the jobs, etc. of out citizens in favor of foreign relations. Does anyone wonder why the public is so hostile to this insanity? As for liberal always spouting off about inequality how about ending practices that lead to so much of it such as trade, mass immigration, etc. that transfer so much wealth to the top. No wonder Trump and Sander terrify our ruling class.

The author poses, "So does a trade deficit mean fewer jobs? It depends on which force is more economically powerful: fewer jobs creating exports or investment dollars flowing into the country."
I believe it was Studs Terkel who said that he preferred to give money directly to beggars (regardless of how they might use it), rather than give it to charities. This way he could be sure that 100% of his donation would reach its target. Using financial repercussions from outsourcing to bring jobs back seems like a Rube Goldberg to me. And what's to keep newly created jobs from going the same route? What's the point of learning a transient profession anyway? It's very inefficient - and social assistance alternatives are costly to the state and to the psychology of the recipient.

.
On the subject of 58 v. 59, it would seem each of you has made a noteworthy Declaration.
Huh? Did you forget Bush Sr and Bush Jr (2004)?

The idea that if an atheist is honest about it he must necessarily own up to having doubts is a concept constructed by a religious world view. It could be the faith talking, or the lost faith talking, but it is clearly not the voice of those who have never had faith and find the very notion risible.

I once set out to cowrite a fantasy novel with the son of a minister. We immediately ran into difficulty while trying to outline the local religion. My coauthor kept referring to the aliens as pagans. When I objected that they could only be pagans if somewhere on this planet there were Christians the project withered and died.

The author of this piece is suffering from a similar misconception when he says: "We can all exist along a continuum of doubt. Some of us will approach religious certainty at one extreme and others will approach atheistic certainty at the other extreme. Many of us will slide back and forth over time."

And the actual atheists have better things to do and don't bother worrying about invisible friends.

Pagans are beings who believe in multiple gods rather than One God, the Creator of this and all planets.  Paganism pre-existed Christianity and exists in places Christianity has never reached, including, perhaps, other planets.  The paganism or any religion of aliens would have to survive intellectual and technological developments that allowed them to reach other planets around other stars.  I think that is where your enterprise ran into problems.

You are describing polytheism. Pagan is a term that essentially means non-Christian, and where you have non-Christians, you have Christians. You confuse yourself when you refer to Paganism pre-existing Christianity. Yes, there are and were non-Christian religions that came before Christianity. But, when you refer to them as pagan you are implicitly calling them non-Christian, regardless of where they fit in history. It's kind of like calling a people non-white. It only has meaning if there are white people. If there were no whites you'd just call them... People.

Rd Mn, you might want to expand your realm of seeking answers to include history. Religious people don't need to unhand our democracy considering religious people gave us our democracy and warned us it couldn't be maintained without a religiously based moral code. They even based the existence of our most basic rights to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness on the self evidence and gifting of a creator. Without this religious assumption, from where do you suppose our unalienable rights come? And if they are not mandated by a creator existing above us and our government, do governments have the responsibility to secure them if a majority or controlling, violent minority chose not to recognize those rights. And if that becomes the situation would that be moral, since a truly atheistic society has no moral standard other than the prevailing majority?  In an atheistic society there are no true minority rights... Unless the majority recognizes them because there is no standard above the majority to whom a member of the minority can appeal. One can reason and debate, but without a higher creator and morality giver, there is nothing to claim the majority is wrong if they refuse to recognize your right. But that is the real appeal of atheism, the moral superiority of placing yourself as the sole moral standard. If I must choose you or God as the standard of proof of my unalienable rights I, like the religious founding fathers, choose God.

Qua, qua, quack.   Why do people persist in using this noise word 'God'?   Until the word is defined, it's part of speech specified, until the author can tell us what possible meaning this word that he insists on writing - could possibly have, then he should remain silent.  Wittgenstein: Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent.  You might as well be saying "Even an atheist must have doubts about Quack, and there must be moments when he wonders about Quack.  It's just a lot of gabble.  There is no doubt because there is no subject.  There is no answer because there is no question.   It's all noise.
The noise word God is no more difficult or easy to define than the noise word Consciousness. Qua, Qua, Quack.

There is a massive surplus of tech and science graduates in this country, but US firm refuse to pay the going rate and prefer cheaper imported workers be it roofing or IT jobs. Wonder what the fired workers from Disney will end up doing?

No matter what anyone has to say here we are finally having a conversation the powers to be have sought to avoid. Thank you Mr Trump and thank you New York Times for this series of article that have reinforced everything Trump has claimed. As one of those sacrificed on the alter of globalism and corporatism I say go Mr. trump.

Eric, "there is no evidence that a God of any kind exists"?

What if one defined "god" as the original cause of time being launched, then the logical coming into existence of time-space and matter? And not asserting this originality has human characteristics, or any characteristics known to humans?

It would be so much simpler, and logical, for there to be nothing instead of the "something" we believe we observe and experience.

There must be an explanation for our "something," right? Does it do harm to label it "god" without attributing to it any personality or intentions?

That's what I do. God created this existence I think I experience. I can leave it at that. I don't need to paint a picture of this "god." And I don't need to assume it imposes any expectations or rules on me. It started, I resulted. I will go away, it's creation will continue. So what?

"Research has shown that science does not have all the answers."  Science provides us with a way to rationalize our world by rules or probability.  It does not give us anything else.  So to the big question why, or where from, no answer.  We could all be hooked up to a computer as in the movie the Matrix.  We don't know.   A belief in God is an optimistic way to say the Universe came from somewhere.  We have been wondering about that since we became sentient.

Um. China has 80% of the mining concessions in Zimbabwe. There is 80% unemployment in Zimbabwe. Cyanide used in mining is used to poison elephants and to stop the vultures from alerting Rangers to game poached. This might be a good place for China to invest in people and animals. It is sorely needed.

Lot of talk here about ones and done---and justly so.  Makes Oklahoma's success more impressive.  4 Seniors in the starting lineup.  The starters have started in 104 consecutive games.  That is a real program.  Congratulations to Lon Kruger and the Sooners.

Here are my questions for all the atheists commenters like Rd Mn from NJ who are denouncing religion and religious influences in our democracy and society. It was a religious people who signed the document that gave us the religious statement that we are all equal and possess unalienable rights to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness because we are created that way and our creator gifts us with those rights. These predominantly religious people then proceeded to establish our democratic republic to secure these rights. Throughout our history various minorities have pointed to these truths as proof and defense of their rights.

Define for me where minority rights come from in an atheistic society. If there is no moral standard above us or our government, how can any right exist without the acceptance of the majority or a dictatorial minority? And if there is no moral standard above us or the government is it wrong for the majority to deny a minority these rights? In the absence of a creator , from where does my or your unalienable right to life or Liberty come? And if it is simply us that grant them, can't we just as morally take them away? And if that is the case are they unalienable?

I can't speak for other non theists, but I believe justice and fairness and compassion are desirable and needed qualities not because god says so but because they just are. I don't feel they have to be justified by some external authority or deity, to me they stand alone as worthy ideals irrespective of any religion or god.

They come from common sense.

I applaud Professor Irwin's call for open-mindedness, which is so often lacking among the faithful of many faiths, not excluding Christianity.

May we someday overcome the curse of an ideology (religion in all of its variants) which justifies suicide bombing, genital mutilation of children, racism and oppression of women. Here's hoping.

The Atheist commenters here only fuel the thesis of this excellent piece.  They are the equivalent of fundamentalists who believe with absolute certainty that their version of God is the One and Only way.  Only when we approach each other with humility will there be any dialogue but humility is no longer a virtue in American society and certainly not in our politics yet it is the cornerstone of all religion.

One thing believers apparently don't get: God is something to believe or not believe in only for those who acknowledge it. For the rest of us it's just a historical epiphenomenon that can be explained but will probably wither away with the age of reason.
Ok. How about you keep your mind open? Let's suppose that the God exists but it's a mad genocidal maniac?

comments.commentBody: Parallel holes.  Move your lips along them.  Different notes come out.  The notes go up one way and down the other.  Name a third.

Just to add, in practical every day speaking, you're going to hear people say "yuan" most often, simply because you're usually just taking about the amount of money. In other words, nobody says "can I borrow 100 renminbi?" (Unless they needed to explicitly distinguish between currencies)

I really enjoyed the concept of qualifiers the short time I studied Mandarin, and how each qualifier has to do with the properties of the thing it's describing. Like "tiao" is used to describe "long things" like snakes, or better yet "you tiao" the long fried donuts. "I'll want some donuts... How many?... 3 tiao". Or "pian" used for flat things or slices, like sheets of paper or the sky.

learning chinese or eastern languages not only teaches you how to communicate, but different methods of thinking, counting, etc.

That 70% reduction in crashes associated with moving school start times was from a single high school in Wyoming.  Other studies have not found anywhere near that large an effect.  I expect better of the Times.

You are likely correct about effect size. Here are citations for studies in Kentucky and Virginia.

Danner, F., & Phillips, B. (2008). Adolescent sleep, school start times, and teen motor vehicle crashes. Journal of clinical sleep medicine: JCSM: official publication of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine, 4(6), 533.

Vorona, R. D., Szklo-Coxe, M., Wu, A., Dubik, M., Zhao, Y., & Ware, J. C. (2011). Dissimilar teen crash rates in two neighboring southeastern Virginia cities with different high school start times. J Clin Sleep Med, 7(2), 145-151.

Vorona, R. D., Szklo-Coxe, M., Lamichhane, R., Ware, J. C., McNallen, A., & Leszczyszyn, D. (2014). Adolescent crash rates and school start times in two central Virginia counties, 2009-2011: a follow-up study to a southeastern Virginia study, 2007-2008. Journal of clinical sleep medicine: JCSM: official publication of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine, 10(11), 1169-1177.

Where are the parents in all this?

I would take a conventional/early bird circadian rhythm over a superpower such as flying or invisibility. I was a teenager before the internet, cell phones, TVs in every room, etc., or the concept of delayed sleep phase syndrome. I also had strict parents who kept me and my brothers to a regular, early bed time. I lay awake for hours every night, trying to deal mentally with the energy surge that came at 10pm regardless of how little sleep I got the night before, or how sleepy I had felt at 7pm. Left to my own devices (as I discovered one heavenly year in my mid-30s), I would sleep from 7am to 2pm, with no insomnia and no hangover feeling. I am just sleepy at 7am and wide awake at 11pm. Behavior might be controlled by discipline, but circadian rhythms are not. I think people whose body clocks happen to coincide with what society considers "right" have difficulty fathoming, and therefore feeling any empathy for, those of us whose body clocks follow a different schedule.

Strict parenting and self-discipline ensured that I had a full night's sleep and was awake and ready for high school class at 8 AM sharp. Thus, having to report to the office by 8 AM now in my 40's is 2nd nature. I don't understand all the hullabaloo over this simple issue of personal responsibility. If some immature teenager wants to shirk his required sleep, let him. There's no need to foist his crazy sleep schedule on the rest of mature society.

Why on earth would you bother to comment on an article that you obviously didn't read?  It has nothing to do with personal responsibility or maturity and everything to do with hormonal differences in teenagers.

For many students, enough sleep is not a matter of time management. In the community where I reside, those who wish to remain competitive academically often return home no earlier than 6 pm, what with extracurricular activities and other school engagements. Then, they must study and complete assignments for up to six AP classes, each class requiring no less than an hour of undivided attention. Factoring in other commitments, such as time spent preparing for standardized tests, or writing applications for summer programs and college, it becomes clear that students have no choice but to stay up late. Reporting for school the next day at 7 or 8 am becomes difficult, and even for students who never appear tardy at school, the previous night's hard work and fatigue often catch up to them and lead to decreased attention in class, thus forcing students to stay up even later in order to self-learn the information. This vicious cycle is not created by the students, who have no alternative to sleep deprivation should they desire admission into a competitive college, and so I urge you to consider the demands of modern education and schooling—especially for accomplished high-school students—before claiming that the harmful sleep schedule of teenagers are perpetrated by irresponsibility and shoddy time management.

Luckily, she now works at home for a boss who is in a time zone 3 hours earlier, so she can sleep according to her inner clock!

Doubt is what makes us human. Science has nothing to do with religion or belief in a Creator. Science is a system of thought based on observable evidence in conjunction with other systematic forms of thinking, like logic and mathematics. Science is not dogmatic, and its findings are always subject to revision after appraisal of new evidence. No religion allows itself to be revised that way because God doesn't volunteer for experiments.

Judaism has a tradition of rigorous study of religious texts (for men, anyway), with the goal of testing faith by asking difficult and mostly unanswerable questions. Doubt is what creates true faith; without it, "faith" is just blind acceptance of somebody else's professed authority. Would that more Christians could understand that.

The Torah, the New Testament, the Qur'an -- they are collections of ancient texts of questionable origins that were never intended to be factual historical accounts or to stand up as coherent philosophical systems. They are anecdotal, piecemeal by nature. The ONLY evidence that they are "religious" is that they themselves say they are. That's why they shouldn't be evaluated by an empirical, scientific method. A "non-believer" doesn't have to be against religion, but may believe that questions about God are irrelevant to morality or philosophy (since they get muddied up with religious politics and traditions), or that because they are unknowable to humans, they must always be questions rather than answers.

You over estimate Judaism's tradition of rigorous study of religious texts. FIRST, the students BEGIN with the unquestionable assumption that the religious texts are PURE and EXACT truth, not subject to ANY questioning. Then the students jump through all sorts of intellectual hoops to prove or disprove all sorts of OTHER things that have been derived from the 'perfect' texts.

It is all a structure built on the quicksand of assumed perfect truth. It's all nonsense.

PS: I am a Jew.

The application of the empirical tests of science to religious claims depends entirely on the nature of these claims. Where they are empirical claims, such as a shroud was worn by Jesus, or the Earth was formed in a few days, empirical tests apply. However, some religious claims lie outside the reach of science, being largely subjective. They are not specious just on that account, and may be very significant to the individual. Being subjective, however, they may not carry the same conviction for others.

The problem to be faced is what to do when entire groups have adopted a set of such commonly accepted subjectively based beliefs, important to the group, and a clash arises with another group of differing beliefs. If the conflicting groups accept their own tenets as a subjective choice, all may be well. But if any group thinks their beliefs are "better" than another's, as is often the case, trouble may ensue.

I am unsure that an argument that "God is a question" will settle such differences. As the beliefs cannot be empirically established, finding a basis for persuasion poses a dilemma. Historically the solution appears to be a bloody battle to exhaustion, after which agreement to coexist appears preferable to unending warfare.

The blurb, probably not written by Prof. Irwin, "How can atheists and believers stop acting like enemy combatants in a spiritual or intellectual war?", has a simple answer.  Let the believers stop trying to impose their beliefs and practices upon the rest of us.

I seem to know a heck of a lot more about the story than you do.

Did you read the court order itself? That would tell you that the FBI only wanted Apple to help them get past the "10 incorrect passwords in succession and the iPhone wipes its memory" feature. They did not want to risk losing whatever data was on the iPhone.

To do that you need to either disable the counter that counts to 10, or set the number (10) that it compares against so high that it is never reached (higher than 10,000, the total number of possible code combinations), or reset the counter to zero after each entry (so it never gets to 10), and then you can do a "brute force" attack on the password (if need be trying all 10,000 combinatons). Once the phone is unlocked, it is straightforward to see what is there.

What is so tough about figuring that out? If you have been programming as long as I have, nothing.

I think Tim Cook was stupid to tell the FBI to "get lost." He now has the problem that the WORLD knows the iPhone is not invincible.

Part of what concerns me with this whole thing is how imprecise most of the discussion is. The government request to vacate the order actually says that it "successfully accessed the data stored on Farook's iPhone", it doesn't say how, and it doesn't say they unlocked it. If that means they did in fact unlock it, they're silent on the method used.

The point is that we can't actually draw any conclusions from the government's motion regarding the security of Apple's devices, certainly not after the release of iOS 9.3 and the security features of future devices. We also can't draw any conclusions about how the government gains access to data stored on our personal electronic devices. The only thing we know for sure is that this discussion about balancing privacy and security (in its many forms) is far from over.

Conventional security wisdom has always been that if a determined hacker has physical access to a computer (phone), they can get in eventually. "Cloning the drive," as may have happened here, would be one way to do that.

The moral of the story for the security-conscious end user: If someone gets their hands on your phone/computer, always assume they *can* access the data, no matter what security or encryption is installed. Whether the time and effort involved would be worth it is a different matter.

A problem with so-called "strategic voting" is that an election is then subject to manipulation by the media, or an organization with a lot of influence on the media.  Moneyed interests can create a myth that, based on polls or other non-verifiable information, Candidate X is bound to win unless people vote for Candidate Z, who has no chance of winning but can deny the race for X.  The media amplify the myth.  Now we have voters who are voting under this influence and denying Candidate Y from winning.  In other words, strategic voting is based on some pre-determined view of the outcome, which is subject to manipulation.  A dangerous idea in a real democracy.

It needs to be realized: There is no prospect of preventing the ice sheets from melting, independent of man's activities. None whatsoever. The issue is: When?

That only gives us more time to abandon the doomed coastal cities -- not to hold back the inevitable.

Yes, this is a wake up call -- not to wring our hands and buy more electric vehicles (which need energy to be charged -- but that's another discussion) -- but rather to plan our response to this inevitability. Start with a new mantra: "Move out of Manhattan, let the sea take it." There really is no alternative, whatever amelioration is adopted.

Accept the reality, and make plans for coping with it. The sky really is falling.

James Powell and Gordon Danby are great scientists. I was fortunate to hear them when they testified before the US Senate Environment & Public Works Committee, Chaired by Senator Moynihan of NY who rediscovered them & Maglev in 1987 and he requested that they appear and testify. They did & were asked to lead a study committee of Maglev & transportation experts, The report made a convincing case that a Maglev transport network capable of carrying both trucks & passengers at an average speed of 300 mph and also capable of electronic switching and operating on conventional railroads on Maglev adapted railroad tracks should be our next surface transport system to add capacity to our aging, costly and congested Interstate Highway System. Comparisons between urban concentrations are notoriously difficult and often flawed.  In Massachusetts, for example, the central city is obviously Boston.  When the Census Bureau then defines of the Boston Metropolitan Area, they are able to make quite precise calculations as to how far the Boston area extents outward because the real political jurisdictions in Massachusetts are town and cities, not counties, as is the rule outside New England.  So the Boston metro area is made up of the central city any and all cities , e.g. the city of Somerville, and towns, e.g. the town of Lexington, that are economically and socially integrated with Boston.  Elsewhere in America, the task is much more difficult. For example, a city such as Cleveland is an urban center of the metropolitan area inside the next political jurisdiction, which is Cuyahoga County and which includes residential areas which are clearly rural.  So it's apples and oranges. As in Lexington, MA versus North Randall, OH, both in metropolitan areas.

comments.commentBody:
Exactly, Jerry. What happened?

I agree that he was right that the banks should have been nationalized regardless of the perceived laws.

What has happened ever since has been pretty inexplicable. Emotion? I suspect some of it is that. Krugman doesn't make friends easily. Does he have any besides his wife?

I don't. Analysis can only go so far. Eventually, politics is about shared goals and friendship.

Some people are not good at that. Some feel a kinship without friendship. This is probably advisable to influential people. Friendship gets in the way of analysis.

But what is better, kinship or friendship? It depends upon the need of the individual and the situation.

Some of the worst despots originated due to a lack of friendship. At the same time, some of the worst friendships originated out of the lack of good analysis. But in most cases, good analysis combined with friendship and kinship are better. The world is a mess, and good feelings are fleeting.

Everything else follows our feelings.

Every reader--every reader--should read in detail Bob Woodward's interview with Trump in the Wash Post. Also listen to the video of Woodward giving his reaction. It is absolutely incredible in every conceivable way, most of them favorable. He all but announced Kasich as his VP to serve almost as co-President. Hillary is in the deepest of trouble in the general election, the very deepest of trouble.

But of more immediate importance, he did something that no major political figure, let alone a presumptive major party nominee has ever done. He said flatly that the market is way too high and that no one should buy stocks. One might even guess that might lead to an interesting week on Wall Street.

The Woodward interview shows that Trump is very deep and thoughtful, if not very informed. (The argument that we are the verge of a really major recession and that he will end the national debt in eight years is, some may think, slightly contradictory and should produce some response from Krugman.) Pitching more than 250 innings in a season? Consider these pitchers: Warren Spahn: from 1947 through 1963, there was only one year in which he did not pitch more than 250 innings; he only pitched 245.2 that year. In 1963, he was 42, and went only 23–7. He had 13 20  game seasons during that period, and pitched more than 300 innings twice. Early Wynn pitched more than 250 for eight consecutive years, 1951-59 (ages 31-39), winning 20 or more five of those years. Whitey Ford first pitched more than 250 in 1961, when he was 32. He also did it the next two seasons, winning 25, 17, and 24 during those years. Sandy Koufax, meanwhile, also pitched more than 250 in '61, when he was 25. He pitched more than 300 in 1965 and 66, winning 26 and 27 games in those years. There are more of course. (And, from the same era, consider the extraordinary relief careers of Hoyt Wilhelm and Roy Face.)Those were golden years for baseball and baseball fans. I'm not sure what Casey Stengel would have thought of pitch counts, but I think the answer is – – not much. As an aging Baby Boomer, I have spent entirely too much time wondering aloud why the pitchers of my youth were able to do what no pitcher would be asked to consider today.

As with other major sports, playing the game at the highest level has become more physically demanding than it was in those golden years. Nothing against those pitchers, but they faced lineups that included players that were slower, fatter, weaker and quite likely, hungover.

comments.commentBody:
There are many reasons to convert a single image to a pdf before transmitting it. (Of course, if you're trying to combine multiple images into a single page, pdf will be the only natural choice.)

I email a lot of images and almost always burn pdfs. The resolution you select will not be tampered with, and it will look the same on any device its displayed or printed on. A bitmap format like jpg will render differently on devices with different natural resolutions.

Many professional printers use pdf internally and produce optimal, predictable results when fed pdf.

Of course pdf supports documents of arbitrary complexity, but using pdf for a single image is common and certainly a best practice.

This notion that this clue, which has appeared in many crosswords from many publishers, is incorrect is not right. Sorry.

While there is clearly a value and a niche at the moment for these services, the sad aspect of their utility is that they push yet another aspect of how we structure and control our lives from one which is relational to one which is transactional. Instead of (as Bittman notes) thinking about, and engaging with, the food we eat, instead we have paid someone else to take that trouble.

I don't begrudge those who find this a relief to the challenge of cooking 7 nights a week, nor those who simply need some adjunct to help them build confidence in the kitchen; but let's not lose sight of the fact that this is a privileged means to a pampered end, and one which strips us of an integral aspect of how we relate to what we eat.

That Mark Bittman of all people -- he of the "The Minimalist" and several fine cookbooks -- would go in for this is shocking at the very least. It was Bittman who hectored people to learn to cook at home! and eat healthier.

You won't ever learn that if you are led by the hand, and get meals that are pre-packed and pre-designed and require no thought.

Shopping and planning are just as integral skills for eating (and for LIFE) as the actual job of cooking food in a pan over the stove.

Shipping people basic ingredients, at triple or quadruple the store cost -- and packed in miles of cardboard, boxes, shrink wrap, plastic, foam, etc. -- just cannot make sense if you have the slightest concern for the environment. It is just unbelievably wasteful and expensive.

Concerned Citizen - I fully agree on your point about the environment, but when you say this:
"You won't ever learn that if you are led by the hand, and get meals that are pre-packed and pre-designed and require no thought."
do you think about people who don't know how to cook? When my mother started teaching me, she did not say: boil that pasta until done and fry the meat with appropriate seasoning added, she showed me the step-by-step process. Also the basic cookbook her mother got her when she started cooking for herself.

Once you know what the basics mean, you can use your imagination. Unitl then, learning necessitates some no thinking required reading of recipes.
I doubt it. Doing so would have egregiously been legislating from the bench, of which he was no fan.

What a load some commenters are leaving. Non-citizens have absolutely no right to representation. Zero Zip Nada. Thus the hue and cry or Republicans is entirely misplaced. We only demand that those that do vote are properly identified, a reasonable request given the large 'undocumented' population, and that non-citizens surely should not be counted for representation, regardless of whether they are included in the census. Let's not excuse on problem with another. The result of leftist policies is the destruction of the country.

This reader remains baffled. The Court's ruling now allows states to count all residents for apportionment, so Democratically controlled states will and cannot be challenged for doing so. But since the Court is not requiring states to count all residents, Republican states such as Texas and Arizona will not, to exclude representation to residents without voting rights.

How can this be a victory for Democrats, except that they can continue to do what they have been doing and so can Republicans.
One has to wonder if reporters actually read Justice Ginsberg's opinion. Along with merely allowing States to do what they already do, she may have also permitted the sun to keep rising in the east.

The issue of whether the states could use eligible voters as a standard was not properly before the court. The court cannot in general rule on issues that have not been brought before it, so the resolution of that question will have to wait.

We have a sitting governor with an abhorrent record, a guy who's never been elected to anything but owns a lot of real estate and has a big tower, and a guy who's been elected but has stabbed all his colleagues in the back. In other words, our choices are Denethor, Sauron and Saruman. We gotta melt that ring, and fast
This may be the best summation of the current GOP candidates that I have seen the entire election cycle. We are definitely bound in darkness.
Hey and Bernie is Dumbledore...or Gandalf to keep the hobbit themed image.

What does it say that the only GOP candidate that can beat either DNC candidate is considered too moderate?

This is not the party of Reagan.

And to the Republic for which it stands....
Kasich is no moderate. He just seems sane in comparison...

Re: "What does it say that the only GOP candidate that can beat either DNC candidate is considered too moderate?"

Sanders polls about Kasich. Kasich couldn't beat him.
What arrogance. I want Kasich to stay in. I hope he does.

Silly Republicans aren't good at math.  The only chance of derailing Trump from getting the nomination is to keep him below the threshold to win the first ballot.  With Kasich in the race, this is more likely to happen. Cruz should be happy he is staying.
It is also mathematically impossible to Cruz to even get near the magic 1237. Nor does he possess any plausible chance of catching Trump on his home turf of the future primaries in new England.
Whether or not Trump wins on his home turf, it's not because New Yorkers like or want him;  it's because they really really don't want Cruz or Kasich.

I'm always amused when politicians get upset that other politicians are playing politics.  What the heck?  Of course Kasich won't withdraw.  If he's got enough delegates to prevent Trump or Cruz from getting a first ballot win, then he's got some power at the convention.  What pol would give that up?

The Republican primary race, now down to Cruz, Trump, and Kasich (sort of) has all the elements of a great film noir or, funny enough, a creepy slasher flick.
I would like Alfred Hitchcock or, perhaps, Orson Welles to direct the ending. The cast is a rich melange of oily fabulists and horse faced hacks. All zeroes, no heroes.

and Elke

MTF Tobin- Not me !
If Ted's not happy, I'm happy.
It is so very simple: Kasich could win the general; Cruz can not.

Re: "It is so very simple: Kasich could win the general; Cruz can not."

What evidence is this assumption based on? As Cruz appositely points out, Kasich can't even get any Republicans to vote for him. He certainly wouldn't get any Democratic votes in the general election. If Kasich somehow became the Republican nominee (which is virtually impossible), the media would actually publicize his record and that myth the he's a "moderate" would be immediately exposed for the fabrication it is which would rule out votes from independents. That leaves pretty much nobody at all supporting Kasich.
I would have a modicum of confidence that Mr. Kasich could win the general [election] if he could carry a state in the primary. Or even place second.
So the Canadian guy running for the U.S. presidency is mad that the Pennsylvania-born Ohio governor/competitor doesn't "bow out"? That's rich.

If there's a contested convention, it's Paul Ryan they want. It isn't likely that any of Trump, Cruz, or Kasich will win the general. Unfortunately for the rest of us, the three who are running are going to get more and more desperate. Lord help us, it's already unbearable to watch!

Throwing Ryan into the mix makes an already scary scenario even scarier. Never has a more unqualified slate of candidates been placed before the voters. When Kasich is the voice of reason and sanity, you've got a problem.
Agreed. Ryan is the one the want.
One problem is that the GOP just a few scant years ago voted AGAINST any brokered conventions, so if they go down the illegal path to a brokered convention they lose and lose large!  And are dead!

All the Republican candidates are horrible. It's like choosing between whether to contract Malaria, the Plague, or Swine Flu. All of them will make you very sick, and might very well lead to your demise.
Jim, It's hard to imagine the American public winning at the end of the Republican contest! What an embarrassing cast of characters.

Nice one with a few bumps. It took a while to remember that while SEEGER has a double-E, PEABO uses EA. Didn't get the theme until after the puzzle was done, but it is a good one.

Depending on your generation the WHITE joker could be Betty, Slappy, or Ron, who is part of the Blue Collar Comedy Tour.

Loved the Seeger video. "Simpler" times, but harder for people of our political bent.
Perhaps, perhaps not...but he is better than Cruz.

Kasich hasn't been attacked yet or deeply investigated for the entire country to see. Most people in the U.S. don't know his record on issues because he doesn't like talking about it. If he's the Republican nominee, many of the moderate Republicans who initially breathe a sigh of relief will discover what he's really about and reluctantly decide to vote for Clinton.

IS the Cruz campaign stupid or is the Cruz campaign stupid? Do they really believe that by criticizing Kasich he is going to be more willing to step out of the election??? Mind boggling how stupid Trump and Cruz are!
All of them?

comments.commentBody:
Stylin’ piece, Herr Douthat. Like Gertrude Stein. Your there is there. Penetrating yet impenetrable. Verbiage oblique. Attacking the WSJ for not attacking Ryan for not attacking Trump by name. You’re so good with your stiletto, we don’t even see the blade. Ryan could say more, more forcefully. But I agree with his crystal blue persuasion. History shows again and again how nature points up the folly of man. Trump support derives from sympathy. Jimmy Boy Edming has it right: “The more and more that they attack Trump, the more people are going to vote for him.”
http://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2016/03/30/meet-wisconsins-first-pro-trump...

"Reality", she "earned" those speaking fees with her vote in support of the 2005 Bankruptcy bill, a yuge giveaway to banks, that makes discharging student loan debt almost impossible, even in bankruptcy, even though the government indemnifies private lenders against losses in default on those loans. So, once again, privatized profit and socialized loss, just the way the banksters like it.

I have long found the WSJ edit page to be bizarrely out of touch. Climate change is just a liberal plot to take over more of our lives- really? Supply tax cuts always pay for themselves and unleash mega growth....except when they don't (e.g. Bush Jr.). Obama more or less hates his country.

The list goes on and on but it is just one more example of how the Koch driven conservative movement has so overplayed their hand that they deserve to be deeply marginalized (and likely will).

But, its Murdoch media so one never knows- maybe we''ll get treated to girlie pics on the front page in the not too distant future.....

Whatever I think there's perfectly good reasons why Ryan who hasn't been supportive of Trump wouldn't want to campaign against him or endorse another candidate not the least of which is it will give him more credibility in a likely brokered convention.

The modern GOP invented itself when Reagan launched himself in Phil Ms dog whistling states rights at the location of the freedom rider murders. H W Bush sold his soul to the devil with Willie Horton. W went to Bob Jones University which prohibited interracial dating to launch his campaign. Both Ryan & Romney peddled the maker taker ideas. Now Trump is the same guy without the dog whistle.

These guys howl about the low growth environment Obama created. Obama's skills are so great he's created that same environment around the world. Our low growth experience leads the world.

Facts don't matter. The fast talking idiot in Louisiana has ruined that state. Kansas is racing to the bottom. North Carolina is on its way. What they have in common is devotion to the supply side voo doo.

The outrage these folks feel is real. Corporations and the financial industry have enriched themselves while shafting the middle class. Now the bills have come due in terms of low growth b/c no one has any money to spend except the top 10%.

Here in NC dem votes don't really matter. They outvoted pubs in 2012 by about 80,000 votes and yet the US House votes ended up with 9 pubs and 4 dems. In 2014 they outvoted dems 55% to 45% and the result was 10 pubs to 3 dems. So the con movement is not above real voter fraud.

Facts don't matter in con world. Faith is all that matters. Faith in nonsense that results in the rise of the 1%.

Oh it's fair. It's more than fair.

Brian Williams lost his job over exaggerating how much danger he was in in a helicopter flight. Hillary claimed that she and her then teenage daughter ducked sniper fire in Kosovo, and now is running for President.
Looking forward to the campaign shifting here to New York. Clinton is counting her eggs before they hatch.
How does Ryan beat Bernie?
He won half the registered democrats in Wisconsin

1) as to Bernie's ability to catch Hillary in pledged delegates, note that the NYT and AP delegate counters don't include 67 pledged delegates from Washington State that will be awarded based on voting results by Congressional District and Bernie romped throughout all districts in Washington State, and Dem race is only now passed the 50% mark. Its only half-time; its close; Hillary's biggest wins are behind her and Bernie has momentum.
2) The writing is on the wall that the Repubs will find a way to nominate somebody other than Trump, so the Dems should not want to be the single party that nominates a candidate with such high UNfavorable ratings; Bernie does much better in most of the head to head polls against the various republicans and Hillary can only beat Trump. But Cruz is not much better, if at all, for the country than Trump.
Cruz is worse than Trump if that's possible.

If Bernie gets the nomination, I will vote for him. But I'm under no illusions: the way he looks today in those head to head polls is exactly the way the Republicans want him to look. They even praise him on the talk shows. They're trying to help him get the nomination, and are even quite open about it http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-01-19/republican-operati... .

Hillary has been in the cross hairs of their smear machine going on 3 decades, and whatever you think of her, is tough as nails and can stand up to their filth and give back every bit as good as she gets. When people see that happening in the general election campaign, you will see her numbers MOVE. The Republicans know that, and that's why they would much rather run against Bernie. Their smearmeisters are itching to go to work on him, but they have the sophistication and the discipline to keep their powder dry for now. They already have lots of ammunition stockpiled. He started political life as a Trotskyite. He made a documentary in the 70's urging world wide revolution. He hung a hammer and sickle flag in his Burlington office. He went to the USSR for his honeymoon. That's just for starters. By the time they're finished with him, I guarantee you he won't look the same in those head to head polls as he looks today.

Right Julia...thanks .... N. Kashkari, the Gop fed reserve chair of MN, said tbtf banks are under capitalized, under regulated by govt. thus putting us at risk.
So why isn't Kashkari in the cable news TV shows explaining this to the masses??
Or why doesn't Sanders cite him in his speeches???

The banks are regulating our govt, not the other way around.
Just now on CNN, Peter Beinert and fellow pundits are minimizing Sanders, saying he hasn't been specific re regulating the banks. I wonder where these well paid pundits invest their money? Maybe they should have to disclose!

I'm waiting for the big media to follow up on the 170 top economists who publicly support Sanders plans to reform Wall St. Google it. Why is the media avoiding this, especially it's star liberal economist? Ahem.

Clinton only said that it's shadow banks that caused the crash, and Glass Steagall would't help, and if she thinks they're getting too risky, she'll tell the to 'cut it out'. Sounds pretty unspecific. What's her definition of risky? How about rule of law instead of her judgment?
And gun control? Suddenly the establishment is so, so pro, pro gun control, when Sanders has the slightest perceived weakness there. Didn't he get a D minus from America's great arbiter on this subject, the NRA?

GIO: "Bernie may not be a banking expert but his idea resonate. I fully trust him to do the right thing. So the Daily News says he does not have a full-on plan to break up the big banks? So what, there is time for that later."  Seriously??  Bernie doesn't need to be a banking expert, but this is a major plank in his CENTRAL (arguably only) platform!  He should have been able to speak fluently on the topic this far into the primary, even if it meant being coached by a team of banking experts.  But this is what happens when the press allows a candidate to get away with regurgitating talking points and avoiding details.

Please explain how Clinton will accomplish her goals any more easily than Sanders will accomplish his.  The Clinton camp has sold Sanders' goals as "pie-in-the-sky", while she is supposedly practical and, one assumes, can accomplish things.  Just what can she accomplish and how will she accomplish things any easier than Sanders will?
You got that right, Big Guy.
Well Bernie was old school

New York is not his home state.  He abandoned New York for Vermont quite some time ago.  He does not know that we have not used tokens on the subways for many, many years.  Speaking of tokens, after 25 years working in a city with one of the most heavy concentrations of African American citizens in the country, he did not have one black person on his staff - not one at any level - until well into the presidential campaign when he was evidently informed that a large portion of the Democratic electorate is . . .wait for it . . .black! He runs a large government-funded office and there were no black people there.  It looked just like his actual home state - lily-white Vermont - and the people who vote for him.

Utter hypocrisy such as this Mook comment below is why so many distrust and loathe Clinton:

"Robby Mook, Mrs. Clinton’s campaign manager, said on Monday that Mr. Sanders’s unlikely path to the nomination would amount to “overturning the will of the voters” by trying to flip pledged delegates at state and party conventions, as was done in Nevada."

Sanders has won and/ or virtually tied states where few of the superdelegates chose him despite the proportional will of the voters. Why isn't Mook complaining about that?

And seeng that made me donate more money to Hillary!  Why do you Sanders' supporters hate her so much? She worked so hard as a public servant for so many years doing the best she can with the system we have.  You're mean, hateful and unrelenting comments are not just toward her, but toward her supporters too; I'm getting so sick of it. I can't wait for her to win, have more Superdelegate support, and see Bernie go bye bye.

See www.Counterpunch.org and Cent Unger (sp.) "Young Turks" tv (or website) program for the reveal of the laundering of money by the DNC and the Clinton campaign, whereby some of the large donations get sent back to state Democrat parties, and "bribe" the super delegates. Horrifying and corrupt.
Congratulations to Sen. Sanders on his win in Wisconsin. I, 74 year old woman, will be voting for him in the New York primary.

Jackie: Sanders has said nothing about switching pledged delegates. He and his campaign have only been talking about superdelegates--who can switch at any time.

Mook is trying to make it sound like switching superdelegates means overriding "the rule of the people." It's a bogus claim.
Hawaii is the most diverse state in the country. How did Bernie did there again?
I personally suspect that while Bernie is a decent guy with pie in the sky ideas, many of his votes are actually acts of revulsion against the alternative.

Pie in the sky ideas that work perfectly well in other Western industrialized nations.

But, yeah, I feel a lot of revulsion against the alternative candidate who has enriched herself feeding at the trough of the interests whose boots are on our necks.

Advances are often initially dismissed as "pie in the sky" or the equivalent.  Such pessimistic assessments were wrong when the outlandish idea was put forward that we could be governed by elected leaders rather than by royalty... or that education could be made universal... or that we could develop flying machines... or that the viscous racist Jim Crow laws could be dismantled... etc., etc., etc.
Clyde, I agree with you, but that wasn't what I meant.

Can you tell me how Bernie will realistically get anything done as the President of the United States, with his stubbornness and his inability to work with other fellow democrats? Like it or not, politics is a dirty business, and you need to play well with others in order for things to get done. I'm being realistic here. It's so easy to say," Let's overhaul the system!" and "Free Education for all!" But how is it plausible in our current framework. It's brings to mind middle school elections where kids dangle longer recesses and pizza Fridays as carrots in order to get votes. Sure you're going to galvanize people with those sky in pie ideas, but it's not going to happen unless you have mass protests every day a bill is being voted on. So if he even the the very unlikely event he wins the nomination, he'll be a one-termer. His own people will truly feel the burn when they realize he can't make good on any of his promises.
Concerned Citizen, your debating skills are severely lacking Suggest you take some lessons. And stop generalizing to absurdity.

A standard test is the best way to counter favoritism and discrimination. It is obvious that candidates from lower socio-economic background would get lower scores in tests. A bitter truth is that they also have lower success later in life. People like to throw in exceptional examples and argue against statistics.

Instead of seeking alternatives to tests, let us improve tests, lower the cost of test taking.

"Yes, students need to be assessed, and yes, transcripts will show the rigor of courses they take, so assessments should be authentic and meaningful, as opposed to an alphabet "

There's something to be said for objective measures. Here in Montclair, we're sending teachers and other staff to training against unaware racist attitudes and assumptions. The entire basis of this is that subjective evaluations are exactly that. The accumulating evidence of a problem in this regard was becoming impossible to ignore.

We speak of grades being a great predictor of college success, but are the grades measuring or are they actually influencing the outcome. If the latter, then these subjective measures could be doing great harm to those student that don't fit teachers' images of success.

Hopefully, programs such as what Montclair is doing will reduce this. But subjective will always be subjective.

...Andrew
Joe this is gross. Is it slavery to be required to serve black people? To you see how ridiculous your assertion is?

My one quibble with  conclusion that the WSJ opinion writers have their heads in the sand, under the spell of the "power and influence" of the moneyed rump of the Republican establishment. That's not quite true. They are paid to hold this specific positions. If they change their opinions, they'll need to find new places to write them and the WSJ will find new people to sit at those keyboards to spout the same garbage.  Its like wondering what it would take to get the editors of Pravda to recognizing the wisdom of the markets.

comments.commentBody: I saw this very much in my own family, where my ridiculously favored sibling struggled and never figured out what he wanted to do in life, hates what he wound up doing and has been counting down his remaining years to retirement for some time now.  And because he was favored, he was expected to be a pleaser, and that affected him well into adulthood as well.  Being decidedly un-favored, but having a huge amount of pride, I grew up expecting to not be liked and found over time that it was immensely freeing.  People were happy to get basic cooperation from me whereas my favored sibling had the constant pressure of making my mother proud and happy.    The book you reference sounds fascinating-- I had never thought of the favoritism as a form of narcissism, but it absolutely was.
How so? Giancarlo Cruz Michael Stanton is of Puerto Rican ancestry.
I agree with you.
Bob Gibson would have put an end to the bat flipping as good as anyone could.
What part of "media coverage" didn't you get?
Ditto from a 72 year old.  I was in college during the '60's - it was an unbelievable time to be young.  Nothing since has come close.
The Wonder Years, indeed. ✌️
Magic waters, indeed. ✌️
And, now, yours does.

The beauty of baseball is that you can never know if the game is over by the second batter until the end of the game. The biggest deficit a team can have after the second batter is 2-0. The game is by no means over at 2-0, unless Koufax or Gibson are pitching. If you are that bored attending a ballgame just whip out your cell phone and text away. Better be sitting behind some screening, unless you want to take a shot off the old noggin from a boring baseball.
Magical. Beautifully controlled and staged...scary. People blending so easily into a "design for living", so efficiently conveyed by the zenithal p.o.v.  Bravo.

The article talked about the behavior of players, not fans (or fans of the 1940's). Larry Bird played basketball, so his rah, rah perhaps would fit in the NBA, although a rah-rah speech would likely be okay in a baseball dugout--this article is saying that the MLB's discouraging showboating is essentially crypto-racism.

The point is basketball reflects the cultural mores of those who dominate it today. Why can't baseball do the same? Maybe baseball's lessons: humility, respect for opponents, and even-keeled behavior that doesn't over react up or down over one outcome are worth learning...

Football: Four fifteen minute quarters. Loads of violent physical contact. Scantily clad cheerleaders and boffo halftime shows. One game per week a few months each year. The Super Bowl media blitz.

Baseball: Nine innings, or more. Games run three hours plus, no time limit. Plenty of down time. No showtime, no sexy dancers, little physical contact and what there is, mostly prohibited and penalized. One hundred sixty two games plus a long post season of wild card games, intraleague playoffs and a seven game final 'World Series.'

In this age of short attention spans, twitter, you tube videos and cars that have become rolling wifi nodes and video infotainment centers, you wonder why baseball's fans average over 50 years of age?

Hint: it ain't because baseball is a racist, white man's game. The guys playing major league baseball are as diverse as they have ever been, with players from all over Latin America, Japan, Korea, anywhere the game is popular and well played, by young men (oh no, it's a sexist game as well!) of whatever color.

I've loved watching baseball since the 50s. Played it as a kid. I stood up and cheered and laughed uncontrollably when Bautista flipped his bat, because it was exactly the right thing to do at that point in that game; just as I loved Junior's style. Part of the fun was how much it rankled dour old Buck.

Oh, by the way, I'm an old Jewish white guy. What percentage of the players are Jewish? Is baseball 'unbearably anti-Semitic?' Balderdash.

What percentage of the players are Jewish? Legitimate question.

What percentage of the owners are Jewish? Also a legitimate question.
Me bragging: I met Duke Snyder.  Biut not Koufax, alas.
Acceptance, not fairness must be purchased--by respecting traditions and assimilating.

Race problem? What's the race solution? Kids play what they want to play. There are enough fantastic current and ex Major Leaguers that could grow the game as they do in Latin America and in communities in the USA. As for "bat flipping". I wonder what Bob Gibson or Dave Stewart would have done the next time Bautista came up to the plate?
EXACTLY! chin music is what bat flipping gets you.
We don't have to speculate.  Sal "The Barber" anyone?

A very similar thing happens in New York City's private high schools. Aid offered to families to lure their children in can be yanked away at any point. And parents, they realize, will do everything to avoid disrupting their child's education at that point, even if it means massive debt.
Natural talents... I believe they were more synthetic with these too.

Eliminating tenure will have three undesirable consequences
1. Faculty will become the servants of administrators. Most universities have substantial numbers of non-tenure track faculty who understand their only responsibility is to cater to the whims of people who became administrators to make more money, because they didn't like teaching, and their research interests dried up.
2. Highly competent faculty will abandon academia in droves, those incapable of leaving will stay behind.
3. Competent faculty will cost substantially more. Scholars will give up income for security and stability, take away security and you will have to pay a risk premium for talented faculty, or hire the untalented.
The Unbearable LIGHTNESS of Being...having nothing to do with skin color.

And not surprisingly, rural or surburban kids are much more likely to have an involved dad. But no, you feel a need to chalk it up to racist thinking. Perhaps next time you will be open to thinking critically.

What are the parameters that define a race problem? What's the number of African American players on rosters that signal the end of the problem? What's the number of managers needed? Are clubs wittingly or unwittingly not signing black players because they don't want black players on their rosters?

I grew up playing baseball, listening to World Series games on an AM radio in school, playing baseball as a kid, in high school, and in college, and coaching in Little League.  But I haven't watched more than a couple of innings of a game on TV in decades, and stopped going to games years ago - it's 3+ hours of the pitcher and batter daring each other to waste more time.  The lack of young fans has nothing to do with skin color.

Love the TOERING Inferno, which says "Meta Lurching unDaunted in Search of a Pirandello" to me.

Coincidentally, while driving home tonight, just heard on NPR about the Brazilian "Neon Bull"; some distant echoes of "Le Boeuf SEETOIT" there

"According to a Wall Street Journal study of four recent broadcasts, and similar estimates by researchers, the average amount of time the ball is in play on the field during an NFL game is about 11 minutes."
--http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704281204575002852055561406
There's actually more action in a baseball game.
People who call baseball boring are themselves boring.

Then I'm afraid a lot of people, including people under the age of 50, are boring as well.

I like baseball, but it certainly does drag at times in the majority of the games played.
