comments.commentBody: Hands down Patrick Barry is my favorite constructor. That's not meant as a slight to any other puzzle master but I'm in Patrick's wheelhouse (or he's in mine). It's probably because my ego gets a big boost when I solve one of his puzzles. It's Friday, it's a romp with sly and fun clues. I loved LAPCAT, the wicked KNEED and TALKING HEAD. I didn't know FAITH NO MORE (after watching the clip, I can't imagine why) but got it on the crosses. Loved it all.

Remind me again why our elections last so long? The only positive I see is that they allow time for less-known candidates such as Sanders to gain recognition and momentum. In return, we get greater polarization, millions upon millions of dollars wasted on advertisements, and hate-spewing egoists like Trump clawing their way out of dismissive ridicule and into positions at the front of their party's nomination.
so it should be a popularity contest?

They last so long so that every last dime can be wrung out by news networks, campaign staffers, hotels, convention centers, & advertizers. I read a book about William McKinley. He was running against famous orator, William Jennings Bryan, & knew he couldn't hold a candle to his speaking style. So, he spent the entire campaign season on his front porch, spending no money & making the media come to him. Guess what? He won. Too bad we don't do that any more. In Great Britain, the campaign season lasts 6 weeks.

They last so long because campaigns are good for "business" and enrich thousands of businesses around the country and the world.
In short -- it's all about the MONEY -- it's always all about the MONEY.

Does Bernie Sanders really think he can beat the Republican candidate once the GOP machine starts actively conflating his socialism with communism, and once they start a whispering campaign about his Jewishness with all the negative stereotypes involved? (The latter would have to be done completely behind closed doors.) Does he really believe that Americans would elect someone who would be 78 years old after only one term?

I don't believe Sanders really has the welfare of the American people completely at heart. He's not pure as the driven snow, and I believe there's a massive amount of ego involved (similar to Trump, perhaps?).

If Sanders really wanted to change America he would have done it by now. He could still achieve a great deal by leading his "revolution" from outside government, as did the great Gandhi and Martin Luther King.

Something stinks here, and Sanders is looking less and less attractive all the time.

I can barely stand to hear his voice anymore.
I agree.  His voice and lecturing tone really grates on my nerves.  He never really smiles unless he is scoring a point against someone.
He'd be 79 after one term!

Forget the repeated claims Bernie shouts or offers pie in the sky or that Hillary is strident or she's tough, seasoned, the most qualified person ever to run for president. This isn't what matters. Bernie's not calling her unqualified because he's a misogynist and hates women - that's ridiculous and false.

Bernie's called her unqualified because of her very bad decisions on the Iraq War vote and regime change in iraq, the two most significant destabilizing foreign policy disasters in recent history. Decisions which resulted in political chaos and the rise of terrorist states in the middle east, endangering Europe, North Africa and the United States. Decisions which led to the loss of American lives - the lives of our troops, our allies, & tens of thousands of innocent civilians.

Hillary made these decisions about the Iraq War (which was a no-brainer to anyone paying attention!) and regime change in Libya after being presented with facts and careful consideration. These weren't dumb remarks she made on the campaign trail while exhausted. These decisions are the most important things she's running on - that she's the person we should trust to answer that 3 a.m. phone call that there's a crisis somewhere in the world that the U.S. president must respond to. And her record shows that in these 2 most important situations in recent times, while she held important office as senator or in the cabinet, she made terrible, destructive choices that had tragic, ongoing consequences.

If you're to blame anyone for the Iraq war, blame Nader and his supporters. You can also blame Nader and his supporters for 911 as well.  If you don't believe in regime change, then let a regime change not happen in the US in 2016!  Vote Hillary Clinton to keep the ball rolling in the right and best direction for this country. She is the most qualified to be POTUS!

And it matters because she is running for president unlike most of those pols who voted yes, in fact, that's WHY she voted yes, for her future presidential run, so she would not appear weak as woman candidate.

I always thought and hoped a woman president who brings life into this world would not so easily take it. Would be more of dove like Bernie.

Makes me want to puke.

From suggesting Sanders is not qualified to saying that he didn't 'prioritize' women's rights in abortion to exploiting the Flint water crisis and the tragedy at Sandy Hook, I am appalled at Clinton's tactics. On the surface, these moves almost seems too greasy and too corrupt to be from her campaign, but yet she continues to smear her opponent rather than talk about the issues that make many Americans wary of voting for her.

What did she say to Wall Street that they gave her so much money? Why is she still holding fundraisers with special interest groups and the rich when Americans detest campaign finance? Until Clinton can muster the courage and integrity to address these issues with at least some authenticity rather than condescension and rhetoric, many Americans will see her as an extension of the rich and the establishment.

If Clinton comes out and says "This is how the system is, and that is why I am forced to fund raise in this way. I am sorry. From this day on, I will no longer accept money from X, Y, and Z." This is authenticity and a fearlessness needed in our next president, and I doubt Clinton or her campaign advisers would agree to do such a thing that would require character and insight. Instead, they will double down on their smear campaign and detract from her weakness as a candidate.

That is why I hope Bernie Sanders continues on with his integrity and his passionate anger. I will continue to give and give to his campaign because we deserve better.

If you had lived through all the Clinton years as I have you would not be surprised at all, they do worse and it will come.

Bernie has every right to defend himself, he must, and on certain issues, fire back. He is used to wrestling alligators in Washington. Politics is ugly, hrc and bill do stupid stuff like this when threatened (oh my and worse). Watch.

And you give excellently with your astute, balanced, well-written comments. Thank you.
Bernie 2016

@Tiffany,
This time, I agree with you.

4-8-16@4:27 am

He didn't actually mean she was unqualified, he meant that her acceptance of campaign contributions from the financial services industry, the petroleum industry, the insurance industry and the pharmaceutical industry disqualify her because of the debts she's amassed with them that will come due if she reaches the White House. It's simply not the same thing - few question her qualifications, many question her honesty.

Why does every one have to explain what Sanders "means"?  Can't he put together an articulate explanation or position on anything?    So choosing the wrong word, or not being able to explain how to achieve his goals, is just another chance for his supporters to tell us what he really means or what he meant to say.  That is just pitiful.  He is not in Vermont anymore-- put a sentence together Sir!

You're tying yourself in knots trying to distinguish between Bernie saying she is "disqualified" for various reasons but not that she is "unqualified". I respect Bernie, but today I have slightly less respect for him than I did yesterday. He did not have to go down this road.
My God, she is the most honest of any of the candidates that we have, including Sanders and the most qualified.

While I respect your views on Secretary Clinton, I find it horrifying and offensive that you'd suggest Sanders' supporters are falling for Republican rhetoric. I have never voted for a Republican in my life, I find the current GOP rhetoric horrifying, and I don't watch FOX and co., nor do I read any right-wing media. I find Hillary untrustworthy because she claims to be for campaign finance reform while engaging in and benefitting immensely from the Citizens United decision. I find her untrustworthy because she claims to be for tougher regulation of Wall St. while holding fundraisers and having given $225K speeches to their elite. I could go on.

While I don't doubt that she is a hundred times better than any of the Republicans running today and I'll vote for her easily in November, Bernie is raising issues that resonate with millions of Democrats, and while he trails her significantly in delegates, many of us have and will continue to vote for him until June because we believe in his message and his integrity. Don't try to sweep these valid criticisms of her under the rug by claiming that they're manufactured by Republicans.

I have always voted Dem because I agreed far more with their stances on the issues, but I've always identified as an Independent. I even changed my party affiliation to vote for Sanders this month. It's a sad day when Democrats try to discount Sanders supporters by claiming they naively believe right-wing rhetoric.

The most compelling thing about Bernie’s campaign was that it might actually be possible to be outside politics as usual, and, for a sweet quixotic moment, made me actually dare to hope for something different. But the strains of  campaigning and the long overdue vetting have revealed him to be exactly like any other politician, but maybe worse, because he is wrapped in so much sanctimony. It must be incredible to finally find oneself a rock star at 74, and I am sure these are the best moments of his life, but he is seriously in over his head. For the first time last night I donated to Hillary’s campaign and I have noticed a similar subsiding of enthusiasm all over the internet.

Bernie is not saying that Hillary is not theoretically qualified. One only has to be a "natural born citizen" and be 35 years of age. Hillary has a resume of many years in the political business that would be impressive if time spent at something is all that matters. What she lacks is good judgement and integrity. Bernie is saying that she disqualifies herself by all the bad decisions she made such as supporting the Iraq war, promoted the Lybian war, wants to go to war with Syria, supported all those destructive trade deals, accepting millions of dollars from firms that could benefit from her decisions and so on. She had the qualification but she forfeited them.

What are the qualifications for the presidency? One has to be at least 35, a natural born citizen of the US, and have resided within the US for 14 years. So by those criteria, both Hillary and Bernie are qualified. But of course what both are talking about is whether the other has the mettle to become a good president. Hillary points to her resume, as thought heaping one more accomplishment, one more activity polishes her credentials for the office. But we all know people whose resumes are replete with exceptional experience but whose judgment, whose moral fiber is wanting. And this is what Bernie and so many of us are saying. We keep returning to the Iraq resolution, because even though 2003 was a trying time when many of her constituents were afraid and wanted to strike out in retaliation, as Senator, her job was not to vote for the politically expedient thing, but to show leadership and do the right thing. Her hawkish positions as Secretary of State show that she hadn't learned that lesson, and her actions since 2012 -- the email server, her decision to sell herself to the highest bidders on Wall Street, her late criticism of Keystone and TPP -- all speak to serious lapses in judgment. I prefer a president whose ethics and trustworthiness are above reproach, because the rest of the job can be learned; trust and character are nurtured from childhood.

You can always cherry pick anyone, and a lot what your saying is either Republican attacks (email) or Bernie attacks. Bottom line is she has worked a lot harder, knows the end and outs of Washington, knows how to fight money, is honest about what can realistically be done, than Sanders, thus is far more qualified to lead this country.

I read many comments from Bernie supporters claiming they will never vote for Hillary because of her vote for the Iraqi war resolution.

John Kerry also voted for that resolution.

Did those self-same Bernie supporters sit out the 2004 election? If they did, they are fools who gave us another four years of the W wrecking ball.

Or, understanding the stakes, did they go ahead and give Kerry their vote? While boasting today, when the stakes are horrifyingly higher, that they would not do the same for Hillary?

To call them “fools” would insult fools.

I did vote for John Kerry, and I will (reluctantly) vote for Hillary in November, if she is the nominee.  But look where John Kerry evolved since 2003: as Secretary of State, he has taken the US on a different path from the regime-change policies of Secretary Clinton.  That speaks to the kind of judgment that we seek, the ability to not only 'apologize' for the incorrect vote, but also change course and abandon the old perspective that lay behind that incorrect vote.

As a private citizen, she is allowed to make those speeches and be paid for them and by the way, she makes the same or less than other folks with the same expertise or credentials which makes them of interest for a seminar.

Sanders has proven, through his interviews, that he doesn't really have a grasp on the important issues of today. It is one thing to declaim about the country's woes, it's another to be able to address them.

And then there is the question of the Sanders' FEC filings. When will his campaign clarify the millions of unaccounted for dollars? Sanders seems to be in this for the money and less in it for the people.

This is a little kerfluffle based on media reports and headlines that may have been misunderstood by one or another of the two candidates,  it is nothing compared to the mess in the Repiblican Party and is just another attempt by the news people and Clinton apologists to create something out of nothing. Again they come to the defense of their candidate, Hillary, threatened  by a mythical misogynist rival. The journalists and supporters pretend that questions about her character and judgement are not relevant to the campaign.  The sports metaphors in the campaign have now gone from horse racing to boxing since mudslinging doesn't seem to be a recognized Olympic event yet. Mrs. Clinton pulled the same kind of stuff in 2008 against Obama, insinuating among other things that he was an inexperienced candidate with just a pretty speech.

I respected Sanders earlier this year when he was not pointing fingers to Clinton. He wasn't attacking her emails nor he was questioning her speech fees. At that time he didn't want to participate in a negative campaigning as it was with republicans.

However, I believe it was around the Michigan primary, Sanders started to attack Clinton about free trade agreements, emails, and speech fees from GS. His popularity increased as a consequence. But his purer ideals fell.

Now he's even saying that Clinton is not qualified. I think he has fallen too far. If he wants to save what he says he stands for, then he should resign from the race.

The Clintons have always played dirty, so spare us this sanctimony. Just google "Bill Clinton + Obama + 2008" and you will see that they are using the same vile playbook they used against then Senator Obama when he was challenging Mrs. Clinton for the nomination.

"Two years ago this man would have been carrying our bags and bringing us coffee..." That is how Mr. Clinton disparaged Mr. Obama.

The internet is a wonderful thing.

Um... you do realize the point of elections is to actually contrast yourself against the other candidate, right? Make a case why your campaign has the better platform? There is no disconnect between his means and his message.

So he should resign from the race and let a person win the nomination who is indebted to special interests, corporations and Wall Street, votes for unjustified war and lacks trustworthiness and good judgement all because he said "She is indebted to special interests, corporations and Wall Street, votes for unjustified war and lacks trustworthiness and good judgement"

That makes no sense

I prefer Sanders credentials. He is against going to war. Whether he busts up the banks or not, I don't think they would continue to operate as they do currently. Companies that are too big to fail ARE too big. He thoughts ruminate form the vantage point of the citizen, voter, people. He's got no grandfather type backers to ease the way for him to become President. It's what he's done and what he says he will do.

Contrasted against Clinton who is fine with the banks as they are and corporate owners who are contributing to her Super PACs. If she told me she wasn't and would change them, I would not believe her. She did vote for the Iraq War. How many hundreds of thousands of NYers marched against it? She has said it was a mistake. Yes, it was! A costly one that we have not stopped paying for yet. She is a Hawk, not a smart power advocate. It's her "smarter than thou" attitude that gets in her way all of the time. She'd take this nation to war just to prove that she could. She's driven. Driven to become President no matter what it takes. I think what disqualifies her is that she felt she was going to sail into the Presidency as if she was owed it. Her air of entitlement disqualifies her.

Anyone, Trump as a prime example, who after 15 years has not succeeded to the Presidency (both he and Clinton have desired the role for many years) does not mean there is a swell for them to do so now. Clinton is smart. Sanders is smart. I prefer Sanders smart for today's challenges.

It's surprising that Bernie has held off for so long given Sec. Clinton's many failures. The narrative that Clinton is highly qualified defies empirical evidence.  Yes, she has been in the public arena for three decades but her actions have been marked by poor judgement and failure beginning with the botched attempt at health care reform in the first years of the Clinton admin. when the Dems had majorities in the House and Senate, her vote for the Iraq War, and while Sos pushing for regime change in Libya, Syria, Ukraine and setting off a firestorm in large swaths of the world.  All that while pandering to Wall Street and corporate interests and raking in huge sums in speaking fees from same. We can ill afford more of that kind of experience in the White House.

And what has Sanders done?  I can't stand the criticizing when no one has been in the positions she's held. She was not the only one the voted for the Iraq war.  Many senators respected Senators did. She had said it was a mistake. Sanders voted to fund the war. She was an excellent SOS and a very good NY senator.  What has Sanders done?

I have to agree with another post. Many, many women have seen a job, a promotion or other recognition go to a male co-worker in the guise that they male was more qualified--even in the face of facts to the contrary. So saying that a female past Senator of New York and Secretary of State of the United States is unqualified to be President is really misogynistic. He could simply not do this with a straight face had HRC was male--no matter the record of the Senator and former Secretary of State.
I am a 63 year old female that lived this in Silicon Valley and in scientific research earlier in my career. Woman my age can hear the dog whistle! Stop in Mr. Sanders--we all vote!!!

You do recognize that, prior to Sanders' remarks, Clinton had questioned Sanders' qualifications, right?  That's the Bernie Sanders who has about 30 years in elected office, from mayor of a small city to a U.S. Senator.  Where is your outrage at Clinton's initial, unwarranted remarks?  And to throw in the word "misogny"? It's a strong and pointed word--let's try to use it when appropriate.  Otherwise, what words should we be flinging at Clinton for starting this spat?

Presidency is a great responsibility, not a corporate job. People with great honesty, conviction deserve it.HRC does not have either. If US is going to get its first women president, she should be a inspiring leader not some one who says anything to become a president. We can wait for a better candidate.

George Bush was a failure at every position he held -- even the ones the financed by his GHW Bush's friends. He served as the governor of Texas -- one of the weakest governorships in the country -- and he was AWOL from his pathetic position in the Texas Air National Guard -- but if Al Gore had said flat out that "George Bush is unqualified to be president" the media and the GOP would have gone into maniac mode attacking Gore and tearing him to shreds for even whispering it let alone saying it loudly in an interview. It's definitely a dog-whistle from Sanders.
I wouldn't vote of Sanders just for the fact that he sat on his axx in the Senate for years until he was 74 before he decided to do any of the heavy lifting to put himself in the forefront of American politics -- meanwhile people like Hillary Clinton has been in the thick of it for years -- many times being attacked not for anything she did but because people were angry with her husband for personal failures on his part. Clinton stood up to all of it and she's running again -- even after suffering a defeat in 2008 that no one thought was possible. That's a strong woman of conviction that she has something to bring to the table as President -- I'll vote for Hillary Clinton -- not the old guy who hid in the Senate for many years and only emerged when he was 74 -- a time when he should be retiring not looking for a new job.

Several US presidents didn't hold many "qualifications" when they first ran for president. Obama was in the Senate two years, and had served a couple of years as a state legislator. Eisenhower never held elective office before becoming president. Same with Andrew Jackson. Theodore Roosevelt was vice-president for six months when an assassination made him president--he had never held a federal post before. And Abraham Lincoln had served two years as a Congressman in the House, and then he had failed to reelect.

The president sets the tone and direction of the administration and communicates with the people and with foreign leaders. The technocrat advisers and bureaucrats in the administration fine-tune policy and carry out the executive functions.

What's important to me is where a candidate stands on the issues, and the strength of their character.

It's a big deal over nada.

I hope Bernie tells them to go fish. That's the Trump "polite" and "nice" way to do it. Yet Bernie is actually right. From every appearance, Mrs. Clinton hardly evinces a hanging-chad of comprehension of her husband's work as president.

I hope his wife didn't mean it when she mentioned to Rachael Maddow today that he would support Clinton if he loses. Sanders should run as an independent. Trump probably will, too, if he loses to that Canadian Senator. And Sanders will probably win, nevertheless!

The two party structure is a joke, and hopefully it will mean the end of the two party experiment and extended debacle in the United States.

There is nothing impractical about what Sanders wants to do except that so many Democrats have drunk the Republican Cool Aid that they now believe that there is no money and that we should be giving tax cuts to billionaires instead of investing in our people. Centrists are a bunch of suckers doing the bidding of global corporations without (in most cases) even realizing it.
Fight for what is right instead of constantly giving away more and more in the vain hope that the lunatic right will ever be satisfied. It hasn't worked for thirty years and it never will.

I think there is substantial evidence that Mrs. Clinton may have the MOST honesty and integrity of the candidates.

She was tops in an unbiased evaluation of all 15 on Climate Change, one of the top issues of our time. http://bigstory.ap.org/article/3e946f29fa534a0b9c1d064b16e06b61/ap-fact-...

She has long had detailed policy positions on her website - transparent to voters, more than any other candidate. And most importantly, scads of economic and tax policy analysts have long said that she's the only one whose numbers add up.

I'll forgive all of the candidates a bit of spin when it comes to framing themselves in the most favorable light. And I understand that Sen. Sanders is a working Senator and can't be equally prepared, but he's had ample funds to hire folks to re-work his numbers and hasn't. He will not win the general election with the tax rates that he is proposing... but I fear he may have handed the GOP an election they had all but conceded.

Mrs. Clinton has had to move her position "to the left" because of Senator Sanders entry into the primaries. If she becomes the nominee, she will do what her husband did: move as the wind blows. If elected, she will solidify her family's position among the world's elite, mostly at the expense of the Sanders constituency.

The conventional wisdom, that she will mash any Republican in the general election, should be more closely examined. Many, like me, who see no meaningful difference between Mrs. Clinton and ANY Republican, will vote for the Republican, in order to force the political situation in America closer to its crisis.

We are sick of business as usual.
That's reprehensible.

If you think you are "sick of business as usual" wait until you see what a Republican President can do with a Republican Congress.  Then you, and all of the rest of us, will discover what "sick" really feels like.

"Many, like me, who see no meaningful difference between Mrs. Clinton and ANY Republican, will vote for the Republican, in order to force the political situation in America closer to its crisis."

No intelligent thinking person would make that statement "force the political situation in America closer to its crisis" -- so you'd rather see the country crash and burn with millions of people losing health care, social security, the social safety net, equal rights for women, blacks, Latinos, etc., more guns everywhere, more poverty etc. You are literally the enemy within.

My husband was an academic physician, I an attorney. We were married for 45 years. I learned a lot during that time about how medical institutions work, met most of the people he worked with and socialized with them, and vice versa. I cannot imagine that any of the experiences we shared with each other would have qualified my husband to defend a client in court or me to write a research grant proposal.
Hillary managed to bootstrap her marriage to a president and her residency in the White House into an uncontested Senate seat, and later a mediocre term as SOS. Those are her only earned qualifications. Hillary's supporters should recall that Al Gore was Bill Clinton's VP, not Hillary.

That is the most ridiculous and insulting analogy I've ever heard. The presidency requires strong analytical skills and solid knowledge of domestic and foreign affairs. In that sense, a common citizen could be a good president.

Whereas medicine and law require specialized training. It's sad that despite your law degree, this has to be explained.

What is the relevance? You are forgetting that Hillary has been interested and involved in politics and policy making for at least as long as Bill has.

Why do women project their own personal experiences onto other women, and expect them to behave according to their playbook? I'm so happy for you that you and your husband had independent professional lives. Don't see what it has to do with Hillary, or for that matter, any other woman.

I find your last comments to be especially revolting. Her "only earned qualifications" of being a Senator and a Secretary of State are because she managed to glom onto a president? Sexism -- directed against your own gender -- is alive and well.
Excellent logic. You are absolutely right.

Sorry, but the questions he was asked by the Daily News were not "hyper technical." They were substantive, and for someone who has made this his signature issue, if not his only issue, he should be able to discuss it in detailed terms. In fact even if he got asked questions that WERE hyper technical he should be able to participate in the conversation meaningfully. I think it was extremely revealing to see that he had nothing concrete to say that went beyond his stump speech.
Just like Obama in 2008.. who got us healthcare.

Look at it this way. That healthcare plan has helped a lot of Americans who are perhaps, less fortunate than yourself.
How can that be a bad thing???

I am an ardent Bernie supporter, but am very disappointed with his remark.  He is handing the election to the Republicans by making it more difficult for Bernie fans to switch their allegiance to Hillary should he lose the general election.  He could have said, "Clinton is qualified because of her experiences, but I believe I am more qualified because of my judgment."  He lost the high ground on this one and I hope he can regain it.

If Bernie fails to win NY, his best bet at the presidency will be to run as an independent. If Trump does the same when his party tries to shut him out at the convention, Bernie will win the general election and we might actually have a shot at ending the two-party system that has utterly failed the People for the last three decades.

Any Democrat is qualified to be President right now. Has anyone noticed Trump and Cruz? Sanders loses a great deal of his appeal when he attacks a fellow Democrat. They should both be competing in the who-can-beat-Cruz/Trump-the-best, not each other. I like both Sanders and Clinton, but he just lost my support.

The truth is, HR, that there is NOT plenty of time. As someone born and raised in New York, I see that this race for the nomination will be decided this month, and New Yorkers and other in the Northeast watershed states need to take real and sudden notice of how HRC's judgement and decision making is severely lacking, and always has been. All the experience in the world does not necessarily result in good judgement, and qualifications on a resume' are simply not the same as qualifications of character.

comments.commentBody:
A Hard Act to Follow.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bld_-7gzJ-o

While everyone is here in the Big Apple trying to reassure absolutely every potential voter that he/she is the best possible candidate imaginable wouldn't it be nice to see even one of these folks schedule a speech or some other campaign event at a mosque or at a Catholic church with a Mexican congregation?  I mean just for the heck of it?
I guess you did not see the cartoon where the pope said he would have invited Hillary but he could not afford her speaking fee.
The south Bronx isn't filled with enough Catholic Latinos for you, Stu?

Wow! I heard about it but watching it is frightening, the Clintons are dismissive bullies.

"First they ignore you, then they laugh at you, then they F I G H T you." Ghandi

The Clinton campaign is running out of patience?

With what Democracy?

Oh, the oligarchs are sick, I am SO SICK of DEMOCRACY!
Many of these isolated people were cattle ranchers. If you like beef, you might consider a way of supporting the people who put food on your plate for many years

"Who controls the past controls the future. Who controls the present controls the past." -- George Orwell, 1984

The American Enterprise Institute understands this very well.

Ryan, an interesting side note.
When I returned to North America for my second job interview with Airline XYZ,I had to face the make or break "Board Interview" .
You sit down with a group of Senior Captains, who can ask you any questions they want.
I passed around my logbook, East African Commercial License, and pictures of the various aircraft I flew, maps to the Game Parks, etc. We talked about the DC-3s I had flown up to the Sudan out of Nairobi, too.
I had pictures of the house on the beach I shared with a German Pilot, and our three house servants. Fishermen came every day to sell us their fresh catch.
It was a cold, wet dreary day, raining outside for the interview. After talking about the flying and showing pictures of the wild game I had seen in the Masai Mara, and Amboseli, one of the Captains asked me, "Why are you here?" The next Captain said, "How can I get a job over there?"
So the interview had turned around quickly!

The IRS's most comprehensive study of taxpayer compliance (National Research Program--NRP) based on intensive audits of 42,000 returns revealed that most taxpayers cheat when they think they can get away with it, usually when income they receive is not reported to the IRS by the source of the income. NRP proved Will Rogers to be 100 percent accurate when he opined, "The income tax has made liars out of more Americans than golf."

I'm sure, sfdphd, you are much more honest than most of your fellow Americans, who don't pay their taxes because they are proud to support their country, pay because they fear the consequences of not paying and being caught. Without any near competitor, the IRS is the most feared agency in the U.S. People don't pay taxes because they want to, they pay because they are coerced into paying-or else. You paint a pretty, patriot picture of yourself. You say you don't complain. May I point out that it wouldn't do you any good if you did. Even tax heroes like yourself do their utmost to minimize hoe much they pay, which doesn't indicate a particular fondness for their nation so much as it reflects the fact that not paying has severe consequences. Taxation is virtually indistinguishable for extortion as practiced by the Mafia, except it is better organized and exponentially more productive. Calling paying taxes a duty is akin to putting lipstick on a pig.

"Meanwhile, Bernie Sanders announced he is going to the Vatican, where he hopes to meet with the pope."

Hopes to meet with the pope? He was invited by the Vatican to speak there! "Hoping to meet with the pope" sounds like a teen who goes to a concert in the hope of meeting their idol. That just isn't the case. Why write like that? What purpose does it serve. Does such an opportunity really need to be minimized? I know, this column is usually written in a lighthearted tone, but really... It is precisely the sentiment behind this kind of writing is what prompted Reuters to ask a Vatican official if Sanders had invited himself to the event. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-vatican-idUSKCN0X5257

As for Sanders acting "a little off..." There is a good reason for it. The Clinton campaign signaled, through cable news, at first, that is was going negative, right on the night of the Wisconsin primary. Sanders dished out what he was served. I hope the Clinton campaign will think better of things in the future http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-2ao

The person who really acted off this week was Bill Clinton. He has a history of of getting awkward while campaigning for his wife. http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-2aG

As for who is more of a New Yorker, one only need to hear Sanders speak to know how much New York is a part of him.

This election cycle is about the issues, no matter how hard some try to make it personal. It's about neoliberalism vs. progressivism.
I hope you smarten up and vote for the Democrat who wins the nomination.  We already know you love Bernie and hate Hillary.

mtrav,

Why the insulting tone?

Sal,

The media has been really bad this cycle, far worse than in 2008. Watch Charles Blow talk about an invitation he received by one of the campaigns to a mixer they were putting on for the press with campaign staffers.

http://www.rimaregas.com/2016/04/charles-m-blow-on-anonymoussources-medi...

Then, watch Bernie Sanders talk about his invitation to the Vatican as Morning Joe made the announcement:

https://www.facebook.com/msnbc/videos/1159336190829298/

Of course he does. Bill always pretends to be all things for all people.  If you don't like the BLMers, look at Thursday's video when he criticizes them.  But if you don't like that, look at Friday's when he apologizes.  Tomorrow, something else to appeal to some other group.
For God's sake, Bill, sit down and be quiet. You owe that to your wife. Hillary doesn't need your complications and it's important that you understand it is not going to be you in charge.

Two neighbors I hike with and I were discussing the next stage of life, when we'd have a hard time maintaining our property and plowing the road. People who love living in rural areas love the clean air, mountains, the huge sky. A solution might be elder communes in rural areas. A garden, some chickens, a nurse to administer medicines, a driver. I might be putting something like this together when I can't hike up the mountain any more.
Yes, definitely cohousing.  And possible small assisted care homes. It is the most encouraging idea to develop.

Agree.  There are several co-housing options where I live in Portland, OR, but admit I never thought of this in a more rural area.  Do any of these currently exist?  Will explore online tonight - thanks for the comment!!

You've hit on one reason that some people do create and live in "intentional communities." A multigenerational one would be even better! It is good for all of us to be around people of all ages. It is one of the things I love about my little coastal town. It's not a commune, but we are a community, and we look out for each other. I'm in my early 40s, and my friends here range from their 30s to 70s.

.
There is a Temple within a mile of where the musical was/is staged. A graduate of my high school who belongs to the "EGOT" club owes his Tony and his Grammy to said humorous musical.

I have not seen the musical, but my understanding is that it treats Mormons affectionately as being earnest and likable. Matt Stone and Trey Parker grew up in Colorado, where there was some LDS influence. I read somewhere that many of their collaborations make some reference or other to the LDS Church.

The official church position -- again based upon my reading -- is non-opposition. The church has even advertised in the musical's program (Playbill), urging the curious to check out the real Book of Mormon. I only know what I read, but it's said that some people have pursued their curiosity to such a degree that they have joined the church.

GE makes a vast amount of its profits from the Defense sector as well.

And yes, unfettered free market capitalism produces this result. Which is unsustainable once the race to the bottom of the wage pool has been reached.

Best to adopt sensible regulations and yes, protectionism, to the degree necessary to benefit US citizens, not global profits.
What is there to say?  It's pathological and there is little that she can do about it, if anything.  She needs professional "counseling."
...speaking of a lack of historical consciousness — "one of the greatest presidents of the twentieth century"? — not.
Thank you, Common Sense.   That's how I remember it, too.

comments.commentBody: I sleep in a room surrounded by windows. Outside is a hill covered with trees, and a stream flows below. At night the moon awakens me so that I can view her beauty and that of her handmaids, the stars, and those naughty clouds who try to spoil the scene like some vaporous streaker. If I were an architect I would design houses with "sleeping bubbles"....rooms just a little larger than the bed, surrounded by windows like a green house.
I once had a room like that - in my then home in Oakland CA and it was the perfect sleeping bubble.
" vaporous streaker"....That is beautiful writing. Thank you!

This article of looking out windows reminded me of when I was looking out the window of an eight person cottage for people with intellectual/developmental disabilities on the grounds of Mansfield State Training School in Connecticut.  The year was 1984, my twenty-something enthusiasm envisioned the day that people would live in homes in the community, receive quality health care and be given the opportunity to be a friend and have friends too. That year my boss wrote in the annual performance evaluation as an area to work on "get your head out of the clouds and more down to earth with your thinking."  Sometimes are assumptions are for better futures. Over three decades later, my work allows me to visit, talk with and assess the quality of services these individuals enjoy for the most part.  "We all need to be more like that man."

I agree with MH. I think that the people who are often the most capable at the prime of their cognitive lives are woefully underrepresented. I think we need to insist that people aged 28 to 39 have a much greater voice in both political parties. I think it also grossly distorting that we have a system where you 'graduate' from elected position to position and thus almost all US senators are aged over 50. Perhaps one senator from each state needs to be a 'young' senator meaning that when elected they are not aged over 40. The other one can be over any age and we need to change the constitution to allow anyone to be a US Senator above she 18.

The whole issue of superdelegates begs a much larger question. Why should there be a system that so distorts the will of the people by having superdelegates, caucases that make participation very hard for most, and a system where we elect 'delegates'. It's time to modernize an eighteenth century model and have primaries that are directly proportionate to the number of votes cast, albeit at staggered intervals as is currently done. If one person achieves over 50% of the total votes vast they become the nominee. Otherwise we should have a national runoff primary election between all candidates who have obtained above 25% of the vote where the winner subsequently becomes the nominee. All votes should be weighed equally. Anything less is undemocratic.

Casting black and Latino actors as the founders seems rather derivative to me of Quentin Tarantino and his historical dreamscapes in which the deserving finally get their comeuppances at the hands of those whom they mistreated. But which is the more dramatic statement? A multi-ethnic American founders generation or “Inglourious Basterds”? Or “Django Unchained”? Frankly, for what-might-have-beens I’ll take Tarantino.

Alexander Hamilton was one of the most conflicted of our founders, a man of raging ambitions and not-very-subtle and just as raging insecurities rising from his low birth amid a group of landed grandees who were more central founders – and he was very young indeed during the Revolution (21 in 1776). His anti-slavery stance was about as energetic as he could away with in an early Republic that was so dominated by the South while he was still alive, under Washington and Jefferson; and that energy was far more nuanced and intellectual than the play is said to communicate. I haven’t seen it yet, and don’t know that I will – I probably know too much about Hamilton to really enjoy it.

The best treatment I’ve ever seen of Hamilton was Gore Vidal’s, a fictional but pretty well-researched one in the historical flashbacks we were offered in “Burr”. Not a lot about black and Latino co-founders came through in THAT character treatment. However, if this spectacle gets our kids and even adults excited about American history, I’m all for it, historical pedantry aside.

Really, Richard Luettgen, saying you think something is "rather" derivative when you haven't seen it sounds rather like hubris. I liked Gore Vidal's "Burr" a lot but i assure you, as he always does Vidal rather gives into whimsy and self-delight than does Miranda.  Rather.  Me, I am rather delighted you probably won't see it, not because you know so much about Hamilton -- I assure you that every night there are many who know more while also having the capacity to enjoy a work of genius and joy and classic tragedy -- but because it would be such a shame to waste a seat on someone who already knows [sic] he'll take Tarantino over the topic of the day that he has not even seen.

I haven't seen it -- ticket prices alone exclude literally 99% of the population -- though I've seen clips & interviews with Mr. Miranda. He alone is so handsome, articulate & charming that no doubt it has an effect on audiences. The show is tremendous theatre. But I believe much of the enthusiasm is for this "multi-culti" version of US History, that dovetails neatly with lefty liberal ideals -- wouldn't it have been super if our Founding Fathers were perfectly mixed group of all races? if the only bad guy was a WHITE king?

A kid who gets excited by this, THEN finds out that the real Alexander Hamilton was just another WASPy white guy, is going to have a major disappointment. And lose interest ASAP.

The analogy of Tarantino films is apt. If you saw those at a formative age, without much background (US schools do an especially abysmal job of teaching history) and THEN later found out that gee, apparently the Jews did NOT rise up to revengefully murder their Nazi oppressors....and gee, handsome escaped slaves did not return to the Plantation & summarily execute the slaveowners & their families in bloodbaths (with the help of some random German dude, couldn't even figure that one out myself). Indeed, had some Jewish European in 1943 -- or some black slave -- remotely done even one killing like this, they'd have been dead; tortured, gassed or lynched. Gee, not a fun story at all.

Richard, the only difference between you and William F. is that he used better words to disguise his extreme right wing agenda. Being wordy and ponderous is a poor way to communicate, as well as pretending to be tolerant by mentioning writers (Vidal) you despise.

Martin, I'm sipping the nectar of the gods and listening to the Time Life Collection of romantic songs from the 1950s - 1970s era and am thinking of buying it. I can have 5 hours of music to listen to while I sleep on the sofa. And they say growing old is not for sissies....

Of course the founders were pro-slavery. They were British first.

http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/12/british-history-slavery-bur...

Even George Orwell's family - yes, that Orwell - owned slaves. I don't hear much static about that never getting mentioned today. In fact, it's Orwellian.

I'm sorry, you are wrong. They were not British. They were American born under British control, thereby British "subjects". That was how the entire country got started. George Washington's parents were born here, so things go a ways back further than what you think. None of the Founding Father's spoke with an English accent. Rather what was spoken in England at the time resembled more of an American accent now.  But yes, if one wants to pin the Slave Trade on anyone, the biggest and most ruthless of them all were the British.
What does this have to do with Orwell the writer? You are dismissing Orwell because you disagree with him. Sneer sneer.

I'm so sorry. They must have been Native Americans, then. But America didn't even exist until the American Revolution, which must have just a simple misunderstanding. It seems like a lot of trouble for nothing. I'm totally confused.

If you don't like the way the reader butchers the word "amontillado," here's one that La Jollans could relate to:

https://youtu.be/hqSIRsmu7DE

What puzzled me about this one were 6d and 8d--10-letter words that are not themers?

Do APESUITS ever have pockets? SKIBAGS?
Not APE SUITS.  But KANGAROO SUITS do.

I think the fairest thing actually is that the American women's and men's federation split, so that there is separate accounting on both sides, and then the women are paid with respect to whatever money they bring in.  Apparently this has a good chance to be more than what the men earn, and we're done with it.  Unlike tennis when the men and women play roughly at the same time at major championships (so marketing dollars for instance cannot be distinguished), the men and women play at different times, so there  should be no major obstacle to getting up two separate books.
how about not

Assuming the USSF stays together and covers both the women and men then perhaps the financial reimbursement system should be "equal" for both teams. In other words the discussion about whether the men are equal to the women (hmm, I love watching both teams play but it is more fun to watch a team that plays well together and wins tournaments) is not the point.

Rather, the women generate x amount of revenue and the men generate y amount of revenue. Both the women and the men should receive z (the same) percent of pay from that revenue. I don't know how to structure different pay within the women's team (e.g. number of games player or minutes, etc).

As a father of two girls playing youth soccer, and as a human being, this pay inequity has got to stop. Go Ms Lloyd!

Revenue is irrelevant. I could post my own argument, but really Travis Waldron said it best:

"The revenue-based argument might make sense if international soccer existed in a market in which sportsmen and women have been afforded the same opportunities to succeed. But it doesn’t. So basing USWNT pay — or any international women’s team’s pay — solely on a market force like “revenue-generated income” ignores the ways in which the gatekeepers of international soccer have systematically suppressed the women’s game for years, keeping them from having the chance to generate similar revenues."

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/uswnt-equal-pay-us-soccer_us_56fda31...

I wish I would wave a magic wand that would make Kobach and Newby and all others who pretend they are protecting our nation against those phantom fraudulent voters speak truthfully about their real motives.

It wouldn’t be pretty.
This may be the wrong way to choose a Monday avatar.

As usual we are seeing the Sanders crowd telling us why he is superior to all the rest.
And their complaint is, the party is backing Clinton because she is an insider, part of the establishment.
What is being ignored, is Clinton did fund rising for the Democratic candidates for congress, she has worked with the establishment to try and make things better.
Sander is a declared pacifist, he is listed as an independent, but now he is running as a Democrat, yet rejected the party label while in the Senate. he has not helped raise fund for the democrats but wants their support now.

He also did not volunteer for Viet Nam he could have gone as a non combatant. Yes HRC voted to give W the authority to invade Iraq as did the majority of senators, and if you read why, they believed Saddam would stop his murdering of the Shiites, but he called Ws bluff, and W had his little ego bruised, so had to show what a great warrior he was.

Sanders was opposed to giving the banks the reserves to stop runs on them. most of the banks were not engaged in the derivatives trading, but no bank can survive a run, and when depositors get scared, that is what happens.
Geithner and Bernanke were excellent secretaries, and they do no get enough credit from those who do not understand just what it took to keep the economy from melt down.

You want to talk about reading about the economic crisis?
Then read the facts, read the Angelide Commission report it has the facts, they went through thousands of pages and files.
It is not a collection of opinions, it is the facts.

So you think r. K is wrong about his opinions, well what is your expertise? Did you teach at MIT, or Princeton? Have you served on any international commissions? Do you have a Nobel Prize? I find him to be very credible.
So, you are saying climate change is a myth?

So both the Sanders and Trump people are opposed to trade agreements.
The say it takes jobs away from America and gives them to third world countries.

True many jobs do go elsewhere but they are jobs that would go anyway. Even with high import taxes they would e made cheaper, and thos other countries would impose their own restrictions. Remember the VW Beetle, the sold like crazy, so did the Honda CVCC, while at the same time Germany and Japan had import tariffs.

Korea was sending Hyundais here, but limiting the small Dodge pickups. Trade agreements get rid of protectionism, we have seen that throughout history. Remember st one tome garbage men (Refuse Engineers) had to carry the trash cans climb up and dump them in the truck. it was a good paying job, and there was usually a driver and four workers. Today on man or woman does the job of those five.
Notice how many shop a the low price leader, then complain about loss of jobs. Do you think Walmart will get cheaper made goods here? What brand of tires are on your car, where was the steel made? All trade barriers do is make you pay more for cheaper goods.

Actions by Mr. Kobach and Mr. Newby and others at the state level are being orchestrated to deny people their legitimate, legal, and sacred right to vote. This is a systematic attempt to shut down the process and wait out the clock. I hope the lawsuits prevail and these specious assaults on our democracy are stopped.

Sanders and all politicians should include vocational training as a right at low cost or free, not just college. About 70 percent or so of the population doesn't attend college. That's the majority and they deserve training for skills to be self supporting. But unions were weakened or forbidden, and apprenticeships are down. This is not healthy for society.

Also there are many vocational schools set up as criminal enterprises to take students' money and deliver nothing in return.
onshoring is the key

Calvin Trillin is a food and humor titan.
His detractors are humorless midgets.

We need all kinds of reform, not just banking reform, and that has always been Sanders' point. The banks need their reform and non-financial institutions, like Met-Life, that have a big influence on the economy and the financial sector need theirs.

As for the contention that financial crises are rare, I disagree. Since the repeal of Glass-Steagall in the 1990's, we've been in a loop of worsening financial bubbles. Larry Summers has been warning about Secular Stagnation for the past two years and you have agreed with him since he began talking about it. Summers recently picked up on an Economist piece to renew the conversation on the topic of a new recession, too much Wall Street profit, and jobs. That threat is real and few are the US economists who have been writing about it. http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-29j

But back to non-financial institutions and the risks they pose... Sanders has never indicated that they aren't in need of their own reforms. He's been railing against the damage that money in politics has caused and the generalized corporate greed that has been rotting our society to its core.

While Prof. Krugman is not saying, now, that 2010 reforms weren't enough, former Congressman Barney Frank made an argument that is false about bank and risks in a hot debate against Robert Reich and made no sense. It's about consolidation and risk, as well as lack of regulation. http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-2ao

We need reforms in just about every sector of government to undo 30 years of rot.

Having a disabled family member or being disabled yourself, is a perfectly valid position from which to make political decisions.  As you probably know there are a lot of people with disabilities and others could join that group at any time.

I saw the back and forth between Reich and Frank, and I thought Frank got the better of it.  Krugman is arguing in this column, quite correctly, that any Democrat in the White House would enforce the spirit and letter of reform and would appoint judges sympathetic to reform, while any Republican would undermine it.  He is also arguing that further reforms are necessary.  Both Bernie and Hillary agree further reforms are necessary.  Their differences are in the details.   Clinton has a very comprehensive plan, while Bernie's is pretty much Glass-Steagall, "break up the banks", and "release the transcripts.

Impervious to facts and reason, you say.  Bernie's prescience shows otherwise.  He accurately predicted the consequences of invading Iraq and of free "trade" agreements (all about the free flow of capital, actually) - notably with Panama, which has sprung into the news lately.

On Bernie I'd like to rely,
A Wall Street-unencumbered guy,
Transparent and frank
No tricks in the tank,
No one's friendly Fish forced to fry.
A pretty good group.
***causes, will stop big banks from being so regal

So dan,

So, Pope Francis is a Bernie Bros, is he? To be a Bernie Bros, one must accept all of Bernie's pronouncements without question, and beat on anyone who disagrees.

Sorry dan...even if the Pope approves of some of Bernie's ideas, he wouldn't make the cut as a True Bernie Believer.

This op-ed is in line with the attack some of the media have joined the Clinton campaign on, to help her keep from losing New York. That attack was announced on Tuesday night last week on CNN by former NYT reporter Jeff Zeleny. Charles Blow made a video in which he explained the poor ethics of using anonymous sources and an invitation he received from one of the campaigns to attend a mixer where campaign staff would be available, but on the condition of anonymity. So, I wonder, with the proliferation of pieces like this one, just who attended and how it has affected their pieces?
http://www.rimaregas.com/2016/04/charles-m-blow-on-anonymoussources-medi...

Van Jones spoke about what really happened with NY Daily News on Democracy now and you can see his interview in my news roundup.
http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-2bd

comments.commentBody:
Steve Brown
The gunophobic fear evidenced by many of the commenters here is nothing new. Such dire consequences predicted by allowing concealed carry have been common fare almost three decades. The recurring fact that none of these dreadful predictions come to pass hasn’t dissuaded the prognosticators in the least. Check the comments a few years back when these same commenters were offering the same thing about allowing concealed carry in our National Forrest.

Once again the Government is bribed and the criminals face no jail and no forfeiture while the shareholders pay, the American people pay and the charade of equal justice before law cheapens and destroys societal values.
what does that mean. what failed presidencies. Not only does he protect his family but he would date his daughter.

trump is as rotten w corruption as th rest of them

you think you make billions in real estate in nyc being totally honest and by th book ??

Teflon Trump has withstood the most attack ads (by far), spent the least, yet has secured the best results in the Republican contest.  That's the attitude he is going to bring against Clinton (who for some reason was given a pass on her emails by Sanders).  And that's the attitude he's going to bring for America.

The NYT should do us- the readers a favor and give us a list of donor money that is going into the 2016 campaign. If there is anything Trump has proven, he can fight back. After decades of years with politicians who bow to the will of their Wall Street donors, it's good to see someone who has some fire to them, along with Bernie Sanders. I am SICK of the establishment. How long will it take them to realize this?

The pivotal point in regards to this election is whether WE the electorate are willing to take a chance with an outsider. If we don't- when will be the next time we get an opportunity to revolutionize the political system? Do you think party leaders are going to loosen their grip and allow insurgents to run their party? NO! We either fight back this year or my generation and I are ruined for decades to come of a corrupt system that masquerades a form of democracy that is nonexistent.

Please, it is either Sanders or Trump. We have to start somewhere to change the system. I KNOW they are not perfect but, the establishment scares me more than them.

Your question: How long will it take for the establishment to realise that you are sick of it?
Answer: Never, unless you run a series of very big ads to tell it.
Well said!

Make sure you look for the source of the Nile.

If you look carefully at the litany of the conservative voices and published works from the GOP string of policy shops, pundits and talk radio you will find an alternate universe of lopsided analysis, reporting conclusions and just plain outright propaganda. The GOP is supported by a massive propaganda engine that simply distorts and intentionally seeks division. That is why Mitch McConnell is going bonkers to preserve Citizens United. This funds the GOP propaganda system. Koch Brothers, and Rupert Murdoch's FOX News.

And no it is not a symmetrical phenomenon. No one show symmetry. The GOP is built on a house of cards and the wind is blowing.

You all have to admit that Fox News is not offering Johnny-Carson style professional courtesy to Donald Trump. What a chuckle.

Yes, much of the funding for the anti-Trump ads is coming from the billionaires.  They don't trust Trump to support Citizens United and the various tax laws that allow them to increase their share of the wealth at ever increasing rates and to dominate the political system.  I think that Trump would be a disastrous President, but the billionaires fear him for entirely different reasons.
so why is is he not right for the job, that is the debate

Incorrect.  The establishments motto is Vote Cruz to Lose.  They are using Cruz to stop the real threat to the gravy train.  There is little likely hood Cruz will get out of the convention and if he is the nominee he will be slaughtered.  Every Republican operative knows this.  Cruz is a lying and nasty version of Todd Akin and Sharon Angle, etc.  If an establishment candidate comes out of the convention, with the mood of the country he will lose the general election.  Either way, the establishment stays in power and on to 2020.  Vote Cruz to Lose and the establishment remains.

What you characterize as "thin-skinned," many see as simply aggressive. And as a billionaire, aggressive has apparently worked for Trump.

Never let an attack go unanswered. Respond with overwhelming power.

Those are principles I can respect, even though I may not want to practice them personally.

Trump is running to disrupt, and disrupt he has. He doesn't have to 'work' at his campaign, he just comes out and opens mouth.

Sometimes, he puts his foot in, deeply, sometimes its brilliant what he says. Sure, he's got MAJOR flaws ... but there is no one else in this entire country willing to stand up and say what he says.

We cannot keep giving our country away to foreign investors, and hiring from overseas. Rebuilding and retraining our own, first.

We have to quit hating, and start listening to reality. None of the other candidates can wing business life as well as Trump. While this isn't the be-all end all ... it's something missing today in politics.

So, disrupt away Mr. Trump. You may not be 'electable', but you sure are compellingly interesting, warts and all.

*None* of the recent candidates have been successful businessmen, with the possible exception of 2012's Mitt Romney, destroyer of jobs and businesses, sweeping the shards into his pocket.  But yes, the son of Queens' own Fred Trump mis-managed his inheritance, cratered a few businesses, and out-hustled his lenders.  Like its bagels, New York's chutzpah is the greatest in the world.

I haven't seen or heard a political ad.
For our TVs I use TiVo DVRs to avoid ads.
I have ad blockers on my computers.
I listen to public radio that has no political ads.
Once in a while I catch Chevron ads with the cute cartoon character cars.
Go Democrats, preferably Clinton, but Sanders is OK.
Sander's ads are playing every few minutes.  They are not attack ads.  They are really inspiring.  I am sending what I can to keep them going.
Iceland put their bankers in JAIL!  Why do ours get a slap on the hand, with a fine that will be passed on to investors and not touch any of them?

Why do we still ask why when we already know the answer?

THE SYSTEM IS RIGGED!!!
The governments only purpose is to protect the wealth of the elite from commoners like us. Look through the veil, they don't care about you, and until we have MAJOR government reform they never will.
China claims the right to pollute the entire South China Sea as well. Let whoever can look after it have it, should be international law.
No. I believe we are already importing chickens from China?

A penalty for a bank is much less than the grand announcement of a settlement (which also affords this bank the unearned privilege of continuing to claim they did nothing wrong) would make us believe.

Well I am just shocked.

And do I even need to ask, did anyone go to jail?

Trump and Sanders, anyone?

'national working group that was set up in 2012 to investigate how Wall Street exacerbated the mortgage bubble and ensuing financial crisis.'

Odd to choose the word 'exacerbated' - more accurate would be 'created'.

don't be surprised when once out of office, either obama ends up as members of the boards of directors at one or more of these banks.  keep an eye on those coming appointments.  i'm sure there will be a small, community foundation thrown in for the distraction...

Unlike the shareholders of AIG the government didn't wipe out most of the equity for Goldman shareholders. Instead Goldman senior management got HUGE government funded bonuses by way fo stock options that went way up from the Fed Reserve funds pumped into Goldman.

Obama should really reconsider what his biggest mistake was. We the People didn't get our crumbling infrastructure repaired that would have created lots of jobs; underwater homeowners never got their mortgages reset as promised by the Big Banks & foreclosures using fraudulent documents were allowed to proceed on a wholesale basis. But Obama made sure the shareholders of the Big Banks kept their equity & their management got bonuses. Obama even insisted that no reforms be imposed upon the Financial Sector when they would have had to agree to any conditions asked just to survive

So Obama got what he wanted, the Tea Party, Radical Republicans & lost the House & Senate ergo no legislation after Obama gave us National RomneyCare in which anyone not willfully blind can see the horrible problems of a healthcare plan birthed in a Republican think tank-too large co-pays & deductibles so that insureds have "skin in the game"

So Thank you Obama for once again performing for Wall Street; you never delivered what you promised & could have delivered when you had a Democratic majority in Congress. Vast numbers of the Little People will continue to suffer from your sell out to Wall St long after you're gone

You cannot pursue a criminal action against a company for something that is not legally a crime.  That has been the problem since day one of the economic collapse: what these shadow bankers did was NOT illegal or criminal.  It was gambling, it was stupid, it was risk taking with other people's money and only the extent of the actions make it anything out of the ordinary for the capitalist system.  The Dodd-Frank Bill seeks to make illegal and criminalize at least some of these actions, and that is why Republicans are so anxious to weaken or get rid of it.  Their bread is mostly buttered on the business side, not the worker side.

Where does HRC stand on this?

In line, at the bank, waiting to deposit yet another big fat check from Goldman Sachs.

"If you're going to steal, steal big."

Al Capone.

I thought at first you were quoting Lloyd Blankfein, the CEO of Goldman-Sachs. Then I read "Al Capone". Sometimes I get those two confused. Here's a quick way to separate them:

Lloyd Blankfein-New York-21st Century-Goldman Sachs
Al Capone-Chicago-20th Century-The Mob

Main difference: time and location.
Both knew how to work the system. Except, one worked from outside and the other works from within.

Hillary Clinton got $675,000 in speaking fees from Goldman Sachs sometime between 2013 and 2015, but has yet to divulge what she said to the bank. Reading this article in the context of her silence, one can only speculate.

That thought will go with me to the polling place next week here in New York.

WiltonTraveler, East Germany was not a socialist democracy, it was a communist country. It has been a united socialist country for greater than 20 years at this point in time, with a thriving economy, and a high standard of living.
Dear Mr. corporate troll!  Get back on the Wilton spur.  Sorry but I'm tired of people like you sprouting such nonsense.
What Hillary said to Goldman is irrelevant. This is a payoff; a campaign contribution that slides right through the "non-profit" Clinton Foundation into their discretionary asset pot.

But remember, all those tens of millions of dollars in political donations from Goldman Sachs have absolutely zero influence on our government. None whatsoever.

That's why nobody should be concerned that THIS EXACT COMPANY has been intimately tied to Hillary Clinton for the last 25 years. From Robert Rudin right on down the line.
Friendly reminder that Goldman Sachs has been Hillary Clinton's No. 4 contributor over the course of her political career.
